The doctors said if their demands were not met by Monday, they would paralyze emergency services from Tuesday.

On February 28, Badri Vishal of Sonbhadra district, who is studying in a private management institute, had allegedly misbehaved with a junior resident at OPD of orthopaedic department and later attacked him with the help of his two accomplices.

Inspector, Lanka, Bharat Bhushan said, “An FIR has been lodged under sections 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 504 (intention insult), 506 (criminal intimidation), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty) of IPC and Section ¾ of the Medical Protection Act. Vishal was arrested on Friday night. His two accomplices have been identified and raids are on to nab them.”

The doctors had gone on the strike on February 29 in support of their demands. Elective operation theatres were partially affected due to the strike.

Besides holding talks with agitating doctors, the BHU administration made an appeal to resident doctors to call off their strike in the interest of patients.

Title: Gang that stole 9 bikes from Pappanaickenpalayam held
Content:
Coimbatore: The city police have busted a four-member gang involved in motorcycle thefts in Pappanaickenpalayam area and recovered from them nine stolen vehicles. Sending out a strong message that buying a vehicle without valid documents could land one in jail, police have also arrested four people, who had either bought stolen vehicles from the gang or taken them for sales.

Race Course police inspector Sujatha said the gang comprised three youths - R Vignesh Bharath, 23, an autorickshaw driver from Dhandapani Street at Pappanaickenpalaya; M Marudhachalam, 22, an auto driver from Kumarapalayam near Annur; and S Sabari, 20, a two-wheeler mechanic from Annur – and a 16-year-old boy.

According to her, the gang was busted during a vehicle check that was taken out on Friday night. “We stopped a motorcycle that had two pillion riders. The trio not only failed to produce valid documents for the motorcycle, but also gave contradictory statements. We took them to police station and during further inquiry they confessed to have stolen the vehicle,” the officer said.

Explaining the gang’s modus operandi, the officer said it was the minor boy’s responsibility to steal the motorcycles by using fake keys. “Vignesh befriended the boy and taught him how to steal motorcycles. They limited their activities to Pappanickenpalayam area, and it was the duty of Marudhachalam and Sabari to identify the motorcycles to be stolen and assist the minor boy. In total, they have stolen nine motorcycles from Pappanickenpalayam area.”

While they sold two motorcycles to M Abdul Rahman, 20, a car driver from Annur, and S Vigneshwaran, 22, a carpenter from Puliyakulam, for Rs 5,000 each, three each vehicles were handed over to R Ramesh, 33, a power loom worker and K Prabhakaran, 24, a van driver, both from Annur, for sales.

“We have arrested these people also and recovered from them eight motorcycles. The ninth one we had taken into custody during the vehicle check,” the officer said.

All the arrested were booked under Sections 120 (b) (criminal conspiracy), 379 (punishment for theft), 411 (dishonestly receiving stolen property) and 414 (assisting in concealment of stolen property) of the Indian Penal Code.

While the minor boy was produced before the juvenile justice board and lodged in the juvenile home at Lakshmi Mills, the remaining seven were lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under judicial custody.

Title: Ahmedabad: Man charred to death in car fire in Sola
Content:
The doors of the car got locked and Yogesh Prajapati could not escape

AHMEDABAD: Yogesh Prajapati, 50, of Suryaratna Society in Sola, was charred to death after his hatchback car caught fire near Mother Dairy in Gandhinagar on Sunday afternoon.

Fire department sources said that prima facie it appears that the car caught fire because of short-circuit. The doors of the car got locked and Prajapati, who owned a petrol pump, could not get out of the burning car.

Adalaj police sources said that the car was destroyed and it was difficult to identify the body. “The victim was eventually identified based on the registration number of the car,” a police source said. “The details available are that Prajapati took a turn from Apollo Circle towards Indira Bridge and just opposite Mother Dairy his car suddenly caught fire,” the source said. Police said that according to fire officials, when the wires of the car caught fire, the remote-controlled doors got locked.

“We have sent the body for the postmortem examination and have registered a case of accidental death,” an Adalaj police official said. “We have sought help of forensic experts to determine the reason for the fire.”

In another case, a van caught fire near the flower market at the end of Sardar Bridge at about 7.30pm on Sunday.

“While the reason of the fire is yet to be ascertained, nobody was injured,” said a fire official. According to sources, the van was travelling from the NID side of the bridge to the other end when smoke started billowing from the engine.

“The driver, Ghanshyam Thakkar, immediately got off the vehicle, which was engulfed in flames in minutes,” said a fire official.



In Video: Ahmedabad: Man charred to death as car catches fire

Title: From house of IIT: Stubble remover and smog tower
Content: NEW DELHI: To combat the issue of air pollution in the country, select IITs have developed prototype of air purification machines. Among them is a smog tower developed by IIT Bombay, which can clean air in a 300-metre radius; and a stubble removing machine, developed by IIT Ropar, which helps reduce stubble burning in Punjab and Haryana.Track the pollution level in your cityUnion minister of state for human resource development, Sanjay Dhotre, recently inaugurated an exhibition on clean air technologies organised by the Centre of Excellence for Research in Clean Air. The exhibition showcased clean air technologies developed by IITs at Bombay, Ropar, Dhanbad and Delhi, with the latter showcasing its work through their incubated start-ups like Aerogram and Kriya Labs.Dhotre emphasised that “in an age of environmental concerns, the need is to accord highest priority to civic awareness regarding clean environment.” He claimed that the Centre is committed to the cause of fighting rising air pollution levels and is taking all possible measures to spread awareness on clean air issues and providing all possible support for the development and promotion of cleaner air technologies.One of the prototypes on display was an air cleaning system tower developed at Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay.Awkash Kumar of IIT Bombay, who was part of the team that developed the ambient air cleaning system, said: “In urban areas, there are no industries and pollutants are usually from traffic or construction. So we have to focus on the machines that can handle pollution.”However, it was the machine developed by IIT Ropar that attracted the most attention. “The removed stubble is collected in a trolley, which is attached to the main machine. It can collect one acre of stubble in an hour. This is then turned into manure or cut into small pieces and spread over the land,” said Fateh Singh, a student of IIT Ropar.IIT Delhi director, V Ramgopal Rao, appreciated the effort being put in by the young scientists and said that the low-cost air pollution monitors developed in IIT-D will be used in vehicles and in different places to improve the extent of monitoring.

Title: Attukal temple fest: Rs 85 lakh insurance cover for devotees
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Attukal Temple Trust has arranged an insurance coverage of Rs 85 lakh to ensure safety of devotees during the 10-day temple festival. Each devotee, who participates in the festival, will be covered for accidents and calamities.

The temple festival began on Sunday morning with ‘Kappuketti Kudiyiruthal’ ritual. The pongala will be held on March 9. The 10-day festival will conclude on March 10.

Considering the temperature alerts, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, during a review meeting held on Saturday, asked departments to ensure availability of drinking water during pongala.

The government has allotted Rs 2.8 crore for pongala related works. The revenue department will deploy around 200 volunteers for disaster management while the corporation will deploy 3,500 staff for sanitation works.

Around 500 Green Army volunteers will ensure green protocol during pongala. Around 10,000 steel glasses and 3,000 plates will be distributed among devotees to avoid use of plastics and disposables.

Kerala water authority will install 25 tanks to ensure water availability in festival areas. KWA has begun filling Iranimuttam tank to stock water in advance. Around 1,270 temporary taps and 50 shower taps will be installed.

Areas under 32 corporation wards were renovated using a fund of Rs 1.5 crore. The public works department has completed renovation of 21 roads. Kerala state electricity board has taken steps to ensure 24-hour power supply during the festival days. New transformers were installed near Attukal Temple. Around 14 squads of food safety department has held inspections in various eateries. Samples of water collected from various sources were sent for quality test.

Fire and rescue department has arranged 97 points in the city for its works. The vehicles of the department will be used to fill drinking water in tanks. Health department will constitute a medical team and will arrange facilities in hospitals. KSRTC will conduct additional services for pongala. The police will deploy 3,000-4,000 personnel.

The industries department is organizing an expo titled ‘Attukal Mela 2020’ at Nayanar Park, Putharikandam, as part of the festival. Minister E P Jayarajan will inaugurate the expo of handloom, handicrafts and pottery items at 5pm on Monday.

Title: Woman flees with cigarettes worth Rs 70k
Content: Hyderabad: An unknown woman thief broke into a pan shop and stole cigarettes worth Rs 70,000 in Saroornagar limits, at Manda Mallamma X Roads. The incident came to light only on Sunday. A case was registered on shop owner’s complaint. TNN

Title: Telangana: 5 Maoist party couriers arrested with explosives
Content:
Police with the seized explosive material on Sunday

HYDERABAD: Bhadradri-Kothagudem police arrested five Maoist party couriers while they were transporting explosives stolen from stone crushing units to Maoist cadres on Saturday.

Police suspect that Maoists are planning to use the stolen explosives to target police by setting up landmines.

At around 11 am on Saturday, during a vehicle check in Jagannadhapuram village of Paloncha mandal, Paloncha (Rural) SI K Sridhar and his team spotted six persons travelling on two bikes and a Tata Magic vehicle. Upon seeing the police, one of the suspects fled the spot.

The police managed to arrest the other five persons, including P Saraiah (45), resident of Nimmalagudem in Kistaram mandal of Sukma district, Chhattisgarh, K Murali (24), K Nageswara Rao (40) of Dabbanootala village in Dummugudem mandal, K Sammaiah (26), Veerabhadrapuram village in Dummugudem mandal and J Hanumanthu (28) of Toggudem in Paloncha mandal.

Police seized three vehicles, 40 gelatine sticks, 40 detonators and 27 explosive boosters from the possession of the accused. “During interrogation, the accused confessed that as per the request of Maoist party state leadership, they have been working as couriers for Maoist party. The accused procured the explosive materials from different stone crushing mills near Toggudem village to supply them to Maoists as per the directions of the state level leadership including Haribhushan, Damodar, Lachanna, Azad and Ravi,” additional SP Ramana Reddy said.

Based on the information provided by the accused, special teams of Bhadradri-Kothagudem district police conducted surprise checks at Sri Vengamamba quarry in Jagannathapuram, Bhavani crusher mill and VSI crusher mill in Toggudem, TCMM crusher in Juluripadu, Sai Ganesh metal and crusher in Chunchupalli and KRK crusher mill in Kothagudem.

During the checks, police seized 2,170 gelatine sticks, 1,428 detonators, 2,632 explosive boosters and bundles of detonating wire. “Cases were booked against the owners and managers of stone crushing mills for violation of rules and a few of them were arrested,” the additional SP said.

Recently, Kothagudem SP Sunil Dutt said that they have stepped up surveillance on Maoist party couriers and people resorting to illegal sale of explosives.

Title: Real victim in marital discord is always the child, says Delhi court
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: In the case of a warring couple, the real victim is the child, a city court has observed. It also questioned why, in cases of dispute between a man and his wife, the burden to look after the child always fell on the woman, who fends for herself while men around her ogle?

“There may be dispute between both of them with respect to marital life but what about that child who is the actual victim,” judge Ajay Goel questioned.

Goel was hearing a matter stemming from a domestic violence case filed by a woman. Her mother-in-law had filed an appeal against an order refusing to discharge her in the former’s domestic violence case. Interestingly, the judge narrated the scenes in his court in his order.

It was seen in the order that a woman was struggling with two bags — her office bag and a school bag — hung on her right shoulder with a child on the left while the husband stood behind his mother. The woman, teary eyed, barely managed to hold the case files. The child seemed restless, unable to fathom why she was there. “The little angel had done no wrong. Her fault is that her father chose to bring her in this world without any responsibility,” it noted.

It went on to observe that litigation is between a man and wife. And societal norms have paved the way for him to remain careless and free from the responsibility of bringing up a child — mentally, financially and emotionally. It pointed out that when a woman starts earning, it is argued that she is capable of maintaining herself.

In the case before Goel, it could be seen that the father didn’t even bother to extend his arms towards his estranged wife to help carry the child. While the husband was enjoying all luxuries — a car and a home — the wife travelled by bus to work, to drop off her child at school and to court to fight her case. It remarked, “The court could decide on the facts, but its heart burns.”

Keeping in mind the background, the court had to decide on the appeal filed by the woman’s mother-in-law, who claimed to have severed her relationship with her son, and therefore, there was no ground made for her to be party to the domestic violence case. She also argued as it was a love marriage, there was no dowry exchanged between the families.

The wife disputed her mother-in-law’s contention and called hers a “love-cum-arranged” marriage, for which her side of the family spent over Rs 15 lakh. She claimed the jewellery and other ornaments that she got from her mother were taken from her and deposited in a bank locker.

The court, meanwhile, took note of the “lies” spoken by the mother-son duo. “On the one hand, the petitioner is saying she had severed her relationship with the son and had debarred him from the properties but the son is standing in the court beside her defending her; bringing her to court; dropping her from the court to home; living with her,” it said. The observation prompted the court to further remark, “Rather, both of them should be prosecuted for taking a wrong defence and that too to harass the lady.” As a result, the court dismissed the mother-in-law’s appeal.

Title: ‘Mission Shakti’ strikes its target with precision in Nagpur
Content:
U Rajababu addresses the gathering at BRA Mundle Hall, South Ambazari Road, on Saturday

Nagpur: Facts regarding India’s anti-satellite ‘ Mission Shakti ’ were unfolded by project coordinator at the Defence Research and Development Organization (DRDO), U Rajababu, at a programme organized by Vidarbha Pradesh Mandal of Vigyan Bharti recently.

The programme was staged on the premises of the Blind Relief Association, South Ambazari Road.

The anti-satellite missile or a kinetic kill vehicle was launched as part of the test on March 27, 2019, from Abdul Kalam island. The aim of the test was to hit-and-kill a satellite in the Earth orbit. The mission was successfully accomplished and it made India the fourth country to have tested an ASAT weapon after the US, Russia and China.

On the accuracy of launching the weapon, Rajababu explained how important it is to be sure regarding the time, location and other aspects. He added that as time zones differ in various regions, the team launching India’s anti-satellite (ASAT) ensured that no errors were committed.

He highlighted the challenges faced by his team while preparing for the mission. The biggest challenge Rajababu faced was to give instructions to employees as they were unaware of the actual plan. The secrecy of the mission had to be maintained for many reasons. Only a handful of people knew the actual motive.

Rajababu’s address included diagrams and pictures which gave a better insight regarding the concepts proposed by him.

Highlighting the achievements, Rajababu said that the mission was carefully designed. This indicated active participation from Indian industry in concurrent mode. He added that the hit-to-kill accomplished against the live satellite with an accuracy of less than 10cm is by far the best reported performance worldwide.

Rajababu’s presentation was followed by a short interactive session with the audience.

Title: Covid-19: Bhavnagar sample tests negative
Content: AHMEDABAD: A sample taken from Bhavnagar in a suspected corona virus infection has tested negative on Sunday. With this, all 24 samples tested for corona virus (Covid-19) at the B J Medical College have tested negative.On Sunday, 165 passengers were screened at airports in the state. Of these, 65 passengers were from Ahmedabad, while the remaining were from different districts. Till date, a total of 1,495 passengers of Gujarat with a history of visiting China have been screened and placed under surveillance. Of these, 599 have completed the 28-day observation period and none have shown any symptoms of corona virus, a state government statement said.Apart from setting up fully equipped isolation wards at all district hospitals and designating the Ahmedabad civil hospital as the base hospital for corona virus, the state government has been carrying out intensive screening at airports and ports.Covid-19 or novel corona virus has been declared a “public health emergency of international concern” and the state government, in furtherance of directives issued by the Union ministry of health and family welfare, has issued guidelines to people. Top officials of the state health department have been carrying daily monitoring of steps being taken to tackle corona virus threat.

Title: City residents pitch for a practical corpn budget
Content:
Trichy: During the past seven years, the residents of Trichy have heard several promises from Trichy City Corporation on the development front, many of which remain unfulfilled. As the civic body is preparing to table the budget for 2020-2021 for the fourth consecutive year in the absence of an elected council, residents have urged the civic body to be more practical and futuristic in implementing projects.

In 2013-2014, the corporation tabled a budget by announcing that the large Yanaikulam ground in Singarathope will be utilised for constructing a four-floor commercial complex. The proposal still remains a non-starter. Similarly, a proposal to relocate the existing Puthur fish market to Kasivilangi on the outskirts also remains on paper. The long-pending proposals in the previous years’ budgets such as an integrated bus terminus (IBT), bus stand at Srirangam and shifting of the wholesale traders from Gandhi Market to outskirts are yet to materialise.

"Satellite bus stands are needed if IBT is getting delayed. Proper pedestrians platforms are absent in many areas. The authorities should give priority to removing encroachments on roads," Deepak Saravanan, a resident of KK Nagar, said. In 2013, the corporation mooted a plan to set up a water theme park at Panchapur. However, the proposal did not materialize.

A heritage centre planned at the corporation’s main office to portray the historical significance of Trichy has also been grounded. Apart from promoting recreational sites, residents have demanded to improve road infrastructure to eliminate snarl ups. "Trichy needs new flyovers. Localities such as Head Post Office signal are too congested. We need to focus on providing elevated roads," Subash Chandran, a resident of Woraiyur, said. Last year’s budget promises such as the redevelopment of Mavadikulam tank and renovation of the old Cauvery bridge at Srirangam still remain unfulfilled. Officials said that the budget for 2020-21, which is being prepared, will focus on the key issues.

Title: CM Rawat, Yogi Adityanath launch International Yog Festival
Content:
Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath inaugurates the Yog festival in Rishikesh, in the presence of Uttarakhand CM Trivendra Singh Rawat

Rishikesh: The International Yog Festival, organised by Uttarakhand tourism department and the Garhwal Mandal Vikas Nigam (GMVN), kick-started on Sunday. The week-long event was jointly inaugurated by Uttarakhand chief minister (CM) Trivendra Singh Rawat and Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath on the banks of the Ganga at the Ganga Resort at Muni Ki Reti in Rishikesh.Speaking at the event, CM Yogi said, “India has a rich spiritual tradition and yoga has emerged as a result of this tradition for the benefit of all living beings. I am glad that Rishikesh has emerged as a focal point for yoga practitioners from across the world.” He also praised PM Modi for “taking yoga to every corner of the globe as a result of which the entire world is getting connected to this ancient tradition.”Uttarakhand CM Trivendra Singh Rawat said that it was a matter of pride that yoga teachers from Uttarakhand were at the forefront of disseminating knowledge about the practice in many countries across the world. He expressed happiness at the yog festival this year hosting yoga-knowledge seekers and teachers from 11 countries and nine states of India.An estimated 2000 participants are attending the festival, which this year is seeing a star-studded line-up of gurus and guides including Sri Sri Ravishankar of Art of Living Foundation, Avdheshanand Giri of the Juna Akhara, Gaur Gopal Das, international life coach, BK Shivani of Brahmakumaris and fitness ambassador Jonty Rhodes among others.

Title: 54 detained for protesting outside forest min’s residence
Content:
Dehradun: Around 150 men belonging to the “Uttarakhand Berozgaar Union” on Sunday staged a protest outside the residence of forest minister Harak Singh Rawat in Dehradun against unemployment and cheating scam in the recent forest guard recruitment exam. They demanded that the forest guard exams conducted on February 16 be declared void.

The protestors raised slogans outside the residence of the forest minister, who is also the UPNL minister. They wanted to hand over a memorandum to him, but Rawat wasn’t present at his residence at the time. City magistrate Mayaram Joshi offered to take the memorandum but the protestors insisted on giving it to the forest minister.

Police detained 54 of them and took them to Sudhowala prison. The men continued their protest there and demanded that they be taken to dharna sthal.

The protestors claimed that they called on the CM’s helpline number so they could be taken to Dharna Sthal, but to no avail. “We called them and asked for a vehicle to be arranged to take us to dharna sthal as we didn’t have the money for cab fare. They brought us 20 kms from the city and refused to take us back,” said Bobby Panwar, chairperson, Uttarakhand Berozgaar Union.

The protestors also demanded that all 18,000 vacancies in the state government announced by the chief minister in July 2018 be filled. Also, they demanded that the annual examination calendar of Uttarakhand be released.

Title: Kochi: Non-infectious diseases can increase TB deaths
Content: KOCHI: Tuberculosis patients in Kerala now don’t die of the disease alone. A study among the TB deaths in Alappuzha district shows that almost 60% of those who died had other diseases along with TB. Health experts said this true of whole of Kerala.“In Kerala, TB is affecting the elderly population as they are prone to non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Majority of those who have TB also have NCDs. That is why we have a joint coordination between TB and NCD programme in the state,” said state TB officer Dr M Sunil Kumar.In Kerala, as of 2019, there were 25,421 TB patients, with a majority of them between the age group of 55 and 65 years.For the study in Alappuzha, doctors studied the cause of deaths among patients registered with Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) unit in the district. As per RNTCP, a patient who dies during the course of treatment regardless of cause is declared as ‘died due to TB’.For the study, they looked at 1,618 patients who were registered under RNTCP of Alappuzha district in 2015. Of these, 90 patients had died, showing a case fatality rate of 6%. So as part of the study, they visited homes of those who died for verbal autopsy.The mean age of those who died was 62 years, with 77% of them being men. After verbal autopsy, it was found that while 60% of those who had died had other diseases along with TB, the rest had nothing other than TB. Of the 60 % patients, about 18% suffered a heart attack, 15% died due to cancer, 3% suffered from stroke and 24 % due to other causes, including COPD and renal failure.“60% of TB deaths in Alappuzha district were due to other diseases,” said Dr Karthika M, Community Medicine, T D Medical College, Alappuzha and the lead author of the study.

Title: Lord Shiva’s ‘gauna’ procession on Mar 5
Content:
festivities in the air

Varanasi: Like ‘Tilakotsava’ of Lord Shiva, which was performed at new residential address of Mahant Kulpati Tiwari, former priest of Kashi Vishwanath temple, in Tedhineem area on Basant Panchami, the ‘ gauna ’ procession of the deity will take place with minor changes in route plan on Rangbhari Ekadashi on March 5.

Providing details of Rangbhari Ekadashi celebrations, Tiwari said, “After performing of initial rituals of 356-year-old tradition of ‘Gauna’ (farewell of Goddess Parvati with Lord Shiva following marriage on Mahashivratri), the main procession will be taken out from my residence in Tedhineem area. After passing through Sakshi Vinayak, Kotwalpura and Dhundhiraj Ganesh, the procession will reach Kashi Vishwanath temple,” he said, adding that the procession would cover over 450m.

Tiwari said ‘Gauna’ rituals would start from Monday and a musical event would also take place in Tedhineem.

Title: Telangana: Farm hand arrested for raping 6-year-old girl
Content:
Representative image

JAYASHANKAR BHUPALPALLY: A six-year-old girl was allegedly raped by a relative at Parlapally village of Mogullapally mandal here on Sunday. The accused works as an agriculture labourer. He used to visit the girl’s house frequently and got acquainted with her.

On Sunday, the accused allegedly lured the girl to go out with him. He took her to a forest area nearby and allegedly raped her there. He also allegedly threatened to kill her if she reported the incident to anyone.

While the girl was walking back home, she started bleeding. The locals who noticed this informed her grandmother and the girl was rushed to a hospital in Jammikunta for treatment. There, the girl narrated the incident to her grandmother. The girl, whose parents work at a hospital in Hyderabad, lives with her grandmother and aunt in Parlapally. The victim is a student of Class 1 at a local school.

The villagers apprehended the accused and handed him over to the police. D Vijay Goud, SI, Mogullapally, said that they were investigating the case.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Goa: Activist held for ‘hate speech’ at anti-CAA rally
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI/PONDA: Goa police's crime branch arrested activist Ramkrishna Jalmi on Sunday for hurting religious sentiments by making derogatory remarks at an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) rally at Benaulim in South Goa on Saturday.

“We have received a complaint from Mapusa-based Hindu Yuva Sena against Jalmi for making derogatory remarks against lord Parshuram,” SP (crime branch) Pankaj Kumar Singh told TOI.

“Based on the complaint, we have arrested Jalmi,” he said.

The FIR has been registered under Section 259 A (deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious belief) and 153 A (promoting enmity between different groups) of IPC, Singh said.

The Hindu Yuva Sena, in its complaint, said Jalmi has deeply hurt the religious sentiments of the Hindu community. Jalmi was one of the speakers at the anti-CAA meet.

“Lord Parshuram, who is the sixth incarnation of lord Vishnu, is greatly revered and worshipped by the Hindu community,” the complaint states.

The group demanded stern action against the activist for hurting religious sentiments as well as to prevent any untoward incident arising out of the said " hate speech ".

Demanding that FIR be registered to prevent any communal tension in the state, the group said that anger among the Hindus is being expressed on various platforms.

Meanwhile, another complaint was filed against Jalmi by Hindu Janajagruti Samiti (HJS) in Ponda.

Ponda police inspector Mohan Gaude said the complaint will be transferred to Colva police station, as Benaulim, where the meeting took place, comes under Colva police jurisdiction.

Signed by eight members of HJS, the right wing group’s complaint has also raised objection to Jalmi's speech.

Title: Delhi: Panel for action against misuse of Connaught Place properties
Content:
Connaught Place

NEW DELHI: Around 90 shops in Connaught Place might face sealing action for alleged misuse and illegal constructions on their premises.

After surveying the recent report on properties in CP submitted by the New Delhi Municipal Council, the Supreme Court-appointed monitoring committee found that many shop owners had constructed their ground floor below the ground lever to create inter-mediate floors in violation of the original lease deed and as per provisions under the Master Plan for Delhi 2021.

The committee directed the NDMC chairman to take punitive action against all such properties and submit action taken report within a month. “Many people created mezzanine floors or mid-floors and even extended it beyond permissible limit in violation of norms. When CP was constructed there was no provision for basement. However, over the years these were constructed illegally. We asked NDMC officials to issue show cause notices to violators and take action if their replies were not found satisfactory,” said a member of the monitoring committee on the condition of anonymity.

The direction was issued during a meeting called on February 20, regarding sealing operations and retrieval of government and DDA’s land.

In the minutes of meeting, it was mentioned that in connivance with officials of NDMC and Land and Development Office, shopkeepers constructed basements illegally, in violation of the lease deed.

“The architect department had done some survey and submitted a report to the monitoring committee sometime back. Other departments were yet to receive the committee order and details of the surveys officially. After seeing them, future course of action would be decided,” said an official.

Atul Bhargava, president of New Delhi Traders Association, said that none of the shopkeeper had received notices so far. “In fact, NDMC did not communicate anything officially,” Bhargava added.

Title: Inspired by song, students & teachers start a campaign to check migration
Content:
Ramnagar (Nainital): Inspired by popular song ‘Gaon Chhodab Nahi’ (Will not leave village), teachers and students of Government Inter College Dhela have jointly started a campaign to check migration.

Under the campaign, around 50 current and alumni students of the inter-college will be trained with self-employment oriented topics around the Corbett National Park. During weekends and vacations, the experts of various disciplines of fauna-flora and local environment will train these students for the next two years. ‘Gaon Chhodab Nahi’ was penned by Jharkhand lyricist and Padma Shri awardee Madhu Mansoori Hansmukh.

“While the knowledge obtained from the experts during this campaign will make the students are more sensitive to wildlife and their surroundings, it will also motivate them to seek self-employment. It can also be a means of stopping migration,” Navendu Mathpal, a teacher, told TOI on Sunday.

Four senior guides, bird watching expert and photographer of Corbett National Park - Rajesh Bhatt, Bachhi Singh Bisht, Deep Rajwar and Sandeep Giri - will provide training through workshops and park visits. Apart from this, students will participate in seminars on wildlife, where they will interact with scientists, environmentalists and learn from them.

Mathpal added that in the first week of March, students associated with the campaign will be taken to a summit on wildlife in Corbett Park where they will interact with senior scientists.

“We have promised to provide all possible help to students involved in this campaign. We have decided that every week we will take 15 students of this campaign and other local schools to Corbett National Park and introduce them to the wildlife,” said Ramakant Tiwari, warden at Corbett National Park.

Title: Women’s Day: Night run & bike rally to be held
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Various organizations are conducting gender sensitization initiatives as part of Women’s Day observance, which is celebrated every year on March 8.

Empowering women in IT (eWIT), an organization of women IT professionals, is conducting a night run on Wednesday. A two-wheeler rally, organized by Manaveeyam fraternity, will be held on Tuesday.

The night run is organized to create awareness on the need for better women’s safety measures and gender parity in the community. Employees of Technopark will attend the night run, which will begin from the Amphi Theatre in phase I campus of Technopark. The event will be flagged off at 7pm. A music festival will be held after the run. There will be prizes for fastest runners, youngest runners, senior runners and most enthusiastic organizations.

Registration can be done through http://ewittvm.co.in/register-run.php. Registration fee is Rs 200. Those who register by paying Rs 300 will receive a recycled cloth bag. Those registering for Rs 400 will get a recycled cloth bag and a T-shirt. The organizers said that money raised from the event will be used to fund two women-run community projects within and outside the Technopark.

A two-wheeler rally, organized by the Manaveeyam fraternity, will be led by women. They will raise slogans like ‘safe women, safe society’ and ‘drug-free city, safe city’.

The rally will begin near the Neermathalam sapling at Manaveeyam at 4.30pm on Tuesday. After taking a ride through the city, the rally will conclude at the street library at Manaveeyam. The rally is conducted to raise awareness on ensuring freedom of movement of women, campaign against alcohol and drugs, gender justice and equal opportunities.

The rally will be followed by cultural activities at Manaveeyam. Manaveeyam fraternity will distribute certificates to the participants. For registration, call, 9048202083, 9497571803.

Title: Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik sanctions Rs 10 lakh for BSF jawan who lost house in Delhi riots
Content:
Odisha chief minister Naveen Patnaik. File photo

BHUBANESWAR: The state government on Sunday lent a helping hand to a BSF jawan from Delhi whose house in the Khajuri Khas area of the national capital was damaged by rioters last week.

Chief minister Naveen Patnaik has sanctioned Rs 10 lakh for the repair of the house of 28-year-old jawan Mohammad Anees, who was posted in Maoist-hit Malkangiri district till the recent developments prompted the BSF to attach him to its HQ in Delhi. Naveen also spoke to the jawan over the phone and expressed regret at the violence.

“The chief minister consoled Anees and sanctioned Rs 10 lakh from the chief minister’s relief fund for him. Anees works in the BSF’s 9th battalion and was deployed in swabhiman anchal in Malkangiri,” a statement from the chief minister’s office said.

Anees expressed gratitude to the Odisha government. “A mob ransacked and set ablaze my house, which is located in a street in Khajuri Khas, on February 25. My father was alone in the three-storey home, as everyone else had gone to a relative’s place in Delhi,” he told TOI.

“On the morning of Tuesday, hundreds of armed miscreants attacked our house. My father begged them to go away, but to no avail. Luckily, my father escaped while the rioters torched our home by exploding gas cylinders,” said the jawan who joined the force in 2013.

Anees, who is to get married in April, visited his ravaged home on Sunday. He expects to be moved back soon to Malkangiri, where he has been working since September last year. Sources said he had earlier served three years in Jammu & Kashmir.

The BSF said the force had already started providing support to Anees. “We (BSF) have started repairing his house. Other help, including financial assistance, is being provided to the family,” BSF’s DIG in Delhi, Pushpendra Singh Rathore, told TOI over the phone. “In the wake of the unfortunate incident with Anees’s family, he has temporarily been attached to the BSF headquarters in Delhi. He may rejoin the Odisha unit when everything settles,” the DIG added.

Title: Youth pedals from Haridwar to Kochi for spreading hygiene message
Content:
on a mission: Luis Das started his cycle journey on October 30

KOCHI: Luis Das cycled all the way from Haridwar, covered 19 states, and reached Kochi a few days ago, to spread the message of hygiene . Dressed in full white, Das, an admirer of Mahatma Gandhi, had posters on cleanliness and Swachh Bharat campaign displayed on his cycle as he pedalled through the streets of Kochi. Das, who hails from Morigaon, Assam, witnessed indiscriminate littering in all states he went through but he was expecting to not see garbage piled on roadsides in Kerala as well. “I had high expectations of Kerala but here also there is rampant littering,” Das said. Das’s late father was a school teacher and his only brother a government servant. A 29-year-old unmarried man, Das who used to run a business of decorative items, found a guru two years ago and has been working at his ashram at Haridwar since then. He took up the ‘Bharat Yatra’ mission on October 30 and began cycling. He carries tent equipment, items for personal hygiene, a mobile phone, earphones and a microphone and speaker to talk to people about hygiene. “Wherever I go, I meet with people to spread my message. I do a bit of online research ahead of my visit and tie-up with those interested in partnering with me. I have talked to students about the need for hygiene,” said Das. He recollected how he had organized a solo sit-in at a town in Uttar Pradesh against littering. “I went to the town and found that even the government offices were unclean. So, I did a sit-in. Later I realized that if I keep on protesting, I am never going to complete my goal and moved on,” said Das. Das said that his spiritual guide, Mahamadaleshwar Sidharth Giri Maharaj, assisted him in purchasing his gear and bicycle for the journey and he receives financial assistance from well-wishers on the way. He is waiting for permission to go to Lakshadweep from Kochi.

Title: Stunt for TikTok post kills teen
Content:
NEW DELHI: An 18-year-old youth died while having a video shot for a TikTok post when his head hit a rock as he dived into the Ganga canal near Muzaffarnagar .

He was knocked unconscious and his body was recovered two hours later. The video of the incident went viral.

Title: Locals protest for removing waste pile, say will write to PM
Content:
Dehradun: Miffed with the waste pile, residents of several areas, including Kargi, Banjarawala, Dehrakhas, Vidya Vihar, Brahmanwala, Majra and Clement Town, staged a protest outside the open garbage transfer station at Haridwar bypass road on Sunday. The locals say that the openly lying garbage at the transfer station is a “blot on Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Swachh Bharat Mission”.

“We are left with no other option but to approach the Prime Minister’s office now. It seems that our demand to shift waste pile from garbage transfer station is not a priority for the administration. The residents have collectively decided to send a letter to the PMO in the matter,” said Aakesh Bhatt, a local.

The protesting locals allege that they have filed more than 250 complaints at the Uttarakhand Chief Minister’s portal but to no avail. Meanwhile, the locals continued to demand action in the matter from Dehradun Municipal Corporation officials and the mayor. However, they say no concrete action has been taken so far to address their issue.

“Living in this area has become a nightmare for us. The authorities have no idea what we go through each day. The decision to shift the transfer station was taken long back but the garbage pile is still here,” said Padminder Negi, another local.

Meanwhile, DMC’s chief health officer Kailash Joshi told TOI, “We have already identified a spot for shifting the garbage transfer station. The work is ongoing and will be completed by March 15.”

Title: LLB student held for ‘cheating’ in forest recruitment exam
Content:
Roorkee: A 23-year-old student of LLB was arrested by Roorkee police on charges of being involved in cheating in forest guard recruitment exam.

The exam was conducted on February 16 in Uttarakhand. Following allegations of cheating, a probe was conducted in which a Roorkee-based coaching centre owner was recently arrested.

SSP, Haridwar Senthil Avoodai K Raj, said that accused student Shah Nawaz was working as an agent for Mukesh Saini, a coaching centre owner near Roorkee. “Shah Nawaz used to search prospects for Saini. He confessed to us that he had collected money for Saini from the prospects,” the SSP said.

Haridwar police have registered an FIR at Manglaur police station against eight men, including Saini.

Title: Cops arrest criminal after encounter
Content:
Prayagraj: A criminal with a reward of Rs 50,000 on his head was arrested after an encounter in Charwa area of Kaushambi district on Saturday evening.

The accused was identified as Maan Singh and is a resident of Nathai Ka Pura (Kokhraj). Police also recovered a 0.315 bore countrymade pistol and two bullets from his possession.

ASP Ashok Kumar said the accused was wanted in connection with over 22 criminal cases registered in Kaushambi, Prayagraj and other districts.

Singh was arrested when police swung into action after being tipped off about the former’s whereabouts near Kaju village. During the encounter, when police tried to stop Singh, he opened fire at them. He sustained a gunshot in his right leg during the exchange of fire.

Title: Month on, no system to check if Goans enter casinos for gambling
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: A month after Goans were banned from gambling in casinos, the gaming commission has still not put rules in place. Without any notification, it is still unclear whether any Goan has been denied entry into any of the state’s 15 casinos for gambling.

The state government had notified the Goa Public Gaming (Amendment) Act, 2012, to ban the entry of Goans into the six offshore and nine onshore casinos in the state from February 1, and appointed the commissioner of commercial tax as gaming commissioner, to keep tabs on whether Goans were gambling at the casinos.

A senior official said that as the rules have not been notified, they have not conducted any monitoring or inspection of casinos to check if Goans are entering the casinos.

The official said that the gaming rules files have been sent to law department for vetting before they are notified. He said that chief minister Pramod Sawant had cleared the files.

Sawant had said that till rules are notified, tourists will not be stopped from entering the casinos, but action would be taken if Goans are found gambling at the casinos.

As per the act, the gaming commissioner has to issue a ‘tourist permit’, authourising tourists to enter the areas designated for gambling.

The gaming commissioner is empowered to exercise overall control over the games conducted in the designated areas and is also authorised to maintain the records and documents in connection with the games.

The commissioner has the right to order closure, to seal any casino in a five-star hotel or to take custody of any casino vessel, and while exercising this power, the commissioner shall make an inventory of all the items of which the custody is taken.

Banning the entry of Goans into the casinos was a long-pending demand of the people, with the legislators echoing their concerns in the House, as many families had gone bankrupt due to gambling addiction.

In June 2015, the home department had first drafted the rules, in which there was a provision to arrest any person under the age of 2, found gambling.

It was in June 2012 that the state government passed the amendment to the Goa Public Gaming Act, 1976, by introducing the Goa Public Gaming (Amendment) Bill, 2012.

Title: SC/ST scam: Four govt employees booked for forging income certificate
Content:
Dehradun: In a first, the special investigation team (SIT) probing the multi-crore SC/ST scholarship scam in Uttarakhand lodged a complaint against three government employees on charges of forging income certificates. These certificates were allegedly used to claim scholarship money for their wards.

Rajpur police station in charge Ashok Rathore told TOI that an FIR was filed in the police station against three government employees under section 420 (cheating), 467 (forgery), and section 409 (Criminal breach of trust by public servant) of the IPC.

“We have lodged an FIR against Nainbagh resident Baldev Singh Tomar, Kalsi resident Mohan Singh, and Tyuni resident Sardar Singh. The annual income of the student’s family must be under 2.50 lakh for scholarship. The accused, who are government employees, have produced fake income certificates to get the scholarship money meant for economically-weaker SC/ST students,” said the official.

Another FIR was filed in the case against Vikas Nagar resident Gopal Singh, also a government employee, at Raipur police station. Reportedly, both daughters of Singh availed scholarship money by producing fake income certificates of their father.

Till now, the SIT had mainly filed cases against educational institutes which have allegedly siphoned off funds meant for SC/ST students. However, this is the first instance where wards of students have been booked for forging documents.

To recall, the state police department had set up the SIT to probe irregularities in the SC/ST scholarship scheme in April last year. The move came after they received complaints stating that colleges in Uttarakhand and Uttar Pradesh claim scholarship money from the state social welfare department by producing fake documents.

Dehradun-based activist Ravindra Jugran had also filed a petition in the court alleging that it is a Rs 500 crore scam.

Title: Team of 10 docs to oversee SCB expansion work
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Sunday appointed a team of 10 eminent doctors to oversee the transformation of SCB Medical College and Hospital (SCBMCH) in Cuttack into a world-class healthcare institution. Seven members of the team are Padma award recipients. Four are alumni of SCBMCH.

On the panel are cardiovascular thoracic surgeon at Asian Heart Institute Ramakanta Panda, heart surgeon and chairman of Narayan Health Devi Shetty, president of Public Health Foundation of India K Srinath Reddy, gastroenterologist Subrat Acharya, renal transplant surgeon Mukut Minz, pioneer in lung cancer and tuberculosis treatment Digambar Behera, medical director of Tata Cancer Hospital Rajan Badwe, an innovator in cardiovascular medicine Jagat Narula, ophthalmologist and director of L V Prasad Eye Institute G N Rao and noted obstetrician and gynaecologist Purna Chandra Mohapatra. Director Medical Education and Training CBK Mohanty will be the convener of the panel.

“The SCBMCH is the crowning glory of our healthcare system. It is the symbol of hope for millions and millions of people. This transformational initiative is aimed at providing world-class health facilities to the people of Odisha,” said a letter issued by the CMO. ‘

Gynaecologist Mohapatra said, “I am thankful to the chief minister for including me in the team of advisers. I am a student of the institute and also worked here for several years. I will give my best to the project.”

In November 2019, the government had announced a package of Rs 1,000 crore to overhaul SCBMCH. It will be converted into a 3,000-bed integrated hospital with state-of-the-art facilities. It will also be designated as an AIIMS Plus institute.

Work on the expansion will take place from March 1. Land acquisition for the project began in January. The government will rehabilitate those affected because of the expansion work. The SCBMCH campus will also be increased in size with the addition of 50 to 60 acres to the existing 100 acres.

Title: Two nursing students struck by lighning in Nainital
Content:
Dehradun: Two nursing students at Ramsey Hospital received burn injuries after they were hit by lightning late on Saturday evening. Several phones and electric sockets were also burnt at the institution after lightning hit it.

According to police, the injured students, Kiran Rawat and Babita Kumari, were admitted to BD Pandey hospital. Their condition is stable now. Both the women were third year nursing students.

“The lightning struck a tree inside the hospital’s general nursing college wing. The tree fell on the GNM hostel and broke a window and a wall. The girl students were standing near the window when they were struck by lightning. Three others fainted due to the noise,” said an official from the hospital, who did not want to be named.

Title: Black flags at PM rally: BJP takes on SP
Content:
Prayagraj: Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and Samajwadi Party (SP) were caught in an exchange of barbs on Sunday, a day after a group of members of the Akhilesh Yadav-led party were detained for allegedly waving black flags during an event attended by Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

BJP (Mahanagar) president Ganesh Kesarwani said, “The people of the country have blacklisted SP and its workers for their mischievous acts. The mentality of SP workers has been exposed.”

SP spokesman Daan Bahadur said, “Everyone has a right to register their protest in a democracy. It is not acceptable to send innocent party workers to jail just for protesting. Also, the five SP workers have been booked under some serious sections at the behest of the state government.”

“A delegation of party leaders met the five when they were brought to the district court before being sen to jail. Party leaders assured the workers that our legal cell would help them to fight their case,” Bahadur said.

On Saturday, five SP members were booked for allegedly waving black flags at an event attended by the PM at Parade Ground. Modi was in Prayagraj to distribute disability aids among differently abled persons. The SP workers were booked under sections 147, 148, 332, 353, 504, 506, 188, 352, 153A, 505 (1) B, 419, 420, 467, 468 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code and section 7 of the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act. Police also said that the five were carrying fake identity cards to attend the event.

Title: Kerala University youth festival begins from today
Content:
T’puram: The Kerala University youth festival 2020 titled ‘Palayanam’ will be held from Monday to Saturday.

Over 5,000 students from 250 colleges will participate in the event which will begin with flag hoisting at 4pm on Monday. Minister K T Jaleel will inaugurate the festival at a function to be held at Government College, Kariavattom, at 5pm.

A R Riyas, chairman, Kerala University Union said, “It is the first time that the festival is held at a college outside the city. ‘Survival through art’ is our theme for this year’s festival”.

The venues include Government College, Kariavattom; SN College Auditorium, Chembazhanthi; seminar hall at SN College for Advance Studies; Seminar hall and arts block at SN College; and seminar hall at University B.Ed College.

The organizers have also given unique names for the venues associated with people and contemporary topics in the country such as ‘Article 14’, ‘Shaheen Bagh’, ‘Fathima Latheef Nagar’, ‘Alan Kurdi’, ‘Rohingyan’, ‘Abhimanyu Nagar’, ‘Ambedkar Nagar’, ‘Ajay Nagar’ and ‘Gouri Lankesh Nagar’.

While asked on whether the names of some of the venues, which are related to protests against the Central government will be opposed by students of ABVP, mayor K Sreekumar, who is the chairman of the youth festival organizing committee, said that there will not be any issue in this regard at the festival.

Also, it will be the first youth festival to include ‘transgender’ as a category along with male and female categories in the competitions. Spot registration facility is arranged for transgender candidates at the venue. Unlike the previous editions, the festival will have a special prize for a women’s college, which scores the highest points in all competitions.

Title: Truck driver fined Rs 1.10L as strict enforcement of MV Act begins
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Tension gripped several places in the state on Sunday as joint squads of the transport department and police started the strict enforcement of the amended Motor Vehicles (MV) Act leading to clashes between enforcers and violators.

In Rayagada, a truck driver was imposed a fine of Rs 1.10 lakh towards different violations under the amended law.

In Bhubaneswar, the transport authorities issued challans amounting to nearly Rs five lakh to several violators on Sunday.

Though the new MV Act came into force on September 1 last, the state government had refrained from implementing it strictly owing to the unavailability of transport-related documents with people.

The state government had relaxed the enforcement drive for six months, the deadline of which ended on Saturday.

“Our focus is on strict enforcement of rules related to drink driving, speeding, driving against the flow of traffic, using mobile phone while driving, triple riding on two-wheeler, overloading, jumping the red light, not wearing helmets and seat belt,” state transport commissioner Sanjeeb Panda said.

He added, “We have asked the district collectors and SPs to prevent inconvenience to motorists during the checking drives. A maximum of four vehicles should be detained for checking at one spot to avoid traffic congestion.” tnn

Title: Silent efforts help indigenous cattle breeds flourish in Kerela
Content: KOCHI: The state consumes nearly 2.5 lakh tonnes of cattle and buffalo meat every year, and on the other hand it conserves indigenous breeds with negligible milch capacity. In the past few years, Kerala has seen concerted efforts by farmer groups and heritage breed conservationists in rearing heritage livestock, which has so far remained a silent activity.From the plantations of Cheruvally in Kottayam to the banks of Periyar in Ernakulam and the foothills of Thiruvilwamala in Thrissur and rural Vatakara in Kozhikode, several groups are trying to bring back rare farm animals from the brink of extinction.Two known success stories of indigenous cattle conservation from the state are that of Vechur cows, considered smallest in the world, and the Kasaragod dwarf. While Vechur cow has been recognized as an indigenous breed, the only one from Kerala, Kasaragod dwarf failed to gain the status.Currently, seven cattle varieties, excluding Vechur and Kasaragod dwarf, are being reared across the state. But a concerted effort at increasing the quality of livestock is being made in the case of four varieties - Periyar cows, found near Periyar River; Cheruvally cows of Cheruvally Estate, Vilwadri breed of Thiruvilwamala and Vatakara cattle. Lesser known populations like Wayanad cattle and Highrange dwarf are also being farmed by individuals.Dr Jayadevan Namboothiri, assistant director, animal husbandry department, said only localised efforts would work and conservation activities needed to move out of university environment.Cos Kurien, who leads the conservation of the Periyar variety, along with 40 other farmers has floated ‘Periyar pashu samraskshana samiti’. “Efforts to conserve Vilwadri stock are being carried out under the leadership of Ramesh Korappath of Ivor Madam while that for Cheruvally cattle are led by Lijo C Mathew. Vatakara cattle conservation is happening under the leadership of Dr P Girishkumar,” said Jayadevan.Scientists from National Bureau of Animal Genetic Resources had visited the farms to collect samples of Periyar and Vilwadri cattle to determine their claim for indigenous breed status. Indigenous breeds can be maintained with zero input cost, are disease resistant and can withstand high temperatures. The milk is A2 quality, which will fetch higher value if properly marketed, and the dung and urine has special characteristics.“Indigenous breeds like Wayanad cattle has the potential to resist vagaries of climate change. It is high time we moved from high-yielding breeds to local ones,” said Dr Anil Zachariah, assistant director, animal husbandry department.

Title: Experts urge for a rethink on mega dam projects
Content:
Convenor of climate and energy group Dr Soumya Dutta speaks at the conference on Sunday

Bhopal: The national conference on river valley has a word of caution for the governments and policymakers to give up ‘short-sightedness’ while planning river projects. The two-day conference began at Gandhi Bhavan here on Sunday.

Experts urged governments to take rivers in their entirety as they are not bound by the geographical boundaries.

A river economist, Dr Bharat Jhunjhunwala said, “There is no conflict between economic development and environment. The long-term development is environment. We need to have proper evaluation of cost and benefit of the projects.”

The difficulty is that the government looks at the short-term returns, he said “they are driven by commercial interests, they are ignoring the social cost ... But it is counterproductive”.

The expert said, “We need to push the government, plead with it or force it ... whatever possible — soft and hard — that you make a proper dispassionate assessment of all the benefits, all the social and environmental costs...if we are able to this, lot of issues are resolved ... it is not commerce against people, it is short-sightedness that is affecting us.”

Dr Soumya Dutta, convener of climate and energy group said that the government must recognise the rivers in their entirety. “They need to understand all the functions that a river performs but there are two popular terms when they talk about the rivers- Cumec (that is water flow unit) and MGH — how much hydropower it can generate.”

Datta said, “we have to dismantle some of the dams and many countries have started to realise this. Dam builders will always give argument of power generation ... but, do you know, we are power surplus state for fourth year in succession. The peak demand in India was about 1.90 lakh MW but we already have a capacity of about 4 lakh MW generation including about 58 000MW in captive power plants.”

Quoting the Central Electricity Authority (CEA), Dutta said, "we don’t need any power plant for the next 8 or 10 years.”

Former chief secretary and now an activist SC Behar said, “We need to take the fight against the big dams to a different level.”

Water conservation experts, research scholars and activists working across the country in Ganga Yamuna valley, Godavari, Krishna, Polavaram, Kaveri, Kosi and Halon river valleys among others are attending the conference.

Title: Teacher, who treks 8km to school, on a hunger strike
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: K R Ushakumari, the only teacher at the tribal school at Kunnathumala in Amboori, who had won several accolades, including national honours, is in news again.

Ushakumari has been on a hunger strike at the school for the last three days, demanding job security and clearance of salary arrears.

“People know about my 8-km daily trek to school through dense forest. But, they don’t see my struggle after school to make both ends meet,” said Ushakumari.

Announcing her protest in a detailed Facebook post with a picture of a shelf full of awards she had received, the teacher shared her ordeal. “The awards are all laughing at me. I cannot appear for any PSC examination because of the age limit fixed for such exams. Will I get a permanent appointment? There is no answer to the question,” she said.

Ushakumari joined the Agasthya Multi Grade Learning Centre in Amboori panchayat as teacher in 1999, which is around 8km away from her home. Later, the centre was taken over by Sarva Siksha Abhiyan. Later, the qualification of the teachers was raised from SSLC to TTC.

“I have passed SSLC. I am now 52 years old and cannot go for another job. Many teachers across the state, who work in such schools, are above 55 years of age. We informed the government that we were are ready to complete the TTC course, if we get an official order in this regard. The assurance from government that our demand for permanent posting will be considered was never put in a written document. Believing in the false claims we all continued our work. But nothing happened. I have given 20 years of my life for this job. Don’t we deserve a happy retirement life. One can see the results of our efforts at the school and kids from tribal settlements,” said Ushakumari.

Mentioning about the delay in payment of salaries, Ushakumari said, “For the past five months, none of the teachers in the single-teacher schools received salary”.

“Recently, I along with other teachers approached the authorities concerned to check the reason for the delay in payment of our salaries. And we did not get a clear answer. It is then that I decided to conduct a hunger strike till I get a written assurance from the government regarding our appointment,” she added.

Officials of the education department said that file regarding disbursal of salary for the teachers will be cleared by the finance department in the first week of March itself.

Title: Securing shores: Navy officer upholds law on troubled water
Content:
The India-Pakistan war in 1965 and the valour displayed by Indian soldiers had a telling effect on a young man from Jaunpur in Uttar Pradesh. While villagers discussed the war and the developments, Chandra Shekhar listened intently.

“I wish that one of my family members too joins the armed forces to serve the nation,” his grandfather Choudhari Indrajit had said. Chandra Shekhar took his grandfather’s words to heart and joined the Indian Navy in 1969. “I chose to join the Navy as I liked the uniform,” Commander Chandra Shekhar recollected, in a conversation with TOI in the city.

Upon joining the armed forces, Chandra Shekhar got to play a role in the 1971 war against Pakistan as he provided logistic support from Goa .

As someone who was involved in providing logistics support in the Navy, Chandra Shekhar sailed to different countries. He was posted in different parts of the country, including Visakhapatnam. As part of the mine-sweeping squadron of a war ship, he would carry out operations to detect if there were any bombs in the water when the war ships moved. “I loved the sea,” the 72-year-old said, talking about his 22 years in the Indian Navy.

He also brought out sweeping reform by getting all the service records of Navy personnel documented thoroughly. “Otherwise, it was taking nearly 8-10 months for those who retired to get their pensions. In just one month, we put the service records in order without any gaps so that retired personnel would not have to wait for their pensions,” he recalled.

But it wasn’t just the sea and providing logistics that he loved. As a trial judge advocate in the Navy, he was firm that the guilty should be punished in court martial so that it can be a deterrence to others. In one instance, an officer who was charged with embezzlement of Rs 34,000 was dismissed and given a jail term. In another instance, a sailor attempted to attack a Naval officer on board a warship due to personal issues and he got a jail term and was removed from service. Chandra Shekar had also ruled to dismiss a naval officer for desertion. “What if he deserted the Navy during war?” Chandra Shekhar said, when officials wondered if it deserved a jail term.

Shekhar acted with Amitabh Bachchan in the movie ‘Kaala Patthar’ in a courtroom scene and also met with the then Chief Justice of Pakistan Muhammad Haleem. After his retirement, Shekhar has been engaged in teaching yoga.

Title: ‘Periyar’ may soon become recognized desi breed
Content:
Kochi: A closely-knit group of organic farmers in Ernakulam district are engaged in conserving one variety of cattle, Periyar, which they believe is eligible for indigenous breed status. The breed, also known as Kuttambuzha Kullan and Plantation Pashu, is mostly found in places like Kodanad, Malayattoor, Kalady, Paniyeli, Vadattupara, Kuttambuzha and Charupara, which are located close to Periyar River.

Scientists from the National Bureau of Animal Genetic Resources (NBAGR) under the Indian Centre of Agricultural Research (ICAR) have already made visits to these locales to assess the cattle population and to determine their claim for indigenous breed status.

Leading the group of farmers is Cos Kurien, a native of Kodanad. “There are around 40 people who are actively involved in conserving Periyar cows. Now, there are 2,500 Periyar breed cows in the area,” said Kurien, who was honoured with Breed Saviour award in 2019.

Getting indigenous status is a laborious process. “As per the new eligibility criteria, the population need to have at least 1,000 animals and they need to have unique stable and uniform attributes. Periyar cow stands a good chance of being recognized because it meets several of these criteria,” said N Jayadevan, who was involved in efforts to procure breed status to Vechur cattle.

“I feel we haven’t been able to define it uniformly,” said K Anilkumar, professor, department of animal breeding, genetics and biostatistics. A major problem in conserving these breeds is the absence of bulls. “If the animal population is scattered, artificial insemination is the only solution. Lack of breeding plan may affect the population,” he said.

Title: Mark the planets to know your lucky colour this Holi
Content:
rashi roulette: A vendor sells gulal in Prayagraj on Sunday

Prayagraj: Holi is round the corner and city-based religious scholars are flooded with queries from revellers seeking to know what colours suit them best as per their Zodiac signs and Vedic astrology.

Astrologers claim Holi will see powerful planets Jupiter and Saturn in their respective positions. Choosing colours based on planetary positions can ward off evil, they claim.

An astrologer Ashutosh Varshney said, the role of navgraha (nine planets) in our horoscope governs our birth, how we spend our life, death and beyond. “The nine planets are emitters or reflectors of rays of different colours. If a person is facing a rough patch under Saturn, also known as Shani sadhesaati (difficult period of 7.5 years), then he or she must play Holi with black and blue. These colours offer a healing touch for worries, stress and anxiety,” he explained.

The astrologer maintained that those “affected by Saturn” should avoid red which stands for Saturn’s enemies, the Sun and planet Mars. Those born under Aries or Scorpio, must play Holi with red as it will discard ill effects of Mangal or Mars, their governing planet. Similarly, Taurians and Librans, ruled by Venus, should go for shiny white to ward off evil influence of Shukra (Venus).

Gemini and Virgo, ruled by Mercury, should use green to buffer the negative influence of Budh (Mercury).

Cancer is ruled by the moon. Those undergoing a bad phase must use white. Leo, on the other hand, is ruled by the sun. Hence, red and orange are very favourable.

Sagittarians and Pisceans, ruled by Jupiter, should go for yellow and golden that symbolise the virtues of Brihaspati (Jupiter). Those aspiring to earn the virtues of the planet should use yellow in abundance, he suggested.

Capricorn and Aquarius are once again ruled by Saturn. Hence, black and blue in any form will earn the goodwill of Shani (Saturn) for those who are affected by the planet’s unfavourable position in their horoscope.

Title: Need more women farmers at the helm: Study
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: A survey by dairy development department has recommended formation of more women cooperative milk societies in the state, to have women presidents in societies at least once in 10 years and 40% seat reservation for women in the governing committees of these societies.

‘Women dairy farmers survey report-2019’, released by health minister K K Shailaja during the dairy farmers summit being held in the state capital, has also identified rise in fodder prices and high production costs as major problems currently being faced by dairy farmers.

The survey, claimed to be the first of its kind in the country, initiated on the recommendation of the state planning board, found that 59.8% of the women dairy farmers do not have membership in the Kerala dairy farmers welfare fund board. Of the total 3,647 registered cooperative milk societies, only 65 are women cooperative societies, the study said.

“This makes just 2.2% of the total number of the societies. Top priority should be given to formation of women societies. Whenever a new society is being formed, the possibilities for making it a women’s society should get special considerations,” the report recommended.

Citing the meagre presence of younger generation among women dairy farmers (12.2%), the survey report warned against a drastic fall in the number of women dairy farmers in the near future.

Title: Mondaikad Koda Festival begins
Content:
T’puram: The 10-day-long annual ‘Koda’ Festival at the Mondaikad Bhagavathy Temple in Kanyakumari began on Sunday with the traditional ‘kodiyettu’ ceremony.

Amidst loud chants of ‘Devi Saranam’, temple tantri Edakkode S Mahadeva Iyer and temple head priest Chattanatha Kurukkal initiated the festival rites in the presence of Telangana governor Dr Tamilisai Soundararajan.

Despite being in Tamil Nadu the temple and its festivals are run as per the rites and traditions followed in Kerala. It was in 1803 that the former ruler of Travancore took over the administration of the temple.

‘Valiyapadukka’, one of the major rituals of the festival, will be held on March 6 and the procession of ‘valiya theevatti’ falls on March 9. The legendary ‘Koda’ will take place on March 10. The festival will conclude on March 10 with ‘odukku pooja” at midnight.

Although devotees offer pongala at the temple every day, on festival days, their number swells to thousands. tnn

Title: Cong, BJP gear up for Agar Malwa bypoll
Content:
Bhopal: The BJP and Congress are ready to flex their muscles in Agar Malwa ahead of bypoll, as both the parties are busy chalking out plans to wrest the seat. On March 2, chief minister Kamal Nath will visit Agar Malwa and announce major sops for the district, while the BJP has decided to hold a workers' convention on March 4 to display its strength.

Nath's visit to Agar Malwa district is likely to boost Congress prospects in the Malwa region as the CM is all set to announce development projects worth Rs 865 crore. "The chief minister will distribute farm loan waiver certificates up to Rs 2 lakh at `Kisan Samman Sammelan’ in Agar Malwa. He will also lay foundation of development projects and dedicate a hospital in the district," said an official release.

To boost its prospect in the bypolls, the BJP will organise a mega worker convention on March 4 and expose the failures of the state government. On Sunday, BJP state president VD Sharma held closed-door meetings with former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan and leader of opposition Gopal Bhargava at the state head office to plan a strategy for the convention. The BJP will also raise the issues related to crop loss due to the recent hailstorm. "We have demanded survey and 100 precent compensation to farmers whose crops have been damaged by the hailstorm. The state government is betraying the farmers in the name of farm loan waiver, but relief has not reached farmers till date," claimed Sharma.

He said the BJP will survey the hailstorm-affected areas, including Gwalior Chambal region and parts of state, and demand compensation to the affected farmers at the earliest. The party is also likely to raise the issue of farm loan waiver, deterioration of law and order, apart from failures of the state government, during the workers’ meet. Kamal Nath's visit to Agar Malwa is just to woo voters and announce big sops ahead of bypoll. The state government has not fulfilled the promises made during the previous assembly election," said Bhargava, who along with Chouhan and VD Sharma is likely to address workers' rally in Agar Malwa on March 4.

This would be the first worker meeting the saffron party will organise under the leadership of newly appointed state chief VD Sharma. Sources said bypolls will be the litmus test for Sharma's organisational strength and political acumen.

Title: School principal & son held for running cheating racket
Content:
caught in the act

Prayagraj: A manager of a UP Board examination centre and his son were among the three persons arrested for running a massive cheating racket in trans-Yamuna area of Prayagraj district on Sunday.

Special Task Force (STF) also recovered three mobile phones, screenshots of five WhatsApp chats and many solved answer sheets.

The accused were identified as Indrabhan Singh, Ashish Singh and Vikas Yadav, all residents of Meja.

Indrabhan was the principal and centre manager of the examination centre, his son Ashish was a computer teacher and Vikas a solver.

Additional SP (STF) Neeraj Kumar Pandey said, “We were tipped off about a gang of three running a copying racket in Meja. An STF team conducted a series of raids and nabbed the three accused from Meja.”

The ASP said that the accused had planned to submit the solved answersheets of class XII of mathematics on Saturday, once the exam was over.

“Vikas was arrested while he was solving questions of class XII mathematics examination near a brick kiln on Saturday afternoon hours,” the SP added.

During interrogation, Vikas told the police that he had to deliver the solved copies to Indrabhan, who was the principal and centre manager of Mata Daan Singh Inter College.

On the basis of Vikas’ statement, STF nabbed Indrabhan and his son Ashish.

The father-son duo told the police that they used to send question papers of class XII board exams to solvers through WhatsApp. They used to charge Rs 4,000 from each candidate to provide a solved question paper.

They used to charge candidates around Rs 35,000 to Rs 40,000 to provide copies of solved question papers of all subjects.

Title: KIIDC set to take over KWA bottled water plant
Content:
KIIDC officials will visit the plant at Aruvikkara on Monday to review the remaining work

Thiruvananthapuram: Officially, it is curtains for Kerala Water Authority ’s ( KWA ) own bottling water plant . The water resources department on Saturday decided to hand over the ambitious project at Aruvikkara to the Kerala Irrigation Infrastructure Development Corporation Ltd ( KIIDC ), which manufacturers the bottled water ‘Hilly Aqua’.

Officials of KIIDC will visit the Aruvikkara plant on Monday to review the remaining work of the project, mainly the BIS certification process. KWA’s bottling water project, which was cited as a major income-generating scheme, has been wholly transferred to KIIDC, with KWA eligible only for the lease, which is yet to be finalised.

As per the GO, the period of lease will be seven years initially. The KIIDC will be responsible for carrying out the remaining operations, including licencing with BIS and marketing.

The decision to hand over to KIIDC came up amid opposition of KWA employee unions, including Left-affiliated ones. Water resources department has cited inability to draw scarce resources for the bottled water project since KWA has to tackle more important works such as drought mitigation.

“KWA has been entrusted with administrative approval for over Rs 9,000 crore on drinking-water projects funded under KIIFB, Jal Jeevan Mission, state Plan, Nabard, etc. It may not be prudent to draw its scarce resources and divert its limited personnel to a niche market such as bottle water. KWA is over-staffed in lower cadres and need restructuring of its human resources. In view of the possible drought likely in the state in 2020-21, KWA needs to focus on drought relief. It is highly essential to operationalize the bottled water plant on a war footing which has already sunk a cost of Rs 16 crore,” the GO said.

Crediting KIIDC for successfully marketing ‘Hilly Aqua’, the GO stated that the expertise of KIIDC in obtaining the withheld regulatory clearances and floating cost-effective marketing campaign would be far superior to KWA or any other agency hired for the purpose.

KWA had envisaged the bottled water project at Aruvikkara as a model project for setting up similar ones in other parts of the state. With the project slipping away, KWA has to wind up similar plans too. The project, with a capacity to produce 7,200 litres per hour, was conceived in 2006 and the water supply and sewerages act was amended for it.

Title: Vintage beauties attract residents to Bithoor fest
Content:
The vintage car rally started from NRI city and covered a 13-kilometre distance to reach Bithoor on Sunday

Kanpur: Sitting ignored in garages for years, four-wheeled beauties from early 20th century stole the show at a vintage car rally organised during the Bithoor Mahotsava on Sunday.

The cars paraded during the rally included a 1913 mode of limousine, a convertible Morris Minor from the 1950s, a Silver Ghost Rolls-Royce and a Chevrolet Austin Chummy from 1925.

The rare automobiles lured many from the comfort of their homes to the rally despite it being a Sunday.

Many car owners welcomed queries about the vintage vehicles and let visitors click selfies with their vehicles.

The rally started from NRI city and covered a 13-kilometre distance to reach Bithoor. The chief guest at the event divisional commissioner Sudhir M Bobde flagged off the rally.
