Other guests who attended the event were chief development officer Sunil Kumar Singh, SDM (Sadar) Lakhsmi and other district officials.

The participants were welcomed by municipal commissioner Akshay Tripathi when they reached Bithoor. The car owners were presented mementos.

Meanwhile, on Saturday Mohit Gaur and Sujit Gaur walked away with a prize of Rs 51,000 after winning a traditional boat race organised as part of the Bithoor Mahotsava.

Pintu and Sanju Gaur stood second and won a prize of Rs 21,000. The third prize was bagged by Deepak and Sumit Gaur and were awarded a cash prize of Rs 11,000. The 3.5-kilometre race commenced from Siddheshwar Ghat and ended at Brahmavarta Ghat.

Singer Sudesh Bhosle, local MLA Abhijit Singh Sanga, district magistrate Brahmadev Ram Tewari and CDO Sunil Kumar Singh distributed the prizes. It was the first time that a boat race was organised in the Bithoor Mahotsava.

The race was followed by several cultural programmes.

BJP MLA and UP minister Satish Mahana performed a Ganga pujan and visited an exhibition organised at Nana Rao Park on Sunday evening.

Title: HC quashes PDKV’s change in teachers’ promotion criteria in Nagpur
Content:
Representative image

Nagpur: Quashing Dr Panjabrao Deshmukh Krishi Vidyapeeth ’s ( PDKV ) decision to change teachers’ promotion criteria from merit-cum-seniority to seniority-cum-merit, the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Thursday directed the university to make appointments as per earlier rules.

While cancelling promotion of many teachers who were promoted to associate professor’s post by applying the new criteria of seniority-cum-merit, a division bench comprising Justice Atul Chandurkar and Justice Vinay Joshi allowed all five petitioners’ prayers.

“Since it has been observed that the manner in which respondents were promoted as associate professor is not as per law, we’ve no hesitation in setting aside the promotion of the respondent-teachers in agricultural botany, agronomy, agriculture economics,” the bench held, while disposing of pleas by petitioners — Amrapali Akhare, Manish Deshmukh, Vanita Khobarkar, Sanjay Kakade and Shivaji Nagpure.

On the fate of other professors who too were promoted after following the new criteria, but were not made respondents in any of the petitions, the judges clarified that it was up to the university to take appropriate steps as per law.

On November 16, 2017, the university had issued a notification inviting proposals from eligible candidates for effecting promotions to associate professor’s post. On January 25, 2018, PDKV vice-chancellor issued orders granting temporary promotion to assistant professors bringing them to associate level for 11 months.

The university convened a meeting of its academic council on January 3, 2019, where issue of finalizing modalities for promotions came up for discussion. A resolution was passed which permitted to make modifications in the way selection committee would discharge its functions.

Quoting a letter of higher education director, it was decided that for effecting promotions, seniority of candidates and minimal educational qualifications along with academic performance index (API) points and confidential reports should be taken into the consideration.

The resolution was passed and forwarded to executive council which also cleared it without any change on January 7, 2019. Subsequently, on the recommendations of the selection board, which named the respondent-teachers as per new criteria, the VC issued promotion orders. This and the executive council decision was challenged by the petitioners.

All five petitioners through counsels Ashutosh Dharmadhikari, Bhanudas Kulkarni and Mohan Sudame contended that though their API score was better than the respondents, they were declared ineligible due to the change in criteria of merit-cum-seniority.

“As the executive council’s resolution has the effect of amending the relevant statues, and the exercise was done without complying with the procedure, the criteria adopted by the selection committee based on it is faulty,” the HC held while allowing all petitions.

Title: 100 vendors sell wares amid Mandai metro station work
Content:
Pune: The rehabilitation of over 100 stall owners from Mandai area is neither here nor there even as MahaMetro has started the preliminary work for an underground station that will come up close to the huge wholesale market.

The shifting of stalls is essential to make way for the station. MahaMetro officials have said they have already submitted a plan and prototypes of the stalls to be set up for the vendors to the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC).

The civic body is now expected to finalize the location for rehabilitation and the type of stalls suitable for the vendors. The proposal was sent four months ago and MahaMetro is waiting for a feedback from them.

“Mandai will be a crucial station in terms of commuter footfalls. It is expected to be high because of the market area. We have started preliminary work for the station. It will gain momentum only after the existing stalls are shifted to another location. We want the civic body to resolve the issue at the earliest to avoid any further delays,” MahaMetro officials said.

MahaMetro is going to set up stalls at a new location and the space that the vendors now occupy will be handed over for the station’s work.

Sources from the civic body said the issue has been under discussion since the last year. “The elected representatives from the area, civic and MahaMetro officials have jointly visited the area and have identified a few locations to rehabilitate the stalls. But the civic body has not reached any conclusion,” sources said.

Sanjay Shinde, a vendor, said some meetings were held a few days ago but there has been no progress in the proposal for their rehabilitation. A joint meeting between vendors and elected representatives can resolve the issue, he added.

A PMC-run multi-storied parking lot located near Mandai has been under consideration for the rehabilitation. Sources in the civic body said vendors were not keen on this location as it has a single entry point and not all stalls would be on the ground floor.

Local corporator Hemant Rasne, who is also the chairman of PMC’s standing committee, said the civic body was in favour of resolving the issue at the earliest to avoid any delays in the Metro work.

“Discussions on shifting vendors are underway at various levels. Some technical issues are required to be resolved for shifting of stalls. A breakthrough will come through soon,” he added.

Title: Civil aviation minister discusses Pune airport issues with authorities
Content:
Pune: Minister of state for civil aviation Hardeep Singh Puri interacted with the authorities at the Pune airport on Sunday.

Puri, who was in the city for the Asia Economic Dialogue, was informed about the passenger and flight movements. Sources in the airport said Puri was apprised of the issues, particularly related to the shortage of land the airport was facing.

“The minister told us to work towards increasing flight movements and passenger traffic at the airport,” a source at the airport said.

The Pune airport, being a defence airbase, has been struggling due to unavailability of land which has been hampering its expansion.

While the new terminal building is under construction and set to be commissioned by mid-next year, connectivity to the airport when it comes to proper roads and space for parking remain unsolved.

The airport is looking for around 34 acres of land mainly from private landowners and shifting of the existing international cargo terminal which will pave the way for seamless construction of the new terminal building.

Four water machines installed on premises

Four drinking water machines have been installed at the Pune airport for the passengers, who time and again have been complaining about the high cost of the bottled water provided at the facility, the airport’s director told TOI.

“Flyers can fill their containers from the machines for free,” the director said.

“These four machines have been installed in the departure, arrival and the security hold areas of the airport ,” the director added.

Title: MP to pay Rs 580 cr to pvt players without buying a single unit of power in 2021
Content:
BHOPAL: The Madhya Pradesh government is likley to pay Rs 580.22 crore to private power companies in 2020-21 without buying a single unit of power. At least that’s what the annual revenue requirement (ARR) submitted before Madhya Pradesh Electricity Regulatory Commission (MPERC) indicates.

Sources say that if this is plugged, then it will bring down the revenue gap of discoms by more than 25%, which means they would have to seek a lower power tariff hike.

As per the ARR submitted by discoms before MPERC for 2021, they have said that due to surplus power and after meeting the requirements of the state, they will “back down” power of producers. ‘Backing down’ means not buying the power that the state is entitled to under power-purchase agreement (PPA).

“After fully meeting the requirement of the state and selling power on the power exchange, the petitioners still have to partially back-down plants so as to save on the variable costs being incurred,” discoms have said in the ARR. In the same ARR, they have provided the amount of power available from each producer and the amount of power that they would back down in 2020-21.

Sources say discoms will ‘back down’ on four of the nine private power producers with which MP has signed PPAs — Torrent Power, BLA Power, Jaypee Bina Power and Essar Power STPS. This means, as per estimates for 2021, discoms will not purchase a single unit of power from these producers.

In the same ARR, discoms have informed that fixed charges of Rs 62.49 crore will be paid to Torrent Power, Rs 14.98 crore to BLA Power and Rs 504.75 crore to Jaypee Bina Power. The payment to Essar Power STPS hasn’t been revealed yet.

Power producers are paid in two ways — fixed charge and variable charge. If the charges are fixed, they will have to be paid even if the procurer doesn’t take any power. In the ARR, discoms say: “It needs to be highlighted that the payment of fixed charges is required to be made for such generators in accordance with PPAs even if the capacity is backed down.”

Asked about this, ACS-energy, Mohammed Suleman said, “ARR is based on assumptions and actual usage would be decided on demand and supply of power. Payment to any contractor is as per PPA and not decided by the regulator. Fixed charge concept is part of PPA and only the agreement can guide payments to any contractor, nothing outside of it.”

Energy minister Priyavrat Singh could not be contacted for comment, but on social media, he blamed the previous BJP government for bringing power discoms into loss. Tagging former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan , Priyavrat Singh wrote: “If there had been foresight, then discoms would not have been facing losses of Rs 47,000 crore.”

Title: KSUM hub to nurture SC youths’ startup dreams
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: In order to bring inclusivity to the tech sector, the Kerala Startup Mission (KSUM) has launched a major initiative to involve ventures floated by youths from scheduled caste communities . KSUM has set up an exclusive incubation hub here in association with the scheduled castes development department .

The facility, named ‘Startup Dreams’ located at Mannanthala Ambedkar Bhavan, will incubate innovative ideas and technology products, support them through facilities and capacity-building programmes and help them evolve into a scalable business.

The project encompasses startup incubation programmes, training and development workshops and sessions, building business connects and networks, providing linkage to R&D labs and backing branding and operational activities.

The incubation support includes a three-month initial mentorship programme, 3-6 months pre-incubation with a nominal licence fee of Rs 100 per seat for a month. It also offers incubation for 11 months (extendable) with a licence fee of Rs 150, and acceleration for six months for a fee of Rs 200 seat/month, besides extending infrastructure facilities.

Startups with their ideas validated and having developed a minimum viable prototype or proof of concept can apply for the programme. Application is open till March 31.

The highlights of the project include structured cohort programme, startup storyboards and milestone settings, monthly updates and quarterly reviews, mentor speed-dating and investor connects, customized startup sessions/ workshops, demo-day revolving fund (seed fund for SC entrepreneurs), innovation grants and connecting with banks.

The project also includes patent support scheme, VC funding marketing support, and connecting startups with government departments, besides organizing monthly entrepreneurs meetup educational programmes.

For registration details visit http://shorturl.at/acirJ.

Title: Explosives detection needs solution: DRDO chairman
Content:
Pune: DRDO chairman G Satheesh Reddy on Sunday said the detection of explosives has become the need of the hour in the wake of rising terror and Naxal attacks in the country.

The Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) chief called upon the scientific institutes, academia and other departments to work together to find a “universal solution to detect explosives which are being used in varied forms by different inimical organizations against the security forces”.

He was speaking at the inauguration ceremony of the second national workshop on Explosive Detection at the High Energy Material Research Laboratory (HEMRL) in Pashan.

He said, “Whatever devices we have for explosive detection have their own limitations. They function in a particular weather condition and in a specific way. As a result, security forces have to rope in their personnel in these life-risking missions. If an explosive is buried in a culvert, it should be detected automatically. We need this kind of robust and versatile devices in our inventory to deliver desired results for the forces. To achieve these objectives, we need different institutes and research and development organisations to come together and work on such technologies.”

According to him, several unlawful organizations and anti-national elements have used explosives in multiple places in the country over the years. To combat that, a number of technologies were evolving for detection of explosives, he said.

“In a country like India, which is suffering from these attacks, both at the cross border and within, there has been continuous pressure from the nation and the security forces, agencies to develop various detection mechanism of these explosives. To fulfil the requirements, several labs and educational institutes have been trying to develop such devices and HEMRL Pune is one of them,” Reddy said.

He said continuous discussion with security agencies was a key factor in ensuring such devices are developed. “Security agencies and researchers need to discuss, deliberate and understand emerging technologies in this niche field on a regular basis. As a result, this kind of workshop is crucial where all stakeholders come together and discuss various challenges related to explosives,” he said.

He said, “Detection of explosive is an evolving field. As a result, various terrorist groups keep developing various mechanism in quick succession. This is a big challenge for us. We must have effective devices to tackle their new ways rapidly.”

Jayant Naiknavare, Deputy Inspector General of Anti-Terrorism Squad (ATS), Mumbai, called for the need to indigenously develop versatile explosive detection devices.

“If we get to know the type of explosives in time, it would help in establishing a link in investigations of various bomb blasts cases,” he said.

Title: KCB seeks ban on movement of heavy vehicles in Khadki bazaar area
Content:
Pic by Mandar Deshpande

Pune: The Khadki Cantonment Board (KCB) has written to the city traffic police, seeking a ban on movement of heavy vehicles in the busy Khadki bazaar area.

The board has proposed diversion of heavy vehicles via old Pune–Mumbai highway to the poultry chowk and further till VIP Road, reaching up to Holkar bridge.

“We have had a detailed discussion on the matter with the traffic department officials in the past. The matter was also discussed with the deputy commissioner of police (traffic) during a recent meeting chaired by MP Girish Bapat. The stretch has become congested due to various reasons, one of them being plying of heavy vehicles. As a result, it is necessary to restrict vehicles to improve traffic situation in Khadki,” Pramod Kumar Singh, chief executive officer, KCB, told TOI.

A 5km stretch of Khadki Bazaar Road from the Haris bridge chowk to Holkar bridge in Khadki cantonment limit is prone to frequent traffic snarls. The bulk of the traffic, including heavy vehicles, take the route as it provides connectivity to Alandi Road via the Deccan College Chowk.

These vehicles are not allowed to ply on city roads between 9am and 9 pm, said a traffic department official.

“We are studying the proposal placed by the KCB authorities and a decision will be taken in the coming days,” additional commissioner of police Sanjay Shinde said.

The road is narrow and not adequate for movement of heavy vehicles. However, police inspector Sangeeta Patil of Khadki traffic division said a smaller number of heavy vehicles use the stretch. “Besides, our personnel divert heavy vehicles and cars from the Business Centre point to the highway. So, there is no movement of heavy vehicles and four-wheelers on the stretch,” Patil said.

He said that the KCB should provide four traffic wardens for managing vehicular movement in its jurisdiction.

“Presence of stray animals is a big issue as it creates hurdles in movement of vehicles in the KCB limits. We have been urging the KCB authorities to rope in wardens to drive away stray animals from the road,” Patil added.

Meanwhile, residents said that the traffic department and the KCB need to work in tandem to deal with the issue of traffic congestion.

“The traffic flow starts from morning due to the vegetable bazaar on the stretch. Vehicles are parked haphazardly on the road, leading to traffic congestion. The KCB and the traffic department need to resolve the issue. During evening, the situation turns even worse,” said Vikram Salvi, a KCB resident.

Title: Getting bubble-top cans may become tougher in city
Content:
Trichy: With the packaged drinking water production units in the state continuing their indefinite strike for the past three days, the city residents began to experience a shortage of packaged drinking water. The water extraction units seeking relaxation from the state government to operate borewells in the groundwater depleted blocks have ceased their operations, affecting the supply of water.

Sources said that 15 companies are in the business of extracting groundwater for commercial purpose of which only a handful of companies have the mandatory licenses. Ahead of the PWD groundwater officials sealing 23 illegal packed drinking water units in the district that were operating without a license, the packaged drinking water units had suspended their operations. The units sought relaxation for extracting groundwater for commercial purpose as the GO 142 issued by the state government in 2014 calls for a complete ban on extracting groundwater in blocks that have over-exploited groundwater sources. As per the GO, around 23 units out of more than 30 packaged water units were closed in the district. The operators sought the state government to allow the existing operators to stay in business, while they agreed to prevent new players from extracting groundwater in the affected blocks. Registering their protest, all the 15 companies supplying 20-litre water cans in the city have stopped their operations.

The city consumes 50,000-60,000 cans of water (20 litres) per day and the cans are distributed by 15 firms through dealers across the city. The dealers said that they have completely exhausted their inventory as the demand has shot up. "As summer is setting in, people are demanding more water cans, but we do not have stock," R Manoharan, a packaged water can dealer, said.

Since PWD officials are to submit the actions taken in closing the illegal water units before the Madras high court on March 3, protest by the drinking water units is likely to continue for the next few days. "The state government should make relaxations in the GO to permit the existing packaged water can operators to function. Till then, our protest will continue," T Muthuselvan, managing partner of Aandavan and Sons Water Company, said.

Title: Equipment worth Rs 7.1L stolen from parked car
Content:
Pune: A group of four men distracted the driver of a regional news channel’s car parked on FC Road and made off with two bags comprising cameras, mics and a unit of live recording, collectively worth Rs7.1 lakh on Saturday afternoon.

The car’s driver Kiran Kamble (29) of Dattawadi lodged an FIR with the Deccan Gymkhana police. On Saturday, a team of the news channel went to the Deccan area around 1.30pm. Two of the them got down near Gokhale Chowk, while Kamble was sitting in the car. The camera bag, bag of mics and live recording unit were kept on the back seat. “An unidentified man walking on the footpath indicated to Kamble that something was lying outside the car. He did not get down from the car but rolled down the window glass to check what was lying down,” an officer from the Deccan Gymkaha police said.

“When the two team members returned to the car they were shocked to see the bags missing. Kamble did not know anything about it,” the officer said. After checking the CCTV camera footages, the police found that the man’s accomplice had stolen two bags from the parked car. Later, two more joined them. “The gang changed autorickshaws twice so that no one could trace their trail,” the officer said.

Laptops worth Rs21,000 stolen from vehicle

Unidentified men used a similar modus to steal two laptops worth Rs21,000 from a parked car on Shankarsheth Road on Saturday. The complainant had gone for a meeting, while the driver was waiting in the car. “A person told the driver that a Rs100 note were lying near the car. As soon as the driver got down from the car, the suspect stole the bag,” an officer from Khadki police said.

Cops suspect gang is from Tamil Nadu

An officer from the crime branch said police were suspecting a gang from Tamil Nadu was behind these thefts. “The suspects stay in a lodge near the Pune railway station. Stealing bags from cars after distracting the driver is their modus. After committing few thefts in a row, they return to their native place,” the officer said.

Title: Worker digging pit comes in contact with live wire, dies
Content:
Kanpur: A construction worker was electrocuted while digging a pit under the SMART city project at Nand Lal crossing in Govindnagar area on Sunday morning.

Pankaj Kumar (26), a native of Barabanki, who used to live in the city along with his family members, was hired by a contractor under SMART city project at a site near Nand Lal crossing under Govindnagar police station.

When Pankaj and other workers turned up for work, no one was either warned or informed that the area assigned for digging had an underground cable of a transformer. As Pankaj started digging the pit, he came in contact with a live wire and received an electric shock.

His colleagues raised alarm rushed him to a private hospital, but he succumbed.

Govindnagar inspector Anurag Mishra said, “The body was handed over to his family after autopsy. They have not given a complaint yet.”

Title: Man goes to meet future in-laws, gets thrashed
Content:
Kanpur: A visit to the family home of his ‘lady love’ earned a 29-year-old youth in a stint in prison in Hamirpur district.

On February 28, a man was beaten up and handed over to the police when he went to meet the family of the woman he wanted to marry at the latter’s invitation in Maudaha area of Hamirpur district.

However, police said that the woman’s family contacted them after the accused, Suraj Singh, allegedly started creating ruckus.

A native of Raja Tola village, under limits of Paraspur police station, in Gonda, Suraj claimed that he is a magician by profession.

Sources in the village said that Suraj fell in love with a woman hailing from Maudaha area of Hamirpur. The two wanted to get married and told their families about their intentions.

On February 28, the woman’s family invited Suraj to their village. The family had alleged that they would get their daughter married to Suraj on the same day.

He cycled all the way from his home in Gonda to Hamirpur. However, when he reached the woman’s home, instead of welcoming Suraj to their home, the family held him hostage and thrashed him. They later handed him over to the police, sources said.

Inspector (Maudaha) RC Tripathi said, “The woman’s family alleged that Suraj had started creating ruckus, after which they handed him over to the police and lodged a complaint under section 151 (apprehension of breach of peace and tranquillity of an area) of the CrPC. However, he was later released on bail on Saturday.”

Police sources said the two sides got into a heated argument over an issue, which led to the scuffle.

Title: Not a drop from corpn’s water ATMs
Content:
Trichy: Trichy City Corporation’s two water ATMs set up to provide quality water at low-cost for the economically backward people would have been a boon at a time of crisis. But the two water ATMs are yet to start functioning.

Trichy City Corporation installed two water ATMs on West Boulevard Road near the old passport office complex and at Main Guard Gate, Singarathope. It was planned as a public-private partnership (PPP) model, in which the civic body will provide space and facilitate a borewell for the water ATMs to function under reverse osmosis (RO) mechanism. The private player has to install and maintain the water treatment mechanism. To collect one litre of water in a bottle, the user has to pay Rs 1 while it is Rs 7 for collecting water in a 20-litre can. Users have to avail QR card for the payment. Though the work on the water ATMs was completed at an estimated cost of Rs 5 lakh each in November 2019, the facilities are yet to open for public use. “Refilling 20-litre can for Rs 7 will benefit a lot of low-income group people. The facilities should open soon,” K Suresh, a resident of Woraiyur, said.

When contacted, a corporation official acknowledged that water ATMs are not available for the public to collect treated water. However, the official refused to divulge the reason for the inordinate delay in opening the water ATMs.

Title: Belly-dancing & robotics steal the limelight at Undri
Content:
Pune: People, young and old, flocked in hordes at the Corinthians Club in Undri for Happy Streets on Saturday evening.

The main stage was a hive of activity, with Zumba and aerobics being practised to pulsating music. The events recorded the top draw, as people of all age groups tried their hand at a blend of dancing and exercise. Multiple instructors were there on spot to guide the enthusiasts.

In a first, there was also a belly-dancing workshop. The alluring dance form can trace its origin to the Arab emirate.

However, they were also in for something new- a belly-dancing workshop, the alluring dance-form that originated in Arab countries. Vinayak from Core Strength demonstrated the dance form to kids and adults alike. Traditional Arabic music dominated the scene as people revelled in the delight of learning something new.

"I have watched belly-dancing sessions on YouTube and I was amazed at how beautiful the dance form is in reality. Because of this workshop, I also discovered how difficult it is to perform belly-dancing, because it is so methodical an dprecise,” said Shruti Roy, a local resident.

For those seeking more of a gym experience in comparison to dancing, Core Strength had a fitness zone with gym equipment as well as instructors demonstrating freehand exercises.

The dedicated children’s area, set up by Learning Curve and Serra International pre-school, was also busy, with the young ones trying out exercises to improve their mobility and flexibility by using a variety of sports equipment. Next to the area, Skillovate demonstrated robotics to children.

Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India in association with the Pune police, Pune traffic police, Pune Municipal Corporation and is powered by Nyati.

Title: Craters in Ibrahimpura, Moti Masjid road a motorist’s nightmare
Content:
Bhopal: A mammoth pothole, large enough to engulf a medium-sized car, is making it extremely difficult to drive through Ibrahimpura area in the state capital. Not far away, Moti Masjid road, which is part of the BRT corridor, awaits proper repairs for over three years now.

“The pothole is next to a turn. If unaware, most people miss the pothole in the middle of the road. As a result, in the last week, there have been four accidents due to the poor state of the road,” said Ismail Khan, a local businessman. One of the injured was rushed to a nearby hospital, a 108 ambulance paramedic confirmed.

Ibrahimpura and Moti Masjid road witness very heavy traffic activity. On an average, around 3 to 5 lakh vehicles pass through the area each working day. “Ongoing protests against CAA and NRC are taking place in the area. It has made the drive through more complicated. Road accident could trigger a much worse reaction, given the potholes and encroachments in the area,” he added.

Last year, after the monsoon, the state government had declared that all roads would be fixed by November 2019.

Further ahead, the road connecting Moti Masjid area to Kamla Park, has been laid and dug at least five times in the past few months. Public works department (PWD), Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) and National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) have taken no responsibility for the potholed road.

“BMC has completed the task of fixing the area which was dug for pipeline leakage. Other section of the road from Reth Ghat is managed by PWD and some section is managed by NHAI,” said BMC zonal officer, Rakesh Singh. Over the last week, for laying of pipeline, the road stretch has been dug again. Traffic moving from Moti Masjid to Kamla Park would be affected, BMC officials said.

***

Third party assessment of roads

Following a 2014 practice, the district administration is working on a proposal to carry out a third party survey of roads in the city. The assessment would cover roads maintained by PWD, CPA and the BMC. A similar exercise in 2014 exposed claims by road development and maintenance agencies.

***

BOX:

Road network in Bhopal is about 3,500 km

There are about 600 slums, 2,000 colonies, 450 illegal colonies which account for internal roads maintained mostly by the BMC

Majority of the main roads are maintained by PWD

A newly constructed road is under maintenance contract for five years

Older, newly-laid roads are generally under maintenance contract for 3 years

Title: Maharashtra government likely to reverse cow-protection scheme
Content:
The Uddhav Thackeray-led government is not in a mood to continue with the scheme because most gaushala functio... Read More

MUMBAI: The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government is likely to reverse yet another decision taken by its predecessor — the cow-protection scheme Govardhan Govansh Seva Kendra (GGSK) launched by the Devendra Fadnavis-led BJP-Sena alliance after a beef ban came into effect in the state. The scheme intended to boost infrastructure at cow sheds (gaushalas), especially set up to conserve, protect and develop cattle and progeny.

Dairy and animal husbandry minister Sunil Kedar told TOI that the current government is taking a review of the scheme.

“We have not reached any conclusions yet. The department has been asked to review the scheme and prepare a report on how much funds have been spent, the impact of the scheme and other details,” said Kedar.

A senior official saidthat GGSK funds may not be released from now on as neither Congress nor NCP — constituents of the MVA, along with Shiv Sena — is interested to go ahead with the scheme. A minister said that the Uddhav Thackeray-led government is not in a mood to continue with the scheme also because most gaushala functionaries are linked to RSS.

Title: Boat Club gets another selfie point, art from waste installed
Content:
Bollywood actor Bhumi Pednekar unveils the ‘Waste to Art’ installation at Boat Club in Bhopal on Sunday

Bhopal: A ‘waste to art’ installation to foster the participation of public and various other stakeholders so as to promote a sustainable world for curbing the plastic menace was unveiled at the Boat Club on Sunday. The initiative has been undertaken in association with Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC).

“Four months after our not-for-profit group started a campaign to collect plastic from city residents, this art work is to create awareness over ill effects plastic and motivate commitment at the highest level for adopting sustainable living practices,” said Zeeshan Khan, representative of the Plastic Donation Centre.

The plastic used on the globe-like structure is from what he describes as plastic donation by citizens of the state capital. The collection centres are at Moti Masjid, Minto Hall and 10 Number Market parking.

The initiative began on October 2 last year. Since then, about 4 tonne of plastic waste has been collected.

The long term idea is to sell the plastic waste and recycle it, thereby generating resource for more climate friendly initiatives. Eight rag pickers were involved in creating the current art work under supervision of an artist, he added.

Climate Warrior and actor Bhoomi Pednekar unveiled the installation at Boat Club. Bhopal collector Tarun Pitodhe, DIG Irshad Wali and BMC commissioner B Vijay Datta and others were present.

The art work is made using the plastic waste, which was collected at the plastic donation centres in Bhopal. “This is an attempt to start a dialogue with the people who work tirelessly to save the environment and highlight the crisis that we find ourselves in due to climate change,” tweeted Pednekar.

The waste to art artwork was made under the guidance of artist Wajid Khan. The team said, its artwork was made using 500 kgs of waste plastic and also trained rag pickers for making such art works in the future.

Title: Pope Francis: Jailed for 20 years, rape-convict Kerala vicar defrocked by Pope Francis
Content:
Fr Robin Vadakkumchery

KOZHIKODE: Pope Francis has dismissed Fr Robin Vadakkumchery , who was last year convicted of raping and impregnating a minor girl, from priesthood.

The Thalassery Pocso court had in February 2019 sentenced Vadakkumchery, former vicar of St Sebastian Church at Neendunoki in Kannur, to 20 years in prison for raping and impregnating a minor girl.

Catholic diocese of Mananthavady PRO Fr Jose Kocharakkal on Sunday said Pope Francis has dismissed Vadakkumchery from priesthood on the basis of the report submitted by ‘Congregation for the Doctrine of Faith’ in Rome on December 5, 2019.

“From now on, he won’t have any priestly rights and duties and he will no more be addressed as Fr Robin Vadakkumchery. He will be known as Robin Vadakkumchery only,” Fr Kocharakkal said.

The dismissal of a priest in the Catholic Church from the clerical state is a permanent measure which is reserved for the most serious offenses. Only the Pope has the power to dismiss a priest from clerical state.

The Catholic diocese of Mananthavady had suspended Vadakkumchery from priestly duties on February 27, 2017, after the incident came to light.

“The congregation for the doctrine of faith in Rome began the procedures for dismissal of Robin from priesthood in June 2019 and based on their report, Pope Francis has dismissed Robin Vadakkumchery from priesthood and all its rights and duties on December 5,” the statement issued by the Mananthavady diocese said.

The diocese handed over the decree last month to Vadakkumchery, who is currently serving sentence at Kannur Central jail, and an official communication that the decree was signed and accepted was sent to Rome, thereby completing the procedure for dismissal.

The case involving sexual offence against the minor girl by a priest had come to light when Childline in Kannur got an anonymous call in February 2017, saying that a minor girl had delivered a baby in Christu Raj Hospital in Koothuparamba, run by the church, on February 7, 2017, and that the newborn had been immediately shifted to Holy Infant Mary’s Foundling Home at Vythiri in Wayanad.

A police probe revealed that Vadakkumchery had sexually abused the minor girl. The priest was arrested on February 28 from Nedumbassery airport at Kochi while trying to flee to Canada.

In the course of the trial, the rape survivor and all main prosecution witnesses, including her parents, turned hostile but the prosecution secured a conviction by managing to produce the girl’s original birth certificate that proved she was a minor when she was sexually abused by the priest.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Amnesty scheme launched for property owners to secure completion certificate
Content:
Aurangabad: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has announced an amnesty scheme for residents who wish to secure completion certificates for their buildings in the city. Officials said residents can avail a discount of 25% on penalties under the scheme that will run from March 1 to March 31.

The AMC took this decision after a meeting held with architects in the city on Friday. The architects suggested certain measures to simplify the application process for securing the completion certificates.

The drive was also initiated to increase revenue and to ensure structures are built according to standards set by the civic body. It is hoped that the amnesty scheme will encourage residents and commercial property owners to get their real estate regularised.

The meeting, held on Friday at the Babasaheb Ambedkar Research Centre, also discussed the scope of the amnesty scheme. R S Mahajan, the assistant director of town planning at AMC; deputy engineer Sanjay Kombde; senior architect Ramesh Nagpal; president of Architects Association of Aurangabad Sunil Bhale; secretary Swapnil Pargaonkar; Deepak Deshpande; Ajay Thakur; Manish Kale and Miling Vadekar attended the meeting.

Participants also discussed the documents that would be required for the certification and the discount of 25%. It was stated that the completion certificate is an important document for residents — just like Aadhaar is for an individual. It was highlighted by the experts that completion certificates would ensure development and amenities in a city are better planned.

The architects said a complicated process often discourages residents from securing permissions and certificates. The AMC officials said measures would be put in place to simplify the process further.

The architects, as well as the civic officials, then urged residents to make the most of the month-long amnesty scheme.

Title: Cement roads develop cracks within a month in Cidco areas
Content:
Aurangabad: The civic administration’s claim that the cement roads that they are constructing across the city will not wear and tear for 30 years, albeit with proper maintenance, has fallen flat as cracks have already developed on the roads in Cidco N-3, N-4 and N-5 constructed less than a month ago.

The state government had sanctioned Rs 100 crore to the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) for the construction of 30 cement roads in different areas of the city.

The civic body had given the tender of the project to four contractors.

The works on the stretch from the TV Centre to Central Naka kickstarted the road construction project on February 4, 2019. The road from Chistiya Chowk to Avishkar Chowk was completed just three weeks ago. The cement road has also been finished with stripes drawn with thermoplastic paint. However, the new road has already developed cracks. The situation is no better on the cement road in Cidco N-3 and N-4.

Several activists and public representatives had raised concerns about the quality of the road works. In a written complaint directed to the municipal commissioner in January, Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel had stated that several residents had complained that the works being carried out were of sub-standard quality. Jaleel’s allegations were put to rest by AMC’s executive engineer and in-charge of the road construction project Hemant Kolhe. He said that the project management consultant, the third-party inspector and the civic administration was inspecting the work being done by the contractors.

Activist Kishor Pathak said that the AMC was spending 10 times more on cement roads than tar roads. “The civic body should see to it that proper curing is done before the road is made open for use. This is not the first instance of roads developing cracks. A few years ago, the cement road constructed at Shivajinagar and Cidco N-2 also developed cracks. Clearly, the contractors have done a shoddy work and the civic body is looking the other way,” he said.

Activists and residents are already concerned about the new roads that will be constructed from the corpus of Rs152 crore approved by the state government.

When contacted, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said, “It is a serious concern if cracks have developed on the newly constructed roads. I will speak to the municipal commissioner and ask him to take action. If the contractor is at fault, then the AMC can blacklist them.”

Title: BJP, AAP, independents file poll papers; Cong lags behind
Content:
Panaji: A total of nine candidates - three from BJP, one from AAP and five independent candidates filed their nominations for the zilla panchayat elections scheduled for March 22.

Candidates who filed their nominations as independent include Suresh Palkar in St Cruz, Dominic Gaonkar and Fatima Gaonkar in Raia, Bharat Suryakant Naik in Arambol, and Vishal Kashinath Naik in Rivona.

BJP candidates include Sagun Sitaram Vadkar in Honda, Devayani Devidas Gawas in Querim and Rajashri Shahu Kale in Nagargao.

AAP candidate Leandrinha Gomes filed her nomination papers for the Raia seat.

While BJP has already declared 18 candidates in the first round and 13 in the second round, Congress which was split on the decision on whether to hold elections on the party symbol, only belatedly came to a consensus on the matter, but is yet to declare any candidates.

The state election commission will continue to receive nominations till March 5 for the 50 ZP constituencies. Thirty of these constituencies have been reserved for various categories – women, OBC and ST/SC.

The commission will scrutinise nomination papers on March 6, and withdrawal has been scheduled for March 7. The poll will be held using ballot papers. A total of 8.3 lakh citizens are eligible to vote in this election.

The model code of conduct came into force throughout Goa, including municipal limits, on February 21 and will continue till midnight of the counting day on March 23.

A total of 9,000 personnel including police will be requisitioned for various duties during the election.

Title: Guv seeks report on complaint by syndicate member of alleged irregularity in teacher appointment notification
Content:
Kozhikode: Governor Arif Mohammed Khan has asked for a report from Calicut University on a complaint by a syndicate member on alleged irregularity in the notification issued by the varsity to fill up the existing teaching vacancies and the non-acceptance of his note of dissent he had raised on the matter at the syndicate meeting.

The governor, also the chancellor, has asked the vice-chancellor to submit a report on the petition of syndicate member Rasheed Ahammed P. The syndicate member complained that the minutes of the syndicate meeting on December 30, 2019, had resolved to approve the subcommittee report and notification for filling of vacancies in the posts of professors/associate professors/assistant professors while there was no such report placed in the syndicate nor was it appended with the minutes.

“The purported and non-existing report was recorded in the minutes only to vindicate the action of the vice-chancellor and the syndicate to publish the vacancy notification dated December 31, 2019,” the petition said.

Ahammed had also said in the letter that the vacancies were notified as per the order of the high court in a case (WP(C) 9785 of 2015) without specifying the reservation turns to be followed while making recruitments. He said the vice- chancellor has deliberately kept a blind on the other part of the same court order which mandates the university to work out the technicalities of the reservation turns before the notification regarding the recruitment is published.

“As no ‘sub-committee report’ was placed in the meeting held on December 30 as wrongly in the minutes, I strongly objected to this and wanted it either to be corrected or my dissent note to be added to the minutes. But when the final minutes were issued, there was no mention of my dissent note or my objections to the agenda item. When I demanded a copy of the said report, they didn't have the copy of the same and hence they could not supply it to me,” Rasheed said in the petition.

He has urged the governor to direct the vice-chancellor to record the dissent to the agenda item regarding teacher appointments and also to ensure transparency in the recruitment process to obviate the possibility of corruption and nepotism.

Title: Discom disconnects power, BMC work likely to be affected until Monday
Content:
Bhopal: About half a dozen Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) offices would remain without regular power supply till Monday. Power discom disconnected power of the BMC offices after civic body payment was delayed.

“Power supply is expected to be restored completely by Monday evening. Terms of payments with the discom have been in place since January. Almost 80% of the payment due for February was paid, rest would be deposited by Monday,” said the BMC official. He cited a recent meeting between BMC and the power discom officials.

BMC owes the discom about Rs 200 crore. The dues are expected to be cleared within the next few months. BMC was on target to clear it dues in January.

Electricity bill for water supply and street lights account for most of the dues, going by BMC records. Last year, the BMC power bill increased by almost Rs 30 crore, owing to pressure to supply water to the state capital during a water crises. Surcharge of non-payment by the BMC is running into double digit, close to Rs 10 crore, said sources.

For now building permission office at Fatehgarh, water works office at Shymala Hills and few other ward offices continue without power.

BMC senior officials ruled out any retaliation against the power discom. Some ward level officials had hinted at cutting off water supply of the discom offices, citing their water cess dues were unpaid.

Building permission, server was functioning normally on Sunday. However, without electricity office computers are not functional. It would affect work of the building permission department. Much of BMC service is on enterprise solutions software which also links with TNCP, said a zone level official.

Sources said that BMC has not been able to recover Rs 36 crore from the electricity company for ground rent of power poles and transformers and about Rs 2 crore from property tax. More over BMC surcharge from cable and other services using street light poles is pegged in the crores, sources said.

Title: How life has changed for last year’s Nagpur heroes
Content:
Nagpur Heroes 2019

NAGPUR: It’s a moment of pride and satisfaction for anyone, when their work for humanity is acknowledged and appreciated. Even as citizens eagerly await this year’s list of Nagpur Heroes , TOI explores how the title has affected the life of last year's heroes.

Bimla and Avinash Deoskar, the mountaineer couple having endurance to train the youth, believes that this recognition has helped with the support of government of Maharashtra .

“Any award or title comes with a lot of appreciation and responsibilities. We were glad that our efforts were recognized by the Times of India. Ever since the win, we managed to gather more youngsters and draw their passion into mountaineering,” said Avinash.

“The honour was prestigious as it was a Times of India initiative. People now recognize us and know our story, which is a great feeling,” said Bimla.

Iqbal Kashmiri, who received the award for his yeoman service in training the youth in football, shared his joy on becoming the executive member of the Western Indian Football Association (WIFA).

“The appreciation that has poured in from various parts of the country is overwhelming. People who didn't even know me called and greeted for the achievement. I am happy that more youngsters look forward to building their future in football,” said Kashmiri.

Tanveer Mirza — who works in the sphere of rural and social development — expressed his thoughts on how the award has impacted his work and life.

“This recognition has made a huge impact on my personal and social life. Our NGO Yashodhara, and the cause for which we are striving hard became more popular after this. May it be our social and environmental awareness programs or the campaign for entrepreneurship development — all got a different credibility with the Nagpur Heroes tag,” said Mirza.

Ritu Malhotra, Pratik Malhotra and Pratik Harde, the innovative engineer trio from the city who co-founded the start-up ‘Eventuate Innovations’, was ecstatic with the response after the win.

“Our product got placed on several key government platforms. Niti Aayog has appreciated the concept and has instructed the health ministry to prevent spread of virus and bacteria in hospitals through this technology,” said Ritu.

“The product has shown spread and presence throughout the country and abroad. It is showing very good results after the recognition as one of the Nagpur Heroes,” added Pratik Malhotra.

For Vishnu Manohar, star chef and a world record holder, this award opened the doors for his long-pending dream to open a restaurant in the United States of America (USA).

“It was very special. I was approached to open a restaurant in USA, and people got to know about me after the win. It has been six months since the restaurant opened, and it is running well," said Manohar.

Title: Two Bharatnatyam dancers from city get Centre’s scholarship
Content:
Aurangabad: Two city-based girls have received the scholarship provided by central government’s Centre for Cultural Resources and Training (CCRT) to selected candidates performing traditional art forms across the country.

The girls are among six candidates selected in the Bharatanatyam category from Maharashtra.

A student of dance academy Dhyas Performing Arts, 12-year-old Vidisha Vembakkam is being trained by Ketki Nevpurkar in Bharatnatyam for the last seven years.

Vidisha wants to represent India’s cultural art form on an international level.

Meanwhile, 12-year-old Ishani Kulkarni, who has been training at the dance academy Devmudraa under V Soumyasri, has also secured the prestigious CCRT scholarship this year.

Soumyasri said that it is rare to have two girls from the city claim the prestigious scholarship.

The girls had to undergo a rigorous selection process as a part of which they had to perform in front of a panel of judges and also answer questions asked by them.

Of the total 564 students selected for this scholarship award in various art forms, Vidisha and Ishani are among the six students selected for this scholarship in classical dance form Bharatanatyam and the only two from Maharashtra.

Under the scheme, the CCRT will bear the fee paid to the awardee’s teacher of the art form until the person turns 20.

CCRT that runs under the government’s ministry of culture has been implementing Cultural Talent Search Scholarship Scheme since 1982 at the national level.

The scheme aims to provide facilities to children in the age group of 10 to 14 years practising traditional art form and can secure specialised training in the form. These art forms include dance, drama, painting, making sculptures, crafts and literary activities.

Title: Foreman injured after falling from 30 feet at Habibganj station
Content:
Bhopal: A foreman sustained serious injuries after falling from 30 feet from an under construction bridge at Habibganj station on Sunday. Till the report was filed the victim Dara Singh Jadhav, 35, was in the ICU.

Sources said that Dara Singh, who was passing through the air concourse under construction at the Habibganj railway station, slipped his foot and fell on the railway track 30 feet below. While falling from such height he also got scorched severely by Over Head Electric (OHE). He is undergoing treatment at Bansal Hospital, where his condition is said to be critical.

The incident took place at 8.45 am on Sunday. This is the first major accident during the redevelopment work of Habibganj railway station. The task of assembling the air concourse of the station was given to a private agency of Indore. Officials said Dara Singh, a resident of Indore is an employee of the company.

Eyewitnesses said that Dara Singh was not wearing any safety belt or helmet at the time of the incident.

Bansal Path-way Habibganj Pvt Ltd project manager Abu Asif said that the assistant foreman was moving from the top of the single girder to the other side because it is a matter of investigation as 80% of the air concourse is covered to go to the other side through which one can easily go to the other side. “He is undergoing treatment at Bansal hospital,” said Asif.

Title: Goa: Two held for kidnapping one-month old boy
Content:
Representative image

VASCO: Former Mormugao municipal chairperson and president of NGO Savera Tara Kerkar , was arrested by Vasco police on Sunday in connection with a complaint filed for kidnapping and selling a one-month old child.

The complaint was filed by a 40-year-old woman on Saturday, stating that she was staying with Kerkar along with her child. The woman stated that Kerkar, 56, forcefully sold her child on Friday night.

She also stated that Kerkar had tried to convince her to sell her baby boy for Rs 1 lakh, but she rejected the offer. Police traced the child to a woman Fatima Dourado, 47, from Chicalim , who was arrested. The case has been registered under Sections 341, 363, 506 read with 34 of IPC and under Section 8 of the Goa Children ’s Act.

Title: On the sands of Miramar beach, India’s underprivileged have different life goals
Content:
Panaji: As a child, Anish Kumar remembers how rowdies from his locality constantly invaded his house and robbed money from his parents. Struggling to make ends meet themselves, there seemed to be no way out for his parents in Neelasandra, a residential area in Bengaluru which is inhabited by migrants.

Dotted with four huge slums, most of the youth at Neelasandra are school dropouts. They take to crime and alcoholism, but Anish had a different obsession — football . The 19-year-old is quite good at the game and believes it’s only a matter of time before he realises his dream of making it to the Indian team.

From the slums of Neelasandra to the Indian team would be quite a story, and it all begins at the SPN National Inclusion Cup at Miramar for Anish.

The National Inclusion Cup, organised by the Nagpur-based Slum Soccer , is a one of its kind event that brings together children from slums across the country and those underprivileged , trying to change their lives through football.

“Life is a constant struggle back home. With football, things can get better. It’s so different here. We get proper food, clean water to drink and a place to stay. I just want to do the best I can,” said Anish, who cycles 3km every day to fetch water from a tap.

Anish is not alone.

The National Inclusion Cup, now in its 17th edition and started by professor Vijay Barse, a retired sports teacher from Nagpur, has attracted 50 teams and over 500 players, all battling for a place in the Indian team for the Homeless World Cup in Finland later this year. While Anish has moved out of Bengaluru for the first time — apart from a football trip to Mysuru — and made the overnight bus journey to Goa, Junaid Ahmed Laway had to endure five days of travel just to get here.

“I can see that the journey has been worth it. Life can be an adventure and I want to see the world outside Kashmir,” said Junaid, a 21-year old who is dreaming of catching the selectors’ eye and seeing the world in all its glory.

Hailing from Pampore, famous as Kashmir’s ‘Saffron Town’ for its precious high-grade spice, Junaid has heard of a “beautiful world”, but doesn’t really know what it looks like beyond his neighbourhood. On a small ground, he’s seen children of his age kick the ball around and it’s this beautiful sport that can now become his passport to the world.

Kashmir has done well here, winning four of their five games, losing only to Meghalaya in penalties, with Junaid among the goals.

Kajal Shiriange has a different goal. Having lost her father a decade ago, the 21-year-old girl from Gondia district in Maharashtra has seen her mother struggle all her life, sweeping floors at railway stations and godowns, so that they don’t go to bed hungry.

“I want to help my mother. I know if I become a good footballer, I can possibly get a government job and then ease the burden which my mother has been carrying all her life,” said Kajal.

Life has been tough, and cruel, for the Shirianges, who don’t have a house which they can call their own and live with their supportive grandmother.

“When this tournament ends, not just me but all of us will be in tears. We’ve never seen anything like this before,” said Shiriange, raving about the bread and jam she was fortunate to have for breakfast on Sunday morning.

Nobody has had it easy here. At Miramar, the goals for India’s underprivileged are not quite the same.

Title: Jaggery-honey mix to match chocolate syrup? Eat-right advocate innovates with the traditional
Content:
Playing with Indian food and spices, Rohit Dubepatil has been creating healthy products with an international ... Read More

As a proponent of healthy eating and living, Rohit Dubepatil cringes when he sees the roadside 'batata wada' vendor using a single batch of oil for up to seven fries in his ‘kadhai’. Worse, he will later filter the final tar-black oil and mix it with regular palm oil to create a new stock for further use.

We fry our foods at an average temperature of 250-300 degrees Celsius, which does not permit us to go beyond three fries, says Dubepatil. Having travelled the world, he says even the poorest of African countries have some regulations regarding frying in oil. India has none, and we end up with some of the worst fats in our food.

Dubepatil forayed into the world of healthy food items with his biotechnologist wife in 2013 after doing two courses on patents at the National Chemical Laboratory and the Tata Chemicals’ innovation centre, both in Pune. His first focus was good fats and what could better exemplify the key to heart health than antioxidant-rich olive oil.

Now, Dubepatil believes olive oil enjoys a somewhat glorified status, pointing out that our coconut oil delivers equally good fats. But the production and marketing of olive oil in places like Spain and Italy sets it apart from other oils, contributing to its standing. So he got into importing olive oil though the pitch was queered by fly-by-night businessmen who had no qualms selling their adulterated stocks at cheaper rates. “There are only around 10 serious olive oil brands across the world and they are all busy battling manufacturers who adulterate their oils. We had to bleed initially to stay afloat,” he says.

Dubepatil eventually tasted success, notching a healthy turnover for three successive years. Then his venture crashlanded in 2016 after the government hiked customs duty, the rupee weakened against the euro and the drought in Spain and Italy hit the olive harvest hard. Like most first-generation entrepreneurs, he had not paid attention to risk mitigation.

While picking up the pieces, Dubepatil realised the need to diversify. Along with olive oil, he began bringing in almond oil and also cherry tomato sauce. From within the country, he was procuring and packaging peas from Uttarakhand and sweet corn from Pune itself. But his long-term goal was to make healthy, sugar- and salt-free products using traditional Indian foods and spices and give them an international appeal.

Dubepatil cracked the code, as it were, by working on a combination of jaggery , honey and olive oil. These three, if heated in a specific way, at a specific temperature and for a specific duration makes for a product that replicates the taste and texture of sugar. To this combination he added vitamin E, the only fat closest to one’s sebum (oily secretion of the skin glands), and a seven-spice ayurvedic mix.

So, Dubepatil now has an indigenous jaggery caramel to compete with the ubiquitous, fancy chocolate syrup. The challenge for him was to liquefy the jaggery, give it a two-year shelf life and texturise the caramel to match the classiness imparted by cocoa in chocolate syrup. He has also turned the humble ‘shengdana chutney’ into a paste-like spiced peanut butter , whipped up a naturally-sweet plum jam for children and designed an apple-carrot-beetroot concoction which gives a good haemoglobin spike and keeps hunger pangs at bay. The tea-time snack on his table is the protein-rich ‘makhana’ (foxnut), coming in the ‘thecha’, gunpowder, chaat and barbecue varieties to cater to different palates across the country.

The quest for good ingredients has exposed Dubepatil to the huge food basket that India is. He is particularly intrigued by the numerous types of jaggery in the country — almost as many as there are states. He says this variety augurs well for his caramel as chefs can have more than one version of the syrup for their spreads. And he’s waiting, rather amusingly, for one five-star hotel chef to deliver on his promise of coating every post-meal ‘paan’ with his caramel.

Title: People of all ages participate in last leg of Happy Streets on Sunday
Content:
Aurangabad: The last leg of the Times group’s Happy Streets witnessed people of all ages participating in large numbers at the stretch from Kranti Chowk to Osmanpura Circle in the early morning on Sunday.

By the end of the event, the stretch of the road was packed with revellers. A team of forest department, which rescued a leopard found in a residential locality last year, inaugurated the event.

The event had something to offer for every person regardless of their age, interests and talent.

There were various activities like cycling, skating, skipping, hula hooping, archery, hitting the bull’s eye, gilli danda and other games in the last leg. People took part in drawing, rangoli making, face painting, singing, and played the dhol.

Like every time, Zumba moderated by professionals was the most popular activity. A large number of people took part in the dance.

This year, Happy Streets was held on three consecutive Sundays i.e. February 16, 13 and March 1 from 6am to 9am .

Happy Streets is an initiative by TOI through which an attempt is made to free the roads from vehicular traffic for few hours to make the roads pollution-free and people can spend quality time with friends and family amidst a busy lifestyle. The initiative also promotes healthy living. Accordingly, the stretch of road was selected with the permission of Aurangabad police and Aurangabad Municipal Corporation. The stretch did not have any vehicular movements for three hours.

Title: 2 loco pilots, pointsman killed in Singrauli goods train accident
Content:
Bhopal: Three people including a loco pilot and an assistant loco pilot were killed after two goods trains collided at a village in Singrauli district of Madhya Pradesh on Sunday morning.

The mishap took place around 4.40 am when goods train laden with coal from the Amlori mine in MP was heading towards Uttar Pradesh and collided with an empty goods train some 7 kms from Singrauli. The track where the accident took place is managed by the National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) and is used for transporting coal.

“Three people including a loco pilot, assistant loco pilot and a pointsman were died in the incident,” NTPC Rihand, spokesperson, Prashank Chandra told TOI.

The deceased have been identified pointsman Ramlakhan Bais, 29, loco pilot Rasheed Ahmed and assiatnt loco pilot Mandeep Kumar, 27, both hailing from Uttar Pradesh, Singrauli's additional superintendent of police Pradeep Shende said. Their bodies were pulled out from the engine, he said.

“A rake which unloaded coal in the NTPC plant was returning while another carrying coal to the plant collided near a crossover point. It was not a head-on collision, but the train carrying coal hit the rear wagon of the empty train as it tried to cross over to the other track,” he said.

“An enquiry has been ordered and it will take in consideration all safety issues,” he said.

After the accident, several wagons of one of the trains and an engine jumped off the tracks. Initially, it appears the accident might have occurred either due to an error on part of the drivers or because of some fault in signaling, he said.

The mishap has not affected rail passenger traffic as it occurred on the track exclusively used by the NTPC to ferry coal for its power plants, the official said.

Meanwhile, East Central Railway's chief public relations officer (CPRO) Rajesh Kumar in a statement said the Indian Railways has nothing to do with the accident. He said the accident took place in the Merry Go Round (MGR) system completely owned and operated by NTPC, Rihand. “NTPC will investigate the matter,” he added.

Title: Well-planned protests can stop govt implementing NRC/CAA: Teesta
Content:
Mangaluru: Systematic protests in an organised manner, signature campaigns and meeting elected representatives with delegates will stop the Union government from implementing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR), opined rights activists Teesta Setalvad.

Teesta was delivering a talk on CAA/NRC and NPR jointly organised by We The People and Citizens Forum for Mangaluru Development on Sunday.

She said that the proposed Acts not only target the Muslim community, but also adivasis, dalits, migrant labourers, nomadic tribes among others. “If the ongoing protests are not done in a right manner, they won’t bring about any good result,” she pointed out.

“With the move of implementing CAA, the government has shown how it is indulging in divide and rule. People have come out on the streets protesting the hidden agenda of the BJP government. Such fights against this unconstitutional move of the government should be always alive.”

Teesta questioned the NPR exercise and said place and date of birth of one’s parents was not asked when it was done under the UPA government but the same being is asked by the current government. “We are not opposing the census as it is needed to count the total population of the country and to provide government facilities. But, while UPA government had done NPR exercise, the place and date of birth of one’s parents were not asked. Why is it being asked now?” she questioned. Of the total of population of India, only about 52% would have birth certificates and the rest would not have such documents. “If so, how the government will give citizenship on the basis of birth certificates? It is a challenge to the people of our country,” she said.

In Assam, which has a population of 3.2 crore, has spent Rs 1,220 crore for implementing NRC. It will cost Rs 55,000 crore to implement it in all states. “Instead of addressing unemployment and others issues of the country, why the government is spending such huge sum for unnecessary work?” she questioned, stressing that it will be a big blow to the economy of the country.

Title: Alemao backs 2 for zilla elections
Content: Goa’s lone NCP MLA Churchill Alemao on Sunday announced the candidature of Vania Baptista and Menino de Bandar to contest the zilla panchayat polls from Colva and Benaulim constituencies respectively. Alemao said that if Congress wants an alliance with NCP for the next assembly polls, they should declare it now. tnn

Title: Shacks trade thatched roofs for neon lights to lure visitors
Content:
Panaji: With cut-throat competition driving the need to lure tourists by any means necessary, beach shacks in the state have undergone drastic changes.

From their humble beginnings of just two or three tables under a thatched roof, present-day shacks, with their eye-catching gimmicks, bear no resemblance to their spartan ancestors.

The Beach Shack Policy still mandates that shacks have to be set up with eco-friendly material, but today’s shacks cannot be executed merely with bamboo poles and palm leaves, says a shack operator.

“With unseasonal rains, the roofs of our structures require a layer of plastic or other waterproof material for protection, though the outer layer will be made of palm leaves,” he said, pointing out that this further adds to his expenditure.

The cost of setting up a shack without any frills will be nothing less than Rs 2 lakh, he said. “The cost will increase further if an operator chooses to spring for stylish interior decor,” he said.

In such cases, he said the cost will climb to Rs 3 to 5 lakh, or even higher.

The material used is mostly imported, and bamboo is not commonly used. “Some use pine wood as well as eucalyptus poles for the structure while the base is made from engineered or hard wood or plywood,” said another shack operator.

While the materials used in building shacks is reused the following tourist season, there are recurring costs involved that cannot be avoided. “Some materials get damaged while dismantling and they cannot be re-used,” he said.

With incidents of seawater rising and entering shacks becoming increasingly frequent, he said that shack operators are now compelled to fortify their temporary structures, and many now choose to have raised wooden platforms as the base. “So, they are forced to use metal poles, though it is not allowed,” he said.

While a mid-sized shack used to have three or four rows of seating with four to five tables per row, today, each operator has to stock many more tables, chairs and deck beds.

The latest addition are tents or cabana-style dining arrangements that dot the shore in the evenings. When the sun sets, the beach begins to resemble a carnival, or takes on a Vegas-like appearance with neon signs and flashing disco lights the shacks install to lure tourists looking to party.

Title: Hello, world! City welcomes 25 newborns on leap day
Content:
Vijayawada: Once every four years, people born on February 29 get the chance to celebrate their birthdays. This year, around 25 births were reported in the city on leap day even as their parents acknowledged the significance of the day.

The maternity ward at the Old Government Hospital registered nine births on Saturday, out of which five were male and four female. K Revathi, a resident of the city, who delivered a baby boy at GGH said she was happy that she had given birth on leap day. “This is a very special day for me. My son has been born on a special day and his birthday will always be special as he will celebrate it once every four years. We had never planned to have a Caesarean section ( C-section ), but it happened with God’s grace,” she said.

On the other hand, authorities of the health wing said that while many parents show an interest in C-section deliveries on special and auspicious days, most chose not to opt for a C-section on leap day. “A birthday is a very special day for everyone. Children celebrate it in a grand manner but babies born on leap day will miss this opportunity. So we have postponed the C-section to another day,” said K Nageswari, an expecting mother from Madhuranagar.

Health officials also said that on average, the number of deliveries on leap year decrease in comparison to other days. “Around 120 to 130 births are registered across the district on an average per day. But the number is low on leap day. We are estimating around 100 births as per the records available with us,” said Dr TSR Murthy, district medical and health officer (DMHO).

The birth registrar at the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC) said that the actual number of births on any particular day is known only after 21 days. Hospitals register births online based on the Aadhaar number of the parents.

Title: IRCTC warns passengers against cyber criminals
Content:
Aurangabad: Amidst the rising number of cybercrime cases, the Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) has come up with an advisory for the passengers to avoid getting cheated online.

Highlighting that the e-ticket cancellation refund process is transaction-driven and fully automatic, IRCTC has said that it never makes phone calls, sends e-mails, messages asking customers to disclose their personal or security information.

“The refund of a cancelled ticket is automatically processed into user’s same bank account from which the booking was made and is usually completed within a week.,” the corporation has said.

It has requested users not to share their bookings and cancellations details on social media platforms to avoid misuse by miscreants.

The IRCTC, in its advisory, has also highlighted tips for safe online search.

“Users are requested to be careful while searching Google and other similar platforms for IRCTC related queries as these platforms may have mobile applications or websites to misuse the users credentials. Users should refer to IRCTC website for all ticketing, refunds and its authorized business partners related queries,” IRCTC has said.

The corporation has 0755-6610661, 0755-4090600 as is customer care number and has designated email id etickets@irctc.co.in for cancellation of train tickets.

Railway activist Raj Somani said, “The cyber criminals are devising new methods to cheat individuals. The safety tips issued by IRCTC assumes huge significance and must be followed.’”

Title: Greens urge govt to safeguard biodiversity in Western Ghats
Content:
Mangaluru: Prominent biodiversity hotspots of the Western Ghats are affected due to increased human activities, especially felling of trees, hunting and tourism, resulting in loss of natural habitats for king cobras. Over 30 lakh trees, some of them as old as 150 years, were cut for various human activities in Western Ghats. Parisara Sammelana, a convention for environment held on Sunday under the aegis of National Environment Care Federation (NECF) at the Tree Park on the Tannirbavi Beach resolved to urge the government to protect and improve the environment and safeguard forests and wildlife as envisaged in Article 48A of the Constitution.

The convention held in the form of a people’s court took up trials of 36 cases pertaining to environment. Environmentalists from coastal and malnad regions, presented their cases at the event presided by noted human rights activist Dr Ravindranath Shanbhag.

Writer and activist Akilesh Chippali said that there is need for amendments for laws to prevent afforestation. “Over 30 lakh trees are chopped for various projects in the Western Ghats. Some of them were as old as 150 years,” he said.

Activist Yogish from Chikkamagaluru, presenting the case he is fighting, said king cobras in the Western Ghats have been losing their source of food due to human activities. Destruction of habitats through hunting, trekking and other activities have resulted in the loss of food source for the reptiles. Meanwhile, pollution of water also has also affected them, he added.

Environmentalist Kalavathi P said 9,580 cases were booked for vehicular pollution between 2005 and 2016 in the state and penalty to the tune of Rs 82 lakh was collected. However, the problem still persists since those vehicles are allowed to ply after the payment of penalty. “This is not a solution to the environmental issues we face today. The rules should be stricter that such vehicles should be seized and should not be allowed to play on the road,” she suggested.

A panel of advocates present at the programme extended their support to those who are fighting for the cause of environment. Padma Shri awardee and Halakki tribal folk singer Sukri Bommagowda, another Padma award winner Tulsi Gowda, who is known as the ‘encyclopedia of forest’ for her vast knowledge of plants and herbs and activist Diyego Bastyav Siddi expressed their views.

NECF state secretary Shashidhar Shetty and member Dinesh Holla said that none of the officials from various government departments participated in the meet despite the organisers sending them invitations. “Our fight will continue till our demands for the protection of environment and wildlife are fulfilled,” Holla said.

Title: Heritage Walk by Times group completes 150 events
Content:
Nashik: Heritage Walk , which is organised by the Times group, completed 150 events on Sunday with a trip to Brahmagiri, Trimbakeshwar. A total of 175 heritage enthusiasts participated in the event.

“We had started the event five years back and have received a remarkable response from enthusiasts. People only need to know the date and venue and they make it a point to reach there on time,” the organisers said.

For the recent trip, participants reached the Sant Nivruttinath Samadhi Mandir in Trimbakeshwar by 8.30 am where the trustee of the temple, Jayant Gosavi, briefed them about the history of the temple.

“The samadhi (tomb) was built in 13th century, precisely in 1250. Since then it has evolved a lot and took the shape of the temple,” he said.

From there, the trip moved towards the Brahmagiri rest house which was built in 1913 for devotees to rest before continuing their journey to the top of the hill.

“We had to climb 500 stairs to reach the rest house. But, it was totally worth it. The two-storey rest house has good ventilation and continuous supply of water,” the organisers said.

The participants had the most enjoyable moment when they looked at the rectangular step-well behind the rest house. It is a century old Bawri (well) which has ample of water.

Gopinath Tidke, a participant, said, “I thank the organisers for organising such a wonderful event. I would like them to take us to such places more often.”

Title: Over 1,600 appear for MUHS PhD entrance exam
Content:
Nashik: The Maharashtra University of Health Sciences (MUHS) on Sunday conducted the PET (PhD Entrance Test) for the doctor of philosophy (PhD) candidates after four years.

Ajit Pathak, controller of examinations (MUHS), said, “The previous PET was conducted in 2016 and over 600 candidates appeared for it. This time the number of candidates has significantly increased.”

Pathak told TOI that the PET results should be out by April 15. The varsity will try its best to declare the results before that.
