A total of 1,676 students appeared for the examination in 53 streams of medicine, including allopathy, homeopathy, dentistry, ayurveda, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, among others.

“We had received a total of 1,819 applications from across the state of which 143 students remained absent. The conduct of the examination went smoothly in all the four centres of the city,” Pathak said.

The multiple-choice based (MCQ) offline examination included two papers that were conducted on the same day from 11 am to 1.45 pm. The first paper was of research methodology which was common for all, while the second paper was based on the elective subjects.

“A candidate must possess post-graduation degree from a recognised university to be eligible for PET. PhD is mandatory for all candidates who wish to teach in medical colleges. It may take three to five years for a candidate to complete the research work and submit his PhD thesis,” he said.

Title: Two dead in separate incidents
Content:
Vijayawada: Two persons were murdered in two separate incidents in Krishna and Guntur districts on Sunday.

A 46-year-old mason A Venkateswarlu, in a relationship with a married woman, was murdered by her sons following an argument at Pallepalem village under Kruthivennu mandal in Krishna district.

Police said the deceased was in a relationship with one B Sushila of Pallepalem village. Sushila’s sons Durga Prasad and Nani warned Venkateswarlu against continuing the affair and Sushila also decided to terminate the relationship.

In spite of the warnings, Venkateswarlu tried to continue the affair. On Saturday night, Sushila’s sons entered into an argument with Venkateswarlu, beat him to death and dumped the body near a local tank.

A case was registered against Durga Prasad, Nani and Sushila based on the complaint by Venkateswarlu’s family. Efforts are underway to nab the trio. Police have shifted the body for an autopsy.

In another incident, T Satyanarayana (35) was found dead under suspicious circumstances at Gangavaram village under Gurajala mandal in Guntur district.

Police suspect an extramarital relationship behind the murder. A case has been registered and an investigation is underway.

Title: Nashik is a safe city for women: Commissioner of Police
Content:
Nashik: Commissioner of Police Vishwas Nangare-Patil said that the city is comparatively safer for women. He was speaking at the fourth edition of Women Walkathon on Sunday.

The walkathon was organised by Eventz by Sonali Dabak.

“Women have to face many violent acts but there are fewer crimes against women in the city as compared to other parts of the country. One of the reasons for this is women empowerment which happens due to the events like this,” he said.

He also appreciated the theme of the event which was “Me Fit = Family Fit” as such concept helps in maintaining the physical and mental health of women.

Nearly 3,000 women participated in the event and expressed their voices about womanhood.

“All of them celebrated womanhood and participated with enthusiasm. They brought their ideas and vision for a safe and healthy world for women to the streets,” said Sonali Dabak, organiser of the event.

The 3 km walkathon started from Suyojit Viridian Valley towards Makhmalabad, covering a stretch of one-and-a-half kilometre and back.

“We began with nearly 1,200 entries in 2017 which has now reached to 3,000 entries. The ‘Mother and Baby Walk’ category was the most interesting one where over 150 women brought their newborn children in strollers. Also, nearly 25 expecting mothers took part in the event,” Dabak told TOI.

Some women carried posters to express their views while others were dressed up to promote the environment. A lady displayed a costume with six hands showing how a woman can multi task while nursing a child.

The organisers had also arranged two ambulances at the venue to take care of the infants and their mothers.

Various prizes were awarded to 15 individuals, eight groups and nine mothers along with their children.

Title: 3-fold rise in RTE applications this yr
Content:
Aurangabad: The state education department has received over 2.8 lakh applications for the 25% quota reserved in schools under the Right to Education (RTE) Act across Maharashtra, against the combined intake capacity of around 1.15 lakh.

The Aurangabad zilla parishad has also recorded around three-fold rise in applications against the total intake capacity till Saturday — the stipulated deadline for submitting applications.

Aurangabad district has received as many as 15,929 applications as against the declared cumulative intake capacity of 5,043 seats. Among different cities in Maharashtra, Pune is on top in terms of applications under RTE Act with 60,505 registrations followed by Nagpur (30,049), Thane (19,419), Nashik (17,065) and Mumbai (12,149).

“No documents are required for online registration and it is one of the reasons behind the rise in applications. The beneficiaries will have to submit necessary documents during the scrutiny process. We expect the number of claimants to go down during verification of documents,” an official from education department of Aurangabad zilla parishad said.

“We demand stringent scrutiny of income proof certificate and leave-and-licence agreement submitted as address proof. We claim that many fake beneficiaries benefit from RTE Act by producing these documents. The authorities must carry out stringent checks,” educational activist Prashant Sathe said.

Title: Slum kids walk the ramp in style
Content:
Nashik: About 38 children from the Phule Nagar slum area displayed their talents in a fashion and ramp walk show organised at the City Centre Mall in Untwadi on Sunday.

The theme of the fashion show was “a leap to the sky” which was the idea of two junior college students of KTHM College — Rin Yamabe and Garima Nikam.

Yamabe is a host student from Japan under the inter-cultural exchange programme of American Field Service (AFS) who is studying in first year junior college while Nikam is her classmate who hails from Vadodara and stays in KTHM’s hostel for female students.

“When I first met these slum kids through an AFS community service and told them that I am from Japan, they asked me if Japan is ahead of Jail Road (an area in the city). It made me wonder that these kids have no clue about the world which they deserve to know,” Yamabe said.

When she narrated the story over social media, her friends from Japan, Italy, Malaysia, Peru and France offered fashionable clothes of their culture for the kids which gave them the idea of the fashion show.

“These kids are stars and the show is about them. We wanted them to believe that the sky above the whole world belongs to them too,” said Nikam.

Title: Wild elephant tramples man to death
Content:
Udhagamandalam: A wild elephant trampled a 25-year-old man to death in the Mudumalai Tiger Reserve (MTR) on Saturday night.

Vijayan of Bennai village was on his way home around 8.15pm when the elephant attacked him, MTR core zone deputy director Shenbagapriya said. “His family is one of the 24 families out of the 235 in Bennai village yet to be relocated. Vijayan’s father is a beneficiary of the relocation programme. As construction of green houses as part of the relocation package is still under way, the families are staying in Bennai village as of now. Vijayan was staying with his father,” the official said.

The body was sent to the Gudalur GH for postmortem and was later handed over to the family. “Rs 50,000 was given to the family as initial compensation. The rest of the compensation amount will be disbursed after the formalities,” Shenbagapriya added.

In another incident, Vasanthakumar, a resident of O’Valley, was injured in an elephant attack in Masinagudi range of forests on Saturday night. “He was passing through the Bokkapuram Road when the animal chased him. We are not sure whether he fell down and injured himself or the animal attacked him,” MTR buffer zone deputy director Srikanth said. “He is undergoing treatment in the Ooty Government Hospital.”

The forest department has restricted entry on the Bokkapuram Road during night hours. A team of forest staff has been deployed in the area.

Title: ‘Karishma’ portrays love’s beauty & glory
Content:
Kala Sagar stages the play ‘Karishma’ in 59th Maharashtra Rajya Hindi Natya Spardha at Scientific Society Hall... Read More

Nagpur: The play ‘Karishma’, centred around the relationship between a married couple, was part of the 59th Maharashtra Rajya Hindi Natya Spardha 2019-20 organized by the state’s directorate of cultural affairs, Kala Sagar, at Scientific Hall, Laxmi Nagar, recently.

Thakur (Narendra Parihar) and his wife Vandana (Jyoti Rahate) live generously. They always help people whenever possible.

They raise their children Vinay (Suraj Kohade) and Nina (Vijaya Shinde) with love and affection. Vinay chooses the noble profession of a doctor while Nina decides to become a dance instructor.

The story takes a dramatic turn when Vinay falls in love with Shabnam (Rabneet Kaur). After finishing her daily chores, she helps Vinay in his clinic. Her sympathetic nature makes Vinay fall in love with her.

Meanwhile, Thakur is concerned about Nina and wants her to settle down. Pundit (Padam Nair) arranges a meeting with prospective groom Akhlesh (Harshal Sukhdeve), but Nina refuses to marry him because his nature does not impress her at all.

The story takes another turn when Atmaram (Suresh Sangolkar) visits Thakur. He becomes very sad while talking about his son whom he lost at a very young age. The only thing that Thakur could offer Atmaram was sympathy.

As Atmaram is about to depart, Nina notices a mark on his hand which resembles the mark on Shankar’s (Lokesh Chorpe) hand. Shankar was introduced as an orphan who resides in Thakur’s house since childhood and later, works as a manager in his office. But with the series of events that follow, Nina finds out that he is Atmaram’s lost son.

Nina starts to develop feelings for Shankar and turns down many marriage proposals.

When she expresses her desire to marry Shankar, her parents happily agree.

Vinay, on the other hand, has a tough time convincing his parents about the love of his life. Eventually, he succeeds.

The message that love is the biggest relationship was conveyed to the audience precisely through the play written and directed by Nair.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: It is important to under-promise, over-deliver: Cognizant CEO
Content:
Chennai: Brian Humphries was appointed as CEO of Cognizant last April. He took over at a time when the company lost its bellwether status. In conversation with ToI, he details his plans and vision to get back to industry leadership. Excerpts:

How is your “Fit for Growth” plan shaping up?

Things are always refined, but at the end of the day, “Fit for growth” as an initiative is to make sure Cognizant thinks about not just where we are today but also where we want to be in 3, 5, 8, 12 years. We are approximately $17 billion today and I don’t think about Cognizant being just a $20 billion business; but a $30 billion dollar business. So, how do you make sure you allow ourselves to scale to that level?

This is the equivalent of somebody wanting to run a marathon. You don’t run it unless you do some training.

We’ve been very clear: there’s an absolute focus on clients, and associates to make sure that we engage them and motivate them. I am very pleased to say that our voluntary attrition is now at a 2-year low at its mid-teens.

Our employee motivation is picking up. But most of all, the optimism is back that we have a bright future, and are aiming to outgrow the industry and I think people’s morale has picked up.

Is it possible for you to quantify ‘optimism is back’?

When I see our associates, we do one-on-ones and town halls. After every one of those town halls, we get surveys, NPS (net promoter scores). And so, throughout the world, over the last 11 months, I have been tracking the NPS.

Simultaneously, we look at our attrition rates as a company. In Q4, our attrition rate fell 3 percentage points from Q3. Q3 was 24, Q4 was 21. But more importantly, we are trying to drive a performance culture in Cognizant.

You guided to 2%-4% growth in the last quarter, isn’t that a disappointment?

Well, I think you should always differentiate between guidance versus actuals. Hopefully, you have seen that in the last 3 quarters since I’ve arrived, we have beaten our guidance and consensus. So, I am a big believer in setting expectations that we can over-deliver against.

Are you under-promising?

With Wall Street, it is important to under-promise , over-deliver. Our ambition in the years ahead is to once again become the industry bellwether, which requires us to grow faster than 2%-4%.

Traditional expertise in financial services and healthcare appear to be strained?

Well, to be honest, they will both improve in the first half of this year. So we expect those to start contributing to growth again in the coming quarters.

Making sure that the CEO sends a strong growth message. That we hire more freshers, get the right skills and set money aside to invest in growth.

You are probably aware that at this moment of time, we have committed over 500 incremental revenue-generating resources. It also requires stronger partnerships. I have spoken at length about the importance of our relationship with companies like Microsoft, Amazon, Google, Salesforce and Workday and ServiceNow and companies like SAP and Adobe. On strategy, international is just 24% of Cognizant, it needs to be substantially higher. We’ve selected four specific battlegrounds in digital that we want to win in; namely cloud, data analytics, digital engineering and IoT. I am confident that with strategy and client-centric mentality of growth that starts with me, if I am seeing about 20 clients a week, with the increased focus we put on employee engagement, it puts us in a great position to win.

Strategy is about not doing certain things too?

Perhaps, one of the most topical things we made a decision on, is to exit the over quarter of a billion-dollar business in one subset of content moderation services.

It was not an area where we had intellectual property, it was a high growth area, but not an area that was strategic to us. And so that’s an area where at this moment in time, we have decided to work with our platform partners to actually exit that business.

We will have an impact on about 6,000 employees.

Is wage inflation rising?

It’s not something we are overly concerned about.

Every country is becoming very protectionist about its own business?

It’s interesting, I was there in Davos in January, and some of it was around globalisation versus nationalism, and multiple stakeholder management, shareholders vs other constituents - including the environment, etc., so I think as a society we are increasingly conflicted and challenged intellectually when we think about this.

I believe in a global world, I believe in free trade and I also believe that we have multiple stakeholders to manage. As an example, I signed with the business roundtable in the US last year a letter signed by I think over 100 CEO’s advocating that the role of the CEO is beyond simply shareholder value creation.

Future sunrise sectors! What are all the sectors you are seeding now?

I think first of all you have to realise that international is still a huge opportunity, it’s just 24% of Cognizant unlike perhaps, 50% for one of our leading competitors, so I view that as a huge-huge opportunity that we can seed.

We want to expand geographically, diversify across our client base and then, of course, there are next-generation growth areas - things like IoT, software product engineering, even cloud.

I am increasingly aware of IoT. I think it becomes a tremendous set of nascent capabilities for Cognizant, around things like industry 4.0 or autonomous driving or anything where latency and security become very important.

Do you get angry when a client walks away?

I never get angry that the client walks away because invariably it’s our fault, not the client’s.

I had mentioned in our most recent earnings call that our win rate, in terms of every opportunity we are going after, our win rate has materially increased by 5 percentage points in the last 12 months.

Title: Unseasonal rainfall damages rabi crops in parts of M’wada
Content:
Aurangabad: Many areas of the city along with districts like Beed, Jalna and Latur received unseasonal rainfall during the 36-hours ending on Sunday evening.

The untimely showers have damaged rabi crops like sorghum, wheat and maize besides affecting the mango flowering in many places. The India Meteorological Department (IMD), in its bulletin issued on Sunday evening, has forecast similar rainfall activity over the next 24-hours.

Aurangabad district disaster management officer Ajay Chaudhari on Sunday said tehsil limits of Aurangabad along with Phulambri, Paithan, Gangapur and Kannad talukas from reported measurable rainfall activity during the past 24-hours.

“Rainfall in the range of 1mm to 5mm was reported in different parts of the district. The untimely showers occurred between midnight and wee hours of Sunday in some areas. As per Met department, more rainfall is the store for the next day or two,” he said.

“Besides Aurangabad, Beed, Jalna and Latur districts also reported showers amid loud thundering in several areas,” divisional disaster management officer Ganesh Lokhande said.

As per reports from different areas, the standing rabi crops has received damage due to untimely rainfall. Farmer activist Jayaji Suryawanshi said latest showers have caused major damage to the farming community and the government must swing into action.

“The government must order panchanama in affected areas. The rabi crops were in the harvesting stage in many places. The farmers must be extended all possible help due to this natural calamity,” he said.

When contacted, revenue department officials said no immediate estimate was available about the crop damage in the region. “The taluka level revenue officials will report about crop damage, if any, after carrying out spot visits,” he said.

As per IMD, a cyclonic circulation over Arabian Sea was responsible for untimely showers in Marathwada and other parts of the country.

Title: ‘88% beneficiaries used biometrics at fair price shops in January’
Content:
Almost 88% of the beneficiaries of the public distribution system (PDS) in the district use biometrics to get supplies from the fair price shops (FPS), said DSO Arvind Narsikar during a conversation with TOI’s Abhilash Botekar. The officer added that the Shiv Bhojan centres in the Nashik district have already served 27,122 meals since the scheme’s launch

Q) What efforts are being made to ensure timely delivery of goods?

A) Under the supply chain management enhancement system, there is an emphasis on providing grains to the fair price shops by the 14th of each month. At this point, most of the delivery to 2,608 fair price shops from the Food Corporation of India godowns is done by the date. In most cases, the delivery is done by the 10th of each month. The same facility may be extended to all other areas after sorting out the transportation issues.

Q) What measures are being taken to increase storage capacity?

A) As per the directions of the state government and the Nashik collector, the work on the construction of 13 godowns is nearing completion. The godowns are likely to be commissioned in June this year. This will enhance the storage capacity of the district by 34,680 tonne. The work is in the final stages.

Q) Has biometric usage by beneficiaries been made compulsory?

A) Yes, biometric usage has been made mandatory for all beneficiaries to get their quota of grains through the FPA. More than one member is allowed to buy the quota from the FPAs by using the system. But since there are still some connectivity issues in the remote areas, people there are allowed to pick up the goods without biometric confirmation. Utmost care is taken to ensure the beneficiaries get what they pay for and as per their quota. It may be noted, that foodgrain for 6.69 lakh ration cards were issued using biometrics in January. This amounts to 88% of the total cards.

Q) What efforts are being made to resolve the complaints of beneficiaries?

A) The complaints of the beneficiaries are taken seriously. The department has resolved more than 43,756 complaints it had received in 2019-20. The quantum of the complaints was huge and a special drive was conducted for the rederessal.

Q) How has Shiv Bhojan scheme fared in the district?

A) Till February 29, as many as 27,122 people have had lunch under the state government’s Shiv Bhojan scheme across the six centres in the district since the scheme’s launch. Five centres are in Nashik city and one is in Malegaon city. They together serve 2,100 thalis per day. The administration is looking for more centres who can take care of the new quota of 800 thalis.

Title: Budget session likely to start on a stormy note
Content:
The General and OBC employees’ association has announced an indefinite work boycott from Monday with its offic... Read More

Dehradun: The budget session due to start on March 3 in the hill town of Gairsain is set to be a stormy one. Thousands of government employees, who have been agitating on the issue of reservation in promotion, are set for a direct confrontation with the government by boycotting the session and taking out a march to the assembly on the day the session starts.

The General and OBC employees’ association has announced an indefinite work boycott from Monday with its office-bearers saying they will be marching to Gairsain on Tuesday.

Besides, the government has also been facing criticism from opposition Congress which has been vocal about the session being only for five days which they say is inadequate time for deliberations to be conducted.

Making the situation even more worrisome for the government is the fact that the ‘Gairsain-for capital’ agitators have again raised the demand to announce Gairsain as the summer capital of Uttarakhand.

Deepak Joshi, the chairman of secretariat employees’ union and federation of General and OBC employees, told TOI, “We have met the CM over the issue but the talks failed to bring about any results. Therefore, we are adamant on our stand. The motive is not to disrupt work but ensure that the state government follows the Supreme Court (SC) order.”

To recall, through an order on September 11 last year, the government had stopped promotion in government jobs as the matter was sub-judice. The SC on February 7 this year held that the state government is not bound to provide reservation in appointments, and there is no fundamental right to claim quota in promotions. The employees after the SC order are now asking the state government to revoke its September 2019 order and start the departmental promotion committee meeting at the earliest.

Meanwhile, Congress wants the assembly session to be extended saying that it seemed like “a mere symbolic session.” Congress state chief Pritam Singh said, “The five-day budget session is a mere formality as it is too short to hold a budget session. There will not be adequate time to discuss issues. If the governor’s speech and debate on it is held on day one, it will leave us with just four days.”

Meanwhile, urban development minister and government spokesperson Madan Kaushik said that the government was serious on the issue of employees. “The CM and I have both spoken to the employees and are looking into the matter,” he added. On the issue of extending the budget session, he said that if the Opposition was willing, the session on each day can be conducted till the late night hours.

Title: Body of newborn boy found in an open ground
Content:
Aurangabad: The body of a newborn was found in an open ground in Mukundwadi area of the city on Friday.

The baby boy was spotted by the locals, who informed the police. The baby was taken to the Government Medical College and Hospital. However, the doctors there declared the newborn dead on arrival.

Mukundwadi police have registered an offence under sections 315 (acted with intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth) and 318 (concealment of birth by secret disposal of dead body) of the Indian Penal Code.

The last rites of the baby were performed on Sunday after the post mortem was carried out.

Police sub-inspector Rahul Bangar said they are investigating the case and are looking for probable suspects.

“The newborn was likely abandoned immediately after his birth. The baby was still wet from the amniotic fluid. There are no CCTV cameras in the area and, therefore, we are yet to get any clues about the suspects,” the police officer said

Two motorcycles

stolen in the city

Two cases of two-wheeler thefts in the city were lodged with the police on Saturday.

In the first incident, a motorcycle owned by 25-year-old Sadashiv Puri, a resident of Padampura, was stolen on February 19.

The motorcycle was parked near his house, from where it was stolen.

The complainant looked for the bike everywhere and after he failed to find it, he lodged a complaint with the Vedant Nagar police on Saturday evening.

In another incident, a motorcycle parked in the Mukundwadi area was stolen by unidentified people on February 28.

A 27-year-old called Amol Hande owned the bike worth Rs 65,000.

Hande lodged an FIR with the Mukundwadi police.

Externed criminal arrested from within city limits

The cantonment police have arrested Ravindra, alias Lahun Sambhaji Pradhan, who was externed from the city limits for one year starting January 2020.

The police said that Lahun Sambhaji Pradhan was spotted near his house at Padegaon during a combing operation conducted by the local police.

He had not taken any prior permission from the authorities to enter the city, the police added.

Title: Vijayawada: Teacher booked for molesting minor
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: A teacher was booked on Saturday evening for sexually molesting a Class-X girl at Nidubrolu Zilla Parishad School under Ponnur mandal in Guntur district.

According to P Premaiah, inspector of Ponnur, the girl lodged a complaint against the teacher, alleging that he had been molesting her over the last few days. It was alleged that the teacher, who teaches science, had directed obscene comments at the girl and had touched her inappropriately.

The complainant said that though she brought the matter to the notice of the headmaster, no action was taken and instead, the headmaster spoke in support of the accused. On Saturday evening, the accused asked the girl to come to the staff room when no one was present and molested her.

The girl managed to escape and informed what had happened to the warden of the social welfare hostel where she was staying. The warden in turn informed higher authorities and the girl’s parents.

Deputy director of the social welfare hostel Madhusudhan rushed to the hostel at midnight to conduct an enquiry and recorded the girl’s statement along with Ponnur inspector. A complaint was lodged against the teacher with Ponnur police by the deputy director.

A case has been registered under relevant sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences ( Pocso ) Act and the SC and ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: 5 men arrested for trying to grab land in Vellalore
Content:
Coimbatore: A five-member gang was arrested on Sunday for attempting to grab nine cents vacant land at Vellalore from a 55-year-old realtor.

According to police, C V Thomas, of NRR Layout at Singanallur, had bought the land when it was auctioned by a bank in 2007 after its owner failed to repay loan.

“The land was earlier owned by S Gangadharan, an AIADMK functionary from Vellalore, who had pledged it and taken the loan. It was auctioned as he didn’t repay the loan,” a police officer said.

On Saturday evening, when Thomas went to put up a fence around his land, Sathya Pasupathi, 43, of Thoothukudi district, his car driver R Jothish, 29, of Munnar and friends K Dhamodaran, 27, of Sivakashi, Gangadharan and P Petchimuthu, 43, of Vellalore, assaulted him.

They also erected the flags of Pasupathiyar Tamizhaga Munnetra Kazhagam, a political outfit launched by Pasupathi, on the land.

Thomas alerted the Podanur police and a team lead by assistant commissioner of police Cedric Manuel and inspector P Maheswaran reached the spot and asked the five-member gang to vacate the area. However, Pasupathi argued with police and told them that he had taken the land on lease for 99 years from Gangadharan.

Police, however, booked the five under Sections 147 (punishment for rioting), 148 (rioting armed with deadly weapons), 294 (b) (sings, recites, or utters any obscene song, ballad or words in or near any public place), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 447 (punishment for criminal trespass), 448 (punishment for house-trespass), 506 (ii) (criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 of the Tamil Nadu Open Places (Prevention of Disfigurement) Act and arrested them. All the five were lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison under Judicial custody on Sunday.

Pasupathi, the officer said, has three murder cases and as many attempt-to-murder cases pending against him. He was a close aide of Pasupathi Pandian, founder of Federation of Devendrakula Vellalars, who was murdered by a gang at his residence in Dindigul district in January 2012.

“After the demise of Pandian, Pasupathi started his own party called Pasupathiyar Tamizhaga Munnetra Kazhagam,” the officer said.

Title: 23 drinking water packaging companies sealed in district
Content:
Coimbatore: Following the directions of the Madras high court , public works department (PWD) officials along with tahsildars have sealed 23 drinking water packaging units that were functioning without the required license in the district as on Sunday.

As many as 52 such units are functioning in the district, collector K Rajamani said. “The remaining companies will be sealed on Monday. Five of them have applied for the license.”

A few days ago, HC had directed the State government to close the illegal drinking water packing units in the state before Monday and file a compliance report on Tuesday.

Following the judgement, packaged drinking water manufacturers across the state called an indefinite strike, which entered fourth day on Sunday. The manufacturers also assembled for an urgent meeting at Eachanari on the city outskirts.

“The government order that mandates obtaining groundwater clearance from the PWD was passed only in 2014. But close to 920 companies, including 35 in the district, have been functioning for long,” D Suresh Kumar of the Package Drinking Water Association said. “We have other certificates, including those from the Small Scale Industry (SSI) and Indian Standard Institute (ISI). We were facing a lot of practical difficulties in obtaining the license. The order mandates that no two borewells should be operated within a distance of 75 metres. When we had started the companies, there weren’t any borewells within the specified distance. But as years passed, several buildings and borewells were set up on the surrounding areas,” he told TOI.

“Also, before submitting the application to PWD, we need to obtain permission from the revenue inspector or tahsildar saying that there is no waterbody within five kilometres radius. The officials would sign only after inspecting the location. It is a very time-consuming process,” he said.

The units in the district are consuming only a few percentage of the underground water, Suresh said. “If the sealing drive continues, fake companies will enter the market. “We request the government to exempt those companies set up before 2014 from the government order and provide us the license,” he added.

Title: Purusaivari Thototsavam festival held at Tirumala
Content:
Tirupati: The Purusaivari Thototsavam annual festival was celebrated at the Lord Venkateswara temple at Tirumala on Sunday.

Descendants of the Sri Vaishnava saint Sri Anantalwar gathered at Purusaivari Thota at Tirumala on the occasion of the 966th ‘avatara utsavam’ of Sri Anantalwar.

The 26th generation Sri Vaishnavas of the Anantalwar lineage also took part in the annual festival.

Tributes were paid to Sri Anantalwar on the occasion and his services to Lord Venkateswara as a devotee were recalled.

The event was organised under the aegis of the Alwar Divya Prabandham project of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD).

Title: Left outfits using CAA to spread anarchy: State BJP prez
Content:
Nashik: State BJP president Chandrakant Patil on Sunday said that left outfits are using issues like Citizens Amendment Act and Muslim reservation to spread anarchy across the country.

Speaking to reporters during his one-day visit to Nashik , Patil said even the NCP president Sharad Pawar and Congress were unaware of the agenda of the left outfits and urban naxals to destabilise the country.

“The CAA has got nothing to do with the Muslims of the country and yet they are being instigated to oppose the same. The Muslims are unable to gauge that the urban naxals and leftists are the ones who are calling shots by putting them in the front,” he said.

The senior BJP leader said the leftist forces were using several agendas to grab support of the people from all quarters only to destabilise the country.

“During the last 10 years Muslims did not face any issue and there were no riots. What has happened all of a sudden? Their agenda of destabilising the country is gaining momentum through agitations without substance,” Patil said.

“Sharad Pawar is also unable to gauge their game plan. The Congress is unable to understand it either. Muslims are also unaware of it. Opposition to CAA for political purpose is not done. Also opposing the census, a regular feature, is only strengthening the game-plan of the leftists,” he added.

Being asked about the political development in BJP’s Nashik unit, Patil said there was no discord among the members.

The outgoing chairperson of the standing committee, Uddhav Nimse, after the last day in office claimed that BJP corporators, leaders and office-bearers harassed him during his one-year tenure as the chairperson.

“All BJP members and office-bearers were working together. There are some misunderstandings that are taken care of by the party at the end of the day,” Patil said.

Title: Properties with pending dues of Rs 1.92cr attached
Content:
Nashik: The City Survey Office of Land Records has attached 8,665 properties from property holders in the city for pending dues worth Rs 1.92 crore. With this attachment, the property holders will not be able to sell it before this attachment is cleared.

The property card holders have to pay the one-time fees for their properties. As and when they clear their dues, the property will be released.

The land record department has carried out a survey of the city and prepared property cards of all non-agricultural properties in the city. Each property has been assigned a unique identity.

“We have prepared property cards of each property in the city. We have also conducted camps and drives appealing to people to take their cards. Yet, there are many who have still not taken their cards,” Superintendent of Land Record Mahesh Shinde said.

City Survey Officer Changdeo Mohalkar said that the response of citizens towards taking property cards was not very enthusiastic and this was largely because of lack of awareness among the masses.

“In future, transactions in the non-agricultural areas will be carried out on the basis of property cards only. These cards have detailed and accurate measurements. Since, we are in a transition phase at this point of time, and awareness related to property cards is less, people were not very forthcoming to take their cards. We have, therefore, attached their properties,” Mohalkar said.

“The property will be released as soon as the payment is done. But, the process of clearing the dues and getting the attachment released could take over a month’s time. It is better that the citizens go to the city survey offices beforehand and connect with the officers to get the exact idea of the status of their property card,” Mohalkar added.

A total of 45,544 property cards have been prepared by the department even as the work on the cards in others areas is being carried out. A total of 38,729 property holders have cleared their dues while 8,665 property holders are yet to do so.

Title: Innovations for a better tomorrow on display at Manipal
Content:
Dr Shreya Lakshmi and Dr Namrata Datta (), give a demo on Onco-dent at the fourth Manipal Entrepreneurship Sum... Read More

Manipal: About 41 innovations were exhibited as part of the fourth Manipal Entrepreneurship Summit (MES). The fourth edition of MES of Manipal Academy of Higher Education (MAHE) was jointly hosted by Manipal Institute of Technology (MIT), Innovation Center, Manipal Universal Technology Business Incubator (MUTBI) and Manipal-Govt of Karnataka Bioincubator. The two-day event ended on Saturday.

Among other exhibits, on display was Onco-dent, a novel device with multiple functions which helps patients with oral cancer. The project has been developed by Dr Garima Makhija, Dr Shreya Lakshmi and Dr Namrata Datta, interns of Manipal College of Dental Sciences, and supported by Dr Swathi Pai, faculty member. Dr Shreya Lakshmi told STOI that the toothbrush comes with two brush heads. It provides local drug delivery and stimulation of salivary flow, which is ideal during post and pre-operation. “The prototype is ready, and we have applied for a patent,” she said, adding that the toothbrush is cost-efficient.

Suyog Wagh and Prateek Kapoor, fourth-year mechanical engineering students of Manipal Institute of Technology, have developed Rev-X, a refurbished electric scooter. Suyog said: “Generally,any old vehicle which is unfit for use is considered a scrap. Towards effective waste management, we are working on refurbishing old scooters. Our first prototype of converting an old scooter into an electric one has been successful. For two hours of battery charging, the scooter can run up to 60km. The cost is around Rs 45,000. We have applied for a patent, and we will be experimenting with motorbikes soon,” Suyog added.

Recording vaccinations

The Innovation Center at MAHE, the Community Medicine Department of KMC Manipal and the Manipal Institute of Technology have developed a novel digital and visual platform to record vaccinations for children. This includes a mobile app, wherein healthcare workers enter vaccination data. The data is backed up on a secure cloud server and also stored on a smartcard, and mothers are given HealthGate Passport documenting vaccination due dates. It was formally launched on Friday. The package costing less than Rs 200 per child can record the child’s entire vaccination history, said Dr Arun Shanbhag, chief innovation officer, MAHE and principal investigator of the project funded by Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, and Grand Challenges Explorer Awards.

“Currently, over 700 patients are part of this network, and there are plans to cover the entire district. Auxiliary nurse midwives have been provided with smartphones with a sim card, and Wi-Fi dongles have been given to public health centres as part of the project,” he said. The team is working on providing SMS alerts to the card holders a week in advance about the vaccination.

Title: 5 arrested under Pocso Act
Content:
Coimbatore: The all women police (west) have arrested a 28-year-old man who married a Pollachi-based minor girl, his parents , the girl’s mother and a construction worker who raped the girl, under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act, 2012.

The mother of the 16-year-old girl had married her off to the 28-year-old man last August, police sources said. “The couple was staying in Coimbatore city. P Ranjith Kumar, a 23-year-old construction worker from Trichy, who was staying in the locality, befriended her and eloped with her 15 days ago. He raped her several times,” a police officer said.

The girl’s husband lodged a complaint at the Variety Hall Road police station claiming that his 20-year-old wife had gone missing along with Kumar. Police registered a missing case.

A police team rescued the girl a few days ago. During interrogation, police came to know that she was only 16 years old and transferred the case to the all women police (west), who registered a case under sections 5 (l) (penetrative sexual assault), 6 (punishment for penetrative sexual assault) of the Pocso Act against the girl’s husband and Kumar on Friday. The duo was also booked under Section 366 (kidnapping, abducting or inducing a woman to compel her marriage) of IPC. The minor girl’s parents-in-law and her mother were also booked under Section 17 (punishment for abetment) of Pocso and sections 9 and 10 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006.

All of them were arrested and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison. Police are conducting inquiry with the girl’s father.

Title: CAA Protest in Hyderabad: EFLU students complain as Hyderabad police lock campus to deter participation in anti-CAA protest
Content:
EFLU students jump over the main gate as police had locked it to prevent them from stepping out to protest on ... Read More

HYDERABAD: Hyderabad police locked all the gates of English and Foreign Languages University ( EFLU ) and stopped students and professors from stepping outside the campus on Sunday.

Students alleged that police locked all gates to stop them from taking part in a protest being organized in solidarity with Delhi riots victims and against Citizen Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC), near Karachi bakery at Moazzam Jahi Market.

“At around 3pm, police locked all the gates of varsity and restricted anyone from venturing outside the campus. The gates were opened only after two hours,” said Harshal Deshpande, vice-president, student union of EFLU adding that the lockdown of campus was unacceptable. “If they can lock the campus today just because they got information that we would be taking part in a protest, they could hold us as hostages in our own campus in the future.”

The students said that the police informed them that they received intelligence about members of the right-wing student group planning to attack EFLU students if they took part in the protest. They said that police should have taken those planning the attack into custody instead of locking down the entire campus.

“It was not like the protest call was given by the student union of EFLU. We got information about the event and a group of students were discussing about taking part in the protest,” said Samar Ali, general secretary of the student union. She said some students were about to step out of the campus to reach Karachi Bakery when the police locked the gates. “The plan was that a group of students will go for the protest and update the students at the campus so those interested could join the talk,” she added.

Meanwhile, M Ramesh, DCP, East zone said that they locked the campus gates as no permission was given for the said march or protest at Karachi bakery. The varsity administration confirmed that police informed the proctor before locking the gates saying that there is something happening at Moazzam Jahi Market and students stepping out can further aggravate it.

They, however, added that they immediately got the locks removed as there was nothing happening at the campus. At Osmania University campus also, students were allegedly stopped from heading to Karachi bakery.

Title: IAS officer held in Jammu and Kashmir arms licence case
Content:
NEW DELHI: The CBI has arrested two former district magistrates of Kupwara — Rajiv Ranjan , an IAS, and Itrit Hussain Rafiqui — in connection with issuance of large number of arms licences on the basis of forged documents, officials said on Sunday.

During the CBI investigation, the alleged role of Ranjan and Rafiqui — who held the position of district magistrate of Kupwara from 2015 to 2016 and 2013 to 2015, respectively — had surfaced, they said. The agency has taken both the officers into its custody, a CBI spokesperson said.

Title: Fall in number of small saving scheme agents
Content:
Coimbatore: The number of agents working under the small saving scheme to promote the idea of savings among the public, has seen a sharp decline after the state government had withdrew their annual incentive about a decade ago.

Recovering gradually from the blow, the district administration has been working on to increase the number of agents working for the scheme in the district. At present, 1,400 agents are working under the scheme.

An official from the district administration said 1,010 women work as agents under Mahila Pradhan Kshetriya Bachat Yojana (MPKBY) to promote recurring deposits among the public and 390 persons work as agents under Standard Agency System (SAS) to promote fixed deposits in the district. Every year, crores of rupees is being deposited in the district.

Explaining that the agents will have to convenience the public to deposit at least a small amount under the small saving scheme in postal departments, the official said that SAS agents would get 0.5% and MPKBY agents would get 4% as commission for each deposit.

“But until 2011, the state government had been giving 0.5% of the total deposits made in a year as incentive to SAS agents and 2% of the total deposits made in a year as incentive to MPKBY agents. While the neighbouring states including Kerala continue to give the incentive amount to the agents, our state government has stopped it abruptly. As a result, some of the agents had started to opt out of the field,” the source explained. The number of agents in the district in 2011 was as high as 2,000.

After the number started to drop steadily, it is only in the last few years the officials had taken initiatives to increase it. As of part of which, they have been educating both the anganwadi workers and block level officials about the benefits of small saving schemes and who in turn would help both to find suitable agents and make public deposit a sum in the post offices, the official added.

As a result, as many as 27 new agents had started to work under the scheme, this year, the official said, adding that anyone who clears the police verification could become an agent. To encourage the agents, the central government has allotted a sum of Rs 36,000 to identify and honour the best performing agents. For this year, the best performing agents would be honoured by collector K Rajamani on Monday.

Title: 10-year-old found dead in Chittoor district
Content:
Tirupati: A 10-year-old boy was found dead under suspicious circumstances at ST Colony in Parlapalli village in Chittoor district on Sunday morning. Parents of the boy alleged he was beaten to death by his employer for stealing a duck from his farm .

Police said the deceased was identified as Venkata Ramaiah, son of Venkateshu and Rupamma, both from Parlapalli. The deceased was employed as labour on a farm owned by one Muruga Reddy in the village.

According to the complaint lodged by Venkateshu, Venkata Ramaiah was working under Muruga Reddy, who owns farms and other businesses in the mandal, for the past couple of years.

On Saturday evening, Muruga Reddy accused the boy of stealing a duck from the farm. After the incident, the 10-year-old went missing and did not return home. His body was found beside his house on Sunday morning.

A case was registered and Muruga Reddy taken into custody. The body of the deceased has been sent for autopsy.

Title: Seeking fresh declaration while porting medical insurance is illegal: Forum
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik district consumer disputes redressal forum has said it is illegal for insurance companies to seek a fresh declaration of pre-illness from a consumer who has ported a policy from another insurer.

The decision comes in the wake of a move by Apollo Munich Health Insurance, which denied the claim of a consumer by saying he had failed to mention a family member’s disease while porting from ICICI Lombard.

The forum asked Apollo Munich to settle a claim of Rs 1.04 lakh along with 10% interest from March 31, 2017. The company was also asked to pay out Rs 5,000 for harassment and Rs 3,000 towards costs incurred.

Complainant Nitin Bhat, a resident of Indira Nagar, had taken out a family protection insurance policy from ICICI Lombard in 2011. In 2015, he ported to Apollo Munich Health Insurance.

In 2011, Bhat’s son had to be taken into care for problems with his left eye. Doctors were able to treat the patient. But the problem resurfaced in 2014, this time in the boy’s right eye. A year later, in 2015, the boy had to be taken to specialists when the problem occurred again. He was referred to the LV Prasad Eye Institute in Hyderabad, where doctors performed a surgery on December 7, 2016. The cost of the procedure was Rs 1.04 lakh.

Bhat submitted the claim to the company, which proceeded to reject it by saying the boy’s care was part of a “pre-disease”. The company also refused to renew the insurance.

Bhat then registered a complaint with the consumer forum on May 28, 2018. He said the claim should be settled along with a payout of Rs 30,000, for mental stress.

In a written reply to the forum, Apollo Munich, through its counsel P P Pawar, claimed that the son of the consumer was suffering from ‘pitosis’ and that this fact was not disclosed in the pre-disclosure form at the time of porting-in. The company argued that it had not erred while rejecting the claim.

But a three-member forum, headed by president Milind Sonawane, in its judgment observed that the diseases and period being considered by the first health insurance company is binding on the company that the consumer picked while porting. “If this is portability, where does the question of new declaration come in? Therefore, the new declaration is not with the law,” the forum ruled.

The forum also clarified that if the pre-disclosure has to be considered, it would be with the declaration given to the first company, which has not been presented here. It also underlined the fact that insurance companies cannot rely on the “discharge summary” as it cannot be considered as conclusive evidence as ruled by the senior courts.

Title: AIADMK govt’s achievements on display
Content:
Coimbatore: Municipal administration minister S P Velumani on Sunday inaugurated a photo exhibition showcasing the achievement of the state government under the leadership of Edappadi K Palaniswami at the town bus stand in Gandhipuram.

The photos will create awareness about the schemes implemented by the CM and the government’s welfare schemes, the minister said. Rare photographs of late chief minister J Jayalalithaa are also on display.

Earlier, Velumani inaugurated several development works at ward 89 and 93. He laid foundation stone to construction a bus shelter at the cost of Rs 7.40 lakh and a children park and playground at the cost of Rs 55 lakh in Anbu Nagar. He later laid foundation stone to construct an auditorium at the cost of Rs 8 lakh in Ramachettipalayam and an indoor stadium at the cost of Rs 64.70 lakh in Sameem Garden. He also inaugurated a park built at the cost of Rs 28.90 lakh at Radhapuram Nagar.

Title: Displaying manufacturing date must for sweets sold in loose
Content:
Nashik: Starting June 1, it will be mandatory for all food business operators (FBOs) to display the ‘date of manufacture’ and ‘best before date’ for sweets sold in loose.

Senior officials of the Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) Nashik , said that post June 1, they would start collecting samples of sweets sold in loose. They even warned of taking strict action against owners of sweet shops who display wrong information of the date of manufacture.

Joint director of FDA (food), Nashik, Chandrashekhar Salunke said, “Cases will be registered against the FBOs if they fail to adhere to the norms set by the Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI). There is a provision under Section 58 of the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006, to lodge cases against FBOs. The FBOs will also face legal action if they provide wrong information regarding the date of manufacture and best before date.”

FDA officials said that there have been instances in the past where stale or expired sweets have been sold to consumers, posing a risk to their health.

While it is mandatory for pre-packed sweets to mention the date of manufacture and best before date on their labels as per the Food Safety and Standards (Packaging and Labelling) Regulations, 2011, the regulatory compliance division of the FSSAI has decided to make it mandatory for non-packaged or loose sweets also to provide the same details.

FDA officials from Nashik said that FBOs shall decide and display the necessary dates of sweets depending upon the nature of the product and local conditions. An indicative list of shelf life of various types of sweets is mentioned in the guidance note of ‘Safety and Quality of traditional milk products’—available on the FSSAI website.

Food safety officers across the district and Nashik division will ensure that the food business operators are complying with the directions.

Title: Cylinder Blast in Hyderabad: 7 suffer burns in LPG fire mishaps
Content:
In the Malakpet incident, victim forgot to switch off the burner

HYDERABAD: Seven people suffered burns in two separate domestic gas leak-related fire accidents at Saroornagar and Malakpet in the early hours of Sunday.

In the incident at P&T Colony of Saroornagar, a family of seven, including three children, sensing LPG leak rushed out of their home around 2am. However, two brothers — S Ramesh, 31, and S Laxman, 25 — went back to retrieve cash.

When they switched on the light, it triggered the fire. “The fire spread to the neighbouring house, where Leelamma, 62, and her husband stays. She also sustained burn injuries. All three sustained 50-60% burn injuries and were shifted to Osmania Hospital ,” Saroornagar inspector Srinivas Reddy. A fire tender douse the blaze.

In another incident, the four members of a family, including two children, sustained burns after gas leakage at Asmangarh in Malakpet. The victims were identified as Laxamiah, 50 and his wife, Yadamma, 45, along with their grandchildren, Tejaswi, 7, and Mokshadna, 5. Laxmaiah’s daughter had gone to attend an event and left her children with her parents. “The victim forgot to switch off a burner and a spark from the refrigerator’s wire triggered a blast from the leaked LPG. Tejaswi sustained 10% burns, the rest nearly 40% injuries,” Malakpet SI said.

Title: Exempt us from exam duty: Class X teachers
Content:
Coimbatore: Government school teachers in the district , who handle Class X , have sought exemption from Class XI and XII board exam duty.

They would not be able to concentrate on the third and final revision test for Class X students if they are deployed for exam duty, the teachers said.

Board exams for Classes XI and XII begin on Wednesday and those for Class X begin on March 27. As many as 70 Class X teachers from the Perur education district and 50 from the Coimbatore city education district have been enlisted for exam duty.

State auditor of the Tamil Nadu High and Higher Secondary School Graduate Teacher Association (TNHHSSGTA) T Arulanandam said only a few days are left for the Class X board exams. “This is a crucial time period for revision. The third revision test for Class X starts on Monday. At this juncture, if teachers are delegated for higher secondary exam duty, they won’t be able to prepare the students,” he said. “We compiled a list of Class X teachers in the district and submitted it to the chief education officer seeking exemption from exam duty so that they can focus on preparing Class X students for the board exams.”

Teachers who handle Class X are rarely deployed for higher secondary board examination duty, chief education officer P Usha said. “We will exempt Class X teachers from exam duty and have asked them to get a bonafide declaration from headmasters saying that they are handling Class X,” she said.

Title: Inter-agricultural varsities sports meet commences
Content:
Tirupati: Around 3,000 students representing 65 agricultural and allied sciences universities participated in the 20th all-India inter-agricultural universities sports and games meet 2019-20 that got off to a start on Sunday. The meet is being hosted by Sri Venkateswara Veterinary University ( SVVU ).

Indian Council of Agricultural Research deputy director-general (education) RC Agarwal inaugurated the event in the presence of SVVU vice-chancellor Y Hari Babu and dean (student affairs) K Sarjan Rao.

Addressing the gathering, Agarwal spoke on the importance of physical fitness while discharging their duties.

Title: U’khand spent Rs 6cr in past 4 yrs, sterilised 15k monkeys
Content:
Dehradun: The Uttarakhand forest department has spent around Rs 6.02 crore in the past four years in containing the simian menace in the state, data exclusively accessed by TOI has revealed. The state currently has three rescue centres — at Chidiyapur in Haridwar; Ranibagh in Nainital and at Almora. As per the data, 10, 620 monkeys were sterilised at Chidiyapur in the period 2016-17 to 2019-20 while 4,602 monkeys were sterilised at Ranibagh between 2017-18 to 2019-20 whereas 269 monkeys were sterilised at Almora between 2017-18 to 2019-20 (the Ranibagh and Almora centres had not started in 2016-17). In all, 15,591 monkeys were sterilised in the period between 2016-17 and 2019-20, the data reveals. However, a total of 60,002 monkeys were caught during this period, as per the data.

So, why were all monkeys that were caught not sterilised? Forest officials cite a number of reasons — ranging from paucity of trained staff to factors like the ‘right season’ not being there to sterilise female monkeys. “Scarcity of veterinary doctors is a perennial issue being faced by the forest department and often, doctors from animal husbandry department are brought on contract basis which is why, sterilisation numbers are limited,” said a forest official.

Dr Amit Dhyani, veterinary doctor at Chidiyapur Rescue Centre, added, “Monkeys caught between January to June are often pregnant and therefore, it is not possible to sterilise them since it is prohibited by law.”

Forest officials allege that catching monkeys is also a time-consuming and costly exercise. “We call monkey-catchers from Mathura, each of whom charges around Rs 500 per day. It is not easy to trap monkeys. Sometimes, the monkey-catcher does not get a single monkey despite several hours of trying. Once they sense that they are being trapped, monkeys immediately convey it to other monkeys who become extra cautious. Therefore, it is very difficult to justify the money spent in this activity,” claimed a senior IFS officer.

Title: Delhi violence to feature in RSS meet
Content:
NEW DELHI: The communal violence in Delhi and ongoing protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act are likely to dominate proceedings at the three-day annual meeting of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh ’s top decision-making body in Bengaluru, sources said on Sunday.

The annual meeting of Akhil Bharatiya Pratinidhi Sabha will be held from March 15 to 17. The body, which meets once a year to chart the Sangh’s course of action, is likely to ask the Delhi unit for a detailed presentation on the violence, a senior RSS member said.

Title: Police plan to get rid of traffic issues at 85 junctions in a month
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik city police have planned to get rid of traffic congestion at all the important junctions in a month. As part of this plan, the city police have appointed 85 officers. Each of these officers has adopted one traffic junction.

The police officer’s work is to observe the problems at his adopted junction and then work towards addressing those problems.

“The officers have already started their work. Problems at all the 85 important junctions, which have been shortlisted, would be addressed within a month,” said police commissioner Vishwas Nangare-Patil.

“Junctions in the city are facing a range of problems, which all lead to traffic chaos. At some places, the signals are not positioned well, elsewhere, illegal hawkers have occupied space or shopkeepers have made ramps on footpaths for personal use. Many junctions also have illegal parking problems. Posters and banners also only hinder the visibility,” added the top cop. “The police officers are working on all such small, but important, issues,” he said.

Decongestion of vehicular traffic at Dwarka, Shalimar and other such junctions is the result of the continuous work by the police officers concerned.

Police officers said they are also in touch with senior officers of the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) to put in place, or put right, all the necessary infrastructure for a free flow of traffic.

On the insistence of the city police, 65 students of NDMVP Samaj’s College of Architecture studied the traffic situation at the 85 major junctions in three slots of the day and noted down information based on various parameters, including the flow of traffic, condition of road dividers, locations of signals, signboards, rickshaw and bus stands, number of trees and every other things that was hampering the vehicular movement. The city police are working on the suggestions made by the students. At the same time, the police commissioner has instructed all the four unit heads of the city traffic branch to visit at least one junction every day.

Police officers check for various problems that may be obstructing traffic flow — vehicles stopping beyond the zebra lines, wrong-side driving, encroachments, traffic signal timings, signboards, condition of meridians, parking issues, etc.

After visiting one junction every day and observing the traffic there, the officer concerned reports in writing and also sends WhatsApp messages to his seniors about the immediate measures that can be taken to ease congestion, long-term plan, use of manpower and the communication to the department concerned to improve conditions.

Police officials said that everything is going as it has been planned. In a matter of the next couple of months, there would hardly be a junction which would have any traffic congestion related problem.

Title: 3 more Bharosa centres will come up in city
Content:
Hyderabad: Telangana police have planned to open 10 more Bharosa centres across the state, including three more in Hyderabad, at Old City, Rachakonda and Cyberabad.

“We are treating Bharosa centres as a society to provide support to women and child victims of sexual assault. Domestic violence cases will be diverted to Sakhi centres and NGOs,” said Swati Lakra, IG (law and order) and in-charge of women safety wing, Telangana, adding, “We have planned Bharosa centres in Warangal, Nalgonda, Suryapet, Khammam, Sangareddy and a few more districts.”

However, lack of funds could be a deterrent. “The Bharosa centres in districts will be taken up under corporate social responsibility projects by various companies. Five centres are expected to be ready and functioning by the end of this year. The the thrcentres in Hyderabad will take time,” said Lakra.

Title: Missing cop returns, says ‘all is well’
Content:
Tirupati: Rudravaram police sub-inspector Vishnu Narayana who forwarded a message in the police department WhatsApp group on Saturday night and went missing on Sunday morning, came back on the same day and held a press meet to declare ‘‘all is well”.

Sources said Narayana was reprimanded by Kurnool district SP for negligence of duties recently.

On Saturday night, Narayana sent a message in the WhatsApp group of police department saying ‘by the time you read this, I may be dead or alive.’ Allagadda DSP Pothu Raju saw the message and rushed to Narayana’s residence around Saturday midnight and tried to pacify him.

By Sunday morning, Narayana left home in his car. The SI’s family approached Rudravaram police. The SI then returned and held a press conference at the Allagadda police station on Sunday evening.

Narayana told the media,‘‘I wanted some relief from the stress and left. There are no issues between me and my seniors.”

Title: Rural police raid illegal gas refilling den in Igatpuri
Content:
Nashik: An illegal gas refilling centre was raided by Nashik rural police on Thursday in Igatpuri area of the city. Following the raid police have booked two people under sections of the Essential Commodities Act and Indian Penal Code (IPC).

According to police, they have been continuously working to eliminate illegal businesses across the district. “On Thursday, we got information about the centre where illegal activity of filling gas in vehicles is being carried out. Accordingly, a team was formed and it raided the den in Khalchi Peth village of Igatpuri,” he said.

“The team seized 17 gas cylinders, a machine used to refill the gas from cylinders to vehicles and one car — all amounting to Rs 1.04 lakh,” he added.

Police official also said necessary action is being taken against the concerned in-charge officer of the police station if any illegal businesses are found in their jurisdiction.

Title: Plan afoot to upgrade 12 govt middle schools
Content:
Coimbatore: Ministers and members of the legislative assembly from the district have proposed to upgrade 12 government middle schools to high schools.

MLAs from across the state had proposed to upgrade 179 government middle schools. In a recent communication, the director of school education had asked chief education officers to send details such as the number of students in Class VIII and high schools present in a five kilometres radius of the schools proposed to be upgraded, within Monday.

In Coimbatore district, minister for municipal administration S P Velumani and three legislators had sought upgradation of 12 government middle schools in Pollachi, Thondamuthur, Sulur, Mettupalayam and Valparai constituencies, and one in the Annur block.

“We have given the details of the middle schools eligible for upgradation. If there are other schools, we would send the details also,” chief education officer P Usha said.

Among other districts, the most number of proposals was from Tirupur, which has 57 schools in 12 constituencies.

Title: Suspected COVID-19 patient tests negative
Content: Nashik: A 26-year-old patient who was rushed to the isolation ward of the Nashik civil hospital in a suspected coronavirus case has tested negative, district collector Suraj Mandhare confirmed on Sunday.The district administration has, however, appealed to all citizens, especially those who have recently travelled abroad, to take cognizance of the symptoms and immediately contact the nearest public health centre if they observe any symptoms of the virus.The suspect had returned to Mumbai from Italy on February 26. From Mumbai, he travelled to Nashik by a sleeper bus.Having returned from an affected country, medical officers in the city visited the patient on February 27 and 28. Upon examining, they did not notice any cold, fever, cough or breathlessness.However, on February 29, the patient complained of cold and breathlessness, following which he was immediately admitted to the civil hospital. Samples of his throat swab were sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune for investigation.The report of the throat swab arrived on Sunday and the patient was tested negative.

Title: Utilise rights in Constitution to emerge as a force, urges Women’s Commission
Content:
Vijayawada: Chairperson of the Andhra Pradesh Commission for Women Vasireddy Padma on Sunday flagged off a power walk from the Swaraj Maidan (PWD grounds) ahead of International Women’s Day on March 8. The state government, Padma said, is giving top priority to women’s welfare. “Every woman should utilise the rights provided by the Constitution and emerge as a power,” the chairperson said.

Padma added that, “Unconditional humanity is needed for the welfare of women. Chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy is committed to the safety of women. The Disha Act is a landmark legislation and many states are trying to implement similar Acts.”

Padma said that the commission is gearing up to conduct International Women’s Day on a large scale in order to educate women on their rights. “Gender-based discrimination is a crime. But still women face it in many forms. Women can perform better if they are given a chance and we should think in this direction,” she said.

Special officer for the Disha Act Kritika Shukla said that women have the right to question odds against them. She added that the Disha Act will instil confidence in women.

Krishna district collector A Mohammed Imtiaz said that women comprise 50 per cent of the population and can advance in their fields with encouragement.

The rally extended till Tummalapalli Kalakshetram in the city. The commission will also conduct power walks in Rajahmundry, Kurnool and Vishakapatnam.

In Tirupati, faculty members and female students of Sri Padmavathi Mahila Viswa Vidyalayam (SPMVV) held a power walk on Sunday.

The walk was named ‘Our space — our right’ to indicate that women have the right to walk in any place at any time and without fear. Vice-chancellor D Jamuna launched the walk by flagging it off from the campus. She called upon men and women to join hands in wiping out gender inequality, pointing out that dominance by males cannot be an impediment to women’s empowerment. Prof Jamuna also recalled the varsity’s motto of ensuring equal opportunities to women through education and empowerment.

Title: Woman robbed of gold chain worth Rs 30,000
Content:
Nashik: The Panchavati police have registered a case against an unidentified person for allegedly snatching a gold chain worth Rs 30,000 on Friday. The incident took place in the Janta Raja Colony of the Panchavati area at around 8 pm.

According to police, the 54-year-old complainant, a resident of Janta Raja Colony, had been to a weekly market in Hanuman Wadi on Friday evening when an unidentified biker approached her, snatched her chain and fled from the spot.

The woman told police that she was returning from the market and was passing by a private hospital in her locality when the suspect passed by. He went a little further and stopped. Then he took a U turn and began riding towards her. Once he came too close to the woman, he snatched her chain and fled.

The woman told police that before she could understand anything and ask for help, the suspect had disappeared in thin air. She said that the gold chain was worth Rs 30,000. “It also had a gold pendant attached to it,” the woman told police.

The Panchavati police said that they have registered an offence of robbery under section 394 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) against the unidentified suspect.

Police said that the woman was not able to provide any specific details of the bike or its registration number. Nonetheless, they would try to trace the suspect by checking if they could get any CCTV footage in and around the Janta Raja Colony area.

Title: Another spoonbill found trapped in net at Osman Sagar, lark saved
Content: HYDERABAD: While animal rescue teams are still tracking the spoonbill bird which was spotted with a plastic rope from a fishing net tangled around its beak at Osman Sagar lake a fortnight ago, bird watchers and animal activists found another spoonbill and a lark , trapped in discarded fishing nets in the same lake.Wildlife rescue teams are now tracking the two spoonbills and were able to rescue the lark while cleaning the lake on Sunday morning.“We found a lark this morning during a lake clean-up drive. The bird was trapped in a fishing net and was struggling to free itself from it. We gave the bird some water to drink as it was exhausted from trying to escape from the net,” said M Srinivas, a photographer and member of Hyderabad Birding Pals.The spoonbills are still struggling with the plastic ropes tangled around their beaks. “We identified the different spoonbills by the colour of plastic ropes around their beaks,” said Pradeep Nair, founder of Animal Warriors India (AWI). Nair said that the spoonbill spotted earlier had managed to survive as it was still able to eat by partially opening its beak.“These nets pose a threat to all the species that depend on lakes. This is happening despite us cleaning the lake regularly and fishing out leftover fishing gear from it,” said Nair.After AWI recently reached out to the forest department asking them to sensitize the fishing community about the dangers of discarded fishing gear, forest department officials said that they have alerted the concerned department. “We have informed the concerned authority as lakes do not come under our jurisdiction,” said senior forest department official, A Shankaran.

Title: Over 44k benefit from doorstep pension delivery in a single day
Content:
Vijayawada: Ward volunteers with the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation ( VMC ) distributed around 82 per cent of over 54,000 pensions in the city on Sunday. The door-to-door pension distribution process was overseen by the urban community development (UCD) wing of the civic body.

Genuine beneficiaries had been identified under the Navasakam survey and doorstep disbursal of pension was started in February this year.

Pensioners expressed satisfaction at the door-to-door pension distribution process. “Receiving pension was a big task for us earlier. Being physically-challenged, I used to stand for more than five hours in a long queue to get pension. But things changed recently. Volunteers are coming to our doorstep and distributing cash after taking our biometric details. We are happy with this process,” said M Nagamani, a pensioner residing at Ajith Singh Nagar.

VMC commissioner V Prasanna Venkatesh inspected the door-to-door pension distribution process in a few wards in the city and interacted with pensioners. Venkatesh also directed volunteers to complete the distribution process by Monday evening.

Several pensioners who were excluded after the Navasakam survey was held to identify beneficiaries have requested the civic body to speed up its verification process and re-issue pensions.

The state government had launched the village and ward volunteer system to deliver services to the doorstep of beneficiaries.

Title: Corpn officials cause delay in clearing UGD blocks
Content:
Trichy: Corporation officials are holding the city hostage to overflowing sewage and stinky roads as they are causing delays to clear underground drainage (UGD) blocks citing paperwork delay. Despite having digital tools, junior officials have been told to submit a written paper request to senior officials for clearing UGD blocks, and as a result road are overflowing with sewage for days.

Usually, junior engineers on receiving a complaint of sewage block will mobilise a sewer jetting machine to clear the block. After the civic body suspended a couple of engineers last month over complaints of manual scavenging, the corporation orally instructed junior engineers to alert the respective zone assistant commissioner in writing before clearing the blocks.

The senior officials will subsequently forward the request to sanitary officers and inspectors who will accompany them to the spot. Sanitary workers were told to use safety gears and not to venture inside the manholes. Though the restrictions to prevent manual scavenging were welcomed, involving paperwork to clear the blocks has made the city roads stink.

For the last two days, sewage has been overflowing on Williams road and Reynolds road without any solution. “Submitting a written request is a time-consuming process. Sanitary officers could have been told to supervise the block removal process to put a check on manual scavenging,” an official source said. Engineers say that if assistant commissioners are not available immediately, it may delay the work further as per the order. “Till we clear the sewer block in the presence of senior officials, sewage overflow will persist,” the official added.

However, corporation commissioner S Sivasubramanian said that the existing machinery with the corporation is adequate to clear the sewer blocks while assistant commissioners are always available to oversee cleaning works.

“The order to clean sewer block in the presence of assistant commissioners was only to ensure the safety of workers involved. UGD block is due to public error, people should realise the risk associated in cleaning the blocks and use UGD responsibly by not dumping napkins in the toilets,” Sivasubramanian told TOI.

Title: Yoga festival begins at Parmarth Niketan
Content:
Rishikesh: The annual International Yoga Festival held at Parmarth Niketan in Rishikesh began on Sunday. A communique from the ashram said that this year, more than 900 participants from 56 nations are attending the week-long event.

A number of sessions will be held during the course of the week on topics ranging from yoga asanas, sound healing, Ayurveda, Reiki, meditation, eastern philosophy and medicine to ancient Indian philosophy and Vedanta.

The festival was inaugurated by Union minister of state for tourism, Prahlad Singh Patel along with state Ayush minister Harak Singh Rawat and assembly speaker Prem Chand Aggarwal.

Among the experts who will be taking sessions during the festival include Gurmukh Kaur Khalsa, Rujuta Diwaker, Smita Naram, Kia Miller, Janet Attwood, Stewart Gilchrest, Anand Mehrotra, Anandra George, Joanna Faso, Sianna Sherman, and Katie B Happyy.

Title: CRPF told to reinstate personnel who was removed from service
Content:
Madurai: Granting relief to a CRPF personnel who was removed from service for failing to open fire during a militant attack in Manipur in 2002 where seven CRPF personnel were killed, Madras high court observed that since the petitioner was alive on the spot, it cannot be stated that he did not retaliate during the attack.

The petitioner, S Sarin Singh, joined CRPF as a constable at the Avadi training centre in Chennai in 1994. In 2002, he was posted to Manipur where the Army and other security forces were fighting insurgency. On November 20, 2002, when the petitioner was assigned the duty for providing protection to National Hydroelectric Power Corporation (NHPC) officers in a road opening party, there was an attack by the militants. When the petitioner was taking position to retaliate, he fell into a 12-foot ditch and became unconscious. Following the incident, he was suspended from service and a charge memo was issued to him on the ground that he had not opened fire.

Subsequently, after an inquiry, the petitioner was removed from service in 2003. Though the petitioner preferred an appeal and review before the authorities, the same were rejected. Hence, the petitioner moved the Madurai bench of the Madras high court in 2014, seeking to quash these orders and reinstate him back into service with all consequential attendant service and monetary benefits.
