It was the grievance of the petitioner that the inquiry was conducted in a preconceived manner only to indicate that he had not opened fire at the militants and was negligent in his duty.

The counsel appearing for the authorities stated that one platoon consisting of three sections was on duty on the road opening party. He stated that the first section was ambushed and attacked by the underground militants. The petitioner, who was leading the second section, was very close to the incident spot and did not fire a single round to prevent the insurgents from taking away the arms and ammunitions of the deceased personnel. Instead, he had hidden in a safe place. Due to his inaction and cowardice, the force had to lose precious lives of seven personnel and huge quantity of arms and ammunitions.

He noted that during the inquiry, it was established that despite the orders of the Section Commander concerned to open fire on the militants and his statement that he had fallen into a ditch and became unconscious and sustained injury was found baseless. He further stated that as per the statements of witnesses in the inquiry, the petitioner was in good health condition and he reported his shoulder problem only on December 24, 2002 and sought permission to leave the headquarters for treatment only on January 3, 2003. Accordingly, he was granted 15 days’ leave. Justice J Nisha Banu rejected the contention of the authorities that the petitioner has shown inaction and exhibited cowardice without any evidence. The judge observed that the perusal of record shows that the petitioner was available on the spot and whether he had taken effort to retaliate cannot be decided by the authorities.

“It is also not in dispute that the petitioner became unconscious on the date of occurrence and he had taken treatment due to the injury in his left shoulder and there is no explanation by the authorities to show that the injury sustained by the petitioner was not on account of the alleged attack of the militants,” observed the judge.

Taking cognizance of the fact that the petitioner has put in eight years of service in the force, the judge observed that the findings of the inquiry are based on surmises without any evidence. Hence, the judge set aside the orders passed by the authorities and directed to reinstate the petitioner with all consequential service and monetary benefits, within 12 weeks.

Title: In Guntur, Dalits and minorities come together to oppose CAA
Content:
WE, THE PEOPLE: A huge crowd registered its protest against CAA at the BR Stadium in Guntur on Sunday

Guntur: YSRC MLA Mohammed Mustafa said chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy has promised to move a resolution against Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and National Register of Citizen ( NRC ) in the budget session of the assembly.

While addressing a public meeting organized by Jamiath-Ulema-e-Hind along with various SC, ST organisations at BR Stadium, Mustafa said he was ready to quit the assembly if the resolution was not passed in the assembly.

Mustafa said Muslims in AP need not worry about NRC and CAA as long as Jagan is the chief minister.

Former minister Dokka Manikyavaraprasad said Shaheen Baagh protest is courageous attempt to protect the Indian Constitution. He said women were fighting to uphold rights of minorities, dalits, tribals and weaker sections of the country. He said protests against CAA, NPR and NRC were aimed at uniting all sections of society to defeat divisive forces.

Dokka said CAA was not only discriminatory to the Muslims but the entire poor sections of the country. Dokka said it was high-time people from SC, ST and minority communities got united to fight the fascist policies of the Centre.

He said the Constitution should be the guiding lamp for the enactment of any laws in India. “We are demanding the Centre to follow the Constitution. CAA, NPR and NRC are targeting not only the minorities but the poor dalits, tribals and weaker sections of society,” said Dokka.

APCC working president Mastan Vali warned the BJP leadership of serious consequences if it wanted to go ahead with CAA.

Guntur East legislator Maddali Giridhar criticized BJP’s policies. He said people were living harmoniously till BJP came into power. He said the BJP leadership sowed seeds of fear in the country in the name of CAA, NPR and NRC. He said that the chief minister had made it clear that YSRC would not support NRC in the state and was willing to move a resolution in the assembly against the CAA and NPR.

YSRC leader and agriculture market committee chairman Yesurathnam said that dalits and weaker sections of society were with Muslims and they would not allow BJP to crush the Constitution.

TDP leader Naseer Ahmed, Jana Sena leader Zia-ur-Rehman, Mala Mahanadu leader Mallela Venkatrao and BC leader Y Koteswara Rao addressed the gathering.

Title: RTI: Municipalities run by in-charge officers for yrs
Content:
Trichy: Pudukottai may soon be declared a special grade municipality going by the revenue and rate of development it has, but the selection grade municipality is still to have a full-time commissioner, being run only by in-charge officer for over seven years now.

This is not the only civic body run by in-charge officers, as the state has a total 50 others facing the similar fate. “A total of 50 of the 121 municipalities in the state remain headless managed only by in-charge officers for years together,” said V P Sankar, former ward councillor of Manapparai Municipality.

The revelation came from commissioner of municipal administration (CMA) in a reply to an RTI query. When urban local bodies are yet to go to polls, decision making is largely affected in these local bodies as it being run by in-charge officers, he said. Revenue of the local body is affected by the same, said former local body representatives.

“For instance, a few shops constructed by the municipality park road has been shut over the last six months in Manapparai. The in-charge commissioner has been delaying tender to allocate shops which could have earned revenue to the municipality all these months,” Sankar said.

In most municipalities, manager should ideally be made the in-charge commissioner. However, municipal engineers have been given the responsibility as it is easy for the local politicians to obtain tender allocations, says K Muhamed Hussain, CPI town secretary, Trichy.

“We can approach engineers for emergency issues related to roads, street lights and drinking water supply. Engineers are responsible for about half field work and in-charge commissioner is an additional burden to them which often delays decision making,” he said.

Saying that nepotism has been rampant in such municipalities, Ibrahim Babu, former councilor of the Pudukkottai municipality, said that there was rule that close relatives of councillors should not get tender allocations. “But that rule has been thrown to the air,” he said.

Acknowledging that there are the vacant posts of commissioners in municipalities across state, commissioner of municipal administration K Baskaran said that appointments would be made soon to the vacant posts.

There are certain routine steps that needs to be followed while making appointment. Many steps should to be followed in the selection of officers and no pending vigilance inquiry is one of the main requisite, he said. Necessary steps are being taken to fill the posts for smooth administration, he added.

Title: MBA students pay visit to Patchamalai
Content:
Trichy: Visiting Patchamalai was a refreshing experience for 40 MBA students from colleges in Trichy. Among them, many were visiting Patchamalai for the first time.

Students from MAM Business School and MAM College of Engineering and Technology, Trichy were on a field visit to Patchamalai on Saturday. Accompanied by members of Thaneer, a city-based voluntary organisation, they learned livelihood opportunities of people in the hill station.

While greenery is maintained through the year, Patchamalai forest, which is about 90 km from Trichy city, attracts large butterfly population making it an ideal place for trekking expedition.

Being the only place in Trichy district having scope for trekking, Patchamalai has been hosting nature enthusiasts. Top Sengattupatti in Patchamalai is developed as an eco-tourism destination where people from the local tribal community, tree top houses and a couple of dormitories to host nature enthusiast.

Finding drinking water in the hill station much tastier that what is available in Trichy city, S Najma, a member from MAM B School who accompanied the students, said that it was a refreshing experience away from city life.

“We found agriculture being the primary occupation of people living in the hillock where Tapioca is widely cultivated. However, it was unusual for us to find some people also cultivating paddy, said Praveen S, a first year student of MAM B School.

Secretary, Thaneer, K C Neelamagam said that students were made to throw about 150 seed balls around Mangalam waterfalls. “They also joined us in collecting plastic waste left behind by tourists. They were sensitized on not littering forests by explaining its ill effects,” said Neelamegam.

Title: No need to fear coronavirus if you do yoga: Yogi
Content:
yyyyyyyyyy

Rishikesh: Uttar Pradesh chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Sunday said that deadly diseases like coronavirus can be eliminated by regularly practising yoga Inaugurating the week-long International Yog Festival in Rishikesh, Yogi said that one who remains both mentally and physically fit through yoga need not fear diseases like coronavirus. “The Indian tradition needs to be understood more deeply as it has tremendous things to offer through yoga. The world is waging a war against mental and physical illnesses. If these are cured, then no one will suffer from blood pressure, heart attack, kidney failure, liver failure or even coronavirus for that matter,” he added.The UP CM claimed that Japanese encephalitis has gone down by 60% and mortality due to it dipped by 90% in the last two years. He said, “For the past 40 years, I have noticed that around 1,500 children of ages 1 to 15 die during the monsoon season due to encephalitis. Through my fight against the disease in Gorakhpur and eastern UP for the past 25 years, I have come to the conclusion that prevention is the only cure in such cases.” He added that the central government’s ‘Swachh Bharat’ mission has helped people get easy access to clean drinking water thereby helping in controlling the disease.Elaborating on the health benefits of yoga, Yogi said, “The very first training given to space travellers is certain yogic kriyas along with pranayama to stay fit. This is a well-kept secret.”

Title: Veda Shastra Agama Vidwat Sadas ends
Content:
Tirupati: The six-day long 28th Akhila Veda Shastra Agama Vidwat Sadas held at the SV Veda Vignana Peetham at Dharmagiri in Tirumala concluded on a grand note on Sunday.

In his keynote address, executive and administrative officer of Sringeri Peetham, Gouri Shankar, said irrespective of regions and states, the language of ‘dharma’ has united people for centuries.

Gouri Shankar complimented the TTD for organising the vedic sadas over the past several. “Gathering of over 700 scholars on one platform is a commendable task. I wish all the students who are undergoing Vedic education will promote and disseminate Vedic knowledge to future generations,” he said.

As part of the sadas, the ‘chaturveda yagam’ concluded in the veda pathashala. Sri Kuppa Rama Gopala Somayaji and Kalpakamba Somasthini carried out the yaga as a ‘dampati’.

Of the 727 students from across India who had applied for the event, 327 took part, of which 270 passed the exam.

Title: Bengaluru: Man kills porcupine, makes video; held
Content:
Manjunath Biryalhissa

BENGALURU: Killing an Indian porcupine and inviting his TikTok followers to view it proved costly for a 25-year-old man from Kalaburagi. Forest department officials tracked him down and arrested him on Sunday morning.

Manjunath Biryalhissa, a resident of Jewargi taluk, was famous for his various TikTok videos and for lifting heavy stones in his village and neighbouring areas.

According to forest officials, on Friday, Manjunath and his friends caught a porcupine in Sindagi range, Vijayapura and stoned it to death. Later, they fried and cooked it. Manjunath then made an 18-second video, where he spoke about the porcupine hunt and slaughter, besides inviting his followers to like the video and join him in the feast.

The video was on TikTok and Facebook. Wildlife activists who found the video alerted forest department officials.

“Porcupine comes under schedule four of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 . Keeping this video as evidence we were able to trace him through his Facebook account, where he had shared details of his hometown,” said forest officials. tnn

Title: Bengaluru sent 2nd highest number of students abroad in 2019, show education firm data
Content: BENGALURU: Bengaluru saw the second-largest number of students going to foreign universities in 2019 and the average age of those opting to study abroad was 23.7 years, show data from an education consultancy firm.The country’s startup capital came second to Hyderabad among metros which saw students going overseas to study. Data analysis of 1.1 lakh students registered on Mumbai-based online platform Yocket showed around 9 per cent were from Bengaluru. Mumbai, Pune and Chennai are the other cities among the top five.Yocket, which has been seeing registrations since 2015, claimed over three lakh students from India joined various universities abroad every year, of which Karnataka was sending 20,000-30,000.According to the consultant, US is the most sought-after destination for Bengalureans, followed by Canada and Germany. The popular courses are computer science, electrical, data science and mechanical & management information systems (MIS). Interestingly, at 23 years 7 months, the average age of Bengalureans going for further studies is highest among the metros. The youngest is from Ahmedabad and Mumbai at 21.9 and 21.1 years, respectively.“This means Bengalureans work for some time before opting for post-graduation. It’s important to note that a huge chunk of these students isn’t originally from Bengaluru, but moved to the city for studies and work. Several times, professionals who have been abroad for work are aware of the quality of the universities there and want to pursue education. With many companies reducing offsite opportunities, people are also joining foreign universities to go abroad,” said Tumul Buch, co-founder, Yocket.Interestingly, Bengalureans were the best performers when it came to screening tests. The average marks of candidates registered on Yocket in TOEFL was highest among Bengalurueans (104). In GRE quant, Bengaluru was on top (164). The city came second in GRE verbal after Kolkata and New Delhi, which shared the same rank.As per the platform, 8.1% of students nationally had a fully funded scholarship to finance their study and stay in the US. Another 11% had partial scholarships. Around 52% took an education loan, while others managed through scholarships or self-funding or a combination of both.“The number of students pursuing under-graduate programmes from Bengaluru is also on the rise. There is also a large number of students who hold an American passport. Many of the parents are US returnees and want their children to have quality education abroad,” Tumul added.

Title: Bengaluru: BWSSB takes Indian Institute of Science help to improve supply network
Content: BENGALURU: Four technical committees headed by professors from the Indian Institute of Science and with Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board engineers as members, will work on finding solutions to improve the water supply network and ensure efficient wastewater treatment in the city.The committees will focus on electrical system improvement and upgradation, wastewater system management and upgradation, hydraulics and distribution system improvement and upgradation and sensing, communications and data system. Each will focus on one area of improvement or upgradation, said BWSSB chairman Tushar Girinath.“These committees will work as the think tanks for BWSSB,” said Girinath. Each committee will be headed by a senior IISc professor while it will have four BWSSB engineers or assistant engineers as members. IISc is currently monitoring consumption and unaccounted for water in several areas of south Bengaluru.MS Mohan Kumar, department of civil engineering, IISc and head of hydraulics and distribution system improvement and upgradation technical committee, said there is inequity in water supply in the city; there is a huge difference between the amount of water supplied and consumed. “A lot of energy is also spent due to leakages and blocks in the transmission system,” he said at an event recently.

Title: BBMP identifies new locations for 24/7 night shelters in Bengaluru
Content: At present, the city has only nine functional night shelters, while work orders for another eight have been... Read More BENGALURU: Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP), which has been struggling to put in place adequate night shelters for the city’s homeless, has identified a number of new locations to set them up. As per directions by the Supreme Court — which mandate one shelter for every 1 lakh people — Bengaluru needs at least 120. However, at present, the city has only nine functional night shelters, while work orders for another eight have been issued. On February 23, mayor M Goutham Kumar tweeted that the Palike has identified five spots, two near Upparpet police station and three near Kumbargundi. He said these five additional shelters will be set up soon and will cater to about 400 people. “We have 14 facilities where night shelters can easily be operated and the zones which have been identified are Bommanahalli, Dasarahalli and Yelahanka,” said SG Raveendra, special commissioner (welfare). BBMP will soon prepare a detailed project report, he added. The shelters — which will be operational 24/7 — will have separate space for men, women as well as transgenders. One toilet will be constructed for 10 people. “At the nine existing shelters, 350 people are being helped. They have a floating population of 250,” a BBMP official said. The facilities will be equipped with CCTVs and drinking water. Night shelters will be monitored by the joint commissioner, health officer, chief engineer, local councillor and an NGO, Raveendra said, adding that a few NGOs have been working towards rescuing the homeless and their involvement would help the Palike. “We want to ensure that all the NGOs are paid regularly without any financial glitch,” he said. While National Urban Livelihood Mission will release the required funds, BBMP will be the implementing agency.

Title: Be positive in times of diminishing jobs, economic slump, says CIC
Content:
Trichy: It is vital for youngsters to have a balanced life by consciously taking decisions to keep an alternative career plan, said state chief information commissioner R Rajagopal.

He was addressing students as part of the 18th graduation day at M I E T Engineering College on Sunday. He asked the students to remain positive towards future amidst all the negativity around with respect to the diminishing jobs and economic slowdown.

Asking students to focus on upgrading their knowledge with the recent developments in robotics and artificial intelligence he stressed on acquiring knowledge and asked the students to make it a habit. He also asked young graduates to develop interest in research and innovation towards entrepreneurship instead of being job seekers. Rajagopal conferred degrees to 277 engineers and management students. This includes 47 post-graduate students and 230 under-graduates. A total of six branch toppers of the college were awarded with a gold coin and a shield. K Pradeepa, department of management studies, secured Anna University twentieth rank.

Department of computer science and engineering bagged the Justice Fakkir Mohamed rolling shield, which was awarded for obtaining the topmost results in the university examinations among all the branches. A Mohamed Yunus, Chairman, MIET Engineering College, gave away the award. Principal A Naveen Sait was present. TNN

Title: An enterprise with a vision: A school for the blind
Content:
Hyderabad: Driven by his vision to launch a residential school that provides free education to visually-impaired children , Alampur Saibaba Goud approached many families requesting them to send their wards to his new institute. This was in 1992, and it was difficult to convince people.

“I had to go door-to-door to convince family members to send their visually-impaired children to our school,” says Goud, the founder-chairman of Devnaar Foundation for the Blind. “When I started the school, I faced a lot of resistance from the society. For the first six years, I struggled to provide free residential education to all the students.”

Goud pooled in a few lakh rupees, a huge amount then, from his private practice as an ophthalmologist to launch the school. The Devnaar School for the Blind in Begumpet, which began with only four students 28 years ago, now has 550 students. It was India’s first such school then.

Now, among other facilities, the school boasts of a science lab with 3D models explaining anatomy and a modern computer lab. Recently, Goud established an audio-visual studio at a cost of Rs20 lakh, where teachers record their classes that can be accessed by students any time.

“The schoolteachers ensure that we even learn how the light reflects and how an image is developed using 3D models,” said D Chintu, a Class X student. The school also has its own printing press that publishes books in Braille and a library that houses Braille books of Nancy Drew and Harry Potter among others by famous authors.

From chartered accountants to successful entrepreneurs, the school has a large alumni network which now helps him expand his operations. Entrepreneur Srikanth Bolla, founder and CEO of Bollant Industries (Hyderabad), which has an annual turnover of Rs82 crore, is one of the many alumni of this School.

In 2009, Goud was awarded with Padma Shri in medicine. The school has 80 faculty members, many of whom are children who study there. “Nineteen years ago, I was looking for a school for my son, who is visually-impaired and has intellectual disability,” said G Hogla, an English teacher at the school. “Devnaar not only provided free education to my son, but also employed me as a teacher.”

Goud now envisions to launch a degree college for visually-impaired students.

Title: Ease of Living Index assessment: Madurai gets 1.35L citizens’ feedback
Content:
Madurai: As many as 1.35 lakh people from Madurai city have responded to the questions related to various parameters to assess the quality of life in the city as part of the citizen perception survey conducted by the ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA). The Ease of Living Index rankings will be released by the ministry based on the feedback.

The survey was conducted online between February 1 and 29. In total 114 cities, including 100 smart cities took part in the survey. With 1.35 lakh feedbacks, Madurai has secured 3rd spot among the cities in terms of number of participation in the country.

Among 10 cities in the state, Madurai finished second, next to Salem where 1.42 lakh people rendered their response. Coimbatore finished distant third with close to 97,000 feedbacks. Among the Indian cities, Indore secured the first spot with 1.45 lakh respondents, which was followed by Salem and Madurai.

“Madurai was given 10,615 feedbacks as target, but due to the elaborate steps taken by the corporation officials, we were able to reach out to more people to contribute to the survey. The number achieved by the city is more than 12 times of the target,” an official from Madurai Corporation said.

A higher official from the corporation said that they reached out to people through media and newspapers, sensitisations on the sidelines of various activities organized by the corporation and promoting it in functions through in February. They also stuck to the guidelines of the ministry, which insisted on to carryout various information education communication (IEC) activities.

The survey included 24 simple questions on the ease of living in the city. The survey was aimed at capturing the quality of city life based on several parameters such as governance, healthcare, education, security, economy, pollution, water supply, transport, power, housing, wastewater and solid waste management among others.

Officials said that the overwhelming participation of residents from Madurai and Salem helped the state to be on top of list. Ten cities in the state were given a total target of 1,10,096 feedback, but 7.17 lakh people responded, which is 6.5 times higher than the target. Tamil Nadu was followed by Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh and Gujarat in terms of number of feedback.

Title: Coronavirus in Bangalore: Covid-19 outbreak may hit KIA global traffic
Content: BENGALURU: The coronavirus outbreak is expected to have an impact on the growth of international passenger traffic at Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) this year.Three of the top four international destinations from KIA — Singapore, Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok — are in countries reporting a high number of confirmed cases. The fourth destination, that is unaffected till now, is Dubai.Last week, International Air Transport Association stated airlines’ losses due to coronavirus will run into $30 billion.Officials of Bangalore International Airport Limited (BIAL), the operator of KIA, pointed out that passengers have now become ‘cautious about non-essential travel’ and that the coronavirus situation will affect “international traffic, in general, and particularly on Asian markets”. “It is difficult to, however, quantify the impact at this point,” BIAL said.“The spread of Covid-19 virus has had an impact on the growth of international travel. A few Indian carriers have temporarily suspended flights to China, Hong Kong and the Asian region. The virus has made passengers travelling to other southeast Asian countries, many of which have reported cases, cautious about non-essential travel, leading to lighter demand for travel to popular tourist destinations. The situation is evolving and BIAL is monitoring this on a month-by-month basis,” said a BIAL spokesperson.Since January 20, 34,490 passengers have been screened at KIA. Of them, 369 came to Bengaluru from Covid-19-affected countries. Of them, 269 are under home isolation and surveillance.All 198 samples tested for the infection from Karnataka have been found to be negative. Ninty-six passengers have, meanwhile, completed 28 days of observation.While airport authorities have predicted that KIA will record a growth of about 8.9% in international air traffic movements in FY 2019-20, based on the new routes announced and market conditions, it expects about 6-7% growth in international ATMs through FY 2020-21.As of February 25, China continues to be the worst affected with more than 78,497 confirmed COVID-19 cases, followed by South Korea (1,767). The number of confirmed cases on board the Diamond Princess cruise ship has jumped to 705. Italy and Iran have also reported a rise in the number of confirmed cases.

Title: Another box washes up near Vettaikaraniruppu
Content:
Trichy: The Coastal Security Group (CSG) recovered a wooden box containing seashell powder that washed up near Vettaikaraniruppu fishing belt in Nagapattinam district on Sunday morning. As this is the second box of its kind being recovered in a week, police launched an investigation to find out what the powder is meant for and how it washed up near Vettaikaraniruppu.

The 3x2-foot size box was found on the shore of Sallikulam near Vettaikarniruppu, by the fishermen who alerted Coastal Security Group. A team headed by inspector P Raja arrived at spot and recovered the box.

The team found that the wooden box with 12 chambers contained white powder and a heroin-like white powder made of a seashell, CSG sources said, adding that the substance was handed over to customs department A similar box containing sea shell powder washed ashore at Seruthur coast near Velankanni in Nagapattinam on February 24 too.

In another development, police arrested three people and seized 220 kilograms of ganja, 40 litres of petrol and 5 litres of crude oil from them as they tried to smuggle it near Athirampattinam in Thanjavur district. The arrested are Maravakottai Venkatraman, Kumar and Murugesan, police said. The ganja haul came when police conducted a check Pattukottai in Thanjavur district, on information that some miscreants were carrying ganja from a house located at NGO Colony in Pattukottai. They learnt that the ganja was being taken to Athirampattinam on Saturday evening.

The police rushed to spot and found the ganja and fuel stacked on a boat anchored along mangrove. Police seized them and launched an investigation to see if the narcotic was meant to be taken to Sri Lanka.

Title: Power woes to be redressed at local level
Content:
Panaji: After issues revolving around erroneous billing, disconnection notices and requests for part payment of bills were coming directly to the chief electrical engineer , with consumers from Vasco and South Goa visiting the head office in Panaji, the electricity department has instructed its executive engineers to resolve matters at their level.

Long-pending grievances related to power supply, billing, streetlights as well as solar power-related issues will now be directly redressed by the concerned executive engineer on the third Wednesday of each month between 10 am and 12:30 pm, the department has stated.

“Consumers are free to approach the electricity department any day with grievances. Only in cases of long-pending grievances, the third Wednesday of the month has been fixed,”an official said, adding, “The EEs are expected to be present in office without fail on these days. This initiative was brought in to effectively resolve their grievances in the shortest time possible, and save consumers the trouble of travelling long distances.”

Title: TRAI plans for optical fibre infra in housing complexes through building code
Content:
TRAI chief R S Sharma (centre) at the Asia Economic Dialogue on Sunday

Pune: In future, large housing complexes will have an apt optical fibre infrastructure for better mobile connectivity.

Chairman of Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI) R S Sharma said his organization is in discussion with the urban development ministry on including such a provision in the National Building Code which lays down the guidelines for the regulation of building construction activity across the country.

Speaking at the Asia Economic Dialogue on Sunday, Sharma identified people’s reluctance and misgivings about cellphone towers and the absence of inbuilt optical fibre infrastructure in large housing societies as some of the issues contributing to the deteriorating quality of service and call drop problems faced by the telecom service users.

He said, “People do not want (mobile communication) towers, but they want connectivity. There is huge misgiving about cellphone towers causing cancer. Then, there is in building infrastructure. In large complexes, you can’t provide connectivity only through towers. Just like these complexes have infrastructure for electricity, water and gas distribution, you need to have similar infrastructure for optical fibre. We are discussing this with the ministry so that a provision is included in the National Building Code.”

Sharma said TRAI had tried introducing penalty to telecom service providers for each call drop and the law was upheld by the high court, but quashed by the Supreme Court. “We are since focusing on quality service testing, but it has a threshold and we are continuing to punish the service providers. Telecom companies are citing voice-free services to question to the extent they can be punished for free service. This may not be correct as they are cross-subsidizing,” he added.

He said, “People are not allowing companies to lay optical fibre over issues like right of way. A one-km opitcal fibre wire costs Rs 50,000, but it costs Rs1 crore in Mumbai. We hope things will get better soon.”

UPI goes international

National Payments Corporation of India’s (NPCI) MD and CEO Dilip Asbe said the NPCI was trying to see whether its Unified Payments Interface (UPI) can be made international. “As we speak, the first international transaction using an UPI app is being done in Singapore,” he told the audience. “Anybody can scan the QR code put up in Singapore merchant and pay using the vMAP,” he added.

The NPCI was set up as a financial technology company by the RBI and other banks. It has been working on architecture built on fully open source technology and it was now doing a majority of the transactions in India.

“Today, 1,400 banks as customers can receive direct benefit transfer money and 1,200 banks as customers are using the RuPay cards. In fact, Rupay has a one-third market share in terms of point of sale and e-commerce transactions. We want to make it number 1 in terms of volumes and values.”

They are working on real-time payments, having launched the IMPS in 2010 and after an initial period of trial, almost $30 billion are now being transacted every month using IMPS, he said. “The advent of smartphones spurred us to launch UPI in 2016 and today UPI is doing 30 billion transactions on a monthly basis,” he added.

Data security & privacy

TRAI chairman R S Sharma said that data security and privacy had always been a top priority for Aadhaar card system. Privacy has been ensured from the very design of the 12-digit Aadhaar number which is random and difficult in terms of doing any profiling. Highest level of security is deployed for data protection and it is ensure that no data is kept in an unencrypted form, he said.

Title: Cong’s Kedarnath MLA on ‘cycle yatra’ to Gairsain
Content: Dehradun: Manoj Rawat, the Congress MLA from Kedarnath , started a ‘cycle yatra’ from his constituency to Gairsain on Sunday. The MLA will ride almost 150 km and will meet locals during the journey to make them aware of what he calls “anti-people policies of the BJP government in the state.”Talking to TOI, Rawat said that the government is not at all serious to make Gairsain the capital of the hill state. “While the other states hold assembly session for a month, we are holding the session for barely four days. The government is not ready to debate in the assembly as this will reveal its poor record of development and casual approach towards administrative work,” Rawat said, adding that lack of facilities in hills is making people migrate to plains “to the extent that it seems that entire state will shift to plains in the years to come.”The MLA will conclude the 150-km journey from Kedarnath to Gairsain in three days.Meanwhile, senior Congress leaders staged a day-long dharna against the state government’s policies at Gandhi Park in Dehradun on Sunday. The protest was led by state party president Pritam Singh who said, “The unemployment rate is at an all-time high. The government is unable to check cheating in examinations. Scams have become synonymous with the state. Inflation is at an all-time high and every essential commodity is getting costlier. People should remove this government at the earliest.”

Title: Good things come to those who wait? Delhi's Pragati Maidan revamp gets fourth date
Content: NEW DELHI: The Pragati Maidan redevelopment project has got another deadline. Instead of May, the project is now expected to be completed by early July. If the public works department (PWD) sticks to its fourth deadline, the commute on Mathura Road, Ring Road and Bhairon Marg will become a smooth experience thanks to a 1.2km-long tunnel and six underpasses.The project seeks to make Mathura Road — from the ITO W-point to Delhi Public School — and the Bhairon Marg-Ring Road intersection signal-free through the underpasses. The tunnel, on the other hand, will connect India Gate to Ring Road through Purana Quila Road/Mathura Road.The main reason behind the delay is the construction ban imposed during the winter, said an official. The project budget, which was estimated at Rs 932 crore, has escalated at least to Rs 1,000 crore, he added.The six-lane tunnel will run under Pragati Maidan from Purana Qila Road to Ring Road, reducing almost half the snarls caused by three major traffic signals on the stretch. The unfinished section is outside the Pragati Maidan premises, an official added.The main beneficiaries will be the commuters heading for east Delhi from south and Lutyens’ Delhi through India Gate and ITO. The vehicles going towards south Delhi from ITO will also have access to the tunnel from Mathura Road, providing a much-needed alternative to Bhairon Marg, especially during peak hours. This will also eventually reduce the traffic volume at the ITO traffic signal.Around 800 meters of the tunnel, running under Pragati Maidan, has been completed. Of the rest, 200 meters are being dug up underneath railway tracks using the “box pushing method” — segments are cast outside and pushed through heavy embankments of rail or road — to leave the train schedule undisturbed, said an official. Two boxes will have to be pushed, and the work for the second box will be completed by the end of this month, he added.Two of the five underpasses on Mathura Road are near Sunder Nagar while three are between Pragati Maidan and the Supreme Court premises. The other underpass on Ring Road connects it to Bhairon Marg. According to an India Trade Promotion Organisation official, around 60% of the work for all underpasses has been completed.According to the plan, two elevated clover-leaf roundabouts on Ring Road are being built for south- and north-Delhi-bound vehicles emerging from the underpass. Both roundabouts are almost on the verge of completion.The U-turns at the Bhairon Marg and the Subramaniam Bharti Marg crossings are also being replaced with elevated U-turns, giving more space to the vehicles going towards ITO. Instead of traffic signals, the three crossings at Sher Shah Road, Bhairon Marg and Subramaniam Bharati Marg will have underpasses for south-bound vehicles. Two more U-turns will be constructed at Sunder Nagar.

Title: Single-mom maid turns runner for a living, earns lakhs
Content:
Seema Verma

MUMBAI: Nalasopara resident Seema Verma has made it to the winners’ podium at many running events over the last few years, but it’s her personal story of grit that inspires fellow-runners the most.

Verma, a 38-year-old single mother who survived an abusive marriage, worked as domestic help before one of the “memsahibs” helped her take up running professionally.

Today, Verma — mother of a 19-year-old boy — makes a living only out of running. While she refuses to reveal how much she earns, she said, “When I finish in the podium, I get something like Rs 20,000. Collectively, these earnings help me survive.” Considering that Verma finished on the podium in 14 of the races she ran through 2019, it would be safe to assume she made over Rs 2 lakh – considerably more than a domestic help would make in a year.

She isn’t yet an elite marathoner — a title that requires women to complete the 42-km run in roughly 3:05 hours — but she finished on the podium of the Tata Mumbai Marathon held in January with a timing of 3:52:58 hours.

Verma was married at when she was 17-years-old to an alcoholic who deserted her and their son within four years of their wedding. Forced to fend for herself and her toddler, Seema took up odd jobs, including being a househelp. One of her employers, who knew about Verma’s love for sports, exhorted her to take up running to supplement her income. Now, eight years after starting her journey as a runner, she only depends on running to survive.

Title: Secunderabad News: Sec’bad to get 7 FoBs in six months
Content:
Secunderabad: The Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) has given a green signal to construct 38 foot-over bridges (FoBs) of the 52 proposed FoBs in the city in phase 1. Of these seven will come up at Secunderabad .

According to a government order issued on February 28, the GHMC will take up 38 FoBs in four phases at an estimated cost of approximately Rs 1.25 crore in four different zones. In Secunderabad, seven FoBs are set to come up – near bus stop Sai Sudheer College (AS Rao Nagar), Noma function hall (Mallapur), State Bank of India ( Habsiguda) , Neredmet bus stop, Gandhi Hospital (with escalators), St Ann’s School, Tarnaka and St Ann’s School, Secunderabad (with escalators).

“Professor Kumar of Osmania University has inspected the proposed locations of 52 FoBs and eight skywalks and submitted a feasibilityreport on feasibility. Of the 52 FoBs and 8 skywalks, 38 FoBs and 8 skywalks were found feasible,” read the GO.

Other FoBs and skywalks are expected to come up in LB Nagar, Serilingampally, Kukatpally, Khairtabad and Charminar zones . The work will be taken up by private agencies and is likely to commence in the next few weeks. It is expected to be completed within a period of six months.

Title: Water board contract staff booked
Content:
Hyderabad: A contract employee of water board was booked for allegedly misbehaving with a 36-year-old woman at Yousufguda. He is yet to be arrested.

On February 27, the woman, a housekeeping worker, from Rahmat Nagar in Borabanda, lodged a complaint with Jubilee Hills police alleging that Syed Jaffar, 26, a contract employee of water board, had pulled her burqa when she was standing on the road at Masjid Gadda in Borabanda on February 26.

“The complainant alleged that she fell on the road after Jaffar pulled her burqa and the accused left the place on his bike after threatening her,” Jubilee Hills inspector K Sattaiah said.

She told police that she knew Jaffar and he started threatening her recently. Based on the complaint of the victim, police registered a case against Jaffar under Sections 354 and 506 of IPC. tnn

Title: Inspections to be carried out in fish markets across TN: Min
Content:
Madurai: Tamil Nadu fisheries minister D Jayakumar, on Sunday, said that joint inspection will be conducted in fish markets throughout the state to ensure that good quality of seafood is sold to people.

In a statement, which came in the wake of seizure of seafood weighing two tonnes from Karimedu fish market in Madurai, the minister said that officials from fisheries department and food safety department will conduct joint inspections throughout the state.

He said that in a recent inspection, conducted by food safety officials in Karimedu fish market, it was found that stale fish procured from other states were sold to consumers. Such fish were seized and destroyed by the officials.

In connection with the incident, a circular has been sent to officials from fisheries department to conduct periodical inspections in fish markets across the state and take stringent action against traders involved in selling stale fish in order to prevent the unfair practice, the minister said.

Officials from food safety department in Madurai had said that they found presence of formalin, a cancer causing chemical, in the fish, other seafood and ice used for preservation during a check conducted on Friday night.

Samples of seafood have been sent for further lab analysis.

Title: Devpt of inland waterways as alternative transport lacks proper planning: Expert
Content:
Pune: The Centre’s decision to develop inland waterways as alternative means for transport has not been planned properly keeping in mind the ecological impact on the rivers and the fishing communities, said Shripad Dharmadhikary, founder of a water police NGO Manthan Adhyayan Kendra.

He said this at a seminar — ‘Interface between environmental protection and development of transport infrastructure: Issues and challenges’ — at ILS Law College under its ILS Legal Aid Centre and ILS Hariyali: The Environment Law Cell.

Dharmadhikary said under the National Waterways Act passed by the Centre in 2016, 111 river stretches were declared ‘national waterways’. “It was launched in a systematic way and involved rivers passing through 24 states and two union territories,” he said.

Last year, Dharmadhikary said, there were talks that the Mula-Mutha would be included in the Act. “There were talks that the Centre would amend the legislation for this. It has not happened so far, maybe because they are not sure how it will work with the riverfront development project,” he said, adding the project was not feasible.

“The main reason is that the Mula-Mutha does not have enough water for this. Unless you release water from upstream dams, which is basically the city’s drinking water supply, one can’t do it. Creating the correct stagnant water-level, which is ideal for vessels to navigate will be tough,” he said.

Title: Fish sales in Madurai see huge drop following formalin scare
Content:
Madurai: The fish sales in the city, on Sunday, saw a steep slump following the tests conducted by food safety officials on Friday, which found formalin in fish sold in Karimedu market in Madurai.

A Raja William, a retail fish seller, who would sell fish for around Rs 1 lakh on a usual Sunday, but this week he found lull business as he sold for only Rs 40, 000.

It has affected sales by at least 50% in Karimedu fish market. Situation was no better in other fish markets in the city like Nelpettai, South Gate, Jaihindpura and K Pudur. Traders said that the impact was found in neighbouring districts like Sivaganga, Dindigul, Theni and Virudhunagar too.

There are around 55 wholesale tradersand 120 retailers in Karimedu market. While wholesale traders sell tonnes of fish, retailers sell up to 300 kg on Sundays. Fish and other seafood are procured from Rameswaram, Tuticorin, Kanyakumari and Cuddalore in Tamil Nadu. They are also supplied from other states such as Kerala and Karnataka. Fresh water fish are procured from Andhra Pradesh, said traders.

“The sales got affected because of one or two greedy traders from other states and we severed ties with them. No fishermen or trader in the state use formalin,” Raja William said.

V Vanitha, a resident of Ponmeni, said that the news about presence of formalin shocked her family members and they decided to not go for fish this Sunday.

L Sundaram, president of Karimedu Commission Fish Vendors Association suspected that formalin could have been used by ice producers and said that they will be cautious while purchasing ice from factories.

“Outcome of the test conducted by food safety officials is a wake-up call for us. We are working on ways to prevent such issues in future. We will be extra cautious in providing quality fish to the society complying with the regulations laid down by food safety officials,” he said.

Food safety officials said that they continue to monitor for presence of formalin and quality of seafood sold in markets in Madurai and take appropriate action against traders, who don’t fall in line.

Title: Aide’s arrest lands duo in net for businessman’s murder in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: The Chatushrungi police have arrested two men from the city for their alleged involvement in the murder of a dairy businessman (50), who had gone missing from Balewadi on February 17 and was found dead in the Manwath taluka of Parbhani district last week.

The police identified the duo as Vitthal Kale (32) and Narayan Rathod (40). The Parbhani police have arrested their accomplice.

Senior inspector of the Chatushrungi police Anil Shewale said businessman Rohidas Balwadkar had left his house on February 17 after informing his family that he was going to Gujarat to buy buffaloes.

He said, “His family members later lodged a missing person’s complaint with the police, as they were unable to contact him for a few days.”

The Manwath police found a decomposed body near Manwath on February 24. During the course of investigation for ascertaining the identity of the body, the police traced one of the suspects in Parbhani.

“He confirmed that the deceased person was Balwadkar and revealed the names of Kale and Rathod in connection with his death. He also told the police that the duo were in Pune. We arrested Kale and Rathod on Saturday after receiving information on their whereabouts from the Parbhani police,” Shewale said, adding, “The duo were handed to the Parbhani police.”

The officer said prima facie probe revealed that a woman relative of Kale was Balwadkar’s tenant. “He used to harass her, following which the woman and her family had to leave for their native place in Parbhani district. Based on a suspicion that Balwadkar was still harassing the woman, Kale and Rathod hatched a plan to kill him,” Shewale said.

“The duo called him to Parbhani on the pretext of discussing some workhim. Upon meeting him, Kale and Rathod hacked him to death with the help of their third accomplice,” Shewale added.

Title: NPR will be implemented in Tamil Nadu like in Andhra Pradesh & Telangana, says CM Edappadi K Palaniswami
Content:
Edappadi K Palaniswami

MADURAI: Chief Minister Edappadi K Palaniswami has clarified that people can omit three questions that have been recently included in the NPR exercise as the details in Tamil Nadu would be collected on the same lines as done in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana.

He said that residents were free to omit the three newly added questions in the NPR form - language, place of birth of mother and father and details of Aadhaar and ration cards. “They need not submit any records,” he said. He added that the Centre has not said anything about NRC.

Speaking to reporters at Madurai airport, the chief minister said that NPR was implemented during BJP’s rule in 2003, when DMK was its ally then. On being asked about MNM (Makkal Needhi Maiyam) president Kamal Haasan’s statement that the government departments were not functioning well, he asked what Kamal knows about government departments. “The only department he knows is acting and he is not even a full-time politician,” he said, adding that if malpractice in any department is brought to light stringent action would be taken.

When asked about some political parties projecting as a farmer, he said that his primary source of income came from agriculture. “Otherwise, the only salary I have taken till date is of an MLA when I was an MLA, MLA pension when I was not MLA, apart from MP salary and pension,” he said. On being asked about the IT secretary’s decision to quit over the scheme to provide internet facility to over 12,000 villages in TN, he said that the secretary was still in office and that it was false propaganda by the opposition parties.

Title: Cases of stones in urinary tract have risen among dogs: IVRI
Content:
Bareilly: Cases of urolithiasis -- formation of stones in the urinary tract and kidney – among dogs are increasing every year, according to scientists at the Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI) here. Some breeds such as Yorkshire terrier, Lhasa Apso, Shih Tzu, Dalmatians, English Bulldogs and German Shepherd are more prone to the disease. Males are mostly affected than females, they say.

According to sources at the IVRI’s polyclinic, 65 cases of urolithiasis among dogs were reported in 2017-18 and it rose to 95 in 2018-19.

RK Singh, director, IVRI, told TOI, “Dog owners should be made aware about how to properly take care of a canine so that the possibility of urolithiasis can be minimized.”

Urolithiasis is a urinary tract disease in which crystals or stones form within the urinary tract and cause irritation, pain and possibly blockage. Some times they are formed in the kidney. Though there is no single cause of urolithiasis, veterinarians believe that bacterial infection in the bladder, diet deficient in Vitamin A and mineral imbalance and low intake of water are common factors. Besides hereditary factors and size of dog – small dogs are more susceptible – also result in urolithiasis.

Owners often fail to recognize the signs of the problem in the form of discoloured urine that could be due to urine pH or increased intestinal absorption of inorganic minerals. The dog may make frequent attempts to urinate but urine output is low. The dog may also display discomfort or pain while urinating.

Swapan Kumar Maiti, principal scientist, division of surgery, IVRI, said, “Urolith is known as precipitation and aggregation of crystalline and organic matrix at one or more locations anywhere in urinary tract due to oversaturation of urine with crystalloid substances. Uroliths in dogs is divided into four main mineral types -- urate (ammonium urate, sodium urate and uric acid), cysteine, struvites (magnesium and ammonium phosphate) and calcium (calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate).”

Of the four groups of uroliths, scientists said struvites are the most commonly urinary stones found in dogs. “However, there is an increasing incidence of calcium oxalate stones in dogs. It may happen due to excess calcium feeding and feeding of high oxalate diet. Besides, commercially available feed has less magnesium content. Due to less magnesium content, the high calcium content cannot be neutralized and hence, it causes mineral imbalance. Urates are more common among Daschunds. Besides, cysteine stone is a result of enhanced urine acidity due to high animal protein diet,” said Maiti.

Scientists said the medical treatment of urolithiasis vary considering the severity of the disease among dogs. “We first try to dissolve the stone but if medical dissolution fails, we surgically remove the stone,” said Maiti.

Title: Students can submit GCET applications from March 26
Content:
Panaji: This year’s Goa Common Entrance Test ( GCET ), for admissions to professional degree programme seats in engineering and pharmacy in colleges in the state, will be held on May 5 and 6. The directorate of technical education (DTE) will begin receiving application forms from interested students from March 26 onwards.

The GCET will be held in physics, chemistry and mathematics across 15 centres in the state.

Students seeking admission to degree programmes in medicine, dentistry, ayurveda, homeopathy, nursing and allied health programmes in Goa institutes will have to appear for the National Eligibility and Entrance Test ( NEET ) UG-2020. Those wanting to join the degree course in architecture, however, will have to answer the National Aptitude Test in Architecture (NATA-2020), conducted by the Council of Architecture.

For students applying for both GCET-based programmes as well as the NEET-based courses, the common prospectus released by the DTE on February 29 is applicable.

The directorate will begin accepting admission forms from all these students from May 15 onwards. The last date to receive admission forms has been set for May 22.

Students applying for NEET-based course seats in Goa too, must necessarily submit their admission forms as per this schedule, irrespective of when the NEET is held or its results declared, officials said.

The provisional merit list for admissions to engineering and pharmacy programmes will be displayed on June 10 and the first round of admissions for these courses will begin from June 15.

Similarly, the provisional merit list for entry to NEET and NATA-based courses will be displayed on June 30. The first round of admissions for NEET-based programmes will begin from July 2 while admissions for the BArch programme will start from July 6.

Title: EPS, OPS thank Modi for 11 new medical colleges in TN
Content:
Madurai: Tamil Nadu was the only state to have obtained permission to establish 11 new medical colleges in a single year, and it is the Central government which made this possible, said chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami after laying the foundation stone for the government medical college in Ramanathapuram district on Sunday. “I thank Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Union health minister Harsh Vardhan for giving us this honour,’’ he said.

The new medical college would be established in Pattanamkathan in Ramanathapuram on 22 acres at a cost of Rs 345 crore.

He said former chief minister J Jayalalithaa who wanted to establish medical colleges in all districts of the state. So far, six new medical colleges have been established and an additional 1,350 medical seats have been created in the last eight years, he said. The decision to increase medical colleges in the state was to benefit students from economically backward sections of the society, he said.

The chief minister said that the cost of establishing medical courses in every new college was Rs 325 crore each. Out of the newly sanctioned medical colleges, six were going to be established in Ramanathapuram, Virudhunagar, Dindigul, Namakkal, Nilgiris and Tirupur. Each of the colleges spanning 20 acres would enroll 150 students from the academic year 2021-2022. This would enhance the medical seats by 1,650 in addition to the existing 3,250 seats in the state.

New medical colleges would be established in Krishnagiri, Tiruvallur and Nagapattinam in the second phase, and the Centre has given permission to establish two new colleges in Ariyalur and Kallakurichi, he said.

The Chief Minister distributed welfare measures, and also inaugurated the Keelakarai tahsildar office, constructed at a cost of Rs 2.72 crore. Welfare measures to the tune of Rs105 crore were distributed at the function. He also made new announcements for the district including cold storage facilities in two panchayats of Mudukulathor block, with a capacity of 100 tonne at a cost of Rs 1.5 crore each. He said that a new mobile soil testing unit will be set up at Paramakudi for Rs 70 lakh.

Deputy CM O Panneerselvam said that the Prime Minister, who won laurels from the US President. Trump, has created a history in Tamil Nadu, by sanctioning 11 medical colleges for TN in a single year. This record will forever be engraved in the annals of TN’s history.

Title: IGNOU seeks beneficiaries for free courses
Content:
Panaji: Around a 100 programmes offered by the Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU) can be pursued free of cost by students coming from the SC and ST communities, however, the awareness about this facility is low in Goa. The IGNOU regional centre is now looking to tie-up with the state commission working with these disadvantaged sections to get beneficiaries for these free programmes.

Assistant regional director G Shrinivas told TOI that Canacona and Pernem will be the focus areas. IGNOU’s regional centre in the state is looking to up its numbers of SC and ST students when the next admission cycle arrives in June.

“There are 100 plus graduate, diploma and certificate programmes offered by IGNOU for which not a single rupee is charged from students belongng to SC/ST communities. We want to reach out to these students in Goa in a bigger way,” Shrinivas said.

The regional centre of IGNOU established in 2009 in Panaji, has four districts covering Goa, Karnataka and Maharashtra under its jurisdiction.

“I also want to tie-up with the Goa Human Resource Development Corporation, which places youngsters who have completed Class XII. They can be easily helped to upgrade their educational qualifications so they can aspire for upward mobility. Even companies can be roped in to fund their education as part of the CSR initiative,” Shrinivas said.

IGNOU has two admission cycles every ear and offers about 228 certificate, diploma, degree and doctoral programmes.

Title: Schools piggyback on pvt firms to get physical education back in shape
Content:
Hyderabad: From most sports classes being hijacked by subject teachers to introducing a sports curriculum, schools in the city have come a long way in making games and sports an integral part of education.

Many schools in the city, in fact, are taking the help of private firms to get their physical education teachers trained and ensure supply of kits to make sure that students get proper sports education .

“Just like for any other subject, we have a lesson plan for sports as well. Students are taught age-appropriate games. For example, preschoolers are encouraged to play games which will help them to improve their coordination or balance,” said Lakshmi Vishwanath, academic director, Johnson Grammar School adding that they have tied up with a private firm which helps them in implementing the sports curriculum.

Vishwanath said that each and every class student in their schools have a sports period every day, and added that as students go to higher classes, they are encouraged to pick up a sport of their choice.

Schools, which are using private firms to help them in implementing sports curriculum, said that following a structured programme helps students in the long run.

“For lower classes, we tied up with a private player to help our teachers in implementing sports curriculum. For high school students, we have coaches for different sports like cricket, football, kabaddi, basketball, tennis, among others. For lower classes, we concentrate on developing different skills to help students pick up a sport later,” said Madhvi Chandra, principal, Gitanjali Devshala. She said that they have made yoga compulsory , especially for students in middle and high schools.

Firms which provide sports education and sports management programs to schools confirmed that several schools are implementing sports curriculum on their campuses. “We have more than 40 schools as our clients. Apart from sending trained teachers, we also help in implementing the sports curriculum,” said Pavan G, regional manager, Sportz Village Schools, a firm that provides sports education services.

Title: Steps to declare Sivakasi as a corpn initiated, says Edappadi
Content:
Madurai: Preliminary works to declare Sivakasi as a corporation had been initiated, said chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami in the presence of union health minister Harsh Vardhan at an event to lay foundation stones for a government medical college in Virudhunagar district on Sunday.

The Rs 380 crore medical college is to come up on 22-acre land. The announcement for upgrading the Sivakasi municipality had already been made during the MGR centenary celebrations last year. As Sivakasi is completing a century as a municipality, a special fund of Rs 50 crore would be released for developing infrastructures such as roads, parks, drainage and street lights as per the demand by local minister Rajendra Bhalaji, he said.

A fund allocation of Rs 3 crore will be made to renovate the rajagopuram of the ancient Kasi Viswanathar temple in Sivakasi, as per popular demand, he said.

Adding that Tamil Nadu is making many strides in the field of health care, Edappadi said that the state is polio-free for 16 years. As per the request made by the union health minister Dr Harsh Vardhan, efforts would be taken to declare the state free of tuberculosis by the year 2025, he said. Tamil Nadu also stands first among the states in organ donation.

All steps are being taken to complete the AIIMS hospital in Madurai at the earliest and the union minister had assured that the hospital would be on the lines of the AIIMS hospital in New Delhi, he said.

EPS also announced new schemes for Virudhunagar, including a new building for the Aruppukottai tahsildar’s office, a new office for the Rajapalayam panchayat union, a gas-operated crematorium in Rajapalayam, and a high-level bridge across Sittrar in Athikovil a tribal settlement in Watrap.

Minister for health C Vijayabaskar said that the chief minister has got 11 runs in a single ball by bringing 11 medical colleges to the state in a year. Deputy chief minister O Panneerselvam, minister K T Rajendhra Balaji were also present.

Title: As docs call for security at hospital, BHU admin grapples with money matters
Content:
Varanasi: In the last one year, doctors have gone on strike for a number of times calling for better security arrangements at BHU’s SSL Hospital and other medical establishments but the promises made to them are yet to see the light of the day.

When TOI contacted chief proctor Prof OP Rai on Sunday to know about progress in enhancement of security, he said: “We We started the process to increase the number of security personnel in university’s proctorial board to enhance security of hospitals under Institute of Medical Science-BHU after junior residents’ strike in November 2019 but it could not materialise due to insufficient budget.”

According to proctorial board officials, around 150 security personnel are being deployed for the security of hospitals while there is a requirement of 450 in view of opening of new wings.

“New wings like super specialty and cancer centre have come with provision of budget for security. Major problem is being faced at trauma centre and SSL hospital where stopping students from other departments of university is a challenging task,” he said.

He said demand for 250 more security personnel had been forwarded to university administration following November 2019 strike.

“Currently, university’s proctorial board has strength of over 800 security personnel. Maximum expenditure is made on their salaries, which range between Rs 25,000 and Rs 28,000 while budget is also required for security equipment, vehicles and other resources. According to rough estimate, the annual budget of proctorial board is around Rs 9 crores, which is mainly spent on salaries,” he said.

Title: 39 leap year babies born at GRH
Content:
Madurai: As many as 39 ‘leaplings’ or babies with birthdays on the leap year day of Febuary 29, were born on Saturday at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) in Madurai.

With 2020 being a leap year, children born on Feburary 29, 2020, across the world can celebrate their birthdays on the actual day only once in four years. Usually, parents globally celebrate it either on February 28 or March 1.

However, in Madurai, the parents of leap year babies at GRH said that the fact did not have an impact on them since they followed the Tamil calendar. As per the Tamil calendar, Feburay 29 this year fell on Masi 17. “My daughter delivered as per her due date, which was given as February 29. We had, even before her delivery, decided that we will celebrate the birthday as per Tamil calendar so there is no confusion,” said Kalavathy S from Sathyamoorthy Nagar in Madurai.

Her daughter, 24-year-old Iswarya M is having her first child. “Leap day or not we are all incredibly happy to welcome our beautiful girl,” added Kalavathy.

Some other parents on the hand are also looking at the Tamil star birthday date to celebrate the birthday of their leap day baby. The star birthday dates come on different dates every year on the English calendar.

“We often don’t realize, but these days, many people in Tamil Nadu, even for other days of the year are looking more at the Tamil calendar and birth star as per Tamil astrology for celebrating birthdays,” said a staff nurse. Among the 39 leap year babies born at GRH , 23 were boy babies while 16 were girl babies.

Title: Edappadi K Palaniswami: ‘Tamil Nadu Muslims will not be affected by NPR’
Content:
Edappadi K Palaniswami

MADURAI: No Muslim born in Tamil Nadu will be affected by the NPR (national population register) exercise in Tamil Nadu as the AIADMK government will continue to protect the rights and interests of Muslims like a fortress, said Chief Minister Edappadi K Palaniswami .

The chief minister spoke this at two different events to lay the foundation stones for the government medical college in Ramanathapuram and Virudhunagar on Sunday. He urged the women from the Muslim community to give up their protest and extend their support to the Tamil Nadu government. “People could omit the three recent questions added to NPR, including details on the place of birth of their mother and father,” he said.

“Tamil Nadu is a garden of peace where people of all creeds and castes lived in harmony. The government functioned on the basis of secularism and continued to protect the minority sections. I stated the same in the Assembly, but in recent times some, who could not tolerate it, were spreading rumours with malicious intent for political gains,” he said.

He assured the members of minority sections that they had no cause to fear through this function. “The people of Tamil Nadu should remain united and without paying heed to false information spread by divisive forces,” he said.

The chief minister also narrated the story of two goats who had realised in time that a cunning fox was trying to create a divide between them so that he could kill and eat them.

Title: Pain for commuters: Bus services from ECIL to Secunderabad discontinued
Content:
Commuters wait at ECIL bus stop to travel to Secunderabad. Discontinuation of bus services has affected thousa... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: Telangana State Road Transport Corporation (TSRTC) has discontinued bus services from ECIL towards Secunderabad via Neredmet, AS Rao Nagar and Sainikpuri, citing mounting losses. Officials said that it had become financially non-viable to run buses along this route due to lack of adequate vehicles, drivers and conductors.

However, termination of services has created resentment among passengers, as these buses ferried thousands. They said that bus no. 24E , which directly connected ECIL to Secunderabad, was one of the many services discontinued. The bus travelled from ECIL bus terminus towards Secunderabad bus station 2 via Sainikpuri, EME Centre, Tirmulgherry, Clock Towers.

“Most buses ply via Moulali, Lalaguda, Tarnaka towards Secunderabad. There are no buses now that covers the other side — AS Rao Nagar, Vayupuri, Tirmulgherry,” said Anitha Yadagiri, a commuter.

The bus operators said that because the routes were running fewer trips every day, expenses were sometimes more than revenue earned per trip. “TSRTC was spending almost Rs 58 per km on buses that were discontinued. We had fewer vehicles, drivers or conductors to ply, due to which the authorities decided to discontinue services” said Gopal, Kushaiguda bus depot manager.

Officials said that Hyderabad Metro Rail Ltd’s (HMRL) decision to introduce shuttle buses from Jubilee Bus Stop towards Radhika X Roads, ECIL and Anandbagh is likely to provide relief to commuters struggling due to discontinuation of these buses. Over 8,000 people are expected to take these three routes daily.

Title: How Sikhs helped end dispute involving mosque and gurdwara
Content:
Muslims also returned the land that was donated by the Sikh side as a part of the peace deal

MEERUT: Sikhs and Muslims in Uttar Pradesh ’s Saharanpur have amicably resolved a bitter six-year-old land dispute involving a gurdwara and a dilapidated mosque due to the “efforts of the Sikh community to help Muslims during the recent Delhi riots”.

Four days after the representatives of the two communities in Saharanpur reached an amicable agreement in the long-standing land dispute, the Muslim community went a step further to reaffirm their commitment for communal bonhomie by returning the land that was donated by the Sikh side as a part of the peace deal.

“The masjid committee, as well as the Muslim community, have unanimously decided to return the land that was donated to us. We are moved by the efforts of the Sikh community and the way they lead from the front when it comes to helping the poor and destitute which we recently saw during the Delhi riots,” Muharram Ali, a representative from the Muslim side, told TOI.

The dispute began in 2014 when Sri Guru Singh Sabha Gurdwara committee started constructing an extension to the gurdwara on a plot it had bought. Members of the Muslim community objected to the move, claiming that a mosque once had once stood on the land. The dispute triggered one of worst communal clashes in the district in 2014, resulting in three deaths while an entire marketplace was gutted in arson. More than 200 people were booked.

On Wednesday, both communities had come to an agreement with Sikh representatives agreeing to buy a plot of land in a minority-dominated area for construction of a mosque there and the minority community representatives reciprocating by promising to perform kar seva in the expansion plan of the gurdwara. In a press conference jointly held by the representatives of both the communities on Sunday, Ali returned the cheque to the members of the Sikh community present there.

“The community representatives have returned the documents and a cheque of Rs 4 lakh which was the first installment for the land that was being bought in the Muslim neighbourhood for the mosque,” Gurpreet Bagga, state unit president of Akali Dal, said. “They said that the Sikh community has always stood for the cause of others like we started langar in Delhi for the riot victims recently. We are thankful to them,” Bagga said.
