Title: 36,293 students to write Class XII exams in Madurai
Content:
Madurai: A total of 36 ,293 class XII students, including 139 differently-abled candidates, from more than 323 schools are set to write their class XII board exams today in Madurai. The students will kick-start their exams with the language paper on Monday.

At the 120 designated exam centres in the district, a total of 17,089 boys and 19,204 girls will write their exams. Following the overall state trend of more girls appearing for the exams, in Madurai, 2115 more girls are appearing when compared to boys. Strict restrictions are also in place to prevent cheating.

A preparatory meeting was held by district education officials last week led by Madurai district Chief Educational Officer (CEO) R Swaminathan to discuss the various measures in place in Madurai for smooth conduct of the exams. Various steps to prevent any leakage of question papers and ensuring that question papers and answer sheets were safe during transportation and storage was also discussed. The 13 strong rooms storing the question papers in the district will be under 24x7 armed guard security. The question papers will be transported via 28 special officers. There students will be writing their exams based on a new syllabus this year. Also they will be writing their exams for 100 marks instead of 200 marks. After an uproar over the time limit for the exams being reduced to two and a half hours instead of three, it was reverted back to 3 hours.

“It is going to be a completely new experience for us, from marks to syllabus, there has been a lot of change and we are not sure of what to expect. We did our best in training them, now it is their time to shine,” said a principal of a school.

Title: Nagpur man obstructs garbage collection, booked
Content:
Representative image

Nagpur: Nandanvan police have booked a man on charges of obstructing garbage collectors (on government duty) from discharging their duty and also threatening drivers of garbage collection vehicles on Saturday at Wathoda Chowk.

According to police, AG Enviro, which has been given contract to collect garbage by Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC), has a parking space for garbage collection vehicles at Wathoda Chowk. On Saturday, the accused identified as Mukesh Shahu went to the parking space and started threatening the drivers who were about to go to the work. He also threatened the parking in-charge Manoj Khankure.

This led to a delay of around two hours as the garbage vehicles were heldup. Following this, Manoj approached Nandanvan police station and filed a complaint.

It is learnt that Mukesh, a resident of Sonba Nagar, also has old offences registered against him, including at Kalamna police station.

Senior PI of Nandanvan police station Sandipan Pawar said, “The reason behind Mukesh’s action is unclear, but he claims to be from a workers’ union. Mukesh could have informed the police about his grievance. Instead, he interfered in the work of garbage collectors and hence we have booked him. He has not been arrested in the matter.”

Title: High court dismisses petition on Manjuvirattu
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court has dismissed a plea to amend the provisions of Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Tamil Nadu Amendment) Act, 2017, for conduct of manjuvirattu events throughout the year.

The petitioner, A Aavudayappan Servai, moved the Madurai bench of the Madras high court in 2017, seeking to declare the words ‘from the months January to May of a calendar year’ under provisions of Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (Tamil Nadu Amendment) Act, 2017, as illegal and arbitrary in respect of the conduct of manjuvirattu events and subsequently amend the words to ‘all the months of calendar year’.

Hearing the plea, a division bench comprising Chief Justice A P Sahi and Justice Subramonium Prasad observed that the counsel for the petitioner had advanced his submissions, which essentially, in our opinion, is asking for the conduct of manjuvirattu events throughout the year. The judges observed that this is an absolutely irrational suggestion, seeking a legal protection for continuance of activities thereby diluting the very effect and purpose of the Act.

The judges further observed that any such alteration would, therefore, defeat the very purpose of regulating the activities of the events and might possibly result in more cruelty to the animals that presently involved, which is sought to be prevented. Observing that the aforesaid relief claimed is frivolous for having raised an issue, which does not further any public interest, the judges dismissed the petition.

Title: HC: Reinstate cop dismissed in recruitment paper leaking case
Content:
Madurai: Madras high court set aside the order passed by the appellate authorities and has directed to reinstate a police head constable back into service citing that the punishment given to him for leaking question paper for police recruitment exam in the year 2005 was discriminatory.

The petitioner M C Pandi was appointed as grade II police constable in the year 1988. The petitioner while serving as a head constable was issued a charge memo alleging that he along with a person had leaked the question paper for police constable recruitment examination to M Suresh by obtaining Rs 10,000 in the year 2005.

Based on the report submitted by the inquiry officer, the disciplinary authority had imposed a punishment of reduction of pay by one stage for two years with cumulative effect for the petitioner. When the petitioner filed an appeal, the appellate authority in the year 2011 had enhanced the punishment to dismissal from service. Aggrieved by the same, the petitioner had filed a review and in the order in 2014, the punishment was modified as compulsory retirement. Hence, the petitioner moved high court Madurai bench in the year 2014, challenging these orders and sought to reinstate him back in to service.

Justice J Nisha Banu observed that on perusal of the records, the punishment given by the disciplinary authority to the petitioner can be reasonably accepted. The judge, however, observed that the appellate authority had dismissed the appeal moved by the petitioner twice without discussing any grounds raised by the petitioner. The judge observed that though the petitioner stated to have been committed serious misconduct by the appellate authorities, the fact remains that he has not been arrayed as accused in the criminal case. The judge observed that while similarly placed people have been given only minor punishment, the appellate authority has imposed severe punishment without any concrete material that too, belatedly.

Confirming the punishment order passed by the disciplinary authority, the judge set aside the order passed by the appellate authorities and directed them to reinstate the petitioner in service with all service and monetary benefits within a period of four weeks.

Title: Going for the skill: Helping youths land better jobs
Content:
Hyderabad: While the demand for jobs is ever growing, the skills fresh graduates possess are often found wanting.

Gampa Nageshwar Rao realised this was true for almost all generations over past many decades. He also understood that youths, despite being armed with various Bachelors or PG degrees, either lacked confidence or direction.

Rao, 58, says, “I drove autorickshaws. I used to distribute milk and newspapers to afford an education. Nobody was there to guide me when I was young. When I completed my education, I knew I had to do something to support others like me.” He knew that youths needed to be armed with soft skills to excel in their careers.

About 22 years ago, Rao, set up ‘Impact’, a foundation that provides free training to youths in public speaking, spoken English, positive body language, entrepreneurship, and even guidance in how to build a resume.

“The training sessions we provide are free of cost. People only have to register themselves on our website,” says Rao, who is an LIC employee. Under the foundation, he conducts various programmes where he helps graduates develop their soft skills.

The training programmes are held in collaboration with professionals from different fields.

“We have several groups on social media so that we never lose contact with those coming for our sessions. These groups also include professionals from different walks of life who can reply to the queries,” says Rao. A young participant at his training programme, said he has realised that instead on just focusing on educational degree, youths must focus on ethics and job satisfaction.

“I met Mr Rao 10 years ago,” says 34-year-old Sai Satish, who is an ethical hacker. “I was a fresh graduate who lacked confidence and communication skills. He helped me rebuild my confidence. Today, I have a very positive approach towards life, and I own a software developing company of my own.”

The intention behind this initiative, says Rao, is to show the young minds that there are may options in life, which they can explore if they develop their skills.

Title: Youth jumps into canal for TikTok video, hits rocks, dies instantly
Content:
Muzaffarnagar: In an adventure gone horribly wrong, 18-year-old Raaz Qureshi hit a rock while he plunged headlong into a canal as his friends recorded the moments for a TitTok video. He died instantly.

In the video which has since gone viral on social media, Qureshi is seen hitting a hard object as he plunges into the water and is knocked unconscious due to fatal wounds on his head.

According to sources, Qureshi, a resident of Meerapur in Muzaffarnagar, and his three friends went to the Ganga canal on February 28 where he jumped into canal but could not be able to move his body after he hit the rock. He went missing in deep water and his body was recovered two hours later.

The video of the incident went viral on Sunday.

Superintendent of police (rural) Nepal Singh said, “The incident occurred two days ago. Taking cognizance of the viral video, we are conducting a probe and action will be taken accordingly.” According to sources, Qureshi had an account on TikTok where he frequently uploaded videos of various adventures.

Title: New tasmac shop coming up in 80 feet road in Anna Nagar causes concern
Content:
356

Madurai: While the government has assured the people, that it would close the Tasmac shops in a phased manner, the establishment of a new shop at the 80 feet road in Anna Nagar, Madurai is a cause of concern.

Social activist, S Karthik said that people continue to protest against setting up of Tasmac shops in various parts of the city, but the administration continues to establish them, in various important places. On Feb 27, this year, people of Kochadai protested against the move to open a shop opposite to a temple there. Two days later, a similar protest was held against opening a Tasmac shop near the third bus stop in the region in Thirunagar on February 29.

Now, work is on to open a shop on the 80 feet road in Anna Nagar, which is about 100 feet away from SP Hospitals. This road houses about five hospitals, and educational institutions.

“As hospitals are on this stretch, this road is frequented by ambulances. The establishment of a Tasmac shop here could lead to accidents,’’ said B Anandraj, a resident.

Establishing these shops in crowded places which would definitely cause a problem and be a menace to the public should be avoided. People from Panangadi, Bypass road, and Surveryor Colony had moved the court against the establishment of Tasmac shops near schools or hospitals in these places and obtained a stay against the opening the shops in specific places.

Soundaraya, a resident of Anna Nagar says that her daughter returns from tuition very near to the spot where the shop is being established. “Many students use the lane, and now we have to look for alternatives because a Tasmac shop is never safe for children to walk past after 9 pm,’’ she said.

C J Rajan, convenor of Tamil Nadu Federation of Anti-liquor movements said that the establishment of tasmac shops show that the government is not committed to fulfilling the statements made by their late leader J Jayalalithaa. “The matter of concern is that they are opening them at prime locations which are frequented by the general public, which could endanger them,’’ he said.

Title: Now, 1 EWS seat for veterinary science course
Content:
Panaji: With the state lacking an institute offering veterinary sciences and animal husbandry (BVSc&AH) degree programmes, the Goa government pays two universities, one each in Maharashtra and Puducherry , to reserve seats for students from the state.

Now, of the 11 seats in the programme available for Goa students, one seat, at the Maharashtra Animal and Fishery Science University (MAFSU) in Nagpur has been reserved for a candidate from economically backward sections (EWS).

Students from Goa wanting to join the BVSc&AH course on the state seats have to appear for the NEET-UG 2020 and qualify. To claim the seats, the students should be residents of Goa for a minimum of 15 years and should have at least 50% aggregate marks in physics, chemistry and biology.

The BVSc&AH programme is of five-and-a-half years duration, including internship period.

Title: Youth arrested for sexually assaulting girl
Content:
Madurai: The Melur police on Saturday arrested a 21-year-old youth from a village near Melur for sexually assaulting a minor girl hailing from a nearby village.

The accused was identified as M Dinesh from Therkupatti, a daily wage labourer at a factory. He had eloped with the 16-year-old girl who worked at the same place on Friday on the promise of marrying her.

He took her to a private lodge and molested her before they were traced by the police. They rescued the girl and sent her with her parents.

Her parents had lodged a police complaint as she had not returned from work in the evening. According to police, although the accused knew that the girl was a minor, he eloped and sexually assaulted her.

Dinesh was booked under Pocso (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act) based on a complaint from the girl’s mother. He was also booked under IPC section 366(a) - procuration of minor girl. The accused was remanded in prison by a judicial magistrate.

It was second sexual assault incident in Melur involving a minor girl as a college student was arrested by Melur AWPS on Friday.

Title: Pune: 70-year-old woman, son survive house collapse
Content:
A big portion of the century-old Singhaniya Wada collapsed early on Sunday morning

PUNE: A man (48) and his septuagenarian mother had a miraculous escape after a major portion of a century-old wada, located near the Shrimant Dagaduseth Halwai Ganapati temple on Shivaji Road, collapsed around 5am on Sunday.

Vinayak Kalyani and Gangubai (70) remained under the debris of the Singhaniya Wada in Budhwar Peth for around an hour before fire brigade officers spotted them. The fire brigade officers said Vinayak and Gangubai were sleeping in their room on the first floor of the dilapidated building when the ceiling, made of Mangalore tiles and wood, crashed. The floor of their room also caved in and the duo fell onto the ground floor of the wada.

Fire station officer Pradip Khedekar said his department received a call around 5.17am and his team rushed to the spot. “While removing the debris, some of our officers heard the sound of human breathing. They then spotted the two persons. There was very little space for them even to crawl out,” he said.

The fire brigade officers made a makeshift platform close to the first floor of the wada and a team used it to reach the ground floor. “The team removed the debris and took out Vinayak and Gangubai. We used bedsheets and blankets to rescue them, as there was no space to enter the wada with stretchers. Both of them had sustained minor injuries and were taken to a nearby hospital,” he said.

The local residents said the wada had nearly nine rooms and most of them were damaged. Few of the rooms were occupied.

In July last year, a section of a staircase and the connected wall of a 75-year-old wada in Ghorpade Peth had collapsed. Fire brigade officials rescued 22 residents. The residents were trapped inside, as they could not descend because the stairs were in a dangerous condition.

Barely a month after the accident, the wall of a dilapidated wada in Guruwar Peth collapsed, rendering its lone resident homeless.

The state government had in 2015 drafted a policy to provide certificates to ensure that leaseholders’ rights were protected. According to the policy, the leaseholders can keep their claim on the structures by submitting the certificate at the time of the wadas’ redevelopment.

Pune city has around 775 wadas and other dilapidated properties. Of these, around 174 are in a dangerous condition. The state government has divided the structures into C-1 (very dangerous), C-2A (needs vacating for repair), C-2B (Doesn’t need vacating for repair) and C-3 (Needs minor repairing) categories.

Title: Rashmi Thackeray: Wife replaces Uddhav as Saamna editor
Content:
Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray with wife Rashmi Thackeray

MUMBAI: Rashmi Thackeray , considered to be one of the driving forces behind husband Uddhav and son Aaditya’s plunge in active politics, seems to have now assumed a more direct role in Shiv Sena ’s affairs.

On Sunday, her name appeared in the print line of party mouthpiece Saamna as its editor. Sena MP Sanjay Raut will continue as the daily’s executive editor and see to its day-to-day operations, a party member said. Rashmi replaces Uddhav, who stepped down as the editor and his name was dropped from its print line on November 28, 2019 the day he took oath as Maharashtra ’s chief minister. This was done to avoid the ‘office of profit’ issue.

Title: Quelossim locals miffed at NOC to project in CRZ
Content:
Panaji: The issuance of a no-objection certificate ( NOC ) by the Quelossim panchayat secretary for a floating platform at the mini India park has kicked off a row, as the villagers have been opposing the project, located in the coastal regulation zone ( CRZ ) – 1, for nearly a decade.

In a series of developments recently, the secretary issued approval for the floating platform on February 11, but then, revoked it in a letter issued on the eve of a gram sabha on February 16.

Facing queries from gram sabha members about the non-transparent process, secretary Narayan Azgaonkar apologised at the meeting chaired by sarpanch Maria D’Souza.

But in another twist, Azgaonkar filed a police complaint, alleging that D’Souza and deputy sarpanch Sebastiao Serrao had forcibly taken away the outward correspondence register to make entries in it.

The matter is still simmering, with the villagers crying foul over the secretary’s latest action. Allegedly with political backing, Azgaonkar issued another letter dated February 20 to the private party, withdrawing the letter cancelling the NOC.

The approval granted on February 11 stands valid, the letter states.

“We will now approach the higher authorities,” said Lopinho Xavier, a local activist.

A large patch in a fertile khazan land under survey number 170/0 had been reclaimed many years ago. The project envisaged installation of replicas of India’s well-known religious monuments. Though the investment promotion board had issued an in-principle approval to it, it later withdrew it after a court litigation.

The Goa coastal zone management authority had declared, after a few inspections, that the land is part of CRZ 1, but as locals allege, it has not submitted the last report for further action.

Title: 10 travellers back from Italy quarantined in Pune's Naidu hospital
Content: PUNE: Ten travellers who recently returned from Italy were quarantined at the PMC’s Naidu Infectious Diseases Hospital on Sunday after they complained of minor illness.Their throat swab samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) to rule of the novel coronavirus infection (COVID-19).“They complained of cough, cold, fever, sore throat and headache, following which they were quarantined. We will get their report on Monday,” a health official of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) said.Passengers arriving from China, Hong Kong, Thailand, Singapore, South Korea, Japan, Nepal, Indonesia, Vietnam and Malaysia are already undergoing screening at the airport. Iran and Italy were added to the list on February 26 on the instructions of the Union government.“Travellers residing in Maharashtra, coming from Iran and Italy, are also being screened at Mumbai’s Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport (CSMIA). They are tracked for 14 days to rule out the novel coronavirus infection,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate said.A total of 61,939 passengers returning from China and other affected countries have been screened at CSMIA since January 18. Of them, 370 were put under 14-day surveillance and 125 were quarantined in Mumbai, Pune, Nagpur, among other parts of the state, after they complained of flu-like symptoms. Most of them tested negative for the infection and were discharged.A total of 241 of the 370 other travellers, who also visited these countries but didn’t develop any symptoms, have completed the mandatory 14-day follow-up by staying quarantined in their respective homes. The remaining travellers are being followed up with regularly, a state health official said.In Pune, 61 travellers were quarantined at the civic-run Naidu hospital over the last five weeks after they complained of minor illness. “A total of 51 travellers have tested negative for the virus so far and have been discharged. The reports of the 10 newly admitted travellers are awaited,” Ramchandra Hankare, chief of PMC’s health department, said.Apart from Pune, Mumbai and Thane, travellers are also being monitored in Nanded, Buldhana, Nagpur, Wardha, Sangli, Ahmednagar, Amaravati, Palghar, Jalgaon, Chandrapur and Satara districts.Health officials have said family, friends, colleagues and other close contacts of the travellers who returned from the affected countries should report themselves to health officials in case they develop flu-like symptoms.The Naidu hospital in Pune is designated as the isolation facility for residents/travellers returning from affected countries, an official said.

Title: Nagpur: Key to nailing history lies in the textbook
Content:
Representative image

As the history syllabus is vast, the major challenge for a student is to complete the portion on time. Students therefore get tempted to study from guidebooks and not refer to the textbooks at all. I would advise students not to commit this blunder.

As per the new pattern, the question paper comprises of 20 objective type questions which need a thorough reading of the textbook. Chapters on kinship, caste and class, Harappan civilization, colonial cities, partition and Mahatma Gandhi and the national movement should be studied thoroughly for this section. While going through the chapters, the student should also study the pictures especially in Book 1 and Book 2.

The picture illustrations of thinker, beliefs and buildings, Vijaynagar empire, colonial city, Bhakti-Sufi traditions are very important for picture based MCQ. Moreover the meanings of certain ancient and medieval terms like ‘Milkiyat’, ‘Daftar’, ‘Mleccha’, ‘Rakshasa’, etc also need to be learnt for this section to score full marks.

The source based questions will test the comprehension skills of the student. So use the reading time to read the paragraphs carefully and read all the questions pertaining to the paragraph before writing the answers. Try to search the answers from the paragraph. Sometimes you might not find the answer in the paragraph. In such cases, you need to recollect the content of the chapter from where the source has been taken.

Every student should be able to score well in the map based questions as the they already know the places that they are expected to locate and identify. For 3 mark and 8 mark questions, I would advise you to jot down the points while learning the answers instead of memorizing word to word which is often the tendency among students.

Jotting down the key points will not only give you clarity but will also help you to remember during the exam. Try to adhere to the word limit and attempt all questions without fail.

Finally, it is necessary to remain calm. Your mind works better when you are calm. All the best!

Title: ‘TN is no Delhi to unleash attacks on minorities’
Content:
Chennai: At the forefront of anti-CAA campaign Nagapattinam MLA and Manithaneya Jananayaga Katchi leader Thamimun Ansari , who contested on the AIADMK symbol, said empty threats of the BJP leaders will not scare Muslims . Hailing TN as the land of social reformist Periyar, Ansari in an interview with TOI, said protesters were prepared to stand their ground till the summer of 2024 and would join hands with Periyarists, Ambedkarists and Marxists to face the fascists

Q: Despite the PM, home minister and CM of TN saying that CAA will not affect minorities in anyway, why are there innumerable protests?

We wanted to see who is saying this. These people said they will not demolish Babri Masjid and that they would only offer pujas. But they demolished it the very next day (in 1992). Besides this, the BJP with its majoritarianism is functioning as per the direction of the RSS. So, the citizens of the country are not ready to believe their words.

As for Tamil Nadu, I agree that chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and other AIADMK leaders are concerned about minorities. But we cannot rely on their assurances as they are unable to protect their own party from the BJP. When they are not able to protect themselves how can they protect others? In such a scenario, the anti-CAA protests are gaining momentum and spreading to different parts of the state. People from different walks of life are also joining us in our fight.

Q: Why are minorities scared of CAA, NPR and NRC ?

Nineteen lakh people were affected after NRC was implemented in Assam. Of these, 12 lakh were Hindus. The NRC exercise carried out in Assam has led to degradation of society. It left out 17 of the family members of former President Fakhurddin Ali Ahmed, besides former Assam CM Syeda Anwara Taimur and Kargil veteran Mohammad Sanallulah. So, we are strongly against the implementation of NRC. We are fighting for the people of other religions and faith, not for us alone. We want citizenship for Sri Lankan Tamils too.

After strong protests against NRC, the Centre is trying to bring it through the back door by adding six controversial questions from NRC to NPR. We are not against NPR that was formulated during the regime of former PMs Atal Bihari Vajpayee and Manmohan Singh. But we cannot allow the present format. We are also not against the census that is conducted once every 10 years.

Q: The BJP and its ally AIADMK are saying the DMK and the Congress are carrying out a misinformation campaign to instigate Muslims for political gain. Your view?

It is wrong to say the DMK, the Congress and the communist parties are instigating minorities. They are only extending their support to the people’s movement against CAA and taking part in it. If what this government says is true, then why are BJP allies like the Shiromani Akali Dal, Nitish Kumar’s JD(U), and the PMK opposing it.

Q: A few BJP leaders have cautioned that Delhi kind of violence will unfold in TN if the state fails to quell protests. They have demanded a ban on anti-CAA protests. Your comment?

I urge the Tamil Nadu government to invoke the National Security Act against people speaking in such a manner to instigate violence. Meanwhile, I can say that they can only threaten and make empty noise, but fascist forces never had the power to defeat a people’s movement. Delhi is not Tamil Nadu. We will join hands with Periyarists, Ambedkarists and Marxists in the state and face the fascists.

Q: The opposition parties and AIADMK ally the PMK have urged the TN government to pass a resolution against CAA. The CM is firm that it will not affect minorities. Even if the government passes such a resolution, how helpful will it be?

By casting 11 votes, the AIADMK had played a big role in leading the country into a destructive path and disturbed the peace of the country. Bihar CM Nitish Kumar had also committed the same blunder, but he changed his stand and is trying to correct it. We urge the AIADMK government to change its stand by passing a resolution against CAA. By doing so, the state government will give a minimum guarantee that it will not harm the people.

Q: Unlike yesteryears, Muslim women are participating in large numbers in the protests. Women in Tamil Nadu have replicated the Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh style protest. What has brought this change?

Muslim women across the country are educated these days and are keenly following the media. Education and political awareness among them have brought them to the streets to fight for their rights and that of fellow citizens.

Q: Since the AIADMK supported the bill in Parliament, are you regretting supporting this government during critical times?

Former CM J Jayalalithaa was a follower of social justice. So, we joined the AIADMK under her leadership. But, the present AIADMK leadership is going against its own ideology, because of which we came out of the alliance ahead of the Lok Sabha elections last year. We have no regrets. In fact, it gave us a sense of satisfaction to fight for a cause and ideology. By doing so, we are reflecting the conscience of the people of the state.

Title: CM lays foundation stones of projects worth crores in Shamli
Content:
Meerut: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath, who is on two-day visit to Uttarakhand and western UP, distributed medical equipment among the disabled and laid foundation stones of development works worth Rs 230 crore in the region.

On day one of his visit, CM Yogi attended a yoga festival with his Uttrakhand counterpart Trivendra Singh Rawat in Rishikesh from where he arrived in Shamli district on Sunday afternoon.

Addressing a gathering briefly in Shamli, the CM said, “Before our government came to power in the state, people used to flee from Kairana and Kandhla. But not now. A battalion of PAC is also being set up in Kairana and Kandhla which will further strengthen the security in the area.”

While laying the foundation stone for the district police lines, CM Yogi said, “Our government has decided to earmark funds on a priority basis to districts without police headquarters, police lines and barracks. This initiative is being taken on a war-footing.”

On Sunday evening, he attended another event in Gautam Buddh Nagar where he inaugurated the newly constructed office of Noida police commissioner.

Title: Coronavirus: M’nagar family on pilgrimage stranded in Iran, seeks help from Indian embassy
Content:
Muzaffarnagar: Suhail Tyagi, 30, who along with his wife and a four-year-old daughter had set off for a pilgrimage to Iran on February 18, is currently stranded at a hotel in Tehran. Tyagi and his family was supposed to return to India via Dubai but was rendered helpless after Dubai cancelled all incoming flights from Iran due to outbreak of new coronavirus.

The family has now reached out to India embassy in Tehran for assistance.

Suhail’s father Inam Ilahi, a retired government employee, said, “They were scheduled to be back to India on February 24. But Kuwait Airways suspended their flights to and from Iran after the west Asian nation reported outbreak of the virus. Later, they booked flight tickets from other airlines via Dubai, but they have been told all airlines have suspended their flights from Iran.”

“They have contacted the Indian embassy in Tehran. The officials are in touch with them and hopefully, help will reach them soon,” Ilahi added.

The family was on a pilgrimage to Imam Reza shrine, the mausoleum of Imam Reza, the eighth Imam of Twelver Shiites, in Mashhad, Khorasan-e-Razavi.

Meanwhile, Iran’s health ministry on Sunday raised the nationwide death toll from the new coronavirus to 54 as the number of infected cases jumped overnight to 978 people.

Ministry spokesman Kianoush Jahanpour said new cases were confirmed in a number of cities, including Mashhad, which is home to Iran's most important Shiite shrine that attracts pilgrims from across the region. Calls by Iran's civilian government to clerics to close such shrines to the public have not been uniformly followed.

The virus, which originated in central China, has infected at least seven government officials in Iran.

(With inputs from AP in Tehran)
