Title: State to come down heavily on illegal sale of drugs online
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The state government is gearing up to take strict action against unauthorized sale of medicines through online platforms. Health minister K K Shailaja said the government was committed to putting the breaks on such dangerous and unauthorized sales of drugs.

The support and cooperation of the Union government was essential to ebb out the unhealthy tendency reportedly taking roots in the state, she said.

“The state government alone could not clamp total restrictions on the online sale of medicines . In 2019, the state drugs control department had issued a blanket ban against international drug major Medlife International that had been selling medicines across the state via online platform. Now, it has come to our notice that the activities of the company and similar ones are still prevalent in the state. Despite the limitations, the state government is putting serious efforts to eliminate the online drug sale to a possible extent. The practice of taking medicines unrestrictedly, not based on any authentic prescriptions from registered medical practitioners could be mortally harmful. All concerned should keep a vigil against such tendencies. The public should also be aware of the same,” the minister said.

As per the Drugs And Cosmetics Act 1940, Drugs And Cosmetics Rules 1945, online sale of medicine is not permissible. However, following media reports regarding rampant online sales of drugs, the department had carried out widespread investigations. “It has come to the fore that all the companies and agencies that are engaged in online sale of drugs are operating from outside Kerala. Often, they provide drugs without any valid prescriptions. The drugs controller had intimated his counterparts in those states from where the drug sales companies operate. However, requests for action against the companies did not elicit any positive result,” she said.

Unrestricted use of allopathy medicines, especially antibiotics, sleeping pills, medicines for mental illnesses and sexual stimulants are highly dangerous.

Over-the-counter sale of such medicines are effectively restricted and monitored by the state drugs control department. However, the menace could be effectively curbed only if the Union government takes steps to carry out changes in the laws concerned, making the unbridled online sale of drugs a criminal offence.

Title: Pune: Hardeep Singh Puri says auto sector no indicator of economic slowdown
Content:
Hardeep Singh Puri (second from left) at the Asia Economic Dialouge on Sunday

PUNE: Union minister for housing, urban development and civil aviation Hardeep Singh Puri on Sunday said the automotive sector could not be a decisive indicator of economic slowdown in the country.

Figures from other sectors, including housing and civil aviation, “bust the false narrative” about an economic slowdown in the country, Puri said at the valedictory session of the Asia Economic Dialogue organised by the Pune International Centre here.

He was responding to the discussion at a preceding session with Ola Cabs cofounder and CEO Bhavish Aggarwal, who was asked about finance minister Nirmala Sitaraman’s comment in September last year, blaming the millennials for the slump in car sales.

A former diplomat-turned-politician, Puri said apart from goods and services, technology was making a big impact on global trade and India must place a “laser like focus” on enabling a settling operation of mammoth scale in network products.

He said, “China’s remarkable export performance has much to do with a deliberate specialization in the large-scale labour intensive network products produced across global value chains operated by multinational companies.”

On the slowdown, Puri said about two-and-a-half years ago when he became a minister, the Delhi Metro rail had a ridership of 2.4 million passengers a day and the number has now increased to 6.5 million per day. He said, “One can get a pretty good picture of what mobility is all about if we calculate the increase in Ola and Uber ridership during this period. Certain high-end vehicles were sold, but some others could not be sold because of technical specifications, such as BS-IV and BS-VI requirements.”

The minister said, “A Mckenzie report of 2010 stated India was adding 700-900 million square metre of urban space every year, which is equivalent to a Chicago. Looking at our flagship housing sector, the objective was to build 1 crore units by 2022. But our committee for monitoring and sanctioning of projects, which met in December last year, had already sanctioned 1 crore homes in a span of three months. We are now into assessment of the revised demand.”

Puri said, “In civil aviation, the Pune airport is handling 9 million passengers every year and plans to move towards the 16 million passengers every year with a demand for more flights. India is already the 3rd largest domestic civil aviation market with 435 million passengers throughout per year. The country is now looking at one billion passengers per year. We will add 100 new airports and the number of civil aircraft has gone up from less than 600 in 2018-19 to 750 as of now. We are adding two-three aircraft per week and a private airline has ordered 300 aircraft. Do these figures look like economic slowdown?”

On global trade and economy, Puri said the Asian continent continued to be shaped by China (with a GDP of $14 trillion), Japan ($5trillion), the vibrant and dynamic economies of south-east Asian countries, the Republic of Korea and a growing Indian economy, which is already 5th largest in the world and seeks to transform from the $2.89 trillion economy to $5 trillion by 2024 and $10 trillion by 2030.

He, however, said any debate on Asia must factor in the domestic political realities and the impact of trade decisions on livelihood and stability.

Niti Aayog vice-chairman Rajiv Kumar identified new binding carbon constraints, new technology and inequality between economies as the key challenges of the 21st century vis-à-vis development and trade. “Emerging economies can no longer follow the models of the developed countries. There has to be a push for electric mobility and electric shared and connected mobility,” he said, adding India should not shy away from openness and multilateral trading.

Maharashtra minister for environment Aditya Thackeray spoke about the “reverse movement of thought and innovation” in Asia and India and the economic opportunity it presented to the country. “Balancing environment and economy is also a challenge and the state government is working towards striking an apt balance. Maharashtra will always remain open to ideas, economy, growth and development,” he said.

Title: Pune civic body shuts down illegal transfer of funds for projects and locations
Content:
The PMC circular refers to a September 2018 notice and says any digression will end up in the project being sc... Read More

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has clamped down on unauthorised movement of funds for municipal works. Internal transfer of public funds for civic works, made by corporators among themselves, has also been barred.

Henceforth, projects will be scrapped, if those works or funds allocated to them are shifted from one municipal ward to another, without proper process and permissions. The move was made to avoid misuse of public money under the garb of transfers.

The elected members get budgetary provisions to carry out development works in their wards. Funds are given through the main office and from the ward offices. The rights to approve financial aid for projects are vested with civic officials if the provisions are less. The green signal from the civic standing committee and general body are a must for bigger projects.

“Projects are designed for a particular ward or location. The money is allotted to them accordingly. These funds need to be moved after due approvals. Then tenders are supposed to be issued and work orders allotted. But some elected members have transferred the works or funds on their own without carrying out due process. Technically, all such transfers are unauthorised,” a senior PMC official said.

He added that the money allotted for the projects should be spent in the given financial year. If not approved, the funds can lapse. Sometimes, the PMC has given extensions to the municipal budget for three to four months. The aim was to make sure that funds are utilised properly.

The municipal commissioner’s office, referring to a September 2018 circular, in the last week of February issued a notice regarding any change of place in the municipal works. The older circular had highlighted that only in case of an emergency can works can be transferred from one place to another.

“Hereafter, those works for which tenders and work orders have been issued should not be transferred. If the project cannot be carried out at the proposed site due to some issue, then that tenders should be scrapped. The department heads of the PMC should follow this order strictly,” municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad said in the circular.

Title: Over 300 women drive to Jaipur from Delhi
Content:
Jaipur: Over 300 women drove to Jaipur from Delhi on Saturday under the Times Women’s Drive , an initiative by The Times of India to celebrate driving by women. The rally was flagged off by Kiren Rijiju , minister of youth affairs & sports in Delhi at 8:30am on Saturday.

The women drivers arrived in Jaipur between 3pm and 4pm in their cars at a private hotel. Later in the evening, the participants were awarded in different categories by chief guest Major General Sanjeev Grover, GOC, 61 Sub Area, South West Command.

“The event celebrates the spirit of women and Indian Army would love to associate with programmes that bring a change,” said the chief guest. The guest of honour and Mrs Asia International and Mrs India 2018, Dr Anupama Soni motivated the participants. The event is being termed as the largest women’s car rally in the country.

Title: Board counsellors take off pressure
Content:
Pune: Counsellors appointed by the Maharashtra State Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education have been flooded with calls from students and parents as well.

The counsellors said they get around 15 to 20 calls a day.

The state board has appointed 10 counsellors whose contact numbers were recently published online for the benefit of the students.

The counsellors have welcomed the idea of parents calling up as it showed a supportive attitude among them towards their children.

A counsellor Gayatri Wani said, “The students who call are not asking about whether they will pass or not. Their main worry is whether they will meet their target or not. Now, parents have become a lot more supportive. They have been calling and asking questions. When parents feel better after talking to us they tell their wards to call too.”

Sagar Gaikwad, who has been counselling for the past three years spoke about anxiety in students.

“The calls are generally from students who are scared about the examinations, who feel they will not be able to perform well or they will not be able to meet their parents’ expectations. Sometimes, after talking to the students, we talk to parents too telling them how they can be more supportive. The calls will increase around the result time as fear of result is another trigger” Gaikwad said.

Another counsellor Smita said that in the first week when the contact numbers were published, the calls by students were mostly about technical doubts such as exam centres or hall tickets. However, once that settled, the calls were increasingly about exam stress and anxiety.

Title: IGNCA to get temporary home at Delhi's Janpath Hotel
Content:
IGNCA will operate from the hotel for 2 years

NEW DELHI: Indira Gandhi National Centre for the Arts ( IGNCA ) is set to shift from its current location on Man Singh Road to a temporary address at Janpath Hotel in June. It will be operating from the hotel for two years, while a permanent complex is created at Jamnagar House on Shah Jahan Road.

The hotel, which was shut down in November 2017, will be revamped to meet the requirement.

Ram Bahadur Rai, president of IGNCA, said, “Janpath Hotel has been taken over by CPWD and work on refurbishing the entire place and developing areas as per our needs is under way. It will have provisions for a library, laboratories, classrooms, a studio for audio-visual recording, exhibition space, conference room, guest house and an auditorium with a capacity for 200 people.”

The IGNCA building and nine others, among them Udyog Bhawan, Nirman Bhawan, Shastri Bhawan and the vice-president’s residence, are planned to be demolished to pave the way for the redevelopment of the Central Vista. The new permanent campus for IGNCA will come on a plot where Jamnagar House hutments are now located.

A panel is being set up to oversee the safe shifting of the arts institution’s collection of books, paintings and manuscripts. IGNCA has been bequeathed the library collections of 28 eminent Indians, including Namwar Singh, Kapila Vatsyayan, Hazari Prasad Dwivedi and Suniti Kumar Chatterji. It also has rare paintings. The centre organises cultural events, conferences and academic activities.

“These activities will continue at our makeshift office,” said Dr Sachchidanand Joshi, member-secretary, IGNCA. “It’s just that the overall space will be less than at our existing complex, where we have a huge basement storage. So, we will need to plan properly about collections to display and those to keep in storage.”

Joshi was amenable to the temporary convenience, saying, “Everything is happening for a better future”. He said that two years, IGNCA would have a bigger and permanent address at Jamnagar House. “Around 15 acres of land have been earmarked for the construction of a new building, which will have all facilities to meet our requirements of the next 30 years.”

Joshi claimed that the current building had only a third of the facilities and infrastructure that the institution actually required. “The auditorium is small, the conference room has pillars standing in the middle and often proving a hindrance to the smooth conduct of an event. Most importantly, there is much open space that is not serving any purpose,” said Joshi.

The IGNCA management has visited the office of the architectural firm redesigning Central Vista and redeveloping Jamnagar House.

The temporary relocation of IGNCA is necessary as the government is planning to build the first modern office block on the land which is now occupied by the government-funded arts organisation. “Since the built-up area in this plot is very less, so demolishing them and starting fresh construction can start early. Once the office block is built on this plot, offices from a couple of existing Bhawans along Rajpath can be shifted to the new building. Subsequently, we can start reconstruction of these empty buildings,” said a source.

Officials said the construction of new office buildings will be taken up in a phased manner so that there is less displacement of people. They added that the offices operating from the Jamnagar House hutments and other such complexes in the area will be shifted to a new building, which will come up on a vacant plot on the Kasturba Gandhi Marg and some of these establishments will also be shifted to an office building in Africa Avenue in south Delhi.

Meanwhile, TOI has learnt that the central public works department (CPWD), has bid out the work for shifting of the present reception area and other facilities at Parliament complex to make enough land available for construction of new Parliament. They added the makeshift reception will move close to the existing Parliament. The relocation of reception area will start soon.

(With inputs from Dipak Dash)

Title: Water billing for only 50% of supply in Nagpur, of which half is unpaid
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Even after running amnesty schemes and giving over a decade to consumers, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and Orange City Water Private Ltd (OCW) have failed to recover Rs194 crore water bill arrears from government, civic establishments and residential and commercial property owners as on January 31, 2020.

As per NMC-OCW data, the civic body is lifting around 740 MLD from Pench reservoirs and Kanhan river but of the total water supplied to meet city’s requirement, billing is done only for 370 MLD (50%).

The city has total 3.61 lakh water consumers. Out of them, 1.7 lakh consumers are defaulters. The arrears indicate that 50% of the billed water has gone unpaid, taking the non-revenue water (NRW) figure to a staggering 75%.

Disconnecting 4,293 consumers led to recovery of Rs14.71 crore so far.

As per the data, the revenue from water supply for the current financial year is Rs116.24 crore against a target of Rs166 crore.

Outgoing NMC water works chairman Pintu (Vijay) Zalke admitted that the civic body has failed to remove the backlog for over a decade now. He, however, said that Rs142 crore arrears were recovered this fiscal,” he told TOI.

Zalke said that under his watch, 33,000 illegal connection were detected and 8,000 of them snapped after following due process. He said after taking over as new standing committee chief on March 5, he will initiate measures for the recovery of Rs194 crore “in a fair manner” along with other works.

Mayor Sandip Joshi attributed the arrears to a couple of reasons, including faulty billing, delay in setting up new connections and ignorance of consumers. “The problem lies in billing pattern of NMC as disputes are not settled fast. At the same time, defaulters too have now become used to not paying dues at all. Therefore, the arrears keep increasing though recovery is an ongoing process,” he said.

Joshi agreed that its high time to take tough decision to fix the problem of non-payment as well as NRW. “OCW will be held responsible for NRW. It could recover only up to 50 to 70 MLD of the unbilled water. These issues would be raised during the meeting of Nagpur Environmental Services Limited (NMC’s special purpose vehicle for water works) this month,” he said.

Zalke too said a new policy is needed as one time settlement (OTS) or amnesty scheme too has failed to make impact. “Immediate disconnection is one solution but due time for filing objections will be given. NRW stands at 52%, and efforts are on to bring it down to minimum. During review meeting of all departments as standing panel chairman, water works will be on priority,” he said.

OCW spokesperson said the agency has been conducting mass disconnection drive against defaulters and illegal consumers. “Every day, stern action is taken against around 300 defaulters and around 200 illegal consumers. NMC is in the process of providing police protection as and when required beside administrative support during the drive,” the spokesperson said.

OCW has planned a 12-hour shutdown of Chinchbhuvan, Pratap Nagar and Khamla ESR for installation of 500 MM diameter valves on inlet of Chinchbhuvan and Khamla ESR on March 2 (Monday). The shutdown will be from 10am to 10pm the same day. Areas receiving supply from Chinchbhuvan, Pratap Nagar and Khamla ESR will be affected due to no water.

Title: Hearing on Goa’s crucial Mhadei plea in Supreme Court today
Content:
Supreme Court

PANAJI: A crucial hearing in the Mhadei water diversion case is likely to come up in the Supreme Court on Monday following the state government’s application seeking interim relief by restraining Karnataka from carrying out construction or any other activity on the Mhadei.

Last week, the state government approached the apex court to seek a direction to Karnataka that it should not approach any authorities for permission till the matter is heard in court.

The government also sought direction from the Supreme Court to Karnataka to stop diversion of water. Chief minister Pramod Sawant had demanded a joint inspection headed by the chief engineer of the central water commission or assessor of the Mhadei Water Disputes Tribunal to expose Karnataka’s illegalities.

The state approached the Supreme Court in view of reports that Karnataka would move to start work on its Kalasa-Bhandura water drinking projects on the Mhadei following the court’s interim order.

Last week, the Supreme Court, in an interim order, directed the Centre to notify the MWDT’s August 14, 2018 award, but said it was subject to the outcome of the petitions filed by the riparian states — Goa, Karnataka and Maharashtra — against the award.

Based on the Supreme Court’s direction, the Union government notified the award on February 28.

The Supreme Court also admitted the Goa government’s special leave petition challenging the award and posted it for final hearing on July 15, 16 and 22.

Sawant had said that during the hearings in the apex court in July, the state government will furnish enough evidence to prove that Karnataka has illegally diverted water from the Mhadei basin.

In August 2018, the three-decade-old dispute between three states — Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Goa — over sharing of the Mhadei waters ended with the tribunal rejecting Karnataka’s demand for 36.5 tmc, and allotted it only 13.4 tmc, including 3.9 tmc for drinking purposes through diversions, against its demand for 7.5 tmc.

Goa, in the special leave petition, wants the tribunal award allotting 3.9 tmc to Karnataka for drinking quashed.

Title: IRTC warns passengers against cyber criminals
Content:
Aurangabad: Amidst the rising number of cyber frauds cases, the Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) has come up with an advisory for the passengers to avoid getting cheated online.

Highlighting that e-ticket cancellation refund process is transaction-driven and fully automatic, IRCTC has said that it never makes phone calls, sends e-mails, messages asking customers to disclose their personal or security information.

“The refund of a cancelled ticket is automatically processed into user’s same bank account from which the booking was made and is usually completed within a week.,” the corporation has said.

It has requested users not to share their bookings and cancellations details on social media platforms to avoid misuse by miscreants.

The IRCTC, in its advisory, has also highlighted tips for safe online search.

“Users are also requested to be careful while searching Google and other similar platforms for IRCTC related queries as these platforms may contain mobile applications or websites aimed at misusing the users credentials. Users should refer to IRCTC website for all ticketing, refunds and its authorized business partners related queries,” IRCTC has said.

The corporation has 0755-6610661, 0755-4090600 as is customer care number and has designated email id etickets@irctc.co.in for cancellation of train tickets.

Railway activist Raj Somani said, “The cyber criminals are devising new methods to cheat individuals. The safety tips issued by IRCTC assumes huge significance and must be followed.’”

Title: Work on platform for artisans to start soon
Content:
Pune: The work on ‘Kalagram’ — a dedicated open-air market in the city to display handicraft and items showcasing cultures from across the country — is set to start.

The cultural space is inspired by the Dilli Haat in New Delhi and will be built on a 3.5 acre piece of land at the P L Deshpande garden near Sinhagad Road.

“The work on the project would start soon. The market would have 28 stalls and would provide a space for the artists and craftsmen to exhibit their produce from across the country, including Maharashtra. The idea is to build the market on the lines of Dilli Haat. The project is likely to near completion in next 6-7 months’ time,” chief garden superintendent of Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) Ashok D Ghorpade told TOI.

The first Dilli Haat was established in 1994 as a platform for artisans from the remotest corners of the country to showcase their skills.

“At present, we are examining the Dilli Haat model. A team of the civic body would soon get in touch with the Delhi Tourism and Transportation Development Corporation (DTTDC) which manages the facility there. We would also visit Dilli Haat as and when Kalagram nears completion. Intricate details of the space would be studied and replicated here,” the senior official added.

Another PMC official pointed out that the stalls at the facility would be given out on a rotational basis to interested parties. “The rotational allotment of stalls would ensure that the visitors have different options every time. We also plan to advertise the facility on a big scale with the help of concerned departments of the state government,” the official added.

“I just hope that the civic body does not delay the project anymore. Pune is called the cultural capital of state, and everyone here would like to have such a facility within close proximity,” Kedar Shikre, a senior citizen from Kothrud, said.

Title: Indian diaspora in Europe slams Delhi violence
Content:
Kolkata: The members of the Indian diaspora in Europe, mostly students and working professionals, took part in a simultaneous demonstration — from 12.30pm to 5pm on Saturday — across 15 European cities, including Berlin, Brussels, Dublin, Frankfurt, Geneva, Glasgow, Hague, Hamburg, Helsinki, Krakow, London, Munich, Paris and Stockholm to show solidarity to the victims of the violence in Delhi.

The demonstration condemned the Delhi violence, the provocative hate speech by BJP leader Kapil Mishra and the inaction by the state and police in abetting the mob. The protesters across Europe chose white rose against the fascist forces and send out a message of peace. Some cities chose to protest silently with posters and placards whereas others like Geneva, Krakow protested by reciting poems, singing songs and reading out the Preamble. Human rights activists and journalists of Europe also took part in the demonstration.

Deep Roy, Phd student of Hydraulic Engineering at University of Pisa, said, “The riots in Delhi are clear example of how far the divisive rhetoric practised by the saffron brigade has poisoned the society. I am shocked at the sheer scale of devastation and loss of human life. We strongly condemn the purposeful inaction by the home ministry to curb the situation.”

A research scholar in Geneva said, “The video footages of places of worship, especially mosque, shops, homes being vandalized, burnt and razed to the ground are disturbing. The reports of journalists recounting their horror was hard to believe as something of this magnitude can happen in a democratic, secular country. The protest is also an integrated attempt to bring the issue to the attention of EU leaders, members.”

About 70 individuals, students from India studying in Europe as well as residents of Europe, have written an open letter to the Government of India raising concerns on the current state of lawlessness and lack of personal liberty prevailing in India and demanded immediate withdrawal of CAA and pan-India NRC to protect the secular and humanitarian ethos of Constitution. Ida Venditti, a political science student at University of Pisa, said: “Indian Constitution is at risk and so is civil society. The act is discriminatory as is being used as a weapon against its own people.”

Title: Ayush clinic to be set up at old GIM bldg
Content:
Panaji: The Goa government has allotted the ground floor of the old campus of Goa Institute of Management ( GIM ) to the ministry of Ayush to set up an Ayush centre, minister of state for Ayush Shripad Naik said recently.

He said around 1,600sqm has been allotted for the centre at Ribandar along with 252 sqm for residential accommodation.

Under the National Ayush Mission, Rs 30 crore has been sanctioned for the two district hospitals, he said, adding that an initial amount has been released to the Goa government to start work.

Naik also said that construction of the All India Institute of Ayurveda, Yoga and Naturopathy at Dhargal in Pernem is in progress. The total cost of phase I of the project is Rs 301 crore, with 250 beds which will be managed by trained and qualified staff, he said.

The centre will offer undergraduate, postgraduate and PhD degrees to over 500 students every year. A memorandum of understanding has been signed between the ministry of Ayush and the Goa government under which 50% of the seats will be reserved for locals .

Title: Pune: Brakes on plan to turn old buses into mobile toilets
Content:
One of the remodelled PMPML buses refashioned into a mobile toilet

PUNE: The civic body’s mobile toilets, fashioned out of the scrapped PMPML buses, have lost the momentum.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC), in association with the Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML), had planned to convert old buses into public toilets in 2016 in an attempt to provide sanitation facilities to residents and tourists, in turn facilitating the reuse of these old vehicles.

The civic body started off with a plan to fashion 100 scrapped buses into mobile toilets. But it remodelled only 10 though funds for another 13 were approved.

The number of toilets for women was to be increased through this initiative. But after remodelling a few buses, the authorities have planned to revert to the old practice of scrapping the old vehicles.

Over 200 old buses will be scrapped instead of converting them into toilets, thus, bringing the project to a standstill.

The PMPML’s guidelines state that a bus is to be scrapped once it completes 7 lakh km and/or has been in service for 10 years.

Nayana Gunde, PMPML’s chairman and managing director, said the public transport body was meeting the demand of the civic administration.

“The PMC has demanded some buses for this project. We have considered it. Further progress will be made soon,” she said.

According to the plan, the buses were to be equipped with five toilet seats — three pertaining to the Indian style and two to the western.

The mobile toilets were also expected to have a shower area fitted with water sensors and a sanitary napkin dispensing machine.

Safety measures such as the provision for a panic button was to be integrated in each facility.

The PMC had stationed these toilets at Jangli Maharaj Road, Shivajinagar, Aundh, Vishrantwadi, Anandnagar, Shaniwarwada, Phulenagar and Baner.

The remodelling cost for each bus was around Rs1.92 lakh. The transport utility has in the past two years scrapped 300 old buses.

Title: Goa: Case against 19-year-old for kidnapping
Content:
Representative image

POINGUINIM: Canacona police have registered a complaint against Mumbai resident Gopal Vithal Naik, 19, for kidnapping a 17-year-old girl. The complaint was filed by the mother of the minor.

A team led by PI Ramesh Shirodkar traced the accused and the minor to Kalyan , Mumbai, on Saturday and were brought to Canacona police station on Sunday.

The accused has been placed in two-day police custody while the minor has been lodged at Apna Ghar.

The case has been registered under Section 363 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 8 of the Goa Children 's Act. PSI Dhiraj Devidas is further investigating the case.

Title: Pune: Senior company official booked for demanding sexual favours
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: The Nigdi police on Saturday registered an offence against a senior official working with a private company for demanding sexual favours from a woman co-worker who is his junior.

The man had been harassing the 31-year-old woman for the past four months. He threatened to sack her from the job. The harassed woman on Saturday approached the Nigdi police and lodged an FIR.

The police then booked the man under sections 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty), 354-A (sexual harassment) of the Indian Penal Code .

An officer from the Nigdi police told TOI that the man works as the project head in the company.

“The woman, in her complaint, stated that whenever she would report to him about work, he would talk to her in a lewd manner and sought sexual favours and threatened to sack her if she did not give in,” the officer said.

Last week, the woman’s complaint said, he told her that he would come to her area.

The man told her to come out with him and that he would drop her back in the evening so no one would suspect anything amiss, she added in her complaint to the police.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Aldona locals oppose jetty for Sagarmala project
Content:
Saligao: Villagers of Aldona unanimously passed a resolution to oppose the central government's Sagarmala project, which includes the construction of a jetty, at Sunday’s gram sabha.

During the meeting, officer from Captain of Ports (CoP) Prem Lal Sirsaikar who had come to give a presentation on the project could not provide answers to the questions posed by villagers, as to how the project would benefit the village.

The officer told the villagers that the jetty to be constructed would only benefit passengers and would not facilitate the transportation of cargo. As the villagers were not convinced with the presentation, they confronted him and Sirsaikar walked out of the meeting. The villagers condemned the officer’s behaviour and took a resolution to oppose the construction of the jetty entirely.

Title: Mumbai team ‘VCET Solecthon’ wins National Solar Vehicle Challenge at VNIT
Content:
Nagpur: The National Solar Vehicle Challenge (NSVC) 2020, organised by the Electrical Engineering Department (VNIT Nagpur) in association with Dynamist Motorsports, New Delhi, concluded on March 3, 2020. The objective of the event was to evaluate solar electric vehicles designed and built by the students’ team from across the country. It was a year-long event with 33 participating teams out of which only 15 qualified for the final round. In the end, only 12 teams with 300 student members were able to demonstrate their prototype vehicles. NSVC 2020 is the 4th in the session and 1st in Maharashtra. Members of the students’ team of VNIT, Team Velocity and Team Tesla dedicatedly worked to organise the event.

Rigorous evaluations such as technical inspection, solar endurance, acceleration, brake test and on-road testing under actual conditions were carried out. Team “VCET Solecthon” from Mumbai were declared overall champions. They pocketed Rs 1 lakh. The first and second runners-up teams received Rs 40,000 and Rs 20,000 respectively. Apart from these awards, prizes worth Rs 1 lakh were given to winners of the evaluation tests.

Arvind Kumar, head, TCS Mihan, was the chief guest and Shrikant Dube, Mahindra & Mahindra Group, was the guest of honour. Shrikant was overwhelmed with the performance and motivation of the students in designing and making solar electric vehicles. He appreciated the efforts of VNIT. Arvind Kumar explained how collaboration with VNIT in the area of electric mobility has drawn the attention of their international clients to setup infrastructure in TCS Mihan. He appreciated the performance of the participating candidates and motivated them with his words. Prof PM Padole, director VNIT, congratulated the student teams and guided them about what more they can do to improve the performance of the vehicle and standardise their prototypes. The event started with the speech of prof M A Chaudhari, head, electrical engineering department. She expressed her views on electric vehicles and what the department is doing to develop electric vehicle technologies.

Ritesh Keshri and Arghya Mitra from VNIT coordinated the event.

Title: NGO initiates mass sterilization drive for cats
Content:
pix mailed/neha

Pune: A non-governmental organisation (NGO) has initiated a mass sterilization drive for cats in the city, under which 5 ,000 animals have already been spayed to control their population.

Representatives of the NGO, Karma Foundation, said nine housing societies had already got in touch with them to sterilize free-roaming cats. “There is a lot of awareness about sterilization of dogs, but not much about cats. This prompted us to take up the mass sterilization drive for cats. Housing societies are getting in touch with us to spay their free-roaming or community cats. The best part is that the societies always want their stray cats back after neutering,” Priya Kailad, president, Karma Foundation, told TOI.

Under the drive, the neutered cats are set free after post-surgery care at the location from where they are picked and one of their ears is notched (an indication that the animal has been spayed).

The NGO said dogs were much easier to handle as they were more trusting of humans. “Cats, by nature as well as biologically, are quite sensitive and introvert. So, they have to be dealt with differently than dogs,” she said.

The NGO representatives first carry out a recce of the societies seeking sterilization of the stray cats, following which trap cages are put at suitable spots. “The traps are then covered with a cloth to avoid stressing the animal after entering the cage. Once the cats are trapped, the cages are transported to our centre, where the sterilization is done,” Kailad said.

Once the cats are at the sterilization centre, their caretakers can check for their online updates on the NGO website.

The NGO is also holding a monthly drive where a few representatives visit the slums to educate the residents about spaying cats and why it is necessary. Once the slum residents agree for spaying the community cats, the NGO seeks out sponsors or donors to fund the surgeries, while 50% of the amount is borne by the NGO.

Ganesh Rao, treasurer of Sylvan Heights in Aundh, one of the socities which approached the NGO for sterilizing community cats, said, “We started getting complaints about some undesirable behaviours like cat calls in the night, among others. We then got in touch with Karma Foundation for spaying the cats. After sterilization, all such behaviours have stopped.”

Title: Barmer custodial death: Body taken away after agreement between kin and admin
Content:
Jaisalmer: Efforts of Barmer MLA and former minister Babu Lal Nagar bore results as family members of the Dalit youth who died in police custody finally agreed to take the body after post-mortem. They agreed after a compensation of Rs 25 lakh, job to one of the family members and a plot of land was allotted to the family.

The agreement was signed by the administration and family members and the four-day deadlock was over.

Jodhpur range IG Navjyoti Gogoi said that the four-day sit-in before the mortuary was finally called off after the agreement between the family members and the state government. He said the post-mortem took place in presence of judicial magistrate as per the National Human Rights Commission guidelines. Videography of post-mortem has been conducted. The cremation of Jitendra Khatik will take place on Monday.

After the custodial death of Jitendra Khatik, his family had been sitting outside the mortuary. The mother and wife of the deceased did not eat anything and were admitted to government hospital. The family members had been adamant over CBI probe.

Attacking the Gehlot government Jalore MP Devji Patel said that this incident has raised questions over the state’s law and order situation. The family is so scared that the government will do something wrong with their two other sons and they want justice.

Patel said that he would raise this issue in the Lok Sabha. The delegation met the mother and wife of the deceased and enquired after their health. On Sunday morning revenue minister Harish Choudhary and Barmer MLA Mevaram Jain met the family members and leaders of the Dalit community.

Title: Northeast Delhi violence: Search for loved ones ends in tears at mortuary
Content:
Wife of Prem Singh, with their daughter at GTB Hospital

NEW DELHI: These were a trying five days for Sunita Singh as she frantically searched for her missing husband, Prem. Having visited several hospitals, her search sadly ended at the mortuary of Guru Tegh Bahadur Hospital. Clothes brought for Singh from “mangal bazaar” (weekly market) in Brijpuri helped Sunita identify her husband from among the six other bodies.

Sunita, who is now seven months pregnant, was inconsolable as she held her three-year-old son. She has two other children, one nine and another five, whom she had left at her home in Gali No. 3, C block, Brijpuri. On Tuesday morning, Singh, a rickshaw puller, had stepped out to get milk. He never returned. “I told him not to go outside, but he did not listen. He said he should get the milk,” said Sunita, who along with her neighbour, Nisha Sharma, had registered a missing complaint at Welcome PS.

For Nasima, too, the search for her son, Aqil Ahmed, ended at the mortuary. Ahmed had gone missing from his house in Mustafabad on February 26. Ahmed’s wife and four children had gone to Loni when the incident took place. Ahmed used to work at a car wash.

At the mortuary, there are still three bodies yet to be identified. A youth, who has been coming to the mortuary since Wednesday in hope of finding his brother, has already looked at 20-odd corpses.

Title: Door-to-door 3-drug therapy drive to prevent filariasis starts in Nagpur
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Health department of state, district administration and Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) have launched mass drug administration (MDA) activity to eliminate lymphatic filariasis on Sunday.

For next 20 days, over 22,900 health department employees will visit every household in six districts of Nagpur division and administer the dose of three medicines to all healthy citizens above 2 years of age. The medicines will prevent spread of filariasis, a parasitic disease caused by infection spread through mosquitoes. It will also keep citizens safe from worms and many types of parasite infestations.

“Filariasis is the second most common vector-borne parasitic disease after malaria. Nagpur division still has major prevalence of filariasis,” said deputy director (health) Dr Sanjay Jaiswal. Chandrapur district in Nagpur division has more than 16,000 patients of filariasis, which is the highest in state.

“Triple therapy is the best remedy to eradicate filariasis. In 2019, this drive was conducted in Nagpur district as a pilot project. A remarkable decrease in new cases of filariasis was recorded in the district,” said Dr Milind Ganvir, assistant director of health services.

This year, the government has given identity cards to all employees trained for the drive. They will convince the citizens and also ensure the tablets are consumed in front of them. The staffers will mark left index finger of a person who has taken the dose.

District malaria officer Dr Rahul Gaikwad said target is to cover 100% eligible population. “Children below 2 years, pregnant women and critically ill patients are to be excluded from this drive. All others should consume the tablets when health department personnel visit,” he said. The drive was formally launched in city at Gandhibagh Garden where mayor Sandip Joshi, MLA Krishna Khopde and others were present.

Title: Actor-politician quits BJP over ‘hate speech inaction’
Content:
KOLKATA: Actor-turned-politician Subhadra Mukherjee resigned from BJP in the aftermath of the Delhi violence.

Mukherjee, who joined the party in 2013, said it was not possible for her to be in the same party with functionaries like Kapil Mishra and Anurag Thakur , both of whom raised “goli maaro” (shoot them) slogans.

The actor, who sent her resignation to Bengal BJP chief Dilip Ghosh , said she joined the party with “hopes and optimism”, but was disillusioned following recent developments.

Mukherjee said, that while she was in favour of CAA , she did not approve of the way the party pressed ahead with it.

She added that she could not identify with a party that treated people on the basis of religion and not as fellow humans.

Title: Groundwater overuse is major concern: Chief secy
Content:
Jaipur: The groundwater situation in the state is very precarious with an exploitation rate of 140%, said chief secretary D B Gupta while addressing Times Water Summit 2020 here on Saturday.

“Water scenario in Rajasthan is the most challenging in the country with per capita availability of water less than 800 cubic meters against the national average of 1,545 cubic metres, said Gupta.

Lauding the summit as an excellent effort to address the water problem, he said it is more important as the state with 10.4% population of the country had to manage with just 1.16% of surface water and 1.72 % of groundwater.

Speaking about the challenges he said, “Not only the rainfall is scanty, but widely varies from 100 mm in arid west to 900 mm in south east. High intensity of rains and improper water conservation system leading to large percentage of the water going waste resulting in depletion of water table and cultivable land deprived of cultivation.”

In the absence of perennial water sources, 90% agriculture depends on rainwater with recurring famine. “Since people here are heavily depended on agriculture and animal husbandry, water and poverty are closely interlinked, and now climate change posed new challenges,” he said.

He expressed concern over the over expiation of groundwater. He said since water resources are very unevenly distributed, 65% irrigation depended on groundwater rest on surface water. So safe handling, conservation and focus judicious use from available water resources is very extremely important.

As per survey in 2017 out of the 295 blocks, 185 were under over exploited, 33 critical and 29 semi critical. The state experiences drought at regular interval. Out of 73 years post-Independence, 60 years were marked by drought. Increasing demand for water due to population growth and unsustainable water use are the main cause of water problem.

He said about 86% of total water is used for irrigation. So major saving will have had to come from irrigation. Flood irrigation was the norm and, in many areas, still the practice prevails, and it had to be replaced with drip and sprinkler irrigation, Gupta said.

He said quality of water is another issue. Water in large areas are affected by chloride, fluoride, nitrate etc. which aggravates the potable water problem. Over 3,300 aero plants were set up to address this issue.

Presently, the state suffers from imbalance in demand and supply, depleting groundwater, deteriorating quality of water over application of water in irrigation, low irrigation efficacy due to differed maintenance.

Title: Relocation of food carts to be discussed at CCP meet
Content:
Panaji: The Corporation of the City of Panaji (CCP) will take a decision on the relocation of 40 food carts that were seized from near Don Bosco school and Miramar, at its meeting on Monday evening.

Fourteen food carts selling everything from ros omlette and Chinese food in the paved area near Don Bosco School continue to be in CCP’s custody since January after they were found dumping food waste directly into the drains.

In addition to this, over 23 food carts operating in Miramar were also seized by CCP in February.

“The corporation will take a decision in the matter on Monday,” Panaji mayor Uday Madkaikar told TOI.

The food carts were seized because they were found to be operating till 4am despite only having permission to function between 4pm and 10pm, he said, adding that some were not following FDA’s hygiene standards, and not using gloves, aprons and caps, as well as failing to install ‘No Smoking’ signboards.

The ordinary meeting of the corporation will also see discussions on bringing more roads in the state capital under the pay parking system. Currently two and four-wheelers on notified stretches are being charged pay-parking fees.

In addition to this, the handing over of the EDC complex/Patto Plaza to CCP, where the corporation will be entirely responsible for maintenance of roads, footpaths, streetlights and pay-parking in the complex. EDC’s pay-parking contract ends on March 31.

Currently CCP only collects garbage from Patto Plaza while EDC manages the entire complex.

The long-pending issue of shopkeepers at the municipal market not paying rent will also be discussed at the meeting.

Title: Kerala Minister vows support for industrial corridor
Content:
V Muraleedharan, minister of state for external affairs

PALAKKAD: The Union minister of state for external affairs and parliamentary affairs, V Muraleedharan , has said the Centre will provide full support for making the Kochi-Coimbatore industrial corridor a reality.

In his address to members of Kanjikode industries forum here on Saturday, the minister said more industries should be set up in the corridor to create jobs opportunities.

“The Narendra Modi government at the Centre has put an end to the ‘licence and permit raj’ and has provided wider opportunities in the form of ease of doing business, startups, Make in India schemes, etc. It has even simplified the income tax payments by making it online thereby putting an end to interference of income tax department. An act on this would soon be introduced,” he said.

“The Centre will also address problems faced by the central public sector companies like Instrumentation Limited (IL) and the Indian Telephone Industries (ITI). It had taken steps to hand over the Palakkad unit of IL to the state government. But there are some delays due to the payment of the value of the land by the state government to the Centre. This could be solved through discussions,” the minister said.

He also invited entrepreneurs to utilize the possibilities of their investing in African counties for which the central government had introduced many programmes. He also said the demand for setting up an ESI and PF office in Palakkad will be taken up with the concerned central departments.

The minister who was on a whirlwind tour of the district on Saturday attended half-a-dozen programmes in different parts and inaugurated six major projects of Palakkad municipality implemented under the ‘Amrut smart city project’ at a function in the municipal office here.

He also has laid the foundation stone for Kalmandapam bus stand and four foot-over-bridges. The minister inaugurated solar plants in three schools, Palakkad Eye CCTV cameras in the municipality and the primary health centre in Koppam.

Title: Times Water Summit in Jaipur: Making Rajasthan water positive is need of the hour, feel experts & officials
Content:
Panelists during a discussion at the Times Water Summit in Jaipur

JAIPUR: Necessity is the mother of innovations, a secret behind the desert state ’s pioneering models for water conservation that it gave to the country in the past. But can Rajasthan do it one more time when the situation demands the most? Renowned experts and senior government officials during a panel discussion on ‘Making Rajasthan Water Positive’ did hold out hope that the critical situation can be turned around but it needs a circular approach of community participation, technology adoption and government policy intervention.

Opening the conversation, Naveen Mahajan , secretary, water resources department, set the context by saying Rajasthan depends heavily on neighboring states like Punjab, Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat as it gets 52% of its surface water from them though rivers like Ravi, Beas & Satluj, Chambal and Narmada. But Mahajan raised the red flag as to what will happen if those states violate the inter-state water sharing agreements in case of scarcity.

“Water being a very political topic, no state is willing to cede its share to the neighboring state. Unfortunately, we are downstream state, at the tail-end. If there is water scarcity in the upstream states, things will be very tough. The major challenge of water security for us is to ensure that our supplies are guaranteed as per the agreements,” said Mahajan.

He listed out the priorities of the government and said it’s high time we went for drips sprinklers. “Whatever new projects will come, now they will be purely on pressure pipe micro irrigation system,” added Mahajan.

Ajitabh Sharma, principal secretary, energy department, who also served as secretary of water resources department in the past, said it would be difficult to achieve sustainability by following a linear approach.

“Technology, engineering, projects, implementation, and bringing in large capital will not lead to sustainability if the community is not involved. Water is not scarce, there is plenty of it. It all depends how you use it. We have to start thinking beyond the engineering prospective. So, it has be a circular economy. We have to treat the water, have treatment standards for different uses which is not there now. In India, we have not started thinking about nature-based solutions for treatment of water, and we have to understand the aquifers for their recharge,” said Sharma.

But answering directly the question of making Rajasthan water positive, director of Central Ground Water Board S K Jain said Rajasthan has ground water which can be replenished up to 12 bcm (billion cubic metre) but we withdraw 17 bcm annually.

“To make it water positive, we need 5 bcm more. Storage of water, creating recharge structures, targeting Chambal basins, recycling and using less water and managing the water used in the agriculture sector will be the key to meet the shortfall and make Rajasthan water positive, Jain added.

Environmentalist and director general of Centre for Science and Environment Sunita Narain dwelt on the immediate dangers of climate change and the urgency to take sustainability seriously.

“We will have to catch up very fast because with climate change you have no time now to waste. Climate change is going to mean that we will have more rain in fewer number of rainy days and India already gets rain only for 100 hours on an average. Now, because of climate change the hours will come down and the rains will increase. This means we will have floods and droughts and it will not be like the traditional droughts or floods. It will be devastating,” warned Narain.

Agreeing with the remarks made by Jain, Ashok Sethi, chairman of Tata Consulting Engineers , said to avoid a situation like Punjab, we need to have better planning to avoid severe water crisis. “It is not the job of just agriculture department or water resource department to think about conserving water. We need to think about water as a model of economic growth, and take this issue seriously,” said Sethi.

Director of NJS Engineering India Pvt Ltd Sanjay Guleria said there have been ancient techniques through which we conserve water but to recycle it we need public participation. “It is not the work of just the government alone but people have to come forward to participate in it. They are still hesitant to use the recycled water and for that, more awareness needs to be created,” said Guleria.

H. Balasubramaniam, managing director, Xylem Water Solutions India Pvt Ltd, who gave a presentation on water crisis and management earlier in the summit said Rajasthan has been able to improve its parameters but needs to take more steps to make it sustainable. Balasubramaniam said, “Rather than building new projects, we have to take maximum advantage of the existing ones. The second thing we tell the state governments is that they do not go for immediate high capex projects. On the other hand, I think the problem of water needs to be taken to the roots. Can the government make a policy and enforce it strictly to ensure that a hotel, for an example, recycles the water it uses so that it does not load the burden on the public.”

“Water being a very political topic, no state is willing to cede its share to the neighboring state. Unfortunately, we are downstream state, at the tail-end. If there is water scarcity in the upstream states, things will be very tough. The major challenge of water security for us is to ensure that our supplies are guaranteed as per the agreements,” said Mahajan.

He listed out the priorities of the government and said it’s high time we went for drips sprinklers. “Whatever new projects will come, now they will be purely on pressure pipe micro irrigation system,” added Mahajan.

Ajitabh Sharma, principal secretary, energy department, who also served as secretary of water resources department in the past, said it would be difficult to achieve sustainability by following a linear approach.

“Technology, engineering, projects, implementation, and bringing in large capital will not lead to sustainability if the community is not involved. Water is not scarce, there is plenty of it. It all depends how you use it. We have to start thinking beyond the engineering prospective. So, it has be a circular economy. We have to treat the water, have treatment standards for different uses which is not there now. In India, we have not started thinking about nature-based solutions for treatment of water, and we have to understand the aquifers for their recharge,” said Sharma.

But answering directly the question of making Rajasthan water positive, director of Central Ground Water Board S K Jain said Rajasthan has ground water which can be replenished up to 12 bcm (billion cubic metre) but we withdraw 17 bcm annually.

“To make it water positive, we need 5 bcm more. Storage of water, creating recharge structures, targeting Chambal basins, recycling and using less water and managing the water used in the agriculture sector will be the key to meet the shortfall and make Rajasthan water positive, Jain added.

Environmentalist and director general of Centre for Science and Environment Sunita Narain dwelt on the immediate dangers of climate change and the urgency to take sustainability seriously.

“We will have to catch up very fast because with climate change you have no time now to waste. Climate change is going to mean that we will have more rain in fewer number of rainy days and India already gets rain only for 100 hours on an average. Now, because of climate change the hours will come down and the rains will increase. This means we will have floods and droughts and it will not be like the traditional droughts or floods. It will be devastating,” warned Narain.

Agreeing with the remarks made by Jain, Ashok Sethi, chairman of Tata Consulting Engineers , said to avoid a situation like Punjab, we need to have better planning to avoid severe water crisis. “It is not the job of just agriculture department or water resource department to think about conserving water. We need to think about water as a model of economic growth, and take this issue seriously,” said Sethi.

Director of NJS Engineering India Pvt Ltd Sanjay Guleria said there have been ancient techniques through which we conserve water but to recycle it we need public participation. “It is not the work of just the government alone but people have to come forward to participate in it. They are still hesitant to use the recycled water and for that, more awareness needs to be created,” said Guleria.

H. Balasubramaniam, managing director, Xylem Water Solutions India Pvt Ltd, who gave a presentation on water crisis and management earlier in the summit said Rajasthan has been able to improve its parameters but needs to take more steps to make it sustainable. Balasubramaniam said, “Rather than building new projects, we have to take maximum advantage of the existing ones. The second thing we tell the state governments is that they do not go for immediate high capex projects. On the other hand, I think the problem of water needs to be taken to the roots. Can the government make a policy and enforce it strictly to ensure that a hotel, for an example, recycles the water it uses so that it does not load the burden on the public.”

Title: Delhi Riots News: Volunteers, locals join hands to help riot-hit pick up the pieces
Content:
Mustafabad

NEW DELHI: Relief poured in for the riot-hit people on Sunday as volunteers from diverse spectrums documented losses, distributed food and provided legal help. At GTB Hospital, independent lawyers were seen providing monetary as well as legal help.

Senior advocate HS Phulka and spiritual guru Sri Sri Ravishankar were among those who visited the riot-affected areas. Police officers could be seen making note of the damage. They approached owners and recorded videos of them narrating their ordeal.

Sri Sri said people should take lessons from those who saved lives. “We should punish the anti-social elements. It is so disturbing to see so many people affected. We need to bring the lives back on track,” he said.

Naresh Aggarwal, owner of a sweets shop in Khajuri Khas, said: “My shop was locked when it was vandalized by goons. Last year, I had sold my wife’s jewellery to renovate it.” Phulka, accompanied by Khalsa Aid volunteers, spoke to shop owners. He said: “High court lawyers are voluntarily coming out to help the victims. We are working in coordination with Khalsa Aid as they have experience in this field. Our first priority is to ensure that people get their means of livelihood back.”

A delegation arrived from Nizamuddin Dargah in Babu Nagar to provide food to the refugees. Md Abdullah, the local Imam, said there were hundreds of people who had arrived in the colony to take shelter. Karan Pal (22) and his family had brought food for the security personnel on duty. “We are taking care of our fauji brothers who are helping everyone,” Pal said.

Right outside the morgue at GTB Hospital in Dilshad Garden, volunteers could be seen offering food, water and tea to the family of the victims. The group is working in shifts, from 9am to 9.30pm. “We are locals. We came here and saw people facing problems. We decided to pitch in,” Gulzar Ahmed (46) said. Teachers of a government school in Tukhmirpur in northeast Delhi also got together and distributed rations at Shiv Vihar. Dinesh Kumar, a political science teacher, said: “Motivated by other teachers, I came forward to help.”

Title: RTE deadline extended to March 4
Content:
Nagpur: The state education department has extended the deadline for online applications for free RTE quota seats in schools to March 4. Though 400% more applications have already come in for RTE seats, the education department feels more people should get a chance to apply.

As per data released by the education department, just over 30,000 applications have been submitted for 6,797 seats. TOI had reported last week that applications have crossed the 300% mark and within a few days, it has breached the 400% mark as well. With applications coming in steadily, it’s no surprise that the officials don’t want to shut down the online application portal yet.

Education activist Shahid Sharif too campaigned for extension of date. “There are many parents who complain about slow server speed, website crashing and applications not going through. It’s only fair that the department permits an extension of the application deadline,” said Sharif.

As the application numbers increase drastically, the other concern is of many schools boycotting RTE admissions. Independent English Schools Association has declared that over 20,000 seats may not be available for RTE lottery candidates because of their boycott till government pays pending dues.

Title: Roar of Ranthambore may fall silent if we don’t act
Content:
Anindo Dey

Ajay Singh Ugras:

Spotting tigers at Ranthambore Tiger Reserve is common. Most visitors go home with loads of photographs of the majestic animal. But experts warn that this lucky feeling could be short-lived. With 30 tigers going missing from the reserve in the last decade, it may not be too long before RTR loses its sighting friendly tag unless urgent steps are taken, reportandAs the vehicle manoeuvred through the mud tracks in sun and shade, it’s first the sudden bark of the sambhar as monkeys scurry up the trees. Soon, the gold and black haze through the bush comes clear as the tiger steps out. It’s what dreams are made up of and the Ranthambore Tiger Reserve (RTR) has over the years gained 'notoriety' of fulfilling them.And that is the draw for thousands of tourists as they pour in from across the globe to the reserve. “I have been to Kanha Tiger Reserve , Bostwana in South Africa and many other parks across the globe. But the sightings in Ranthambore are the best. It’s a dry, deciduous forest that makes sightings easier. Besides, sighting a tiger in the wilderness is a class apart from seeing a lion or any other animal,” says an excited Mustafa Alam Khan, a tourist from Hyderabad, who chanced upon two tigers in his morning safari.He is not alone. The scores of smiling faces as vehicles escort tourists out of the RTR after a safari speak on their date with the tiger. But the smiles, warn experts, may be short lived. With an alarming 30 tigers missing from the RTR in the last decade, it may not be too long before the reserve loses its sighting friendly tag to some other park unless immediate steps are taken.Since 2009, the park has mysteriously lost 30 tigers including seven old and 23 young ones. Among the 23 are 11 females which do not usually venture out for creating a territory, like the males. Out of this, while most number of tigers, nine went missing between 2014 and 2017. It was followed by two periods — 2006-2010 and 2013-2014 -- when five tigers each went missing. Even in the past two years, data reveals, five tigers went missing. They are T-9, T-20, T-77, T-78 and T23.This data, however, does not include 22 other tigers that died natural deaths and their bodies were traced. These tigers were either killed in territorial fights or due to human intervention or were poisoned by villagers.There are even some, where the cause of death still remains a mystery. Ranthambore also had 18 other tigers that were either shifted to Sariska and Mukundra reserves or had migrated to other forests outside the state or had been put into captivity due to “abnormal” behaviour.“A careful analysis of the data on missing tigers reveals that over the years, the reserve has developed two black holes in the north-east and south- east areas of the park adjoining Sawai Man Singh sanctuary. Most of the tigers that went missing were last sighted in these areas,” says conservation biologist Dharmendra Khandal of Tiger Watch.One of the black holes identified is in the region between Sawnta and Kila Khandar with its centre at Banpur. The other is the Kanduli, Kharda Ka Nallah and Bhairupura region. In the first black hole, 11 tigers have gone missing after being sighted, while the second black hole has seen eight tiger missing. The two areas amount to 60% of the total tigers that have gone missing from the park.Both these areas are natural outlets from the reserve but are adjoining 13 villages. The land here is fertile and there is plenty of water because of which extensive farming happens in these regions.“Villagers electrify their fences to ward off animals, but are often themselves a victim to electrocution. On December 26, 2018 the body of one Badri Sharma was found in one of the farms. Another person identified as Raju Gujjar too died of electrocution in the winter of 2017 near Khandar region. That tigers are also killed in these areas became amply evident when bodies of T-45 and T-46 were found in Khandar. Both deaths were due to revenge killing. Bombs used as baits for animals also been recovered from these areas as was a snared leopard once,” added Khandal.Officials conceded that big cats venturing out of the park through nullahs are a menace. “These natural nullah open towards the Chambal area which is surrounded by villages. The farm lands are owned by villagers and tigers are at risk if they venture outside. We have also deployed additional guards at the post, but cannot restrict the animal walking out through natural path,” said Ranthambore DFO Mukesh Saini.“However, we would soon constitute a committee to ascertain the exact number of missing tigers from the park,” he added.Non-reporting of many deaths are also a reason for missing tigers. “Often villagers lay traps and tigers get killed. The body is then quietly buried as they do not want to get into trouble. Sometimes, it is also a case of migration to other states with officials not following it up,” he said.Despite the growing vulnerability of tigers at the park in the recent years, there is little for an already over-worked forest department. “Not only are we under-staffed in terms of manpower, but remain engrossed in catering to VIP tourists’ safaris throughout the year. Most of our seven jeeps and our staff have to be deployed for VIP duty as requests pour in from the high and mighty. Special forces like the STPF, which was to be developed, have remained a piped dream,” explained forest officials.

Title: BSF constable who fell into boiling water cremated with state honours
Content:
Bijnor: Arun Prajapati, 28, a resident of Ambedkar Nagar here in Nagina, who died after he accidentally fell into a cauldron of boiling water was cremated with full state honours at his native place on Sunday.

According to the family, Prajapati was posted as a cook in BSF in Kolkata’s 112 Kalyani Battalion of West Bengal. On February 27, he had accidentally fallen into boiling water and had sustained fatal injuries. He died a day later and his body was airlifted to Bijnor on Sunday morning for the last rites.

Later, his last remains were cremated with full state honours.

Prajapati is survived by his wife and two kids.

Title: Schools may get water-testing unit soon
Content:
Kozhikode: All high schools and higher secondary schools in the district with chemistry labs are likely to get a water quality testing facility soon. The district development committee has decided to submit a proposal for the setting up of water testing labs in schools aiming to ensure service to the residents of the locality.

At present drinking water testing facility is available at Regional Analytical Lab at Malaparamba and at the Centre for Water Resources Development and Management (CWRDM). Not many persons are making use of the water testing facilities owing to various reasons. “Many schools in the district have high-end laboratories which are now only used for academic purpose,” said district panchayat president Babu Parassery, who is also the chairman of the district development committee. Once water testing facility is arranged at the school labs it would be of great help to the residents, including the families of the students, he said. The proposal for setting up water quality testing facility was mooted in the backdrop of increased pollution of water resources including wells. Many wells in the district are polluted with coliform and e-coli bacteria.

Besides, the presence of excessive quantity of iron and other minerals are also not good for health. The water quality testing facility will help the residents to test the quality of their well water and take necessary steps to purify the water.

Many offices, shops and schools are depending on drinking water supplied by private parties. The water quality supplied by the private parties also is a cause of concern as the examination by food safety department has been finding the presence of bacteria in bottled and canned water. The lack of knowledge regarding the source of water is also a concern.

The residents will be able to easily access the water quality testing facility if the facility is introduced in schools, said the Parassery. Students will also be able to learn the issues related to water pollution and the importance for maintaining the hygiene of water resources, he added.

The plan is to set up the water testing facility at the earliest utilizing the asset development fund of MLAs of all assemblies. Government and aided schools with Chemistry lab will be selected for the implementation of the project.

Title: Oxygen cylinder explodes in Chabda Thermal Power Plant, no one hurt
Content:
Kota: A minor fire broke out in a storeroom in Chabda Super Critical Thermal Power Plant under Bapcha police station of Baran district after an oxygen cylinder exploded late on Saturday night. No one was hurt in the mishap as the storeroom was not in regular use and only waste clothes and fibre pieces for cleaning purpose were stored there. The fire is likely to have been caused by an electric short circuit, however, probe by Chabda Thermal Power plant authorities is underway to ascertain actual reason for the fire.

The fire was doused within 10-15 minutes. The fire is estimated to have caused a loss of Rs 50,000 – 60,000.

Terming the fire in Chabda Thermal Power plant premises as a minor one, the plant authorities have not submitted any report to the police, SHO at Bapcha police station Harlal Meena said.

Title: MVA government set to bring back Nagpur Improvement Trust for unauthorized areas
Content:
Representative image

NAGPUR: Despite opposition from BJP, Congress and BSP corporators, the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government of Shiv Sena , Congress and NCP is set to reinstate the Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) as planning authority for unauthorized areas of the city.

It is likely that NIT won’t get back status of planning authority of its earlier seven improvement schemes and regularized layouts handed over to the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC).

Guardian minister Nitin Raut, who took the initiative to bring back NIT, told TOI, “I am firm on giving planning authority status to NIT. At the most, seven schemes earlier under NIT may not become its part,” he said.

Assembly speaker Nana Patolesaid, “Complaints from people have increased manifold ever since NMC became the sole planning authority for city. On Friday, I directed the NMC officials to expedite works it took over from NIT. Government should take decision soon,” he said.

Congress city president and West Nagpur MLA Vikas Thakre, who was present in the meeting, too demanded planning authority status for NIT. “Even after becoming authority for entire city in August last year, NMC has failed to dispose off even a single Gunthewari case. NIT has experience of 19 years regarding regularization and development of unauthorized areas. The previous BJP government did not dissolve NIT totally and now its staff is sitting idle,” he said.

BJP-Sena government under Devendra Fadnavis had decided to dissolve NIT on August 13 last year. On August 27, 2019, NMC was made sole planning authority for city. But the government failed to hand over properties, funds and liabilities of NIT to the NMC.

Over 1 lakh files of unauthorized layouts and plots are still with NIT. The NMC has failed to even open a separate cell for Gunthewari areas.

On January 2, Raut had written to CM Uddhav Thackeray stressing the need to bring back NIT. Raut stated that NMC neither has expertise nor experienced officials and employees to take care of Gunthewari areas.

Responding to Raut’s plan, urban development department wrote to municipal commissioner and NIT chairman on January 10 to submit their opinion. NIT said it would abide with whatever decision the government takes.

NMC general body on February 13 passed a resolution to keep NMC as sole planning authority. All BJP, BSP and Congress corporators present in the house were in favour of the resolution. NCP corporator Duneshwar Pethe, who was not present at the general body meeting, told TOI that NIT should be brought back as NMC is a non-performer.

Sena’s two corporators Kishor Kumeriya and Mangala Gavare were also not present at the GB. But Kumeriya, Sena leader in NMC, had many a time demanded NIT’s dissolution.

Title: Nagaur Dalit cousins get contractual jobs of guards
Content:
Jaipur: Two Dalit cousins — who were beaten up and humiliated at a motorbike service centre in Karnu village of Nagaur district — have been provided with contractual jobs of guards by the state government.

One of them will be posted at Nagaur, while the other will get posted as a guard of Ambedkar Hostel, Khinvsar, Nagaur district. One of the two victims told TOI that they will soon join on duty. They have also been given Rs 2.5 lakh each by the state government.

Nagaur district collector Dinesh Kumar Yadav has issued orders of appointment of special public prosecutor Mahaveer Vishnoi for the two Dalit cousins. In the order, Yadav mentioned that it was one of the demands of the two youths to appoint special public prosecutor for presenting the case from government side at the special SC/ST court of Merta City, Nagaur.

The two youths met chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Saturday and expressed satisfaction on the action taken by the state government in the case. The two youths were allegedly attacked by a group working at a motorbike service centre on February 16 on charge of stealing Rs 50,000 from the cash counter. They were beaten up and humiliated. One of the accused had inserted a screwdriver in one of the two youths. The videos of the heinous incident went viral. After three days of the incident, the two victims had gathered courage and filed FIR against the accused in the case. Eight persons have already been arrested.

Title: Centre approves Rs 53cr for 6 projects under coastal plan
Content:
Panaji: The Union government has approved around Rs 53 crore to take up six projects in the state under the Integrated Coastal Zone Management Plan (ICZMP).

The state had submitted around 12 projects to be undertaken under ICZMP at a total cost of over Rs 200 crore.Funding for the projects would be shared between the World Bank (50%), central government (30%) as grants, and the state government (20%), a senior government officer said.

The officer said the Centre has approved the funds based on the preliminary project report prepared by the National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management (NCSCM), Chennai.

The officer said that the detailed project report (DPR) has been prepared by NCSCM in three projects, including marine biodiversity of critical habitats of Goa, status, threats, conservation measures and management plan; establishing and designating coastal sand dune parks in Goa, and erosion/accretion assessment studies to ascertain feasibility of annual replenishment of sand along the estuarine stretches of the state.

Once the reports for all six projects are prepared, it would be submitted to the World Bank for approval , the officer said.

During the study, NCSCM will identify problems faced and propose solutions, and based on this, the projects would be taken up in the state.

Under the first phase, Gujarat and Odisha was taken up and the rest of the states are being taken up under the second phase under which Goa is selected.

TOI was the first to report that Goa could lose Rs 400 crore for coastal development under the ICZMP as the government failed to submit a detailed project report to the environment ministry. Based on the TOI report, then CM Manohar Parrikar directed officials to go ahead with the projects.

Title: Russian held for growing cannabis in Goa
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Goa police on Sunday arrested a Russian national for cultivating cannabis at a rented house at Morjim , and seized plants worth Rs 1.6 crore.

Police said they received a tip-off that a person was cultivating cannabis on the terrace of a rented house. Pernem police constituted a team and gathered more information before making their move.
