Police said they then raided the premises and found that cannabis was being grown in the house as well as on the terrace. They seized 33kg of plants valued at approximately Rs 1.6 crore.

Police arrested Varsily Rakhmanov, who had come to India on a tourist visa on November 14 and began living in Morjim on November 15. Police said the accused has been visiting Goa for the last 12 years and staying in Morjim during his visits for the last three years.

Police said they are verifying whether he was involved in any other narcotics cases registered.

Title: Kottayam hospital deaths: 33 died in 8 years, reveals probe
Content:
Represenatative Image

KOTTAYAM: Seventeen patients of Puthujeevan trust hospital for psychological medicine and de-addiction centre in Changanassery were taken away by their relatives after health minister K K Shailaja ordered a probe into the deaths of three inmates, reportedly over a period of seven days.

Meanwhile, additional district magistrate Anil Oommen visited the private trust-run hospital on Sunday to probe the complaints he had received about the functioning of the hospital. “We had received complaints from the neighbourhood regarding sanitation and water logging on the hospital premises and it was found that there was lack of cleanliness in the hospital,” the ADM said, adding that during the probe, the hospital authorities revealed that 33 patients had died in the hospital in last eight years. Of the 33 deaths, three were suicides and all procedures, including autopsy, were duly done. The remaining 30 had died of various illnesses, the authorities told the ADM.

The ADM also said there has been allegations that the lead content in the medicines given to the patients here are high. “The health department is looking into such allegations. The mystery will be cleared once the detailed lab report arrives,” he said. Currently, six inmates of the from the centre have been admitted to the medical college hospital for treatment.

Title: Armed with DRDO’s tech, Nagpur's company makes electronic grenades
Content:
Representative image

Nagpur: Economic Explosives Limited (EEL), a company under city’s Solar Group, a major producer of commercial and defence explosives, expects to put up its latest electronic multimodal hand grenade for trials soon. This is one step ahead of the latest grenade being acquired by the Army.

The technology for making the grenade has been shared with the company by Chandigarh-based Terminal Ballistics Research Laboratory (TBRL), a unit under DRDO, a senior official of EEL told TOI.

Based on it, EEL has come up with initial units of the grenade, that were also put up on display at Axis-2020 exhibition under way at VNIT.

TBRL has also shared the technology of the non-electronic multimodal grenades with EEL, making it the sole private player to take part in the process for supplying the weapon to the army.

EEL has already taken part in a request for proposal (RFP) by the Army to make multimodal grenades without using the electronic mechanism. The weapon will also be made by the Ordnance Factory, Khamaria in Madhya Pradesh. Both the entities await the bulk production order from the Army.

In the meantime, EEL said it has also developed electronic grenade — mechatronic — which also has a multimodal function. The mechatronic was on display at Axis 2020.

A senior official from the company told TOI that the company has finished internal trials of the electronic grenades and soon user trials, which is an evaluation by the Army, will take place. The electronic device will ensure the perfect timing for explosion in the grenade.

Maintaining the timing for explosion, once the pin is removed, is a crucial requirement for a grenade’s functioning. As per the Army’s requirements, it has to be not before 3.5 seconds and not later than 4.5 seconds.

In the grenades made so far, the process is chemically controlled. “With the electronic chip fitted, precise timing can be maintained,” said the company’s official.

Title: Man kills his grandfather, arrested
Content:
Bijnor: A man who allegedly killed his grandfather over a property dispute on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday has been arrested .

According to police, 70-year-old Rampal Singh was sleeping in his courtyard, when his grandson, Vishal Kumar, allegedly attacked and killed him. The murder took place at Khedi village under Nahtaur police station area. The deceased’s son found him dead on Saturday morning and filed a complaint against an unidentified assailant.

Police on Sunday arrested Vishal Kumar. Sanjiv Tyagi, Bijnor superintendent of police, said, “Police have arrested the culprit who killed his grandfather by striking him on the head with a hammer for his property.”

Title: No cheating in UP Board exams in state: Dy CM Sharma
Content:
Bijnor: Deputy CM Dinesh Sharma, who also holds charge of secondary education and higher education, has claimed that no incident of cheating or mass copying has been reported in Uttar Pradesh.

“A total of 56 lakh students are taking the IP Board exams in the state. No incident of cheating are being reported," Sharma said in Amroha on Saturday. He was on a day’s visit to Saidnangali town in Amroha district on Sunday.

Sharma made this statement a day after a paper-solver gang’s members were caught impersonating candidates in Aligarh, resulting in the cancellation of the Class X science paper at the centre. He also blamed previous governments for the rise in mass copying during board examinations in the state.

Sharma visited a health camp at Amroha’s Saidnangali town. Talking with mediapersons, he said, “There are 56 lakh students appearing for the UP board examination being held in 94,000 classrooms equipped with 1.90 lakh CCTV cameras and 1.88 invigilators have been deputed. Examination for higher education is set to start soon. They will also be conducted in a fair way. Apart from this, with a view to marinating education quality, we are appointing scores of teachers and principals every month.”

When asked about anti-CAA violence in Delhi, Sharma said, “Opposition wants to divide the country. But they will not succeed in their plan. We will not let the country be divided. Opposition is behind the violence. The violence was engineered to tarnish the image of nation during the visit of America president Donald Trump. Those people who were killed and attacked the innocent in Delhi will not be spared.”

Title: BMC gets cracking on retailers stocking single-use plastic bags
Content:
The civic body fined 11 hawkers and shopkeepers Rs 5,000 each

MUMBAI: A day after the BMC announced the revival of the ban on single-use plastic , its men collected Rs 55,000 in fines from 11 shopkeepers and hawkers.

The action came after state environment minister Aaditya Thackeray announced on Friday that he aims to make Maharashtra free of single-use plastic by May 1. He was replying to supplementaries during question hour in the legislative council.

Over the weekend, civic officials conducted awareness drives in high footfall areas like markets and zones outside railway stations. Using mega phones, they announced that a hefty penalty would be slapped on those found using single-use plastic.

On Saturday, 11 errant hawkers and shopkeepers in Andheri, Goregaon, Borivli and Colaba were fined Rs 5,000 each. Civic officials said they plan to first act against hawkers and commercial establishments, and will act against citizens at a later stage.

“From Monday, we will intensify our drive. Civic inspectors too will have to give an undertaking that no plastic is being provided in areas assigned to them,” said a civic official from the shop and establishments department. “We will also warn establishments and hawkers that in case of repeat offence, we will not only hike the penalty amount, but also consider cancelling their licence.”

But Dayashankar Singh of the Azad Hawkers ’ Union complained that any action by the municipality always starts with hawkers. “But hawkers do not get plastic bags from their home. Instead of targeting them, the authorities should first crackdown on the single-use plastic manufacturing units,” he said.

The BMC had started its drive against single-use plastic in June 2018, and till date has seized 86,000kg material and recovered Rs 4.6 crore as fines after examining around 16 lakh premises.

But the BMC was unable to sustain the momentum. While some civic officials claimed that vigilance reduced last year with staffers going on poll duty, others admitted that the drive slowed down due to lack of clarity, non-availability of alternatives and inadequate awareness campaigns. A civic official had earlier told TOI: “Extended producer responsibility (EPR) is a matter of concern. It was decided that plastic water bottle manufactures would develop a mechanism to collect used plastic bottles for recycling, but it has not happened.”

To fix the problem, the BMC has now decided to create awareness at its schools, asking students to collect plastic at home and deposit it at school for recycling. Most BMC schoolchildren come from slums. BMC will then encourage private schools to adopt similar measures.

Title: Rajasthan CM to PM: Fulfil national tag vow of canal project
Content:
Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: The desert state, where water does not lose its scarcity warning tag even in normal monsoon years, has endured droughts 60 times in the past 72 years.

Chief minister Ashok Gehlot made the reference to the harsh reality at the ‘Times Water Summit 2020’ on Saturday to drive home the importance of the proposed Rs 37,500-crore Eastern Rajasthan Canal Project (ERCP).

“The Prime Minister had come twice to the state before the elections and said he would declare ERCP as a project of national importance. We want him to keep his promise,” Gehlot said while dwelling on how the cost of delivery goes up in Rajasthan due to dispersed human habitations on one hand and limited financial resources to provide water to every segment of society on the other.

Senior state government officials at the event said they were still waiting for approval of the detailed project report that has been submitted to the Centre. ERCP is designed to bring surplus water in southern Rajasthan rivers to deficit basins in south-eastern areas of the state which will meet drinking, irrigation and industrial water needs of 13 districts.

Gehlot, who as chief minister 20 years ago, drove the popular social campaign “Pani Bachao, Bijli Bachao and Sabko Padhao” in villages of the state, said the Centre’s Jal Jeevan Mission is a good initiative, but the funding pattern puts a big burden on the states.

“In Rajasthan, we want to provide piped water to every household. But a 50% contribution to the scheme will require us to spend between Rs 1-1.5 lakh-crore. Earlier, the Centre’s schemes used to be in the ratios of 90:10, 70:30 and 60:40, putting a smaller burden on the states. But now, most of them have been made 50:50 or have been left on the states completely,” added the chief minister.

He said the current economic situation is worrisome, and has put the finances of 17 states in poor condition squeezing the spending for welfare schemes. “In Rajasthan, people have moved from villages to dhanis in their fields, leading to dispersed populations. That’s why the cost of delivery is more in Rajasthan, compared to others states where population is concentrated in villages. Also, it is not that we are getting a heavy rush of large industries that would increase the state’s revenues. The government has to do financial planning as we depend on debt for these initiatives and it is unfortunate,” explained Gehlot.

Speaking on the ‘Times Water Summit 2020,’ powered by Knowledge Partner Xylem, Gehlot said the water scarcity in the desert state forced people to innovative conservation methods like wells, tankas, baoris and ponds, but now it needs new ideas to provide its people fluoride- and nitrate-free drinking water.

“The state will benefit from the new ideas generated from the Summit where experts deliberated on number of issues related to water,” said the chief minister.

Title: Uddhav’s wife Rashmi takes over as Sena daily’s editor
Content:
Mumbai: Rashmi Thackeray , considered to be one of the driving forces behind husband Uddhav and son Aaditya ’s plunge in electoral politics , seems to have now assumed a more direct role in Shiv Sena ’s affairs. On Sunday, her name appeared in the print line of party mouthpiece Saamana as its editor. Sena MP Sanjay Raut will continue as its executive editor.

Rashmi’s appointment comes as a replacement for Uddhav, who stepped down recently, and has surprised many. The Sena president’s name was dropped from the daily’s print line on November 28, 2019 the day he took oath as Maharashtra CM. This was done to avoid the ‘office of profit’ issue.

A Sena leader, on the condition of anonymity, said Raut as executive editor will continue handling the paper’s day-to-day operations. “Raut used to contribute editorials. Uddhav has given him a free hand to run the paper and he will continue to do so.”

Rashmi, for long known as the Thackeray ‘bahu’, a reference to her being the late Sena founder Bal Thackeray’s daughter in law, has always maintained a distance from politics. She doesn’t issue political statements and normally avoids the dais in party functions. A rare occasion when she was seen on the dais was alongside Aaditya, when she announced that her son would contest the assembly polls from Worli.

Minister for tourism and environment Aaditya, talking to journalists in Pune, applauded Rashmi, who is known as 'Vahini' in Sena circles, on her new role, saying he is happy for his mother and will cooperate with her in her new innings.

Bal Thackeray's name has been retained as Saamana’s founding editor on the daily’s masthead. Since its launch on January 23, 1989, Saamana has been vocal in articulating the party’s political and social stand. It was critical of government policies in the state and at the Center, and also pointed fingers at Prime Minister Narendra Modi even while the Sena was in the 2014-2019 BJP-led alliance that governed Maharashtra. One of the reasons given by former CM Devendra Fadnavis (who is now leader of the opposition in the legislative assembly) for strained relations between the Sena and the BJP was continuous criticism by Saamana of the BJP’s top leadership.

The day Uddhav took oath as CM, Saamana carried a special editorial on its front page, taunting the party's critics. It mentioned that the true religion of Maharashtra was one that was comprehensive, and the kingdom established by Chhatrapati Shivaji was based on these principles. It wrote that Uddhav's government would follow the great Maratha ruler’s tenets.

Title: 21-year-old raped by family friend in Jhalawar, case filed
Content:
Kota: A 21-year-old girl was raped by a family friend when she was alone in her home under the Bakani police station of Jhalawar district on Thursday noon last week. The rape survivor initially did not tell her family about the crime due to social stigma attached to it. However, later she gathered courage and along with her family members reached the police station on Saturday evening to lodge a case against the accused. The accused is absconding and search is on for him.

The rape survivor in her report said that the accused was familiar with her family. She said that he reached her home on Thursday noon when she was alone. The accused first inquired about her brother and then finding him away from home, he raped her.

Police have initiated an investigation into the matter. The medical examination of the victim was conducted on Sunday. On delay in lodging the report, the SHO said the survivor first avoided narrating her plight to the family members. It was only later that she told them following which a complaint was lodged.

Title: Lucknow University faces tough test ahead as salaries exceed revenue
Content:
TimesView Lucknow University (LU) has been reeling under a financial crisis for over two decades after the government froze its grants at the 1998 level. Though the grants were increased marginally in 2009, it was not sufficient to meet the expenses required to maintain the quality of education. In the centenary year, government can give LU a heritage university status and increase its grant or allocate special funds. The university also needs to make efforts and raise funds from its alumni the way IIMs, IITs and other central universities have done.

LUCKNOW: It will be a tough test for Lucknow University to scrape its finances to pay salaries to its employees while reeling under a deficit of over Rs 100 crore in its annual budget for 2020-21. The financial state of university is precarious as its total revenue is less than the salary it pays.As per the budget approved by finance committee on Saturday, LU’s estimated revenue is Rs 137 crore, far short of Rs 250 crore expenditure.LU’s expected revenue receipts of Rs 137 crore include Rs 50 crore as self-finance course fees, Rs 44 crore as grant from state government and Rs 43 crore as examination fees from 170 associated colleges.In comparison, expenditure is pegged at Rs 250 crore, including a whopping Rs 190 crore being salary expense alone. The state government gives only Rs 44 crore to the university for paying salaries.In last budget, the salary expense was Rs 143 crore and the deficit Rs 32 crore. The gap was met through transfer of surplus from self-finance courses, bank overdrafts, enchashment of fixed deposits and funds generated by conducting UP BEd Entrance Examination given to it by government.Officials said, the salary expenditure will increase in 2020-21 because of payment of bonus, increments and perks accumulated under the seventh pay commission.“New appointments and development can be deferred but not salaries. We will request government to bear salary expenses. Rest, we will manage through new revenue sources,” said vice-chancellor Prof Alok Kumar Rai.LU’s cash crunch started two decades ago when state government froze salary grant at 1998 level (Rs 16 crore). The increase in salary expenses in the following years were met by starting new self-finance courses and granting affiliation to self-finance colleges.The government increased the grant to Rs 44 crore, but expenses increased by five times in two decades.

Title: Decomposed body of man found hanging in PTR
Content:
Pilibhit: The body of a 25-year-old man was found hanging in the Mala forest range of the Pilibhit Tiger Reserve on Sunday morning.

After receiving information from villagers, police took possession of the body and sent the body for autopsy.

Police identified the victim as Sanjeet Majumdar (25) of Goel Bengali Colony under Gajraula police station, who had been missing for the last 45 days.

According to station house officer (SHO) Jai Prakash Singh, the body was hanging with copper wire from a tree.

Victim’s father Tarak Majumdar said his son left home 45 days ago to see the crop but did not return. “We could not trace him despite our best effort,” he said.

The SHO said police were not presented with a complaint in the matter. “We have been waiting for the autopsy report to find out the exact reason of death. Further action will be taken based on the report’s findings,” he added.

Meanwhile, PTR deputy director Naveen Khandelwal said he would seek an explanation from the range officer concerned as to why did not they come to know the body that was hanging very close to the guest house at Mala forest.

Title: Usgao locals want nullah restored
Content:
Ponda: Alleging that the contractor has destroyed the Dhaushirem-Khandepar nullah at Dhatwada-Usgao, locals demanded immediate restoration of the stretch.

Following opposition to work of laying a pipeline at Dhatwada-Usgao, the superintending engineer of water resources department Pramod Badami had recently inspected the site and tried to reason with villagers.

Residents had gathered at Dhatwada on Saturday as the contractor was supposed to resume work that has been halted since February 1.

The water resources department (WRD) is laying a 1,000mm pipeline to facilitate augmentation of the Mhadei water from the Ganjem water scheme to rejuvenate the Khandepar river.

Every summer, the Khandepar river level dips, forcing WRD to source water from elsewhere to rejuvenate it. Until last summer, water from Ganjem was being poured directly into the Dhaushirem nullah, from where it would flow into the river.

As the entire quantity of water does not reach the river a direct pipeline is being laid from Dhaushirem to Khandepar. However, locals have been opposing it over the possibility that underground water resources could be destroyed.

On Saturday, Satyawati Gaude, a local demanded that the nullah be restored immediately. Another local, Vaibhavi Gaude, alleged that the contractor only give assurances, but doesn't keep his word. She said the nullah is important to locals as they fetch water from it during summer but the contractor has filled the nullah basin with mud.

Title: Focus on application based questions on theorems and concepts
Content:
Representative image

For ICSE X mathematics exam it is suggested that students should stick to prescribed syllabus provided by ICSE board and should put all energy in studying without diverting it into some new concepts which wont be asked in the exam. An important thing students should keep in mind while practicing and solving the exam, is creating a formulae sheet and important concepts used chapter wise, which will help them to understand the overall reviews of all chapters.

Generally application based questions on theorems and concepts are asked in the exam, for this practicing problem solving is the key. For proper management of time allotted, students are advised to solve previous years question papers in a stipulated time.

While solving the paper, students should keep a tab on the time allotted. The exam is of two and half hours and is of 80 marks. It consists of two sections of 40-40 marks. Out of which section A is compulsory and in section B students get options, they have to solve 4 out of 7 questions.

The first 15 minutes allotted as the reading time is the most crucial part of exam. In this time students can choose the questions that they find comfortable to solve and which are less time consuming. It is also advised that students should solve the paper in the sequence i.e. starting with section A and terminating with Section B. While solving problems, only the necessary steps should be included in the solution, and also all the rough work should be done below the respective problems only, marks are also given seeing the rough work incase essential steps are not included in actual solution.

Each sub question should be solved in maximum of 5 minutes. In this manner the entire section A should be completed in 1 hour and the rest of 1 hour 15mintues should be utilized in solving the 5 questions from section B, one considered extra for a safer side. With all this time management tricks, students will be left with a spare 15 minutes which can be utilized in checking the answers.

Title: North East Delhi Riots: Wedding plans come unstuck for caretaker dedicated to his school
Content:
Roop Singh said even his clothes were borrowed

NEW DELHI: After much struggle, Megha Singh (20) had zeroed in on a lehanga for herself. With weeks to go for her wedding, her father, Roop Singh, used up all his savings to buy jewellery. A caretaker with DRP Convent School in Shiv Vihar — one of the many that were targeted during the violence in northeast Delhi — Singh suddenly finds his life in tatters.

“Our samdhis (to-be in-laws) were insistent on getting everything done before Holi. But I told them that exams would be under way in our school and I would need to be extra vigilant at my job. We would have fixed a date after Holi, but now it has been postponed indefinitely,” Singh said. “Our belongings have been reduced to ashes and all the money and jewellery have gone,” Singh said, his hands covered in soot. Megha is still in shock.

A family of five, Singh — three daughters, husband and wife — used to live on the top floor of the school that has now been charred beyond recognition. The rooms are burnt and the remains of furniture thrown into the compound. “Around 2.45pm on Monday, when tension started to escalate, the school sent the children home. We locked the gates from inside,” he recalled. Megha saw the arsonists climbing down into the compound using ropes from the adjacent building. The lock was broken and, soon after, it was mayhem. “I was eating at that time. Megha came running to us and told us to run,” Singh said. “We jumped from a height of nearly 14 feet. It was a matter of life and death,” he added.

When a semblance of normacly was restored, the family returned to find that nothing of their belongings remained. “My wife, Geeta, and our daughters are now staying at a friend’s place in Govind Vihar. I have nothing now. Even the clothes I am wearing are borrowed,” Singh said. Singh alleged that every time he called the police, he was told that a team was on its way. But nobody came, he said. “The rioters had a free run for two days,” he remarked. “Now, the ladke wale are saying that the wedding can’t take place in such an atmosphere. My daughter saved my life, but there is a question mark on her life now,” Singh rued.

Title: Ruling party creating conditions for civil war: Gehlot
Content:
Jaipur: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot believes that the prevailing political and economic conditions in the country are a matter of serious concern. “It is unprecedented. Nobody knows where the country is heading. I can say for certain, I have never seen such a situation,” said Gehlot on Saturday.

The CM alleged, “Everyone in private confides that their business has been hit badly but none has the courage to speak out. An atmosphere of fear is being created through CBI, ED and Income Tax.”

“The government itself creating conditions conducive for civil war are inconceivable and unimaginable. Governments always worry about the opposition instigating violence and take them into confidence to deliver good governance. It was never seen the government adopts a vitriolic campaign to win elections and the results are for everybody to see in Delhi. It is not just the national capital, the country’s image has been tarnished,” he said.

He added that though India is a developing country it had enjoyed tremendous respect among other nations. India had enjoyed the world’s admiration for its constitutional democracy, diversity, religion and languages and regions and above all as the land of Gandhi, while neighbouring Pakistan was plagued by military rule.

Gehlot said the country made tremendous progress in all sectors but still some people asked what had Congress done.

Title: Selling tobacco without licence to attract fine up to Rs 5,000, legal action
Content:
Bareilly: Now, selling tobacco without a licence will attract a fine up to Rs 5,000, and legal action will be initiated against the vendors for flouting norms set by the health directorate. The UP director general of health in a circular to urban local bodies (ULB) in the state instructed them to ensure that no vendor sells tobacco products without procuring a licence issued by them. Besides, ULBs are asked to enforce the vendor licencing system strictly to curb the selling of tobacco by flouting the set rules.

In the circular, director (health) of UP directorate of medical and health services Dr Madhu Saxena stated that nearly 5.3 crore adult people in the state consume tobacco in some or the other form. “Among 5.3 crore, 52% men and 18% of women are suffering from various diseases, including cancer, and they untimely die.”

In the letter issued to all 16 municipal commissioners across the state, including Bareilly Municipal Corporation, she further stated that despite the Centre introduced the Cigarettes & Other Tobacco Products Act (COTPA) in 2003, in the absence of a licencing system, the Act was not being enforced in letter and spirit in the state.

Meanwhile, BMC health officer Sanjeev Pradhan said they were yet to receive a copy of the order to take further action. “Our teams launch drive time-to-time to ensure tobacco products are not being sold to minors. We will soon issue a notice to all vendors, asking them to procure a licence for selling tobacco products.”

According to BMC sources, close to 5,500 roadside kiosks are selling tobacco products in the city.

BMC officials said vendors caught selling tobacco products without having a licence would be slapped with a penalty of Rs 2,000 for the first time, and if caught again, the penalty amount would be increased to Rs 5,000. Besides, legal action would be initiated, along with the fine of Rs 5,000, against the repeated offenders, added BMC official.

A roadside vendor, Rakesh Kumar, said, “Civic body officials never asked me to obtain a licence, so I am not aware of the decision. But, if I get a notice, I will apply for a licence.”

Title: Warm Easterlies spur hottest February in a decade
Content:
According to their observations, after February 10, the surface wind was blowing predominantly from the Easter... Read More

PANAJI: February this year was the hottest in the past decade, said scientists from the India meteorological department (IMD). The maximum temperature reported at Panaji was above 35°C on eight of the 29 days, this month. This is highest number of such days in the month of February in last 10 years, according to the IMD records.

"The last time the state experienced a February this warm, with more than eight days recording over 35 C, was in 2006," said IMD scientist Rahul MC.

IMD has attributed the reason for the high day temperatures to wind direction. According to their observations, after February 10, the surface wind was blowing predominantly from the Eastern side of Goa.

“The surface winds blow from the east-northeast direction for around 6-7 days in February every year, and so, temperatures above 35 degrees would prevail for a few days every February—which is not considered abnormal. This year however, it happened that the easterly wind dominated for more days, bringing with it some heat,” Rahul said.

Maximum day temperatures of above 35 C were recorded on February 11,17,18,21,22,23, 26 and 28. Of these days, the highest temperature recorded was on the 23rd, with the mercury touching 36.6 C, IMD said.

Despite the hot weather right up to February 28, the state experienced rains on February 29 and March 1.

TOI had reported on Sunday that the prevalence of cyclonic circulations in the Arabian sea led to parts of Goa, like Sanguem, experiencing rain on Saturday.

"The cyclonic circulation has shifted North Westward of the coast. On Saturday, the cyclonic circulation was over the South of Maharashtra and on Sunday it moved towards South West Madhya Pradesh . There was another circulation over coastal Karnataka . Due to this combined effect there was an effect of the moisture incursion on Goa on Sunday as well," Rahul said.

Title: Patanjali gets govt soil testing project in Nagpur
Content:
While Patanjali Ayurved hopes to restart work on its stalled food processing plant in Nagpur soon, it has also... Read More

NAGPUR: While Patanjali Ayurved hopes to restart work on its stalled food processing plant in Nagpur soon, it has also been allotted a pilot project by the union agriculture ministry to carry out soil testing and recommend fertilizer requirement to farmers.

Nagpur is among the three districts where the work will be implemented, Patanjali’s managing director Acharya Balkrishna told TOI. “The districts chosen to take up the project on a pilot basis include Nagpur in Maharashtra, Haridwar in Uttarakhand and Hamirpur Uttar Pradesh,” said Balkrishna.

As this would help in increasing the farm yield, Patanjali may also give a buy back guarantee for some of the crops, he added.

“We have already started collecting data for the soil tests. In Nagpur, data from 3,000 farmers has been collected,” said Balkrishna.

“The project is being supported by the union agriculture ministry but even Patanjali is investing its resources in the project. The objective is to help the government in doubling the income of farmers,” he said.

Balkrishna said the company has made arrangements to fund projects, including the one in Nagpur. Patanjali has taken up 230 acres of land in the non-SEZ portion of Mihan for setting up a food park. Even as machines have been procured, the work for setting up the plant has come to a standstill since more than two months due to a financial crunch.

Along with the FMCG business, Patanjali is also banking on its recently-started IT venture. “The start-up was made operational on a secret note to avoid the glare of rivals,” said Balakrishna.

The company, Bharwua Solutions, already has four patents and has developed a software platform that can replace SAP, he claimed.

“It’s a purely Swadeshi software and can do away with dependence on any foreign technology. We have come up with a software that enables real time tracking of the movement of goods. The traceability software will prevent adulteration of the food products. We have already begun the application of the traceability software in milk, honey and grains like wheat and bajra made by Patanjali,” he said

Balkrishna claimed that the software will not only cut Patanjali’s IT expenditure, but also give it an edge over rivals, enabling real time monitoring of movement of goods.

“The software arm is a different company and apart from catering to the in-house needs of the FMCG business, we are keen to offer our services to other companies in the sector. “Its like being a Ayurvedic practitioner whose services are open for all,” he said.

Title: Achievers’ TEDx tales wow Lucknow
Content:
LUCKNOW: A differently abled village boy from Karnataka to an engineer to a 2007 IAS officer who served as district magistrate of Prayagraj during Kumbh 2019 to now a gold medallist in para-badminton at the recently concluded international championship in Brazil. Like every other stage in his life, Suhas Lalinakere Yathiraj, 36, left the stage of TEDx Lucknow on Sunday evening after he had inspired all and sundry with his saga of adversities and accomplishments.

“My first game in 2016 was against world No. 5. After trailing in the first round, I came back with a bang and became the first unranked para-badminton player to win gold in the Beijing championship,” Suhas told his audience. “The lesson here is that it is not the fall that matters, but how you get up and move ahead,” added the first-ever serving Indian bureaucrat to win gold for India in an international meet.

Usha Vishwakarma, the founder of Lucknow’s Red Brigade that teaches women self defence, took the stage next and made jaws drop with tales of true grit. “In 2006, a co-worker had tried to rape me. Ever since, I have been educating and training girls for such situations of unexpected assault. We have come up with our own technique of self-defence called ‘Nishastra Kala’ (weapon-less skill), which we are spreading far and wide,” Usha said followed by a demo by her team.

Kalyani Saha Chawla, originally from Kolkata and now in Delhi, motivated everyone at TEDx Lucknow to take risks and challenge oneself when opportunities come knocking.

“I am a self-confessed serial entrepreneur, juggling everything from marketing to fashion to writing to exporting to building — and all these because I believe in myself,” she said. Concerned over India’s increasingly toxic air, IIT-Delhi graduate Prateek Sharma revealed how he became an entrepreneur to build the country’s first cost-effective nasal filter against the finest particles that harm the respiratory system.

Title: Kerala fishermen stranded in Iran after Covid-19 curbs
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Indian embassy in Iran is taking stock of the situation of a group of Indian fishermen , including Malayalis, are stranded . Iran has imposed curbs with regard to Covid-19 According to reports, around 200 fishermen, including 17 from the southern coast of Kerala, are stranded in Iran as the Covid-19-hit country has clamped severe restrictions on the movement of people.Union minister of state for external affairs V Muraleedharan said the Indian embassy in Iran is assessing the gravity of the situation there and would take appropriate steps to ensure the security and welfare of Indians stranded there.Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan also wrote to Union minister for external affairs S Jaishankar urging him to direct the embassy there to take steps to help the stranded fishermen.A video shared by one of the trapped fishermen on Facebook on Sunday morning claimed the situation there as very serious as the fishermen who reached Iran as workers in a fishing company were running short of food and medicine since they were not allowed to step out of their lodgings. Their sponsor too had expressed helplessness and advised the fisherfolk to get in touch with the government authorities here, the video claimed.State fisheries minister J Mercykutty Amma said the government was taking all possible steps to ensure that fishermen stranded there don’t run short of basic facilities, including food and medicine. “We are not sure about how many Malayali fishermen are actually stranded in Iran. According to reports, they account to hundreds. How many are stranded there would be known only after their relatives here share their details with Norka. Once such details are with us, we would hand over the same to Union ministry of external affairs for further action,” she said said.However, unconfirmed sources said 17 among the fishermen caught up in Iran belong to the southern coast of Kerala, especially Vizhinjam and Pozhiyoor areas. “What we can do is to ensure that their basic needs are taken care of. Since they are in a foreign country that fights the coronavirus outbreak, those stationed there now will have to comply with the rules and restrictions that country imposes,” the minister said. “I am not sure about evacuating them now as all flights have been cancelled,” she said. The minister also appealed to the media not to create a scare about the crisis.The Tamil Nadu government had taken up the issue with the Union government on Saturday. Reports say that majority of fishermen stranded there belong to Tamil Nadu.

Title: PTR gets 3 mist blowers to fight forest fires
Content:
Pilibhit: The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) has gifted three mist blowers to Pilibhit Tiger Reserve for protecting the forest from fires.

According to sources, fire alerts in as many as 184 spots in Pilibhit Tiger Reserve (PTR) were sent last year by Dehradun-based Forest Survey of India (FSI). The fires were detected with the help of GPS (global positioning system). Most of the fires took place in Mala, Mahof and Barahi forest range areas. One mist blower each would be provided to Mala, Mahof and Barahi forest ranges.

On his part, field director of PTR H Rajamohan has issued directions to range officers of all five forest ranges to conclude fire line work by the first week of March. The fire line work is an annual exercise that helps block forest fires from spreading from one part to another.

Rajamohan said, “Directions have also been issued to set up one crew station in each of all the 54 forest beats for prompt assembly of forest force personnel in case any fire is reported in the jungle.” This would help fight fires promptly.

“The fire lines will be laid along all first and second roads in every forest beat,” he added. The task entails clearing fallen leaves and organic matter from the area as these cause surface and underground fires in forests.

Naresh Kumar, project manager of WWF, said, “We have provided three high-speed devices to PTR while another three have been sent to Valmiki Tiger Reserve in Bihar.”

Giving details, Kumar said each mist blower has 50 cc (cubic centimeter) capacity of spraying air under high pressure. The prime function of this fire fighting device is to blow away heaps of fallen dry leaves and organic litter from the ground to a considerable distance so as to completely check fire from spreading to the rest of the jungle parts. Water or chemicals can also be used for spraying when possible and if needed, sources added.

Rajamohan said, “There is a high risk of fire, specially during wheat harvesting period, when farmers burn crop residue despite a ban in the fields near forest areas.

“Although, we constantly get fire alerts from FSI, we have constituted special teams of trained forest personnel to maintain vigilance against any fire or smoke from the 100-foot high fire towers,” Rajamohan added.

Title: UDH tells civic bodies not to pay cash relief for land acquisition
Content:
Jaipur: With coffers running dry after a prolonged real estate slump, the urban development and housing ( UDH ) department has directed civic bodies not to pay cash compensation against land acquisition made in public interest.

The department has proposed to give only 25 per cent of developed land in the project after the land acquisition after the state government’s approval. A senior official said, “Providing cash compensation is a burden on the civic agencies. This hampers the development projects across the state.”

Many believe the move might lead to more protests in the state as owners whose lands are acquired might not settle for compensation without cash.

Nagendra Singh, who is protesting for fair compensation after farmers’ land was acquired for Ninder Housing scheme said, “The state government cannot decide options for land owners. Both the choices should be given. Many owners require cash for constructing houses and other arrangements.”

The officials are also apprehensive that this may hamper projects in the city as affected owners might approach the court after the civic body acquires their land.

An official source at JDA said, “Land for Bais Godam elevated road has been acquired from house owners along the road. Few are demanding cash compensation. In such cases, it is necessary to provide compensation as people might approach the court.”

In the past, lack of funds for land acquiring is obstructing the construction many projects including Ring Road. An official said on Agra Road, the JDA has to acquire 3,200 square-metre land from a petrol pump to construct clover leaves structures. However, the settlement cannot be done as funds are exhausted.

Sources said pressure on the JDA to repay installments of approximately Rs 1,600 crore is mounting. The JDA has taken loans totalling Rs 2,250 crore from NCRPB for the city's major projects. The JDA sought funds from the Centre for ROBs and the elevated road. “The JDA is desperate to earn revenue as it has to pay approximately Rs 30 crore installments against the loan taken from National Capital Regional Planning Board for Dravyawati River and Railway over-bridge,” said a senior official source

Title: Jacobites to launch 5-day protest in Kochi today
Content:
Kochi: The Jacobite faction would hold a satyagraha protest at Marine Drive on Monday. The sit-in protest is planned for five days in the initial stage, organizers said.

“We are planning to conduct a satyagraha protest which would go on till March 6. We are hoping to send a message to the general public about the injustice we have faced through this demonstration,” said Fr Sleeba Paul Vattuvelil, priest trustee of the Jacobite faction.

He added that the protest was against the takeovers of the churches by the rival faction with the help of police. “Locks are being broken open, doors are being damaged and the faithful are driven away from the church before forcefully handing it over to the rival faction. We are grieving and through the satyagraha, we are hoping to open the eyes of the authorities,” he said.

The protest achieves significance as a case regarding the takeover of Mar Thoma Cheriapally, an important church located in the Jacobite stronghold of Kothamangalam is under the consideration of the Kerala high court. The takeover could lead to a chaotic situation as the Jacobites have been campaigning to resist the takeover for the past several weeks.

Title: DM office staff mull over recovering rent from shops
Content:
Bareilly: Divisional commissioner Ranveer Prasad during his recent inspection of the collectorate premises has found the account books missing in which income from other sources is maintained. He found a matter where at least 84 shops came up alongside the boundary wall of the district magistrate office and have been running for decades.

Upon questioning, the commissioner was informed that no rent was being recovered from these shops which left the officer red-faced. He ordered an inquiry into the matter following which the officials concerned have now started searching for decade-old files of the shops in question.

On February 26, during his inspection, commissioner found that all 84 shops had deposited the rent till 1998, but after that no rental record was found with the officials at nazarat’s office.

Sources at the collectorate said that earlier officials at the nazarat’s office had stopped maintaining the shop rent register and in the following years their successors also didn’t pay much heed. Even some senior officials came to know about the issue now.

On Sunday, additional district magistrate VK Singh said that they would charge cumulative rent of previous years from the shops following the rate of the rent mentioned in the rent agreement. “We are examining the records to learn the exact status of all shops before issuing them notice to deposit rent as some of them may be unauthorised. Rent will be charged only from those shops with whom the rent agreement was signed in the past while action will be initiated against the illegal ones,” he added.

Title: Dhaba owner, 40, attacked with acid, suffers 22% burns
Content:
Representative image

PILIBHIT: A 40-year-old dhaba owner was attacked with acid on the face by unidentified persons while he was asleep outside his establishment situated in front of LH Distillery on Bhind-Lipulekh highway under Sungarhi police station.

The victim, identified as Jindal Babu, is a resident of Nabdia Sharifganj village under Barkhera police station. Acid was thrown on him at about 11 pm on Saturday. He was first shifted to the district hospital in Pilibhit and doctors there, referred him to Rohilkhand Medical College in Bareilly.

The police have inspected the spot and have lodged an FIR against unidentified people under IPC section 326 A (voluntarily causing grievous hurt by use of acid, etc) following a written complaint filed by Babu’s son, said Rajesh Kumar, SHO concerned. Police are yet to ascertain why he was attacked.

According to complainant Dharmendra Singh , he was informed about the acid attack by his father. His 12-year-old cousin, Vikas, who was sleeping on another bed beside his father, woke up and started screaming for help. The attackers fled. His father immediately rushed to the adjacent handpump and washed his face, said Dharmendra.

Dr PK Agarwal at the district hospital said the victim had suffered 22% burns.

Title: Kerala: Customs seizes gold worth Rs 1.93 crore, arrest one
Content:
Representative Image

THRISSUR: Customs officials in Thrissur on Saturday seized 4.52kg gold worth Rs 1.93 crore and arrested one person.

According to customs sources, the excise team seized the illegal gold from Arjun Sing, 35, a resident of Rajasthan , near Puthenpalli in Thrissur town on Saturday evening. The accused had come from Mumbai to hand over the gold to a jeweller in the Puthenpalli area.

“The accused did not possess any documents related to the gold purchase. He was produced before the economic offences court in Ernakulam and remanded till March 13,” the source said, adding that Arjun was part of the smuggled gold handling syndicate in the country. “We suspect that he has close links with jewellery shops in Thrissur and has been regularly supplying gold to them,” added the officer.

The customs officials, however, wondered how Arjun was not intercepted by customs officials at checkpoints like the airports or sea ports there. “We call it town seizure as the gold has reached domestic areas, crossing first checkpoints. We are investigating how he smuggled the gold into the country, his source and to whom he was planning to sell,’’ a senior customs official said.

Officials are also investigating whether Arjun was a courier for other contrabands like foreign currency or drugs.

Title: Ejaz Lakdawala: Gangster Lakdawala’s cousin, a top builder, held in extortion ring
Content:
Nadeem Lakdawala had allegedly provided contact details of the complainant to Ejaz

MUMBAI: The city crime branch on Saturday arrested developer Nadeem Abdul Sattar Lakdawala , 49, whose construction firm Hicons has built several high-end luxury towers on narrow plots in Bandra-Khar over the past decade, in an extortion racket involving his cousin and gangster Ejaz Lakdawala .

Ejaz Lakdawala has been arrested earlier. Police claim Nadeem was the gangster’s mole and had allegedly passed on the mobile numbers of the victim, Khalid Qureshi, a member of the Waqf Board.

A lookout notice had been issued for Nadeem, who was arrested as soon as he arrived from Jeddah. The developer owns stud farms in Lonavla and is the fourth person to be arrested for aiding and abetting the gangster.

Held for extortion, ‘mole’ Nadeem likely to face MCOCA charges too

Nadeem has been booked under the IPC sections for extortion and criminal conspiracy and is likely to also face charges under the stringent Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act (MCOCA).

Police informers Salim Maharaj, Faiyyaz Sannata and Dawood aide Tariq Parveen had been arrested earlier for aiding and abetting Ejaz Lakdawala in the extortion racket.

Anti-extortion cell officers said Ejaz had revealed during interrogation that Nadeem had provided information and contact details of Khalid Qureshi and his brother Imran. “To scare Qureshi into giving in to his demand for extortion, Ejaz had even sent pictures Qureshi pictures of his son on WhatsApp,” said police officer.

Inspector Ajay Sawant said a lookout notice was issued against Nadeem since he remained absconding.

Police had arrested Ejaz’s daughter Sonia alias Shifa earlier this year as they suspected she was involved in the extortion case, but she was later discharged.

Qureshi had lodged a complaint in November 2019 that Ejaz was threatening him and had demanded a huge sum. With Ejaz continuing to dodge the police, they maintained surveillance on his daughter. When they got information that she was in contact with her father, who was in Nepal, they arrested her just as she was about to catch a flight to Nepal on a fake passport along with her three-month-old daughter. Ejaz, who is wanted in more than 25 offences, was shunting between India and Nepal via Bihar until recently. The mobile numbers used by Ejaz to threaten Qureshi helped cops trace him to Patna.

Title: Illegal mud roads affect water supply
Content:
Kozhikode: The unauthorized construction of mud roads across the branch canals of Kuttiady Canal is affecting the flow of water in many areas. While the flow is completely disrupted in some areas, the flow is partially affected in many areas in Payyoli , Kuttiady, Maruthonkara .

The mud roads or mud walkways are constructed by the residents to ease their movement. The construction works are carried out when the shutters of the Kuttiady canal remains closed.

“The situation is worse in Payyoli municipality and Kuttiady areas,” said Koyilandy MLA K Dasan. The unauthorized construction activities are carried out without the knowledge of the irrigation department officials, who are the custodians of the canal, he said.

The disrupted flow of water through the branch canal affects the water distribution through branch canals , distribution canals and feeder canals. The Kuttiady canal has 10 branch canals and many distribution and feeder canals.

The Kuttiady canal covers 603km. The canal passes through 43 grama panchayats, three municipalities and the city corporation in the district.

Due to the unauthorized construction activities across the branch and feeder canals , water supplied through the canal is yet to reach many areas in the district including areas in Kozhikode city limit. The shutters of the canal were opened on February 20 by the irrigation department to address drought situation.

Usually water reaches the branch canals, distribution canals and feeder canals in a week. Shutters of branch canals are opened when water reaches all the branch canals.

“We have decided to direct the local self-government bodies to carry out inspection in their limits to detect unauthorized constructions,” said Dasan. All unauthorized mud structures will be demolished and mud removed with the help of the MGNREGA workers, he said.

The unauthorized opening of the shutters of branch canals and breaking of the shutters by anti-social elements were the key cause for the disruption of water supply two years ago. However, the situation could be addressed to a great extent with constant inspection by irrigation department officials and police action against the offenders, said an official with the irrigation department.

Last year, water distribution to many areas were disrupted owing to inadequate repair work of the canal stretches. The residents of Maniyoor, Thiruvalloor, Moodadi, Thikkodi and nearby areas were worst hit during last summer.

Title: Unlike phase-1, metro phase-2 work won’t hinder traffic much
Content:
Chennai: Sturdy steel sheets to be laid on the road to cover underground construction sites will allow smooth flow of traffic when Chennai Metro Rail Limited (CMRL) begins work on the phase-2 network in June 2020. The sheets will replace barricading, which takes up most part of the road causing congestion. CMRL will use the metal sheets to cover all trenches dug to build underground station boxes along the 118.9-km phase-2.

Called the decking technique, metal sheets about 5mm thick will be placed on the roads to cover shafts sunk into the soil on either side of the road for the construction of underground stations and tunnels, a metro rail official said. A portion of these large shafts will later serve as the entry/exit points to the station. The sheets, which will be on the road level, will be 3m wide on either side of the road and sturdy enough to withstand heavy vehicles and traffic movement. The sheets will also have support railing underneath.

“Decking will ensure continuous movement of traffic. This is one of the new methods we are adopting to minimise hassles for commuters during phase-2 work,” a metro rail official said.

CMRL came up with this idea after traffic movement in the core parts of the city such as Anna Salai, Poonamallee High Road and Arcot Road were severely affected during the construction of the 45km phase-1, which took almost a decade. Even then trenches cut on either sides of the road on Anna Salai when construction was underway for LIC and Thousand Lights stations had been covered with sturdy metal sheets in a few places.

While the sides will have the metal sheets replacing barricades, the centre of the road above planned underground metro stations, where the soil will be cut open, will be barricaded. “We may barricade the sides of the road only when we build the underground station’s diaphragm wall. Otherwise, we would occupy only the centre of the road,” the official said.

Title: Forensic team to visit home today
Content:
Kollam: The special investigation team ( SIT ) probing the death of six-year-old Devananda started conducting basic evidence gathering on Sunday for scientific examinations to identify the reason for death.

After her family members raised suspicions on her death, forensic experts from Medical college, Thiruvananthapuram will reach her house at Elavoor near Nedumankavu on Monday as part of scientific investigations. The investigation team will also record the parents’ statements.

The SIT team on Sunday measured the distance from Devananda’s house to the river in which her body was found.

Meanwhile, the girl’s mother, Dhanya, reiterated allegations of abduction. She said that the girl would not have gone to the riverbank by herself. She had not worn her shawl and had not gone to the nearby temple recently, Dhanya said.

Kummanam for expert probe

Meanwhile, BJP leader and former Mizoram governor Kummanam Rajasekharan who visited Devananda’s house demanded that a special investigation team of experts should be constituted to conduct a fool-proof probe into the girl’s death. Speaking to mediapersons here he said the girl’s family had raised some serious doubts of chances of abduction. tnn

Title: IGNOU has ‘har ghar graduate’ in its future plans
Content:
Panaji: Every year, around 18,000 students appear for the state board Class XII exams from Goa, but less than 8,000 clear higher education in the state, including technical programmes. This means that 10,000 or more students each year are out of the mainstream education system, unable to acquire a degree, diploma or postgraduate diploma. This figure is baffling for officials at the regional centre in Goa of the Indira Gandhi National Open University (IGNOU), a varsity established by an act of the parliament. The university’s centre in the state is now planning to go all out to plug this gap.

G Shrinivas, who has just rejoined as the centre’s assistant regional director, said that he has conceptualised a ‘Har ghar graduate’ programme for the state, where the IGNOU centre will tie-up with the directorate of panchayats to hold spot admission camps in even the most remote villages.

“There are many areas in Goa, in the villages, where there is not a single graduate in the family. It makes a huge difference to have one person graduate in the family. It transforms the outlook of the entire family. We want to tie-up with the directorate of panchayats and first hold an orientation seminar for all sarpanchas. Students will be enrolled on the spot for diploma and graduate programmes,” said Shrinivas.

He said that, at a time when the Union government has set a target of taking the gross enrolment ratio in higher education among the youth to 40%, IGNOU can play a key role in helping achieve this in Goa.

Shrinivas said that he similarly plans to tie-up with the directorate of education to hold an orientation programme for principals of higher secondary schools.

“We want to help principals upgrade their skills by enrolling them for our PG diploma in education management. I have also already discussed it with chief minister Pramod Sawant about helping existing employees in government or government-funded organisations to upgrade their skills,” he said.

Title: Nagpur: Thanks to solar panels, these e-cars get charged even as they are driven
Content:
Nagpur: The 200-metre stretch in front of VNIT's hostel block No 2 represented a makeshift automobile workshop with around 12 shamiana given to as many teams participating from across the country. Some team members remained on standby with tools as others took their solar-assisted car prototype for yet another assessment which comprises checking fitness of the vehicle on several parameters on the campus.

The competition got more intense as the five-day National Solar Vehicle Challenge (NSVC), said be to organized for the first time in the state from February 28, reached third stage on Sunday with final endurance test of vehicle slated for the final day of the event.

The e-cars , which run on batteries and get charged simultaneously through solar panels on them, will be driven two hours non-stop on the campus roads before winner is announced for the Rs1lakh cash prize.

The event is kind of an exam for the interdisciplinary team of students who have been preparing for this contest since a year now, says electrical department faculty member Ritesh Keshri. VNIT’s in-house clubs, Team Velocity and Team Tesla, in association with the department and Dynamist Motorsports have organized the challenge. The previous edition was held in Bangalore near the KIADB Airport area.

On Sunday, the e-cars, manufactured by the students, were tested for steering dynamics, braking, cross road, and suspension on a 50-metre stretch in front of the hostel. The cars have been fitted with solar panel on the roof to continuously catch sunlight while on the go. The batteries are charged simultaneously.

“All of them performed well. Those not meeting the criteria are given more chances after correcting the shortcomings, if any,” Keshri said.

The faculty member said the vehicles were also ran without any batteries to check direct transmission of solar power to the motor.

“The vehicles can reach a top speed of up to 40 kmph and have enough charge for two-hour which is good for making city transport pollution free,” said VNIT’s Solaris Team member.

Hyderbad-based Rudhra team added another panel that appears as its bonnet. “We wanted to make it light, more efficient as compared to other EVs,” they said.

Title: Additional CP fumes as only 10 FIRs filed against 471 complaints
Content:
Representative image

Nagpur: The heavily skewed equation of only 10 offences registered against 471 complaints in 2019 by six police stations of zone III of city police seemed to have left senior cops upset.

The issue of functioning of cyber cells in Maharashtra was raised during the ongoing assembly session which also highlighted manpower constraints and issues of pending complaints.

The complaints, forwarded by cyber cell of crime branch, were meant for police stations to probe after registering offences. Not only there had been failure in registering FIRs, little less than 50% of the complaints (242) are still pending for reasons best known to the personnel manning the respective police stations.

A response through RTI underlined the fact that cyber cell had received 3,023 complaints in 2019. Around 2,100 were sent to different police stations, but 251 are still pending and 672 were closed without action.

Around 109 complaints were referred to Pachpaoli police station, but no FIR was registered. On top of it, 84 remained pending since 2019. Another 101 complaints were sent to Lakadganj police station, but only two were converted into FIRs with 31 still pending. Another 90 complaints were sent to Kotwali police station and only three FIRs were registered while 43 still remain pending.

Additional CP Nilesh Bharne, crime, sounded stunned by the high number of pending applications at police station level. “The complaints should not be delayed as it tantamount to ignoring the grievances of the citizens,” he said.

Bharne has now directed cyber cell to refer the complaints to him before forwarding them to police stations. “We would now refer complaints to police stations with direct remark to register offence if there is a strong case,” he said.

The cyber cell, during 2017 and 2018, had a dream run when it had managed to return amounts to the tune of several lakhs before being siphoned off by online fraudsters. The performance of cyber cell nosedived from 2019. There have been no significant detections too.

Though several cyber cells in the state have been converted into police stations, city police are yet to take a decision on the status of it’s unit.

An officer, on the condition of anonymity, said there is dearth of officers to probe the cases pertaining to cyber offences under Information Technology (IT) Act. “Only an officer of inspector rank or above can probe cases under IT Act. At present, there are only two inspectors at cyber cell ,” he said.

Bharne is learnt to have assured the cyber cell unit to take up the issue of lack of officers and personnel with the top brass to open the bottleneck.

Title: Violence in Delhi: Residents stick together in island of peace
Content:
Phase-VII of Shiv Vihar has turned into a virtual ghost town

NEW DELHI: Having borne the brunt of the riots, Phase-VII of Shiv Vihar has turned into a virtual ghost town. But Gali No. 14, in the middle of the colony, stands out as an exception. Some are calling it an island of peace, as stories emerge of how Hindus and Muslims risked their lives to save each other when the violence was at its peak. Most houses are largely untouched in this lane, thanks to this show of strength.

Shiva Kumar (62), who guards the wooden log at the entry gate, said people from both communities joined hands to keep the rioters away. Different groups, with their own sets of slogans, descended on the colony on Monday night, Kumar recalled. “We saved our lives in this storm by begging, pleading and touching feet of these people,” he said. Residents said they prevented attacks by hiding the identities of the people from the different set of rioters.

They said there were a few local participants too in the violence, but the mobs mostly comprised outsiders. Bhanvar Singh, a vegetable-seller, said Hindus and Muslims have lived together for over 30 years in the colony. “Not a single lock has been broken in our lane. We live in brotherhood. No one can hurt you if you stick together,” he said. While the rest of the colony is in ruins, Singh’s comments ring true when you look at Gali No. 14.

Mohammad Aamir, another resident, said: “People helped each other out and that’s why our houses survived. People came in two trucks from the Loni side (to attack),” he said. Lal Devi added: “We lied and protected our identities. We are staying on to save our houses as well as that of our neighbours,” she said. Many people, however, have fled. “I don’t know where she (her neighbour) is now. When she was here, we used to laugh and cry together. But now there is only silence. I miss her,” Devi said.

Title: Raj leads in learning outcomes: MHRD survey
Content:
EDITED

Jaipur: Rajasthan scored the highest points in the category of ‘learning outcomes and quality’ of education in government schools among the states and the union territories.

The category is one of the five categories further divided into a total of 70 subcategories to form the performance grading index (PGI) report 2017-18 released by the MHRD on February 27. The desert state ranked among the top five states in the PGI.

Leading the pack among the states and union territories are Chandigarh, Gujarat and Kerala. These states are listed in grade I category as their aggregate score is between 801-850 while Rajasthan stood in the grade II along with Punjab, Tamil Nadu, Haryana and D&N Haveli for having aggregate score between 751 and 800.

“Rajasthan scored 168 out of 180 to lead in the country in the important parameter of learning outcomes and quality,” reads the report. The learning outcomes are defined by the students’ academic performance in reading, comprehension and mathematics. The state performed poorly in two categories — infrastructure & facilities and access. It scored 84 out of 140 and 56 out of 80, respectively. The poor performance in the access category means that the state has poor retention, transition rate and high dropout rate.

“It is good that the state is doing significantly well in equity category, which means lesser difference in performance among the SC, ST vis-à-vis general category students. The state stood 10th in the combined category of union territory and states. The efforts of the consecutive governments are delivering positive results,” said KB Kothari, an educationist.

The learning outcomes are considered the most important domain and the ultimate goal of the index.

The total weightage under the PGI is 1,000 points with each of the 70 indicators assigned a weightage of either 10 or 20 points. The aim of the report is to inform the state government on areas of improvements. The percentage of average daily attendance of teachers recorded in electronic attendance system, too, is very good in the state.

Title: HC seeks plan for doctors visit to homes
Content:
Jodhpur: Rajasthan High Court has directed the state government to chalk out a plan for bimonthly visits of teams of doctors to all the nari niketans, balika gruhs and observation homes in the state.

With regard to its directions for regular visit of doctors to nari niketans, government counsel informed the court that since all the seven government nari niketans are located at the divisional headquarters, the superintendent of the medical college of each divisional headquarters would have better resources to send doctors to these institutions on a regular basis.

While hearing a habeas corpus petition, division bench comprising Justice Sandeep Mehta and Justice Vijay Bishnoi directed the secretary of the local bodies department to issue instructions to all the municipal bodies to install open air gyms in the nari niketans, balika gruhs and the observations homes all over the state.

The court has sought submission of the compliance report in this regard for its perusal on the next date of hearing on March 18.

While submitting the affidavits in the court in relation to the directions issued by the court during previous hearings, AAG Pankaj Sharma apprised the court that 6 ANMs have been posted on deputation in each nari niketan other than Jaipur as an ANM was already posted at the nari niketan here.

“In addition, seven posts of special women educators have also been created one for each nari niketan at the divisional headquarters in compliance of the direction of the court,” Sharma informed the court.

Referring to the chalking out of a common format for inspection reports of the nari niketans by the Dy. secretary, Rajasthan State Legal Services Authority (RSLSA), the court further directed that these formats should be incorporated in the reporting system and be forwarded to all the nari niketans in the state so that the compliance reports are received in a common format.

Besides this, the court also sought a compliance report of its direction to take steps for imparting skill development training to the inmates in these institutions.

Title: Water packaging units strike: Illegal ones crop up in suburbs
Content:
Chennai: Illegal water packing units cropped up in the city’s suburbs as the strike by packaged drinking water units entered the fourth day on Sunday. The unrecognised units are trying to cash in on the increasing demand for bubble tops .

A member of the Packaged Drinking Water Manufacturers Association said the illegal units are active in suburbs such as Kumananchavadi and added that water filled in unhygienic conditions is being sold. Highlighting that the association had time and again raised the issue of such illegal units cropping up, he requested the authorities to regularise the units by issuing licences and ensuring they complied with safety standards.

In areas such as Red Hills, branded bubble top cans are filled with water from tankers and sold to people at a higher price, he warned.

Cost of bubble top cans continued to increase, with branded ones sold for Rs 100 in many parts of the city. The cheaper ones were unavailable, said shop owners in Adyar and Tiruvanmiyur.

Title: Nagpur: They came on wheelchair, walked out on ‘own’ feet
Content:
Many who came in on wheelchairs, walked out on their own feet as the highly advanced technology replaced their... Read More

NAGPUR: It was a liberating day for the several differently abled people of the country who were provided with free artificial limbs at the inauguration of a weeklong artificial limbs fitment camp in the city. Many who came in on wheelchairs, walked out on their own feet as the highly advanced technology replaced their missing limbs.

This technology of artificial limbs today is giving a new lease of life to several disabled people who once thought that they might never be able to lead normal life.

The fitment camp was inaugurated by Chief Justice of India Justice Sharad Bobde on Sunday at MLA Hostel. The programme was jointly organized by Mahavir International Service Trust , BMVSS and the National and State Legal Services Authorities.

CJI Bobde said, “This is an occasion to celebrate humanity. There is a higher state of consciousness today where a human evolves to a point where he looks at the sufferings of others and decides to do something about it.”

Bhagwan Mahaveer Viklang Sahayata Samiti (BMVSS) is a pioneer in the field of artificial limbs. This organization, which is the world’s largest organization for disabled, is the brainchild of DR Mehta who realized the need of an institutionalized arrangement for helping poor people who have lost limbs only after he himself met with a serious road accident.

There was also a demonstration by few differently abled people who walked, jumped, ran and gallivanted easily from one place to the other after the fitment of these artificial limbs. The highlight of the event was when 3-year-old Icchha jumped with joy and ran across the stage with her new limb.

Supreme Court judge Justice Bhushan Gavai said, “This is God’s work. There is a presence of the divine being in this team.”

The programme was heavily attended by the members of the legal fraternity. Supreme Court judges Justice Surya Kant, Justice S Ravindra Bhat along with retired SC judge Justice VS Sirpurkar were present.

Acting Chief Justice of the Bombay High Court Justice Bhushan Dharmadhikari, Senior Administrative Judge of the Nagpur bench of Bombay HC Justice Ravi Deshpande, Lokayukta of Odisha Justice Ajit Singh, retired Bombay HC judge Justice RC Chavan, all judges of Nagpur bench of Bombay HC and HCBA members were also present.

Title: Agra university: Exams start today, but students yet to get admit cards
Content:
Representative image

AGRA: The Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University exams for session 2019-20 are scheduled to begin on Monday, but many students have claimed that they have not received their admit cards.

More than 27,000 students enrolled in 12 courses are scheduled to appear for the exam. According to the university officials, the exams will be conducted across 100 centres.

The university vice-chancellor Ashok Mittal said the admit cards were uploaded on the website on Sunday, and added that the college administration now have to download and distribute them to the students.

“On Sunday, admit cards of all the students having their exams on Monday have been uploaded on the login IDs of the colleges. The process of physical verification of exam centres has been initiated. It will continue during the exams. Exam enters not found fulfilling the standard norms will be changed. Orders have been issued to remove all the colleges where mass cheating was reported from the list of exam centres,” Mittal said.

Meanwhile, a first-year B.Sc student expressed anguish over the delay in getting the admit card.

“I have biotechnology paper on Monday. But, I have not received my admit card till now. All the students now have to collect the admit card from college before going to the exam centre. The university administration should have uploaded the admit cards at least one week before the exam,” Vinit Kumar said.

Earlier in the day, the authorities of the affiliated colleges had gathered at the Khandari campus in large numbers to get their complaints addressed. Later, police were called in by the university administration to control the situation.

A principal of a private affiliated college, on the condition of anonymity, said, “The university administration has failed to make the arrangements to conduct exams on time. Major malpractices have taken place in the determination of exam centres. A day before the exam, the university officials are determining the exam centres. The admit card has only been uploaded today. Such last-minute decisions are going to hamper the students.”

Moreover, the principal alleged that some exam centres are more than 10 km away from the parent college, which is in clear violation of the state government orders.

He also claimed that no physical inspection of colleges was conducted by the university administration to check the availability of CCTV cameras and voice recorders in classrooms as mandated by the state government.

Title: 15 localities hit by poor water supply due to pipeline leaks
Content:
Representative image

AGRA: Water supply in at least 15 localities in the city was affected on Sunday due to leakages in supply pipelines and other mechanical faults. Residents said despite several complaints, the Jal Sansthan failed to send water tanks to the affected areas.

Due to leakages in the pipelines, water supply was affected in 15 localities, including Awas Vikas, Sikandra, Dayalbagh , trans Yamuna, Baluganj, Mantola, Subhas Bazaar , Transport Nagar , Kailash Road, Balkeshwar locality, Belanganj, Daresi, Rawatpara, Noori Darwaza, Shahganj, Madia Katra, Lohamandi and Idgah.

In some localities foul smelling contaminated water was supplied. These included Awas Vikas, Sadar Bhatti, Prakash Nagar , Chandra Nagar , parts of Dayalbagh and Kamla Nagar.

Water supply in the Old City areas is dependent on Jeevani Mandi waterworks station whereas half of the city gets its supply from Sikandra waterworks. Both these pumping stations are not working to their full capacity. Besides, some 20 leakages on supply pipelines maintained by Jal Sansthan result in wastage of thousands of litres of water in different parts of the city every day.

It is estimated that least 50 million litres per day (MLD) of water is wasted in the city due to pipeline leakages. So far, Jal Sansthan has no city-wide plan to check the situation. Its ad hoc arrangements in dealing with the problem of pipeline leakages are temporary in nature, which last for short periods.

RS Yadav, general manager of Agra Jal Sansthan, said “We are working to fix all the leakages. Pipeline are too old and weak. They are not able to bear the pressure of water and spring leaks. We are working on a plan to lay new piplines in areas where frequent leakages take place.”

Title: Riots in Delhi: Three more bodies found in drain, no link to riots yet
Content:
A little victim shows a tear gas cell which was thrown to his house in a riot-affected area at Karawal Nagar i... Read More

NEW DELHI: Three more bodies were recovered from a drain in northeast Delhi on Sunday. Hospital authorities, however, said that they had not received any bodies. Dr Sunil Kumar, medical director of GTB Hospital, claimed there were no new deaths. “The toll at GTB stands at 38,” he said. The total number of deaths stand at 42.

Two bodies were pulled out from the drain that runs through Bhagirathi Vihar in Gokulpuri and another from a drain in Shiv Vihar. “None of the three bodies has been identified. Whether they are of riot victims or not can only be ascertained after postmortem,” a cop said.

Delhi Police said no call was received in the control room regarding rioting in the last four days. “A total of 254 cases have been registered; 41 of them are under Arms Act. Over 900 people have been detained. The situation under control,” Mandeep Randhawa, PRO, Delhi Police, said.

On Sunday evening, their were reports of a man being beaten up by a group of people in the inner lanes of Bhajanpura. While the victim, Basant Jha, has not filed a complaint with Delhi Police as he is a resident of Ghaziabad, his brother told TOI that he had received injuries and his car was damaged.
