Another professor argued that the state has enough academicians and there was no need to bring an academician from Delhi to select the vice-chancellor for a state university.

Professor Jagadesh Kumar did his post-graduation and PhD at IIT Madras and worked in IIT Delhi before taking over as vice-chancellor of JNU in 2016.

P Maruthamuthu, former vice-chancellor of Madurai Kamaraj University, and P Ramasamy, former vice-chancellor of Alagappa University, have been nominated as senate and syndicate nominees to the panel.

After a government order, the three-member panel will call for applications from eligible candidates for vice-chancellor post, sources said. The three-year tenure of present vice-chancellor of University of Madras, P Duraisamy, will end in May.

Title: VZM strengthens measures to stop illegal sand transport
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The Vizianagaram administration has set up eight check posts and two mobile teams, consisting of mining, police and special vigilance officials to prevent illegal transportation of sand from the district.

During a meeting with special police officers (retired defence personnel), police officials and mining officials on Saturday, J Ram Mohan Rao, officer on special duty (OSD), Vizianagaram, said 14 vehicles were seized for illegally transporting sand in the district in the last two months.

The OSD said sand from various reaches in the district was taken illegally to other states for construction purposes and added there must a be a stricter monitoring to curb the practice.

The OSD said demand for sand in other states has made reaches in Vizianagaram highly vulnerable because of its proximity to Orissa. He said at a time when vast projects are mooted in the state, there should be no shortage of sand in the district.

The OSD said three more reaches were identified in the district at Mettavalasa, Denkada and Peddatadivada. The OSD said the eight checkposts in the district are located at key points across the porous border and would be manned by the police and mining officials.

He said two mobile teams and those manning the check posts would be given special smart phones with the apvigilance3 app, which would help identify the vehicles transporting sand illegally. He said CCTV cameras would be installed in certain target reaches.

Title: No. of staff in Hyd IT SEZs crosses 3 lakh
Content:
Hyderabad: The number of employees in IT SEZs across Hyderabad has crossed the three-lakh mark with the city having around 23 IT SEZs with 292 companies, said Visakhapatnam SEZ development commissioner A Ram Mohan Reddy.

“Ever since the SEZs were formed, at least 74 companies moved out, but many were added. Till December 2019, investments worth Rs 25,890 crore has come into the IT SEZs,” Reddy said, adding that no firm has left the IT SEZs in Andhra Pradesh.

In Hyderabad alone around Rs 46,729 crore of IT exports were recorded this fiscal till December 2019. However, AP recorded Rs 302 crore worth of IT exports.

“AP mostly has apparel and pharma SEZs. HCL is planning to start its SEZ in Vijayawada with 2,000 employees,” Reddy said. — U Sudhakar Reddy | TNN

Title: Atrocity complaint against ‘man on principal’s chair’
Content:
Ahmedabad: Sabarmati police on Sunday filed a complaint under SC/ST (Prevention of Atrocities) act against the ‘principal’ of a college in the Sabarmati area of city. Cops couldn’t confirm whether the accused was the principal of the college, or a trustee, or an administrator with some other designation.

Police registered the complaint after a student of BCom third year of Vivekanand Arts And Commerce College in Raipur area alleged that the accused had uttered caste-based slurs against Dalits while talking with an NSUI leader.

In his complaint, Jaymin Sonara, 28, and a resident of Jashodanagar, said that he had received a video which went viral on social media on Saturday. In that video, the accused, who is seen sitting on the chair of the principal of the college in Sabarmati, is heard uttering caste-based slurs that hurt the sentiments of Dalit community.

Sonara said that the accused, who is not named in the FIR, had used caste-based slurs in response to an NSUI leader's remarks. The NSUI leader had just said that he belongs to Rajput community to which the accused had used a derogatory word while saying that he too is not someone from the Dalit community.

Sources in police said that the incident had taken place last week when some NSUI leader approached the accused over issues related to fees and the video went viral three days ago.

Title: Spectator, 28, dies as bull knocks him down during taming sport
Content:
Krishnagiri: A 28-year-old spectator was killed after a bull barged into the gallery and knocked him down during ‘eruthu vidum vizha’, a variant of jallikattu, here on Sunday.

Police identified the deceased as G Chinnapayan alias Muniyappa, son of Govindappa, from a village near Dhenkanikottai. While 20 bull tamers were injured, two bulls died as they rammed into each other during the event.

The event was organized as part of the three-day annual festival at the Mallikarjuneswarar temple at Mallikarujunamalai. According to police, a large number of people from across the district, particularly from the villages surrounding Mallikarjunamalai, usually turn up for the annual temple festival.

On Sunday too, there was a huge crowd to watch the bull taming sport. One of the bulls barged into the area where spectators had gathered as it ran out of the arena. Police said Chinnapayyan, who was caught unawares, couldn’t flee and was knocked down by the bull. He suffered grievous injuries and died on the spot.

Unlike jallikattu, the arena for ‘eruthu vidum vizha’ would be a bigger one, usually an agricultural field. Hence, the barricades were erected only for a portion, primarily around the starting point, where the bulls would be let loose, though there would be spectators all around the field. Police said all precautionary measures were taken, yet the bulls managed to enter the gallery.

Meanwhile, a bull, which was in the arena even after the next bull was let loose, was rammed head on by the latter. Both the bulls collapsed on the ground and died shortly afterwards.

Title: Centre may help RTC replenish its bus fleet
Content:
Hyderabad: In a major relief to the fund-starved Telangana State Road Transport Corporation (TSRTC), the Centre has proposed to provide new buses to smaller towns and cities to encourage public transport and reduce usage of personal vehicles.

The Centre, in association with World Bank, plan to fund state governments for purchase of new buses as part of a broader plan to reduce air and noise pollution caused by personal vehicles.

TSRTC might have to replace over 8,000 buses in the next five years. It requires over Rs 2,500 crore to replace the existing fleet of buses, which outlive its utility.

As on date, TSRTC is operating over 10,000 buses of which 8000-odd were its own buses and over 2,000 hired buses. Of them, over 6600 were being operating from the city to various destinations across the state and intra-state, from one district to another, including over 300 air-conditioned buses, 2,500 non-AC buses and 3,784 Palle Velugu buses.

In the city, the state-owned public transporter operates over 3,800 buses, including 180 air-conditioned buses (40 electric ones) and the rest ,3,650 non-AC buses. RTC buses transport 95 lakh passengers daily, logging over 35 lakh km. The RTC’s accumulated losses were nearly Rs 5,000 crore.

In such a situation, the new buses offer from the Central government could not have come at a better time for the Road Transport Corporation. TSRTC officials had attended the first round of meeting with the Central government officials in Delhi.

TSRTC officials told TOI that the Centre was still working out modalities and that a final picture on funding would emerge in a month or two. Sources said the Centre was encouraging privatization of public transport as part of its scheme to fund new buses.

Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, who had proposed privatisation of some routes where TSRTC was presently operating, might give the nod to the TSRTC officials to avail the central scheme when they go for the second round of meeting with officials of the Union road transport and highways ministry.

Title: Former chief secretary launches social outfit
Content:
Coimbatore: Former Tamil Nadu chief secretary P Rama Mohana Rao launched a social service forum named Dr RMR Paasarai in the city on Sunday.

The forum would fight for the cause of underprivileged and downtrodden sections of society to ensure equal benefits to them, Rama Mohan Rao said announcing the launch of the outfit at the state-level conference of Boyar community held here.

For now, Dr RMR Paasarai would function as a social and community service forum but Rao hinted that he might convert it into a political forum in future.

Rao was unceremoniously removed from the post of chief secretary after income tax raids at his residence in 2016 and after a brief period of suspension was reinstated in low profile posts till he retired. Over the past few months he has been toying with the idea of launching a political outfit and has been meeting people from few communities across TN.

Last month, there were posters across Madurai featuring Rama Mohan Rao prominently welcoming him for 437th birth anniversary celebrations for Nayak king Thirimalai Nayak. Referring to the Madurai event, Rao said that similar meetings would be organised in all the districts.

Title: IAF kick-starts International Women’s Week
Content: Ahmedabd: A team of 49 sanginis led by Nirmala Ghotia, president, Air Force Wives Welfare Association (Regional), South Western Air Command participated in ‘Pinkathon 2020’ held at Riverfront, Ahmedabad. These women of steel represented true ‘Shakti (power)' of Indian Air Force and their ‘Never Quit’ attitude. I never quit, I never give up, I push myself and turn my pain into lifetime gain, a sangini (air warrior's wife) said. Under the supervision, guidance and motivation from president AFWWA (R), Vayusanginis participated in all categories, with Ghotia herself leading from the front.

Title: Budget session saw Yogi Adityanath’s mellowed self
Content:
Chief minister Yogi Adityanath hosted a lunch for legislators of all parties on the last day of the budget ses... Read More

LUCKNOW: Chief minister Yogi Adityanath was at his aggressive best while tackling the opposition on the issues like CAA and law and order in the just-concluded budget session of the Assembly. However, the session also saw a mellowed Yogi who went an extra mile to mingle with partymen and rivals with equal ease.

On the last day of the session, when finance minister wanted to host a lunch for MLAs, the chief minister offered that not only he would host it himself, but also share a meal with legislators. The occasion saw him spending a good time and striking animated conversations with MLAs.

While earlier, Yogi has been making a front attack against the opposition, even ‘threatening to send them to jail’, in this session he remarked once that a film should be made on the life of the leader of opposition, Ram Govind Chaudhary . “It will become a huge hit,” he said.

When the opposition MLAs had masked their faces on last day of the session accusing the government of denying them from speaking, Yogi did not attack them, but was just laughing and avoided the confrontation by saying “the masks would keep them away from pollution”.

During his speech also, the chief minister thanked the Congress legislature party leader Aradhana Mishra for appreciating the budge. Not only this, whenever Yogi would reach the house, he would make it a point to greet the leaders of opposition parties by walking up to the desk of the leader of opposition and meeting him with folded hands.

Besides, when the opposition leaders led by BSP’s Uma Shankar Singh and Congress’s Aradhna Mishra demanded an increase in MLAs’ local area development fund,Yogi didn’t lose much time in hiking the fund from Rs 2 crore to Rs 3 crore. He also hinted at increasing the salaries of MLAs.

This was quite different from the budget session in 2017, when the entire oppostion boycotted the session alleging threat from the treasury benches and the CM’s aggressive words.

Such was the deadlock that for the whole budget session, the opposition conducted ‘parallel house’ outside the assembly, and elected its own ‘leader of the house’.

The confrontation continued between the government and the Opposition till 2019 deepening the battle lines.

This time, though Yogi retained aggressive posture, he mixed it with a more accommodating approach, inviting the opposition for dialogue and discussion. No wonder, the session passed without much hiccups.

Title: FB accounts faked, lewd posts made
Content:
Ahmedabad: A 50-year-old woman from Vatva area of the city has lodged an FIR with the cybercell police that an unknown person has created several fake Facebook IDs of hers and has posted lewd comments on them. The woman said that she doesn’t use Facebook but the accused has sent friend requests to her relatives using the fake accounts. The accused has put profile picture of her 25-year-old daughter and phone number of her son on one of the fake Facebook IDs.

On November 26, 2019 when her son was checking his Facebook, he found that his mother’s fake ID has been created and the person had sent the friend request with inappropriate demands to his family members.

“It is not for the first time that the complainant’s fake Facebook ID was created. The accused had earlier created the woman’s several Facebook IDs and had put her daughter’s profile pictures with obscene demands. The man then used to delete the IDs,” said an investigator. TNN

Title: 34kg ganja seized, one person held
Content: Hyderabad: The excise department, on Sunday, raided a house in Sangareddy district and seized 34kg dry ganja in 17 packets and nabbed one person. The accused was transporting ganja to Pune. He was also arrested earlier in Pune for a similar offence. TNN

Title: Boards resume for northeast Delhi schools
Content:
Modern Public School burnt in northeast Delhi during communal riots on February 27 (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Central Board of Secondary Education has said that if there are any students in the riot-affected areas who cannot appear for the board exam until March 7, their exams will be held at a later date. The school principals and the directorate of education (DoE) has been asked to provide details of such students.

From Monday, CBSE class X and XII examinations will take place as scheduled all over the city. The exams in the northeast and some parts of east Delhi were postponed earlier due to the violence.

Issuing a statement, CBSE secretary Anurag Tripathi said, “CBSE will hold the examinations of both classes X and XII in the northeast district of Delhi from March 2 as per the schedule given in the date sheet. At the same time, considering the difficult situation that continues with some of the candidates, CBSE is prepared to hold examinations at a later date for such candidates who would not be able to appear for the examinations up to March 7. The school principals have been requested to provide the list of such students to the board. DoE has also been requested by CBSE to provide a list.”

The examination will be held amid security in and around the centres. The board said it has decided to go on with the examinations so that it does not hamper the chances of admissions in professional courses i.e. medical, engineering, law and other UG admissions.

“Few entrance examinations are conducted in accordance with the timelines fixed by the courts and therefore, dates are sacrosanct. Similarly, JEE (Main) is also scheduled from April 3 to 19. The board is also clear that for candidates who are in a position to appear for the board examinations, it would be very stressful and cause immense anxiety if the examinations are further postponed. As per our ongoing consultations with Delhi Police, the exams can be held smoothly and safely now for those students who are in a position to appear for them,” said Tripathi.

Title: Mother drowns her 4-year-old son in Jhunjhunu water tank
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A 30-year-old woman was arrested on Saturday for drowning her 4-year-old son in a water tank under Jhunjhunu’s Chidawa police station area.

Chidawa SHO Laxminarayan Saini said, “Sunita Swami was having a marital discord with her husband since their marriage in 2010. The couple has two children. Around 3am, Sunita woke up and took Vivaan to the water tank in the house and drowned him. She then went back to the room where her elder son and husband were asleep.”

After this, the accused slit her wrist and went back to sleep. When the family woke up in the morning, Sunita gave a fake account and claimed that someone had entered the house in the middle of the night and abducted her son and slit her wrist.

Title: Asaduddin Owaisi: PM Modi must speak up on Delhi riots, demands Owaisi
Content:
Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: Terming the riots in north-east Delhi as genocide, AIMIM chief Asaduddin Owaisi on Sunday demanded that Prime Minister Narendra Modi should speak up on the violence where several people lost their lives. He also questioned the silence maintained by other NDA leaders.

The violence had started small, as clashes between supporters and opponents of the contentious Citizenship Amendment Act.

“I want to ask the PM why he hasn’t spoken a single word on the Delhi violence that took place just a few kilometres away from his official residence. More than 40 people lost their lives in the violence. He should speak up and visit the riot-hit Shiv Vihar as people who died are all Indians,” Owaisi said at a public meeting held as part of the party’s 62nd foundation day at Darussalam

The AIMIM chief said that though the PM mentioned ‘Sabka Saath, Sabka Vikas’ at his Saturday meet in Uttar Pradesh, he did not mention the riots even once. He also accused the Delhi police of not responding to calls my Muslims affected by the violence.

Referring to the slogans raised at a Metro railway station in Delhi, Owaisi said, “Who are these people shouting goli maaro desh ke gaddaron ko (shoot the traitors). This is planned violence.”

Meanwhile, AIMIM leaders have decided to donate one month salary to the families of those killed in Delhi violence.

Owaisi said that his party would also urge CM K Chandrasekhar Rao not to allow the National Population Register to be taken up in the state.

Title: Indian car rally team turned back from Bangladesh border over ‘security issues’
Content:
KOLKATA: A rally with 21 cars from Kolkata to Dhaka and other cities of Bangladesh to promote friendship, named “Moitree”, coinciding with Bangabandhu Sk Mujibur Rahman’s birth centenary celeb- rations, was turned back from the Benapole border on Sunday. The organisers, Automobile Association of Eastern India , have set up an “inquiry” into the incident. Armed with the required visa the rallyists crossed the Petrapole border on Sunday morning, only to be stopped at the Bangladesh end and told to return. Upset rallyists said they were told to return because of some “security issues” and “for lack of permission”. Nothing, however, was given in writing. The rally was supposed to move from Dhaka to Cox ’s Bazar, Chittagong, Mymensingh and Narayanganj, and re-enter Bengal at Siliguri, reports Jhimli Mukherjee Pandey.

Bangladesh deputy high commissioner in Kolkata, Toufique Hasan, told TOI via WhatsApp that while the intention of the rally was good, visas are given only for entry but a rally of this magnitude requires several other permissions from various Bangladeshi authorities.

Title: Now, Maharashtra govt may reverse cow protection scheme
Content:
Maharashtra chief minister Uddhav Thackeray

MUMBAI: The Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government is likely to reverse yet another decision taken by its predecessor: the cattle-protection scheme Govardhan Govansh Seva Kendra (GGSK) launched by the Devendra Fadnavis-led BJP-Sena alliance after a beef ban came into effect in the state. The scheme intended to boost infrastructure at cow sheds (gaushalas) was especially set up to conserve, protect and develop cattle and progeny.

Dairy and animal husbandry minister Sunil Kedar told TOI the current government will review the scheme. “We have not reached any conclusion yet. The department has been asked to review the scheme and prepare a report on how much funds have been spent, the impact of the scheme and other details,” said Kedar. A senior official said GGSK funds may not be released from now on as neither Congress nor NCP—constituents of MVA, along with Shiv Sena—is interested in going ahead with the scheme. A minister said the Uddhav Thackeray-led government is not in a mood to continue with the scheme also because most gaushala functionaries are linked to RSS.

The Fadnavis government had in 2015 enforced a beef ban, making sale or consumption of beef punishable by a five-year jail term and a fine of Rs 10,000.The GGSK scheme was launched in 2017 to set up permanent shelters in 34 districts for aged cattle which had stopped yielding milk to ensure they were not abandoned.

In 2018-19, the financial year when the scheme kicked in, the state made a one-time allocation of Rs 1 crore per gaushala, excluding Mumbai and its suburbs. In the next fiscal, the scope of the scheme was expanded to the taluka level, but with the same overall budgetary provision. Thus, it was decided to distribute Rs 34 crore among 140-plus talukas, with a grant of roughly Rs 25 lakh per gaushala.

An official said the GGSK scheme is beset with problems. On the one hand, farmers can no longer sell old and sick cattle, while on the other, the upkeep of these animals is proving to be a strain on a debt-ridden state. The scheme was intended at looking after unproductive cattle which farmers could no longer afford to feed and so would abandon or send to slaughter houses, especially during drought-like situations. At present, there are 518 gaushalas across the state, where 72,000 animals are being taken care of by various “non-profit organizations”.

As part of a previous cattle protection scheme, the government in 2016 had decided to audit over 1,200 fodder camps set up in different parts of the state during 2012-2014, and on which the government had spent about Rs 800 crore. In 2015-16 alone, the state spent Rs 185 crore on these fodder camps. The government gives a grant of Rs 70 for a big animal and Rs 35 for a small animal in the camps.

Title: Delhi cops up vigil at Shaheen Bagh to ward off trouble
Content:
CRPF personnel at Shaheen Bagh on March 1 (Photo: ANI)

NEW DELHI: Security around the anti-CAA protest site at Shaheen Bagh was heightened on Sunday after a protest call by Hindu Sena to clear the road. Even though the right-wing group cancelled its plan for the gathering on Saturday evening, Delhi Police imposed Section 144 in the area to prevent any untoward incident.

On Saturday, Vishnu Gupta, president of Hindu Sena, said: “This is to inform the general public that we have decided to call off the gathering for the protest site clearance in view of the ongoing law and order situation. I request you to not reach Shaheen Bagh (sic),” Gupta said.

“Last time as well, Hindu Sena had called for a protest for the same reason and despite it being called off, a number of people had reached close to the protest site and shouted slogans. We did not want any form of gathering, which is why Section 144 was imposed. We want to maintain law and order in the area,” a senior police officer told TOI.

Hindu Sena on Friday had called for a gathering to clear the Shaheen Bagh protest site, stating that Delhi Police and courts had not been able to do so. “On March 1, we will clear the roads ourselves. Shaheen Bagh protests are nothing, but a deliberate attempt to encourage and abet riots across the country, derail the economy and defame India on the global platform,” Gupta had claimed.

The protest at Shaheen Bagh has been going on for over two months now and people have complained of traffic bottlenecks.

Title: AIADMK leader rules out Sasikala’s re-entry
Content: AIADMK deputy coordinator K P Munusamy ruled out the possibility V K Sasikala’s re-entry into the party. “The doors of AIADMK are completely shut for her. She has no chance whatsoever to enter AIADMK,” Munusamy told reporters in Krishnagiri on Sunday. In the wake of Sasikala’s imminent release from the prison, Munusamy said even if she is released, she would have no impact on the party, which is as strong as ever.TNN

Title: Corporation relays 100 roads, work on 270 others underway
Content:
Chennai: Various roads across the city, including bus route and interior roads , are being re-laid by Greater Chennai Corporation . Officials said work on around 100 roads has been completed, while work is underway in around 270 roads.

Data sourced from the civic body shows that work on 39 bus route roads has been completed, while in around 39, work is underway. Work on another 106 roads will begin soon. In all, Rs 44 crore will be spent on this in the 2019-20 financial year.

Major roads that have been re-laid completely are Ethiraj Sami Salai and Meenambal Salai in north Chennai and Habibullah Road, St Mary’s Road, Usman Road flyover and New Avadi Road in central Chennai.

As far as interior roads are concerned, work on 60 roads has been completed, while work on 140 roads is underway. Work on another 750 roads will be taken up soon. The expenditure for interior roads is around Rs 150 crore for the 2019-20 financial year. Some interior roads that received a face-lift include Arul Nagar Second Street, Ganapathy Nagar Third Street, Kannadasan Street, Bharathiyar Street and Annaswamy Street in the north and central parts. Work on some bus route and interior roads pending from the previous financial year is also underway, an official said.

In light of the Madras high court taking up road milling in a serious manner, corporation officials said they are scrutinising work done by contractors properly. “Only those contractors who have a sensor-driven milling machine costing Rs 2 crore were allowed to relay the roads. Either they should buy the machines or show proof of lease agreements,” a senior official said. Around 25 contractors own the machine in the city.

Milling is important as otherwise, road height would increase and consequently impact the level of houses. Spot visits show that after the high court stricture, milling on roads in Mandaveli has improved. This could be gauged as the road below the level of the manhole was also found to be milled, while before the HC stricture, this was not done.

Activist Jayaram Venkatesan of NGO Arappor Iyakkam said milling work this time is better than in previous years. “However, there are still complaints in some areas,” he said.

C R Balaji of Mandaveli who travels across the city regularly, said the milling work is not uniform in different areas. “For instance, proper milling work could be seen on St Mary’s Road, but behind the Aavin roundabout in Adyar, the work wasn’t as good. It depends on how ward area engineers supervise the work or how much accountability is demanded by their bosses,” he said.

Title: Retired govt official robbed on MTC bus
Content:
Chennai: A retired government official was allegedly robbed of 11 sovereigns of gold on an MTC bus on Saturday.

According to the complaint by 70-year-old V Parthasarathy, he boarded the bus (route 11A) from T Nagar. When he alighted at Spencer Plaza stop on Anna Salai, he was shocked to find that the bottom of the handbag he was carrying was torn and the valuables stolen. Police sources said the septuagenarian was carrying a six-sovereign gold chain and a five-sovereign necklace .

Police investigation revealed that the victim is a resident of Mandaveli and a retired revenue inspector. He was returning from a relative’s house when he was robbed. Police suspect the robbers may have followed Parthasarathy from T Nagar. The Thousand Lights police plan to examine CCTV camera footage along the bus route to identify if any suspicious-looking person alighted from the bus before the senior citizen got off.

Title: Chandigarh: Drugs, alcohol turn green spaces black, city sees red
Content: CHANDIGARH: Low footfalls and zero policing are making green spaces a den of illicit activities in the city, making residents living nearby furious and showing the authorities in a negative light.If you visit any park during morning or evening for a walk, do not be shocked to find people having beer or smoking marijuana or even taking drugs. A TOI team in a reality check conducted over a week found youngsters, especially school students in uniform, consuming drugs, smoking, drinking alcohol and doing drugs openly without any fear of law.At parks in sectors 7, 8, 9 and even Leisure Valley, of youngsters coolly rolled joints and injected themselves with drugs while gulping alcohol, unmindful of people taking a stroll near them or showing any fear of cops catching them in the act. Such has been the takeover of parks that residents are changing their daily routine.“We fear taking a walk in parks now. Youngsters are openly taking drugs and there is little check on them. Cops must take strict action against such illegal activities,” said Sukhwinder Singh, a retired Army officer and a resident of Sector 8. Similarly, another resident said, “We have informed the police control room and beat officer multiple times but to no avail. We fear these drug/alcohol users might invite some criminal activity in our neighborhood.”Residents who share their boundary walls with parks said they daily spot youngsters taking drugs, including alcohol, on a routine basis, mostly during the afternoon hours.When TOI asked these youngsters from where they procure drugs and liquor, they claimed they were easily available in the city and vend owners provide them booze without checking their identity cards. While the police are focused on catching people consuming liquor at public places, they hardly check parks, said a group of residents.Vineet Kumar, superintendent of police (SP), said, “It is a matter of concern. A special team will be formed. I will ask all police station in-charges to conduct a mapping of all public parks. School students are vulnerable and will be counselled and their parents called while cases will be filed against adults for keeping drugs and alcohol.” He said residents can inform the police of such incidents by clicking pictures and lodging a complaint on e-Saatchi mobile application. The beat officer concerned will be informed and action taken immediately,” he said.

Title: Makkal Adhikaram condemns CAA, NRC, NPR, Delhi violence
Content:
Coimbatore: Members of Makkal Adhikaram on Sunday staged a demonstration at Sivananda Colony to condemn the violence in New Delhi and also against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), the National Registry of Citizens ( NRC ) and the National People’s register ( NPR ).

District coordinator of the outfit S Moorthy said the violence in New Delhi was instigated by the New Delhi police. “The protests have been going on for two months. Police had given permission for pro-CAA demonstrators to hold demonstrations very near to those, who were protesting against the Act. It was done with an eye to incite violence,” he said.

Moorthy said the State should not allow CAA, NRC and NPR to be implemented here. “Several States have opposed the Act. States, which initially had supported the Act, have now passed resolution against it.”

The outfit has been conducting protests condemning the Delhi violence and CAA for the last two days, Moorthy said. “On Sunday, we staged demonstrations in other regions of the State also. As many as 42 people, including children, participated in the protest in the city.”

Title: Food delivery man arrested for spreading rumours
Content:
Cops patrolling in the city on Saturday

Vadodara: The detection of crime branch (DCB) on Sunday arrested a man on charges of creating panic by spreading rumours about replacement of CCTVs in the city.

Abidullah Khatib, a resident of Mogulwada, was nabbed after investigations revealed that he had forwarded the provocative post on social media. Cops said they are on the look out for other suspects in the case.

According to the police, Khatib had posted the message stating that the cops are replacing CCTVs to help pro-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) group planning to take out a rally in the city. Khatib works as a delivery guy with a popular food delivery firm.

“We are trying to ascertain if he created the post or had only forwarded it. He is an SSC pass and knows English quite well,” said Jaydeepsinh Jadeja, DCP (crime).

The cops are searching for another person using the handle ‘Dine Islam’ who had shared this inflammatory post.

Following the provocative post that asked people from the minority community to remain alert for the next two days on Saturday and Sunday, the police had to issue clarifications two days ago that work on replacing CCTVs has been initiated as new cameras are being installed in the walled city to replace the defunct ones.

Title: Delhi: Gang supplying party drugs busted, two held
Content:
Puneet Arora (left) and Vinod Kumar

NEW DELHI: A module supplying party drugs to students and businessmen was busted and two smugglers were arrested a few days ago. Drugs worth Rs 50 crore were seized from them.

Police said the father of one of the accused, Puneet Arora (42) who belongs to Gurugram, runs a medicine shop in Birmingham. He is allegedly the kingpin of the racket.

The Delhi operations were handled by Arora, they added. The other accused, Vinod Kumar ( 44), is a resident of Uttam Nagar.

“We have seized around 69 kg of capsules and 150 kg of tablets of Tramadol. 12.5 kg of Alprazolam tablets were also found with them,” DCP (special cell) Sanjeev Yadav said.

The police got information that the accused used to procure psychotropic drugs from various parts of India and supplied them to Delhi and the UK. “A specific input was received that a large consignment of the contraband was going to be exchanged between Arora and Kumar in Uttam Nagar, after which a team led by ACP Sanjay Dutt laid a trap, and arrested them,” DCP Yadav said.

Arora revealed that his father was running a medicine shop in the UK and supplied psychotropic drug tablets and capsules in the garb of Ayurvedic products. “These drugs were supplied by the father-son duo to pubs and nightclubs. A contact, named as X, was fixed to deliver these drugs. We are looking for that contact,” DCP Yadav added.

Kumar used to work as a courier boy and allegedly knew some clearing agents in customs department who helped him in shipping these consignments out of India.

“Tramadol is considered an opioid based narcotic drug of the same category as drugs like morphine, codeine and hydrocodone...They are some of the most abused drugs in the country,” a statement by Special Cell said.

Title: NCB arrests six of cartel selling drugs in Delhi
Content:
386kg of contraband was seized

NEW DELHI: Sleuths of Narcotics Control Bureau have unearthed an Odisha-based marijuana cartel smuggling contraband to Delhi and arrested six smugglers. As much as 386kg of marijuana worth several crore rupees in the international market was seized from a truck. The cops are trying to identify the source.

The arrested men have been identified as B Lenka, Ajay, Mayadhar, Arjun and Sunil from Ganjam in Odisha and Virender from Palwal in Haryana. “We received an input that a consignment was to enter Delhi from Odisha. A trap was laid at Sarita Vihar and a truck bearing an Andhra Pradesh registration number was intercepted,” said K P S Malhotra (zonal director, NCB).

Two other vehicles, a Ford Eco Sports and a Swift Dzire, which were escorting the truck, were also intercepted. Upon intensive search of the vehicles and questioning of the people, a huge quantity of marijuana was found in a secret cavity behind the driver’s cabin of the truck. The main supplier and the receiver, along with their accomplices, were placed under arrest.

During interrogation, it was revealed that the source was located in Ganjam district of Odisha. Though the district has been removed from the list of Naxalites-affected areas in 2018 by Odisha police, the sleuths will now probe if some Naxal-linked groups were behind this cartel. There are some leads in this regard, sources said.

“There is a big margin in the smuggling of marijuana. The contraband was sold by the source at Rs 2,500 per kg and the end user paid Rs 500 for ten grams. The marijuana was compressed and packed in square shapes so that a large amount could be shipped in a single consignment,” said an officer.

In India, cannabis is grown in large scale in Odisha and Andhra Pradesh. According to police, ganja is grown illegally on vast stretches of Odisha’s inaccessible forested regions and make for the largest produce in the country. “While the state’s climatic condition favours the production, the growth is further aided by barren Maoist-affected hilly terrains as well as prevalent poverty,” an official said. Sources said that districts like Boudh, Gajapati Rayagada, Kandhamal, Malkangiri and Sambalpur have been identified as major production hubs in Odisha.

Title: It pays to manage waste, find 9 south Mumbai societies
Content:
For the first time, a private firm will handle all the dry waste in D ward

MUMBAI: If people don’t turn up their noses, garbage may not be all that smelly. Starting this month, nine housing societies in south Mumbai ’s D Ward will qualify for a 10% property tax rebate—5% for properly segregating their wet and dry waste and 5% for composting the wet garbage on their premises.

The incentive is part of the ongoing initiatives to send zero garbage to Mumbai’s overflowing landfills which are hazardous and combustible. Over the last two years, most societies and bulk waste generators like restaurants have changed their approach to garbage and realised that they must now share the onus of waste disposal with the civic body, in keeping with a 2016 Central government notification that requires people to segregate waste at source.

“We are finding that many societies already doing a great job of taking care of their wet waste on their premises, including Godrej Baug, Infinity Towers, Hill Park and Navrang,” says Rajendra Jagtap, who oversees solid waste management in D ward. “Bulk generators like Malabar Hill Club and Willingdon Sports Club also take care of their own kitchen waste. Even Mahalaxmi and Babulnath Temple and ISKCON have installed machines that compost their floral waste.”

For the first time, a private company has been appointed to take charge of all dry garbage, starting in D Ward because the NGO model has not been consistent. From March 1, Dalmia Polypro, an upcycler that converts plastic waste into film, yarn, furniture and other products, will handle the entire chain of collecting, segregating, recycling and transporting dry waste. It will start first with Nepean Sea Road, Walkeshwar Road and Malabar Hill and gradually move to other areas in the ward. The company has been allotted space in Worli for its upcycling work.

Ragpickers help in waste segregation, to be trained in cleaning up dry plastic

Dalmia Polypro, a plastic upcycling firm, has been given space at Khadye Marg, opposite Mahalaxmi Race Course, where its machines now pack the plastic into tight bales and also neatly divide it into the various grades which can then be sent to be regurgitated into its new avatars.

“PET bottles yield fibre yarn which is used to make clothes, blankets and shoes; fast food packaging becomes fuel or can be used to make agricultural pipes, the hub for which is in Malegaon,” says Shashikant Joshi of Dalmia Polypro. “The multilayer plastic used in packaging has no real value, which is why you can see it lying everywhere, on streets or clogging drains. Now we will handle it and ensure th at it is transported to the cement factories where it is used in place of carbon fuel.”

The vast informal recycling army of ragpickers are being given identity cards and uniforms and continue to participate in the segregation process. There are around 85 ragpickers across D ward, says Jagtap. They will also be trained to clean up the dry plastic that still contain bits of wet food or milk. If this pilot project works, it will be replicated across the city. As for wet waste, all housing societies, restaurants and other generators will eventually have to handle this at source, either by composting on the premises or handing the job over to a contractor.

So far, D ward office has received 14 applications for the rebate. “We have found 9 to be in order and the rest are still being scrutinised,” says Jagtap. The rebate will be effective from April onwards, in the general assessment category of property tax.

Waste management systems in the city has long followed a haphazard system where wet and dry waste collectively found its way into the overflowing landfills in Deonar and Kanjurmarg, leading to periodic combustion caused by compressed gasses. Even after some housing societies started following segregating practices, there has been no proper audit of whether the wet waste was actually being composted by the contractors, or whether it was being illegally dumped in random open spaces. Now both the municipal corporation and citizens are getting closer to realising that this is in every one’s best interest.

Title: Madras HC stays transfer of complaints against lawyers to Bar Council of India
Content:
Chennai: The Madras high court has stayed transfer of disciplinary complaints against advocates pending before the Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry to the Bar Council of India (BCI) on the ground that the former has failed to dispose the complaints within one year. A division bench of Justices N Kirubakaran and R Pongiappan passed the interim order while noting that the state bar council is deliberately dragging the disposal so that the complaints are transferred to BCI under Section 36B of the Advocates Act.

“It is evident from many cases listed before this court that the Bar Council of Tamil Nadu and Puducherry is not exercising its statutory duty and disposing the complaint within the stipulated period of one year. There is every reason to believe that it is being done deliberately to ensure that Section 36B could be invoked and the complaints could be transferred to BCI,” the bench said.

This apart, parties who are already under distress would be put to unnecessary hardship as they would be forced to go to New Delhi which is 2,200 km from Chennai to pursue the complaints, and it would be impossible for the poor litigants. They would be put to untold hardship and grave injustice would be caused to them, the bench added.The court passed the order on a plea moved by a complainant whose plaint against an advocate was dragged for years before the state bar. Now apprehending that the complaint would be transferred to the BCI under Section 36B, he approached the high court.

Allowing the plea, the bench said, Section 36B was brought only in the interest of the aggrieved litigants and also to see that erring advocates are punished at the earliest. However, the bar councils of the respective states are taking advantage of the provision and doing injustice to the complainants by transferring their complaints to the file of BCI deliberately. Thus, the very purpose of the provision is frustrated.

Further, noting that the validity of the provision needs to be examined, the court impleaded the central government as party respondent to the plea and adjourned it to March 6 for further hearing.

Title: Demanding jobs, agri students block Pipliyahana Road for hours
Content:
Indore: Demanding jobs in agriculture department, over 150 students of Agriculture College blocked Pipliyahana Road leading to World Cup Square for a couple of hours on Sunday.

Final year postgraduate students along with former students alleged that state government hasn’t come up with job openings in department for years now.

Mukesh Jat, who has been unemployed for last eight years and has been waiting for government to come up with some vacancies in department since 2012.

“In 2008, government had put up vacancies. After that in 2015, jobs vacancies had come but due to stay order from court nothing has happened yet. We can say that for over 10 years there has been no vacancy,” he added.

Students had been protesting for nearly 20 days. Three-four students had sat on indefinite hunger strike since Saturday.

As most buses use this route, police had to plan traffic diversion to streamline things. Traffic coming MYH has been diverted towards Radio Colony while those coming from Pipliyahana were diverted to Musakhedi said, TI Dharmendra Shivhare.

The protest was called off after SDM Sohan Kanath intervened and assured students that agriculture minister will meet three students on Monday, who sat on indefinite hunger strike.

“We have assured students that we will convey their message to government and they have stopped the protest,” said Kanath.

Another MSc final year student, Vikas Choudhary said that the protest have stopped as SDM has assured us that agriculture minister will meet students on Monday. If it doesn’t happen, a bigger protest will be staged on Tuesday.

Title: Rs 1-crore fraud lens on institute staffer from Kolkata
Content:
Representative image

By: Tanmaya Das

KOLKATA: A city-based academic institute has alleged misappropriation of funds to the tune of over Rs 1 crore by a senior member of its finance and accounts department. The complaint was registered with the Bhowanipore police.

Police has initiated an investigation against the accused, Santanu Bag, under sections 408 (criminal breach of trust), 403 (dishonest misappropriation of property), 467 (forgery of valuable security), 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating), 471 (using forged documents as genuine) and 420 (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property). Bag has been summoned for questioning.

According to the FIR by Global Reach Education Foundation, Bag allegedly embezzled the money meant for the payment of employees’ state insurance and employees’ provident fund. The embezzlement was accounted for Rs1,02,39,305.

Bag had some key responsibilities that included salary payments, regulatory government deposits, vendor payments against claims etc.

The embezzlement was carried out from January 2018 till December, 2019. Bag had been receiving money since April 2016 for the payment of several expenses that he had misappropriated. Based on the revelations of an audit, Bag was asked to cooperate with the emergency internal compliance committee on February 10, 2020, for the inquiry. But his alleged “lack of willingness to cooperate in the committee proceedings resulted in his suspension from the role”.

However, due to lack of response, the final showcause notice was issued on Feb 24, 2020, seeking a probe on the irregularities kept in bookkeeping and the personal bank account statements of Bag. According to the audit report, there has been some irregularity in the filing of GST returns as well. This has resulted in the additional burden of interest and penalty for the institute.

According to the complaint filed by the managing director of the institute Ravi Lochan Singh, he was requested by Bag on December 27, 2019, to approve a hefty amount and transfer the fund online in order to pay for the various expenses of the institute. Singh, who lives outside India, trusted him and transferred the money. However, an investigation revealed a huge difference between the amount paid to Bag and the sum disbursed for ESI and EPF. This prompted the institute to conduct a deeper probe.

Title: Polish student told to leave India over anti-CAA rally
Content:
KOLKATA: A Polish postgraduate student of Jadavpur University’s (JU’s) comparative literature department has been served a notice by the Foreigners Regional Registration Office (FRRO) to leave India within a fortnight for his alleged participation in an anti-CAA/NRC rally in central Kolkata on December 19. This is the second such order issued by the Kolkata FRRO in recent days.

JU sources said the notice was issued to Kamil Siedcynski on February 22. Kamil has been told that his con-duct was “inappropriate for a foreign national staying in India on a student visa”.

A concerned Kamil has informed the embassy of Poland and appealed to the FRRO to reconsider the notice, saying that he had merely gone to click photographs, which “should not be construed as participating in the rally”. He has appealed that he be allowed to stay in India till July to complete his coursework. He was otherwise scheduled to leave India in August.

The first such order by the Kolkata FRRO was issued on February 14 to a Bangladeshi undergraduate student of Visva-Bharati University after the student, Afsara Anika Meem , posted photographs of an anti-CAA pro-test on social media.

Title: Barodians feast on creativity and colours in weekend art fairs
Content:
Vadodara: It was a visual treat for art lovers of Sanskarinagri this weekend. Artists from different walks of life had organized exhibition of their artworks in different studios of the city and Barodians made the most of these paintings. Most venues were buzzing with admirers who didn’t just cherish but also bought the artworks.

If a group of artists came together to exhibit its paintings at Vadodara Design Academy, Jyoti Gaekwad, wife of former India cricketer, Anshuman Gaekwad too put her paintings on display in her exhibition ‘Joy Paints’ at Splatter Studio on BPC Road. Another artist Prem Kumar Singh made the most of the blissful white colour in exhibition of his paintings ‘White Landscape’ at fine arts faculty, MSU.

Rajib Chattopadhyay painted various forms of Lord Ganesha and Goddess Durga in his painting exhibition ‘Niharika’ at PN Gadgil Hall on Sunday. Chander Parkash too wowed the visitors by some beautiful works that he made from wood and papier-mache and displayed in Sama area.

Title: Mumbai: Ditched by hubby, single mom now runs for living
Content:
Marathoner Seema Verma won over Rs 2 lakh last year

MUMBAI: Nalasopara resident Seema Verma has made it to the winners’ podium at many running events over the last few years, but it’s her personal story of grit that inspires fellow-runners the most.

Verma, a 38-year-old single mother who survived an abusive marriage, worked as a domestic help before one of the ‘memsahibs’ helped her take up running professionally.

Today, Verma—mother of a 19-yearold boy—makes a living only out of running. While she refuses to reveal how much she earns, she said, “When I finish on the podium, I get something like Rs 20,000. Collectively, these earning help me survive.”

Considering that Verma finished on the podium in 14 of the races she ran through 2019, it would be safe to assume she made over Rs 2 lakh—considerably more than a domestic help would make in a year.

She isn’t yet an elite marathoner—a title that requires women to complete the 42-km run in roughly 3:05 hours-—but she finished on the podium of the Tata Mumbai Marathon held in January with a timing of 3:52:58 hours.

Running, though considered a nascent sport in India, is estimated to be a $200 million business. The tribe of local elite marathoners is thus slowly but surely growing. In the West, winning races offers rich dividends: most marathons offer special prices for runners who finish the run in specific period (say a $1,000 for finishing under 2:11 hours for men and 2:28 for women) and the winner earn tens of thousands dollars. The first-place runner at the London Marathon, for instance, gets over $50,000.

8 years after starting as runner, she made a mark

Verma lived in Kolkata before moving to Mumbai at eight years of age. She was married at 17 years of age to an alcoholic who deserted her and their son within four years of their wedding. Forced to fend for herself and her toddler, Seema took up odd jobs, including being a househelp. There were days when she had to lock up her son at home so that she could go to work.

One of Verma’s employers, who knew about her love for sports, exhorted her to take up running to supplement her income. It was also the time when Verma was learning karate. Her parents were not encouraging as they wanted her to concentrate on getting a job and raising her son. Under the circumstances, it wasn’t easy for her to spare time to train for a marathon but she slowly over the next couple of years got better at running.

Now, eight years after starting her journey as a runner, Verma has crossed a personal landmark: she only depends on her passion of running to survive.

Title: Nagpur: Follow health chart to track your child’s growth, says expert
Content:
Representative image

Nagpur: Growth is the most important indicator of a child’s health. It depends on various factors, right from food, physical activity, lifestyle and environment. The Indian Academy of Paediatricians (IAP) has prepared growth charts precisely for Indian children. These charts are available free of cost for parents to measure the height and weight of their children in the age group of 5 to 18 years.

Instead of following the growth charts of USA, UK and other countries, Indian parents should follow the IAP’s latest revised growth chart, appealed renowned paediatrician, Dr Vaman Khadilkar, who was the convener of the growth chart committee of IAP.

“Parents can track the growth of their kids simply by downloading the free android app ‘IAP growth chart’. This app will clear many myths about growth,” he said.

Dr Khadilkar was in the city to attend ‘Paediatric Endocrine Update’, a one-day conference organized by the Academy of Paediatricians (AOP) Nagpur. The conference mainly focused on hormonal issues in children.

“One of the major myths is that children don’t have issues related to hormones. The endocrine system is considered as one of the most primitive body systems. Complexities in this system impact growth, development, survival and reproduction,” he said.

Dr Sudha Rao (Mumbai), Dr IPS Kochar (Delhi), Dr Saurabh Uppal (Jalandhar), Dr Swati Kanodia (Delhi) and Dr Ruchi Parikh (Mumbai) shared the latest developments in bone health, rickets, endocrine hypertension and type 1 diabetes. City’s paediatric endocrinologist, Dr Hari Mangtani, spoke about the approach to children with rickets. Dr Anuradha Khadilkar shared her knowledge about obesity and metabolic syndrome.

“Obesity is responsible for many hormonal diseases in children and adolescents, right from thyroid disorders to polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). A healthy lifestyle and proper diet can keep children fit. Reducing screen time is also an important factor. These lifestyle changes need to be followed by all the family members and not just kids,” she said.

AOP Nagpur president, Dr Shubhada Khirwadkar and secretary Dr Mustafa Ali said that these days, paediatricians are better equipped to treat children and adolescents with hormonal disorders.

“Paediatric endocrinology is a specialized branch for hormonal diseases in children. This super-speciality has developed rapidly in the world and India as well in the last few years. Doctors from all over Vidarbha were given the latest update about endocrinology in today’s event,” said Dr Khirwadkar.

Title: Nashik: Over 16,000 apply for RTE admissions, fewer seats to make school entry tougher
Content:
NASHIK: The education department of the Nashik zilla parishad has received over 16,000 applications for school admissions under the Right To Education ( RTE ) Act.

The parents can admit their wards to nursery, junior preparatory, kindergarten or to Class I under the Act. A student, once admitted, can stay in the school under the RTE provision until he completes Class VIII.

The deadline for submitting the online application forms was on Saturday. As many as 16,311 applications were received from parents who are keen on their wards to get admitted in schools under RTE. The number of applications has increased by about 3,000 as compared to last year.

Sources in the zilla parishad said it would be difficult to get admissions under RTE than last year as the number of seats available has dipped this year as compared to last year. This year, there are 5,553 seats up for grabs, while last year, there were 5,735 vacant seats.

“The number of schools that had registered last year was 457. This year, only 447 schools have registered. This will impact the availability of seats,” ZP education officials said.

After receiving the applications, there will be a verification of the documents by the scrutiny committee on the basis of which the applications will be eligible for the lottery round.

The government has taken two initiatives in the admission process of students under RTE this year. It has scrapped the system of having lottery four times for selection of students. Instead, the draw of lots would be done only once.

Also, the same number of students will be put on the waiting list.

“The students sometimes give wrong information, which causes rejection of their applications. Also the students want to take admissions in the schools of their preference in their locality which, if not allotted, they do not take admission under RTE and go to another school,” the officials added.

“By April 13, the list of the students will be finalised after the lottery and the verification of the documents would take place thereafter. After that, a waiting list of the applicants will be released,” the officials added.

Title: Wood chunk to trumpeting tuskers
Content:
Kochi: When Abhisankar K S (22), a fourth year Bachelor of Fine Arts student at Kalady Sree Sankaracharya Sanskrit University, brought a lifelike wooden sculpture of the late tusker Thiruvambadi Sivasundar he made for the college’s degree show exhibition two days ago, students and teachers were enthralled and appreciative of his sculpting skills.

But only a few had known that it was one among the several elephant sculptures he and his two friends, Vipin Raj and Abin M R, had sculpted over the last seven years. For them sculpting lifelike statues of Kerala’s renowned tuskers is a livelihood and more than 200 such sculptures of tuskers like Pambadi Rajan, Thechikottukavu Ramachandran and Thrikkadavoor Sivaraju, have been made in their workshop named ‘ Aana Factory ’ in Chakkumarassery in Paravur .

“We are passionate about elephants since childhood but we knew that we couldn’t afford to own one. Then it was my cousin and Guru Vipin Raj, who put forward the idea of making our own versions of these tuskers with the skills we had. He started experimenting with elephant sculpting 10 years ago and later Abin and I joined him. Our sculpture won appreciation and people started making orders for more sculptures,” said Abhisankar, who is currently working on the statue of Guruvayur Padmanabhan, the tusker that died recently.

The heights of their sculptures range between 1.5ft and 5.5ft. It took one and a half week to complete the 1.5ft-tall piece of Sivasundar and for the larger ones it will take up to a month.

“Based on the order we will take photographs of the particular elephant from different angles. The carvings, detailing and painting are all done by hand. While the smallest one costs Rs 20,000, the 5.5ft-tall Pambadi Rajan’s sculpture was sold for nearly Rs 2 lakhs,” Abhisankar said.

Title: 12 yrs RI to labourer for abduction, rape of minor
Content:
Vadodara: The court of special POCSO judge M K Chauhan sentenced a casual labourer to rigorous imprisonment for 12 years after he was convicted on Saturday of abduction, rape of a 14-year-old girl in January 2017.

As per case details, accused Kanu Khasiya had lured the girl promising to marry her and took her to Ahmedabad and later to Bhavnagar.

Khasiya had come in contact with the minor when he used to give clothes for ironing to her mother.

After she went missing, the mother searched for her at several places and later learnt from Khasiya’s employer that he had eloped with the girl.

The mother then went to Khasiya’s village in Bhavnagar in seaqrch of her daughter but didn’t find the duo there.

She returned to the city and registered a complaint of kidnapping at Bapod police station.

Police later tracked the duo to Mahuva village in Bhavnagar and brought them back to the city.

In her statement, the girl told the police that Khasiya raped her twice at Ahmedabad and then at Bhavnagar too.

Khasiya, who had been arrested for abduction only, also faced charges of rape.

During the trial, the public prosecutor submitted medical evidence and forensic reports against Khasiya.

The court upheld the evidence and also considered testimonies of the girl and other witnesses to convict Khasiya.

Title: Nagpur farmer drowns, mob claims wild animal attack, demands Rs15 lakh aid
Content:
Representative image

Nagpur: Instigated by local leaders, villagers of Dhiwarwada near Koka Wildlife Sanctuary, 70km from here in Bhandara district, created ruckus over death of a farmer who died due to drowning but people wanted it to be considered as victim of wild animal attack. As per the GR, kin of the victim of wild animal attacks get Rs15 lakh.

On February 28, Harishchandra Raut (52), Dhiwarwada, went missing when he had gone to his farm for guarding crop, known as ‘jagli’ in local parlance. Raut’s farm is adjacent to the sanctuary and is separated by a perennial small brook.

When Raut did not return home, his wife approached the villagers who launched a search on February 29. His body was found in the nullah, which had hardly 2-3 feet water.

News of Raut’s death spread like wild fire and a mob of around 200 people gathered at the spot. They were joined by some politicians including former BJP MLA Charan Waghmare from Tumsar, Dhiwarwada sarpanch Dhamdeo Wanve and others.

When forest officials and police reached the spot, villagers led by zilla parishad member Sarita Chouragade and Wanve did not allow them to remove Raut’s body and wanted officials to put on record that his death was due to wild animal attack and his family be paid compensation as per GR.

The mob vent ire on Koka RFO Sachin Jadhav, who had arrested Raut in April last for poaching a wild boar. Raut was among 11 accused arrested. The case is pending in Mohadi court. The mob also alleged that Raut was frustrated with the court case and hence must have committed suicide.

However, as the mob let loose arousing law and order problem, the leaders forced forest and police officials to announce some compensation to the victim’s family. On humanitarian ground, RFO Jadhav gave Rs15,000 while API Nilesh Waje offered Rs10,000 from their pockets.

The people did not stop at this and put Raut’s body in front of forest quarters at Dhiwarwada and forced the RFO to give it in writing that the victim would be paid compensation as per the GR.

Ex-MLA Waghmare said, “Raut’s farm is close to sanctuary boundary and he died due to falling in the nullah after being chased by wild animals. He should get Rs15 lakh compensation as per GR. The fact has been recorded in police panchnama. Post-mortem report will reveal it.”

Sarpanch Wanve said, “It is not confirmed how Raut died. Though Raut’s body showed no major injuries, the area has presence of tigers and leopards. There is no reason why he will commit suicide. Post-mortem report will reveal the truth.”

However, police officials who were on the spot, told TOI, “Prima facie, it appears to be a case of accidental death. We examined the body but nowhere injury marks were seen. There are no eyewitnesses to testify that Raut was attacked by wild animals. We are waiting for post-mortem report.”

NNTR officials said, “Entire area near the spot was scanned but there is no direct or indirect evidence like pugmarks, scrape marks, or scat of any wild animal. Paying compensation in such cases will set wrong precedent.”

Title: Vadodara: Prostitution racket busted on JP Road, six arrested
Content:
Accused in police custody

VADODARA: Special operations group (SOG) busted a prostitution racket on Sunday and arrested six people from J P Road area. The cops acted on a tip-off and raided two different spots on J P Road and near Akshar Chowk they found the six agents involved in the racket.

Police have also rescued four women involved in the racket. While three of them are from other states, one is from Gujarat. According to the police, the accused used to run sex racket through a website Highest Standard Call Girl Escort Service and Oklute. The clients, who visited the website, were sent phone numbers. And later, photos of the girls were used to be sent on Whatsapp of the client.

Those arrested have been identified as Nitin Vala, resident of Amreli; Sandip Kumar, resident of Delhi; Arjan Singh, a resident of Madhya Pradesh; Chirag Dudhat, resident of Ahmedabad; Sanjay Chakravarti, resident of Mahisagar and Vinod Patel, resident of Surat. The cops have also seized six mobile phones and a two-wheeler along with some cash from the accused. An offence has been registered at Gotri police station against the six people.

Title: Top decision: HC to have stack parking
Content:
Chandigarh: The UT has finalized the modalities of its first stack parking (one on top of the other) system for 2,800 cars (extendable to 5,000) at the Punjab and Haryana high court and started the financial exercise.

The project site is opposite the court building in an open area where the bar association is running a temporary paid parking. The work will cost the city around Rs 300 crore for now, but procedural delays might jack up the expenses during construction. The financial estimate for special grant will go to the home ministry because the UT administrator has powers to sanction only up to Rs 100 crore.

The three-tier basement parking will cover 14.75 acres, although the building’s footprint will be just 9.5 acres. The total basement area will be 11.55 lakh square feet, while its each single floor will cover 3.85 lakh square feet. The court is part of Unesco world heritage site Capitol Complex, an eco-sensitive zone. After building the three-floor basement parking, the surface area will be maintained green, but it’s unclear, so far, how Unesco and its related heritage agencies will see it.

A senior officer in the Chandigarh administration said: “We are on with preparing the financial estimate, keeping in mind all the parameters such as structural and fire safety, besides the use of latest technology. All things have been taken care of in making the financial estimate. Since it will be a huge building with electricity sub-station, lifts, automated entry and exit, it will have fire-safety equipment, proper ventilation, lighting, and ramps, besides intelligent parking systems such as boom barriers and electronic screens that show space availability.

Title: Delhi: ‘Power walk’ from India Gate to Janpath raises women safety issue
Content:
Hundreds of women and men participated in the walk from India Gate to Janpath

NEW DELHI: The National Commission for Women (NCW) organised a “power walk” from India Gate to Janpath on Sunday evening to create awareness about women safety at public places.

Hundreds of young women and men including students and activists participated in the walk , which was led by NCW chief Rekha Sharma. Wearing black t-shirts, which had ‘ Power Walk’ written at the back, the participants were seen holding placards with messages and slogans regarding gender equality and women safety.

Among those present at the event included high commissioner of Canada to India, Nadir Patel, and Padma Shri awardee Usha Chaumar.

Addressing the gathering, Patel offered Canadian High Commission’s support to such initiatives. “It is incumbent on all of us to help create an environment all over the world where women can thrive and prosper,” Patel said. “Women are equal contributors to prosperity, both economic and social. I am particularly pleased to see so many men here.” Sharma said the walk was being simultaneously organised in 15 states. A nukkad natak was also held by a group of students from Delhi University.

Title: Housing plots must be ready by March 10: VZM collector
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Vizianagaram district collector M Hari Jawaharlal on Saturday, urged district authorities as well as revenue and survey authorities to complete plot-laying work (for housing) in the district by March, 2020.

Jawaharlal was touring the largest layout in the district in Gunakalam. On the occasion, he said that the plots must be ready for the lucky draw by March 10. He also asked officials to take up levelling and site description work must be taken up on war footing.

The collector further said that the state government will provide housing plots to 25 lakh households by the end of the month and urged revenue and other concerned departments to speed-up the process. He added that efforts must be made to retain as much greenery as possible.

Title: Couple cheats man of Rs 3L in property deal
Content:
Vadodara: An elderly man living on RV Desai Road was allegedly cheated of Rs 3 lakh by a couple.

Complainant Dilip Mali, who retired from Vadodara Gas Ltd, had approached accused Manjit Rajput and Geeta Rajput as he wanted to buy their property located near Somatalav in 2017. Mali and the couple decided to fix the property’s deal at Rs13 lakh and Mali paid Rs1 lakh cash immediately and then paid Rs2 lakh through cheque.

For the remaining amount, Mali wanted to take out a loan from a bank, but his loan requests were turned down by several banks as he was retired. Mali then went to the couple to inform that he was not getting a loan so he would like to call off the deal and asked for his token amount back. Manjit told Mali that it was too late, so the money cannot be returned. Mali’s nephew too talked to the couple for the money, but they gave same excuse to him too.

Later, Mali learned that the couple had already sold the property to some other person without returning him his money. He recently approached police to register his complaint at Wadi police station on Saturday. Police said Mali was suffering from heart ailment for which he had to undergo surgery and advised to not venture out of home for eight months, thus the delay in registering the case.

Title: Hyderabad university shuts gates to stall student protest
Content:
HYDERABAD: Police on Sunday locked all the gates of English and Foreign Languages University (EFLU) here and stopped students from stepping outside the campus to join a protest against Delhi riots and CAA.

Students said they were about to take part in a protest at Karachi Bakery in Moazzam Jahi Market in solidarity with Delhi riot victims and against CAA/NRC when police got wind of it and locked the varsity gates. Some other students of the varsity said police had informed them that they had received intelligence about members of the right-wing students’ group planning to attack them if they took part in the protest.

At Osmania University too, students were allegedly stopped from heading out to take part in the protest.

Title: Araku festival begins: Bonda dance, archery enthrall tourists on day one
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The two-day Araku festival got off to a gala start on Saturday. Festivities kicked-off with tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao beating the drums to declare the fest open. Local MLA Setti Phalguna also participated in the opening ceremony of the festival and inaugurated the traditional archery contest.

Speaking on the occasion, the tourism minister said that Visakhapatnam Agency will witness a lot of development activity in the near future and that the state government is focussed on ensuring that welfare schemes reach tribals living in the region.

Minister M Srinivasa Rao further said that the Araku fest will provide a glimpse into the unique culture heritage of the tribals and will also help bolster the tourism industry in the region.

“The Araku Valley and its surrounding areas have seen a great deal of tourist footfall over the years. The YSRC government will ensure that the tourist footfall translates into benefit for locals,” he added.

With regard to development of the local economy, the minister said that the government is intent on developing the Agency as an organic horticulture hub.

The minister urged both locals and officials to promote tribal culture and heritage by explaining the various facets of tribal life to tourists who had come to witness the fest.

On the first day, a number of sporting events such as an archery contest and a volleyball tournament were held. MLA Setti Phalguna visited the NTR Stadium in Araku Valley to encourage participants. The major attractions of the first day were Bonda dance performed by local groups and traditional rangoli competitions.

Title: Startup festival explores innovation, entrepreneurism
Content:
Vadodara Startup Fest 2020 hosted exhibitions from 67 startups

Vadodara: City-based Parul University (PU) organised its first-ever edition of Vadodara Startup Festival 2020 which ended on February 29.

The university organizes the festival as a means to create an ideal ecosystem for start-up innovation, as well as an idea sharing and nurturing platform that will make students industry ready. With an aim to make business entrepreneurship an integral part of its curriculum, the varsity brought together prominent business personalities, upcoming entrepreneurs and student innovators on a common platform to discuss and explore the scope of start-ups in the country.

The fest hosted leading industrial icons and eminent personalities including Varad Ranjan Krishna, co-founder of 100 Open Startups as chief guest along with Hiranmay Mahanta among others. More than 3,500 students from the university participated in the 2-day event. The start-up expo held during this event also hosted exhibitions from 67 start-ups, showcasing innovative ideas. The event included three panel discussions on start-up funding and social entrepreneurship highlighting connections between start-ups and industry. In addition, 24 sessions were also conducted by mentors to provide the budding entrepreneurs of PU comprehensive knowledge on how to launch and navigate start-ups within business ecosystem.

“The fest acted as much needed platform for developing and enterprising new and innovative ideas of our students. As a university we will continue to perpetuate this culture of entrepreneurship and inculcate industrial best practices among our students during course of their academics,” said PU chief Dr Devanshu Patel.

Title: Vadodara: Woman ends life due to harassment by in-laws
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: A man working in a salon, along with family members, was booked on Sunday for abetting his wife’s suicide. Police arrested 28-year-old Tejal Bhatia’s husband Naresh Bhatia and brother-in-law Jatin Bhatia in connection with her suicide.

According to Tejal’s mother Kusum, her daughter ended her life at her in-law’s house on Ajwa Road on Saturday evening by hanging herself from a ceiling fan. Tejal left behind a suicide note in which she mentioned about harassment by Naresh, Jatin, Jatin’s wife Jaishree and mother-in-law Manjula. She also mentioned that she was suspicious that Naresh had an illicit relationship.

Police said Tejal began to face harassment two years after her marriage in 2010 and was even assaulted and threatened by her in-laws. Tired of the harassment, she decided to end her life, they added.

Based on Kusum’s complaint, an offence of abetment of suicide, cruelty, assault and criminal intimidation was registered at Bapod police station. “We are looking into the allegations that have been made and collecting evidence to ascertain the woman’s claims,” said a police official. Cops said Tejal and Naresh have a five-year-old son, who is currently with Kusum.

Title: Documentary screened at zoo
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Snake Rescue Call— a documentary on lives of wildlife conservationists who work towards solving the human-snake conflict in their communities— was screened at the Bioscope- Zoo Education Centre in Indira Gandhi Zoological Park on Saturday.

The film is based on snake conservation work being carried out by Eastern Ghats Wildlife Society in collaboration with Andhra Pradesh forest department and Agumbe Rainforest Research Station based out of Western Ghats in Karnataka.

The 50 minutes-long feature-length film shows stunning drone shots of snake species found in Visakhapatnam. Zoo curator Yasoda Bai addressed the gathering and shared some facts about reptile conservation efforts in India. tnn

Title: BUTA: Reveal status of service books
Content:
Vadodara: The Baroda University Teachers Association (BUTA) on Wednesday met university registrar to resolve long pending issues faced by the teaching fraternity.

BUTA office-bearers said that the teachers who have retired, while some have even passed away, are not going to receive their pensions immediately as the verification of service books is going on at a very tardy pace. The service books of teachers presently in service are also under verification process at government offices, which is further delaying the process, they alleged.

“We have demanded a white paper with faculty-wise status of the service books of teachers so that an atmosphere of trust is created at the campus. It will reveal the status of all the service books of teachers of our university,” said BUTA general secretary Dr Nikul Patel.

The teachers association has also demanded that all queries raised by the state government in connection to the service books must be expedited and resolved by deputy registrar of ADE section. “As teachers association, we should be updates at all levels so that we too can support the verification process,” Patel added.

BUTA has also demanded that government officers too should be called at the university campus for verification of service books to expedite the process. The association will share minutes of Wednesday’s meeting will all the teachers on Thursday.

Title: Encroachments and illegal buildings ignore GVMC fiat
Content:
Visakhapatnam: In order to make Visakhapatnam grow in a planned manner, the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) has attended to nearly 2,600 unauthorised constructions over the last two years.

Such unauthorised constructions include additional floors, sheds, stairwells and other structures encroaching upon public land. The civic body acts against such encroachments upon receiving complaints from the public as well as on the basis of its own field inspections.

Over the last two years, GVMC has cracked the whip on nearly 1,100 encroachments. The civic body also identified 51 deviations from approved plans and cleared them out. A total of 133 extra floors, which had been constructed against building norms, were pulled down. The municipal corporation has removed 167 structures in total and has taken action against 11 parking violations.

Meanwhile, with property rates skyrocketing in the city, encroachments or additional unapproved floors are coming up indiscriminately. Cases are also being reported of people converting cellars into commercial spaces. There are reports of stairwells being constructed and compound walls being put up by encroaching upon public land.
